entries.entry:
F
F clef the bass clef. See under Clef.
ĕf. F is the sixth letter of the English alphabet, and a nonvocal consonant. Its form and sound are from the Latin. The Latin borrowed the form from the Greek digamma �, which probably had the value of English w consonant. The form and value of Greek letter came from the Phœnician, the ultimate source being probably Egyptian. Etymologically f is most closely related to pkv, and b; as in E. five, Gr. pe`nte; E. wolf, L. lupus, Gr. ly`kos; E. fox, vixen ; fragile, break; fruit, brook, v. t.; E. bear, L. ferre. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 178, 179, 188, 198, 230.
Mus The name of the fourth tone of the model scale, or scale of C. F sharp (F ♯) is a tone intermediate between F and G.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: A syllable applied to the fourth tone of the diatonic scale in solmization.
The tone F.

entry.ety: shortened form of fabulous
entry.def: extremely pleasing.
a large family of trees, shrubs, vines, and herbs bearing bean pods; divided for convenience into the subfamilies Caesalpiniacea; Mimosaceae; Papilionaceae.
entry.syn: Leguminosae, family Leguminosae, family Fabaceae, legume family, pea family.

entry.ety: L. fabaceus, fr. faba bean
entry.def: Having the nature of a bean; like a bean.

entries.entry: ‖Fa*bel"la n.; pl.Fabellae -lē. NL., dim. of L. faba a bean Anat One of the small sesamoid bones situated behind the condyles of the femur, in some mammals.

cs.cd: a policy like that of Fabius Maximus, who, by carefully avoiding decisive contests, foiled Hannibal, harassing his army by marches, countermarches, and ambuscades; a policy of delays and cautions.

entry.ety: L. Fabianus Fabius, belonging to Fabius
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or in the manner of, the Roman general, Quintus Fabius Maximus Verrucosus; cautious; dilatory; avoiding a decisive contest.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the Roman gens Fabia.
Designating, or pertaining to, a society of socialists, organized in England in 1884 to spread socialistic principles gradually without violent agitation.
sn.q: The Fabian Society proposes then to conquer by delay; to carry its programme, not by a hasty rush, but through the slower, but, as it thinks, surer methods of patient discussion, exposition, and political action.

entry.def: A member of, or sympathizer with, the Fabian Society.
a genus of South and Central American heathlike evergreen shrubs.
the principles and beliefs of or similar to those of the Fabian Society, advocating socialism to be established by gradual reforms within the law.

entry.note: A fable may have talking animals anthropomorphically cast as humans representing different character types, sometimes illustrating some moral principle; as, Aesop's Fables .
entry.ety: F., fr. L. fabula, fr. fari to speak, say. See Ban, and cf. Fabulous Fame

sn.def: A Feigned story or tale, intended to instruct or amuse; a fictitious narration intended to enforce some useful truth or precept; an apologue. See the Note under Apologue.
sn.q: Jotham's fable of the trees is the oldest extant.

sn.def: The plot, story, or connected series of events, forming the subject of an epic or dramatic poem.
sn.q: The moral is the first business of the poet; this being formed, he contrives such a design or fable as may be most suitable to the moral.

sn.def: Any story told to excite wonder; common talk; the theme of talk.
sn.q: Old wives'fables.
We grew The fable of the city where we dwelt.

sn.def: Fiction; untruth; falsehood.
sn.q: It would look like a fable to report that this gentleman gives away a great fortune by secret methods.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fabled; p. pr. & vb. n. Fabling
entry.def: To compose fables; hence, to write or speak fiction ; to write or utter what is not true.
entry.q: HeFablesnot.
Vain now the tales which fabling poets tell.
He fables, yet speaks truth.

entry.def: To feign; to invent; to devise, and speak of, as true or real; to tell of falsely.
entry.q: The hell thou fablest.

entry.def: A writer of fables; a fabulist; a dealer in untruths or falsehoods.

entries.entry: ‖Fa`bli`au" n.; pl.Fabliaux -�". F., fr. OF.fablel, dim. of fable a fable Fr. Lit One of the metrical tales of the Trouvères, or early poets of the north of France.

entry.ety: L. fabrica fabric, workshop: cf. F. fabrique fabric. See Forge

sn.def: The structure of anything; the manner in which the parts of a thing are united; workmanship; texture; make; as cloth of a beautiful fabric .

entry.sn:
That which is fabricated; as:
Framework; structure; edifice; building. Anon out of the earth a fabric huge Rose like an exhalation.
Cloth of any kind that is woven or knit from fibers, whether vegetable, animal, or synthetic; manufactured cloth; as, silks or other fabrics; made of a fabric that is 50% cotton and 50% polyester.

sn.def: The act of constructing; construction.
sn.q: Tithe was received by the bishop, . . . for the fabric of the churches for the poor.

sn.def: Any system or structure consisting of connected parts; as, the fabric of the universe.
sn.q: The whole vast fabric of society.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fabricked; p. pr. & vb. n. Fabricking
entry.def: To frame; to build; to construct.
entry.q: Fabrictheir mansions.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: One who fabricates; a manufacturer.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fabricated; p. pr. & vb. n. Fabricating
entry.ety: L. fabricatus, p. p. of fabricari fabricare, to frame, build, forge, fr. fabrica. See Fabric Farge

sn.def: To form into a whole by uniting its parts; to frame; to construct; to build; as, to fabricate a bridge or ship.
To form by art and labor; to manufacture; to produce; as, to fabricate woolens.
To invent and form; to forge; to devise falsely; as, to fabricate a lie or story.
sn.q: Our books were not fabricated with an accomodation to prevailing usages.

entry.def: formed or conceived by the fancy or imagination; as, a fabricated excuse for his absence.
entry.syn: fancied, fictional, fictitious, fictive, invented, made-up.

entry.ety: L. fabricatio; cf. F. fabrication

sn.def: The act of fabricating, framing, or constructing; construction; manufacture; as, the fabrication of a bridge, a church, or a government.
That which is fabricated; a falsehood; as, the story is doubtless a fabrication .

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who fabricates; one who constructs or makes.
entry.q: The fabricator of the works of Ossian.

entry.def: A woman who fabricates.

entry.ety: L. fabrilis, fr. faber workman. See Forge
entry.def: Pertaining to a workman, or to work in stone, metal, wood etc.; as, fabrile skill.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fabuliste, fr. L. fabula. See Fable
entry.def: One who invents or writes fables.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fabulized; p. pr. & vb. n. Fabulizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. fabuliser. See Fable
entry.def: To invent, compose, or relate fables or fictions.

entry.ety: L. fabulositas: cf. F. fabulosité

sn.def: Fabulousness.
A fabulous or fictitious story.

cs.cd: that period in the history of a nation of which the only accounts are myths and unverified legends; as, the fabulous age of Greece and Rome.

entry.ety: L. fabulosus; cf. F. fabuleux. See Fable

sn.def: Feigned, as a story or fable; related in fable; devised; invented; not real; fictitious; as, a fabulous description; a fabulous hero.
sn.q: The fabulous birth of Minerva.

sn.def: beyond belief; exceedingly great; as, a fabulous price.

entry.ety: F. faux bourdon. See False, and Burden a verse

sd.def: A species of counterpoint with a drone bass.
A succession of chords of the sixth.

sn.def: A monotonous refrain.

entry.ety: Abbrev. of facsimile
entry.def: A large ornamental letter used, esp. by the early printers, at the commencement of the chapters and other divisions of a book.

entry.ety: F., fr. It. facciata, fr. faccia face, L. facies. See Face
entry.def: The front of a building; esp., the principal front, having some architectural pretensions. Thus a church is said to have its façade unfinished, though the interior may be in use.

entry.note: ☞ Face is used either adjectively or as part of a compound; as, face guard or face-guard; face cloth; face plan or face-plan; face hammer.
entry.cs: Face ague Med a form of neuralgia, characterized by acute lancinating pains returning at intervals, and by twinges in certain parts of the face, producing convulsive twitches in the corresponding muscles; -- called also tic douloureux. Face card one of a pack of playing cards on which a human face is represented; the king, queen, or jack. Face cloth a cloth laid over the face of a corpse. Face guard a mask with windows for the eyes, worn by workman exposed to great heat, or to flying particles of metal, stone, etc., as in glass works, foundries, etc. Face hammer a hammer having a flat face. Face joint Arch a joint in the face of a wall or other structure. Face mite Zoöll a small, elongated mite (Demdex folliculorum), parasitic in the hair follicles of the face. Face mold the templet or pattern by which carpenters, etc., outline the forms which are to be cut out from boards, sheet metal, etc. Face plate. Turning A plate attached to the spindle of a lathe, to which the work to be turned may be attached. A covering plate for an object, to receive wear or shock. A true plane for testing a dressed surface. Knight. Face wheel. Mach A crown wheel. A wheel whose disk face is adapted for grinding and polishing; a lap. face value the value written on a financial instrument; same as face{13. Also used metaphorically, to mean apparent value; as, to take his statemnet at its face value .

Cylinder face Steam Engine the flat part of a steam cylinder on which a slide valve moves. Face of an anvil its flat upper surface. Face of a bastion Fort the part between the salient and the shoulder angle. Face of coal Mining the principal cleavage plane, at right angles to the stratification. Face of a gun the surface of metal at the muzzle. Face of a place Fort the front comprehended between the flanked angles of two neighboring bastions. Wilhelm. Face of a square Mil one of the sides of a battalion when formed in a square.
Face of a watch, clock, compass, card etc.
the dial or graduated surface on which a pointer indicates the time of day, point of the compass, etc. Face to face. In the presence of each other; as, to bring the accuser and the accused face to face . Without the interposition of any body or substance. “Now we see through a glass darkly; but then face to face.” 1 Cor. xiii. 12. With the faces or finished surfaces turned inward or toward one another; vis à vis; -- opposed to back to back. To fly in the face of to defy; to brave; to withstand. To make a face to distort the countenance; to make a grimace; -- often expressing dislike, annoyance, or disagreement. Shak.
entry.ety: F., from L. facies form, shape, face, perh. from facere to make (see Fact); or perh. orig. meaning appearance, and from a root meaning to shine, and akin to E. fancy. Cf. Facetious

sn.def: The exterior form or appearance of anything; that part which presents itself to the view; especially, the front or upper part or surface; that which particularly offers itself to the view of a spectator.
sn.q: A mist . . . watered the whole face of the ground.
Lake Leman wooes me with its crystal face.

sn.def: That part of a body, having several sides, which may be seen from one point, or which is presented toward a certain direction; one of the bounding planes of a solid; as, a cube has six faces .

sd.def: The principal dressed surface of a plate, disk, or pulley; the principal flat surface of a part or object.
That part of the acting surface of a cog in a cog wheel, which projects beyond the pitch line.
The width of a pulley, or the length of a cog from end to end; as, a pulley or cog wheel of ten inches face .
The upper surface, or the character upon the surface, of a type, plate, etc.
The style or cut of a type or font of type.

sn.def: Outside appearance; surface show; look; external aspect, whether natural, assumed, or acquired.
sn.q: To set a face upon their own malignant design.
This would produce a new face of things in Europe.
We wear a face of joy, because We have been glad of yore.

sn.def: That part of the head, esp. of man, in which the eyes, cheeks, nose, and mouth are situated; visage; countenance.
sn.q: In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread.

sn.def: Cast of features; expression of countenance; look; air; appearance.
sn.q: We set the best faceon it we could.

sn.def: Ten degrees in extent of a sign of the zodiac.
Maintenance of the countenance free from abashment or confusion; confidence; boldness; shamelessness; effrontery.
sn.q: This is the man that has the face to charge others with false citations.

sn.def: Presence; sight; front; as in the phrases, before the face of, in the immediate presence of; in the face of, before, in, or against the front of; as, to fly in the face of danger; to the face of, directly to; from the face of, from the presence of.
Mode of regard, whether favorable or unfavorable; favor or anger; mostly in Scriptural phrases.
sn.q: The Lord make his face to shine upon thee.
My facefavor] will I turn also from them.

sn.def: The end or wall of the tunnel, drift, or excavation, at which work is progressing or was last done.
The exact amount expressed on a bill, note, bond, or other mercantile paper, without any addition for interest or reduction for discount; most commonly called face value.

entry.cs: To face down to put down by bold or impudent opposition. “He faced men down.” Prior. To face (a thing) out to persist boldly or impudently in an assertion or in a line of conduct. “That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.” Shak. to face the music to admit error and accept reprimand or punishment as a consequence for having failed or having done something wrong; to willingly experience an unpleasant situation out of a sense of duty or obligation; as, as soon as he broke the window with the football, Billy knew he would have to face the music .
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Faced; p. pr. & vb. n. Facing

sn.def: To meet in front; to oppose with firmness; to resist, or to meet for the purpose of stopping or opposing; to confront; to encounter; as, to face an enemy in the field of battle.
sn.q: I'll face This tempest, and deserve the name of king.

sn.def: To Confront impudently; to bully.
sn.q: I will neither be facednor braved.

sn.def: To stand opposite to; to stand with the face or front toward; to front upon; as, the apartments of the general faced the park; some of the seats on the train faced backward.
sn.q: He gained also with his forces that part of Britain which faces Ireland.

sn.def: To cover in front, for ornament, protection, etc.; to put a facing upon; as, a building faced with marble.
To line near the edge, esp. with a different material; as, to face the front of a coat, or the bottom of a dress.
To cover with better, or better appearing, material than the mass consists of, for purpose of deception, as the surface of a box of tea, a barrel of sugar, etc.

To make the surface of (anything) flat or smooth; to dress the face of (a stone, a casting, etc.); esp., in turning, to shape or smooth the flat surface of, as distinguished from the cylindrical surface.
To cause to turn or present a face or front, as in a particular direction.
To carry a false appearance; to play the hypocrite.
sn.q: To lie, toface, to forge.

sn.def: To turn the face; as, to face to the right or left.
sn.q: Face about, man; a soldier, and afraid!

sn.def: To present a face or front.

entry.def: Having (such) a face, or (so many) faces; as, smooth-faced, two-faced .
to harden (steel) by adding carbon.

sn.def: an operation to remove wrinkles and other signs of aging from a person's face.
a renovation that improves the outward appearance, as of a building.

entry.def: to perform cosmetic surgery on someone's face.

sn.def: One who faces; one who puts on a false show; a bold-faced person.
sn.q: There be no greater talkers, nor boasters, nor fasers.

sn.def: A blow in the face, as in boxing; hence, any severe or stunning check or defeat, as in controversy.
sn.q: I should have been a stercoraceous mendicant if I had hollowed when I got a facer.

sn.def: a serious difficulty with which one is suddenly faced.
allowing one to maintain one's dignity or prestige; designed to avoid admitting something embarrassing; as, a face-saving compromise; -- of actions.

entry.ety: F. facette, dim. of face face. See Face

sn.def: A little face; a small, plane surface; as, the facets of a diamond.
A smooth circumscribed surface; as, the articular facet of a bone.
The narrow plane surface between flutings of a column.
One of the numerous small eyes which make up the compound eyes of insects and crustaceans.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Faceted; p. pr. & vb. n. Faceting
entry.def: To cut facets or small faces upon; as, to facet a diamond.

entry.ety: L. facetus elegant, fine, facetious; akin to facies. See Face, and cf. Facetious
entry.def: Facetious; witty; humorous.
entry.q: Afacetediscourse.
“How to interpose” with a small, smart remark, sentiment facete, or unctuous anecdote.

entry.def: Having facets.

entry.ety: L., fr. facetus. See Facete
entry.def: Witty or humorous writings or saying; witticisms; merry conceits.

Time spent speaking with a person face-to-face; -- contrasted with time spent communicating by electronic media, such as telephone or e-mail, or via written communications; as, the chief of staff has the most face time with the president.

entry.ety: Cf. F. facétieux. See Facetiæ

sn.def: Given to wit and good humor; merry; sportive; jocular; as, a facetious companion.
Characterized by wit and pleasantry; exciting laughter; as, a facetious story or reply.
without intervening persons; involving direct communication between persons in each other's presence; -- of conversation or confrontation; as, face-to-face negotiations.
having the front parts facing each other.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: See Facet n.
The material of the outside or front side, as of a wall or building; facing.
See Fascia.

cs.cd: the angle, in a skull, included between a straight line (ab, in the illustrations), from the most prominent part of the forehead to the front efge of the upper jaw bone, and another (cd) from this point to the center of the external auditory opening. See Gnathic index, under Gnathic.

entry.ety: LL. facialis, fr. L. facies face : cf. F. facial
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the face; as, the facial artery, vein, or nerve.

entry.ety: From neut. of L. faciendus, gerundive of facere to do
entry.def: The multiplicand. See Facient, 2.

entry.note: ☞ The terms facient faciend, and factum, may imply that the multiplication involved is not ordinary multiplication, but is either some specified operation, or, in general, any mathematical operation. See Multiplication.
entry.ety: L. faciens,entis, p. pr. of facere to make, do. See Fact

sn.def: One who does anything, good or bad; a doer; an agent.

sd.def: One of the variables of a quantic as distinguished from a coefficient.
The multiplier.

entry.cs: Facies Hippocratica. Med See Hippocratic.
entry.ety: L., from, face. See Face

sn.def: The anterior part of the head; the face.
The general aspect or habit of a species, or group of species, esp. with reference to its adaptation to its environment.
The face of a bird, or the front of the head, excluding the bill.

entry.ety: L. facilis, prop., capable of being done or made, hence, facile, easy, fr. facere to make, do: cf. F. facile. Srr Fact, and cf. Faculty

sn.def: Easy to be done or performed: not difficult; performable or attainable with little labor.
sn.q: Order . . . will render the work facile and delightful.

sn.def: Easy to be surmounted or removed; easily conquerable; readily mastered.
sn.q: The facile gates of hell too slightly barred.

sn.def: Easy of access or converse; mild; courteous; not haughty, austere, or distant; affable; complaisant.
sn.q: I meant she should be courteous, facile, sweet.

sn.def: Easily persuaded to good or bad; yielding; ductile to a fault; pliant; flexible.
sn.q: Since Adam, and his facile consort Eve, Lost Paradise, deceived by me.
This is treating Burns like a child, a person of so facile a disposition as not to be trusted without a keeper on the king's highway.

sn.def: Ready; quick; expert; as, he is facile in expedients; he wields a facile pen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Facilitated fȧ*sĭl"ĭ*tā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Facilitating fȧ*sĭl"ĭ*tā`tĭng
entry.ety: Cf. F. faciliter. See Facility
entry.def: To make easy or less difficult; to free from difficulty or impediment; to lessen the labor of; as, to facilitate the execution of a task.
entry.q: To invite and facilitate that line of proceeding which the times call for.

entry.def: freed from difficulty or impediment. Contrasted with delayed.
The act of facilitating or making easy.
freeing from difficulty or impediment; as, facilitative changes in the economic structure.
someone who makes progress easier.
inducing or aiding in facilitating neural activity.

entries.entry:
Fa*cil"i*ty
Facility Expertness Readiness. These words have in common the idea of performing any act with ease and promptitude. Facility supposes a natural or acquired power of dispatching a task with lightness and ease. Expertness is the kind of facility acquired by long practice. Readiness marks the promptitude with which anything is done. A merchant needs great facility in dispatching business; a banker, great expertness in casting accounts; both need great readiness in passing from one employment to another. “The facility which we get of doing things by a custom of doing, makes them often pass in us without our notice.” Locke. “The army was celebrated for the expertness and valor of the soldiers.” “A readiness to obey the known will of God is the surest means to enlighten the mind in respect to duty.” fȧ*sĭl"ĭ*t� n.; pl.Facilities fȧ*sĭl"ĭ*tĭz. L. facilitas, fr. facilis easy: cf. F. facilité. See Facile
The quality of being easily performed; freedom from difficulty; ease; as, the facility of an operation. The facility with which government has been overturned in France.
Ease in performance; readiness proceeding from skill or use; dexterity; as, practice gives a wonderful facility in executing works of art.
Easiness to be persuaded; readiness or compliance; -- usually in a bad sense; pliancy. It is a great error to take facility for good nature.
Easiness of access; complaisance; affability. Offers himself to the visits of a friend with facility.
That which promotes the ease of any action or course of conduct; advantage; aid; assistance; -- usually in the plural; as, special facilities for study. Ease; expertness; readiness; dexterity; complaisance; condescension; affability.

cs.cd: front or pressed brick.

sn.def: A covering in front, for ornament or other purpose; an exterior covering or sheathing; as, the facing of an earthen slope, sea wall, etc. , to strengthen it or to protect or adorn the exposed surface.
A lining placed near the edge of a garment for ornament or protection.
The finishing of any face of a wall with material different from that of which it is chiefly composed, or the coating or material so used.
A powdered substance, as charcoal, bituminous coal, etc., applied to the face of a mold, or mixed with the sand that forms it, to give a fine smooth surface to the casting.

sd.def: The collar and cuffs of a military coat; -- commonly of a color different from that of the coat.
The movement of soldiers by turning on their heels to the right, left, or about; -- chiefly in the pl.

entry.def: In a facing manner or position.

entry.ety: L. facinorous, from facinus deed, bad deed, from facere to make, do
entry.def: Atrociously wicked.

entry.ety: F. faconde, L. facundia. See Facund
entry.def: Speech; eloquence.
entry.q: Her facound eke full womanly and plain.

entries.entry:
Fac*sim"i*le
Facsimile telegraph a telegraphic apparatus reproducing messages in autograph.
n.; pl.Facsimiles -l�z. L. fac simile make like; or an abbreviation of factum simile made like; facere to make + similes like. See Fact, and Simile
A copy of anything made, either so as to be deceptive or so as to give every part and detail of the original; an exact copy or likeness.

entry.def: To make a facsimile of.

entry.note: ☞ The term fact has in jurisprudence peculiar uses in contrast with law; as, attorney at law, and attorney in fact; issue in law, and issue in fact. There is also a grand distinction between law and fact with reference to the province of the judge and that of the jury, the latter generally determining the fact, the former the law.
entry.cs: Accessary before the factorAccessary after the fact . See under Accessary. Matter of fact an actual occurrence; a verity; used adjectively: of or pertaining to facts; prosaic; unimaginative; as, a matter-of-fact narration.
entry.ety: L. factum, fr. facere to make or do. Cf. Feat Affair Benefit Defect Fashion, and -fy

sn.def: A doing, making, or preparing.
sn.q: A project for the fact and vending Of a new kind of fucus, paint for ladies.

sn.def: An effect produced or achieved; anything done or that comes to pass; an act; an event; a circumstance.
sn.q: What might instigate him to this devilish fact, I am not able to conjecture.
He who most excels in fact of arms.

sn.def: Reality; actuality; truth; as, he, in fact, excelled all the rest; the fact is, he was beaten.

The assertion or statement of a thing done or existing; sometimes, even when false, improperly put, by a transfer of meaning, for the thing done, or supposed to be done; a thing supposed or asserted to be done; as, history abounds with false facts .
sn.q: I do not grant the fact.
This reasoning is founded upon a fact which is not true.
sn.syn: Act; deed; performance; event; incident; occurrence; circumstance.

entry.def: designed to find information or ascertain facts; as, a fact-finding committee.

entry.ety: L. factio a doing, a company of persons acting together, a faction: cf. F. faction See Fashion

sn.def: One of the divisions or parties of charioteers (distinguished by their colors) in the games of the circus.

A party, in political society, combined or acting in union, in opposition to the government, or state; -- usually applied to a minority, but it may be applied to a majority; a combination or clique of partisans of any kind, acting for their own interests, especially if greedy, clamorous, and reckless of the common good.
Tumult; discord; dissension.
sn.q: They remained at Newbury in great faction among themselves.

entry.ety: Cf. F. factionnaire, L. factionarius the head of a company of charioteers
entry.def: Belonging to a faction; being a partisan; taking sides.
entry.q: Always factionary on the party of your general.

entry.def: One of a faction.
One who promotes faction.

entries.entry:
Fac"tious
Fac"tious*ly adv. Fac"tious*ness n.
Fac"tious*ly adv. Fac"tious*ness n. . a. L. factiosus: cf. F. factieux
Given to faction; addicted to form parties and raise dissensions, in opposition to government or the common good; turbulent; seditious; prone to clamor against public measures or men; -- said of persons.
Factious for the house of Lancaster.
Pertaining to faction; proceeding from faction; indicating, or characterized by, faction; -- said of acts or expressions; as, factious quarrels. Headlong zeal or factious fury.

entry.usage: Factitious Unnatural. Anything is unnatural when it departs in any way from its simple or normal state; it is factitious when it is wrought out or wrought up by labor and effort, as, a factitious excitement. An unnatural demand for any article of merchandise is one which exceeds the ordinary rate of consumption; a factitious demand is one created by active exertions for the purpose. An unnatural alarm is one greater than the occasion requires; a factitious alarm is one wrought up with care and effort.
entry.ety: L. factitius, fr. facere to make. See Fact, and cf. Fetich
entry.def: Made by art, in distinction from what is produced by nature; artificial; sham; contrived; formed by, or adapted to, an artificial or conventional, in distinction from a natural, standard or rule; not natural; as, factitious cinnabar or jewels; a factitious taste.
entry.q: He acquires a factitious propensity, he forms an incorrigible habit, of desultory reading.

entries.entry:
Fac"ti*tive. a. See Fact
Causing; causative.
Gram Pertaining to that relation which is proper when the act, as of a transitive verb, is not merely received by an object, but produces some change in the object, as when we say, He made the water wine. Sometimes the idea of activity in a verb or adjective involves in it a reference to an effect, in the way of causality, in the active voice on the immediate objects, and in the passive voice on the subject of such activity. This second object is called the factitive object.

entry.def: Making; having power to make.
entry.q: You are . . .factive, not destructive.

entry.cs: De facto. Law See De facto.
entry.ety: L., ablative of factum deed, fact
entry.def: In fact; by the act or fact.

entry.ety: L. factor a doer: cf. F. facteur a factor. See Fact

sn.def: One who transacts business for another; an agent; a substitute; especially, a mercantile agent who buys and sells goods and transacts business for others in commission; a commission merchant or consignee. He may be a home factor or a foreign factor. He may buy and sell in his own name, and he is intrusted with the possession and control of the goods; and in these respects he differs from a broker.
sn.q: My factor sends me word, a merchant's fled That owes me for a hundred tun of wine.

sn.def: A steward or bailiff of an estate.
One of the elements or quantities which, when multiplied together, form a product.
One of the elements, circumstances, or influences which contribute to produce a result; a constituent; a contributory cause.
sn.q: The materal and dynamical factors of nutrition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Factored -tĕrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Factoring
entry.def: To resolve (a quantity) into its factors.

entry.ety: Cf. F. factorage
entry.def: The allowance given to a factor, as a compensation for his services; -- called also a commission.
A factor who is a woman.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a factory.
Related to factorials.

entry.def: A name given to the factors of a continued product when the former are derivable from one and the same function F(x) by successively imparting a constant increment or decrement h to the independent variable. Thus the product F(x).F(x + h).F(x + 2h) . . . F[x + (n-1)h is called a factorial term, and its several factors take the name of factorials.
The product of the consecutive whole numbers from unity up to any given number; thus, 5 factorial is the product of 5 times four times three times two times one, or 120.
The act of resolving into factors.

sn.def: to resolve into factors, as of a polynomial; same as factorize.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Factorized -?zd; p. pr. & vb. n. Factorizing -?"z?ng

sd.def: To give warning to; -- said of a person in whose hands the effects of another are attached, the warning being to the effect that he shall not pay the money or deliver the property of the defendant in his hands to him, but appear and answer the suit of the plaintiff.
To attach (the effects of a debtor) in the hands of a third person; to garnish. See Garnish.

sn.def: to resolve (a complex expression, such as a polynomial) into factors.

entry.def: The business of a factor.

entries.entry:
Fac"to*ry
Factory leg Med a variety of bandy leg, associated with partial dislocation of the tibia, produced in young children by working in factories.
n.; pl.Factories -rĭz. Cf. F. factorerie
A house or place where factors, or commercial agents, reside, to transact business for their employers. The Company'sfactoryat Madras.
The body of factors in any place; as, a chaplain to a British factory .
A building, or collection of buildings, appropriated to the manufacture of goods; the place where workmen are employed in fabricating goods, wares, or utensils; a manufactory; as, a cotton factory .
factory-made adj. made in a factory. Contrasted with homemade.Narrower terms: boughten, store-bought ; mass-produced

fac*to"tum făk*tō"tŭm n.; pl.factotums -tŭmz. L., do everything; facere to do + totus all : cf. F. factotum. See Fact, and Total
A person employed to do all kinds of work or business; a person with many different responsibilities.

sn.def: of or pertaining to facts; as, factual inaccuracies.
containing only facts (as contrasted with opinions or speculations); as, a factual report.

entries.entry:
‖Fac"tum făk"tŭm n.; pl.Facta #. L. See Fact
Law A man's own act and deed; particularly: Civil Law Anything stated and made certain.
Testamentary Law The due execution of a will, including everything necessary to its validity.
Mach The product. See Facient, 2.

entry.ety: F. facture a making, invoice, L. factura a making. See Fact

sn.def: The act or manner of making or doing anything; -- now used of a literary, musical, or pictorial production.
An invoice or bill of parcels.

entry.ety: L., pl. of facula a little torch
entry.def: Groups of small shining spots on the surface of the sun which are brighter than the other parts of the photosphere. They are generally seen in the neighborhood of the dark spots, and are supposed to be elevated portions of the photosphere.
Of or pertaining to the faculæ.

entry.ety: L. facultas -atis, faculty: cf. F. facultatif, G. fakultativ

sn.def: Having relation to the grant or exercise faculty, or authority, privilege, license, or the like hence, optional; as, facultative enactments, or those which convey a faculty, or permission; the facultative referendum of Switzerland is one that is optional with the people and is necessary only when demanded by petition; facultative studies;opposed to obligatory and compulsory, and sometimes used with to.
Pertaining to a faculty or faculties.
sn.q: In short, there is no facultative plurality in the mind; it is a single organ of true judgment for all purposes, cognitive or practical.

entries.entry:
Fac"ul*ty
Dean of faculty. See under Dean. Faculty of advocates. Scot See under Advocate.
n.; pl.Faculties #. F. facult�, L. facultas, fr. facilis easy (cf. facul easily), fr. fecere to make. See Fact, and cf. Facility
Ability to act or perform, whether inborn or cultivated; capacity for any natural function; especially, an original mental power or capacity for any of the well-known classes of mental activity; psychical or soul capacity; capacity for any of the leading kinds of soul activity, as knowledge, feeling, volition; intellectual endowment or gift; power; as, faculties of the mind or the soul. But know that in the soul Are many lesser faculties that serve Reason as chief. What a piece of work is a man ! how noble in reason ! how infinite in faculty !
Special mental endowment; characteristic knack. He had a ready faculty, indeed, of escaping from any topic that agitated his too sensitive and nervous temperament.
Power; prerogative or attribute of office. R This Duncan Hath borne his faculties so meek.
Privilege or permission, granted by favor or indulgence, to do a particular thing; authority; license; dispensation. The pope . . . granted him a faculty to set him free from his promise. It had not only faculty to inspect all bishops' dioceses, but to change what laws and statutes they should think fit to alter among the colleges.
A body of a men to whom any specific right or privilege is granted; formerly, the graduates in any of the four departments of a university or college (Philosophy, Law, Medicine, or Theology), to whom was granted the right of teaching (profitendi or docendi) in the department in which they had studied; at present, the members of a profession itself; as, the medical faculty; the legal faculty, etc.
Amer. Colleges The body of person to whom are intrusted the government and instruction of a college or university, or of one of its departments; the president, professors, and tutors in a college. Talent; gift; endowment; dexterity; expertness; cleverness; readiness; ability; knack.

entry.ety: L. facundus, fr. fari to speak
entry.def: Eloquent.

entry.ety: L. facundiosus
entry.def: Eloquement; full of words.

entry.ety: L. facunditas
entry.def: Eloquence; readiness of speech.

entry.ety: Cf. Faddle

sn.def: A hobby ; freak; whim.
sn.q: It is your favorite fad to draw plans.

sn.def: a practise followed enthusiastically by a number of people for a limited period of time; as, the latest fad in fashion.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A vapid or meaningless remark; a commonplace; nonsense.

sn.def: intensely fashionable for a short time.
prone to follow fads; as, a faddish clique of teenagers; -- of people.

entry.def: a person who subscribes to a variety of fads.

entry.ety: Cf. Fiddle Fiddle-faddle
entry.def: To trifle; to toy.

def2.def: To fondle; to dandle.

entry.ety: F., prob. fr. L. vapidus vapid, or possibly fr,fatuus foolish, insipid
entry.def: Weak; insipid; tasteless; commonplace.
entry.q: Passages that are somewhatfade.
His masculine taste gave him a sense of something fade and ludicrous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Faded; p. pr. & vb. n. Fading
entry.ety: OE. faden vaden, prob. fr. fade a.; cf. Prov. D. vadden to fade, wither, vaddigh languid torpid. Cf. Fade a. Vade

sn.def: To become fade; to grow weak; to lose strength; to decay; to perish gradually; to wither, as a plant.
sn.q: The earth mourneth and fadeth away.

sn.def: To lose freshness, color, or brightness; to become faint in hue or tint; hence, to be wanting in color.
sn.q: Flowers that neverfade.

sn.def: To sink away; to disappear gradually; to grow dim; to vanish.
sn.q: The stars shall fade away.
He makes a swanlike end,Fading in music.

entry.def: To cause to wither; to deprive of freshness or vigor; to wear away.
entry.q: No winter could his laurels fade.

entry.def: That has lost freshness, color, or brightness; grown dim.
entry.q: Hisfadedcheek.
Where the faded moon Made a dim silver twilight.

entry.def: In a faded manner.
entry.q: A dull room fadedly furnished.

entry.def: Not liable to fade; unfading.
Father.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. faden to flatter, and AS. f�gan to join, unit, G. fügen, or AS. āfægian to depict; all perh. form the same root as E. fair. Cf. Fair a. Fay to fit
entry.def: To fit; to suit; to agree.
entry.q: They shall be made, spite of antipathy, to fadge together.
Well, Sir, how fadges the new design ?

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A small flat loaf or thick cake; also, a fagot.
Losing freshness, color, brightness, or vigor.

def2.def: Loss of color, freshness, or vigor.

entry.def: An Irish dance; also, the burden of a song.
entry.q: Fadingis a fine jig.

entry.def: A fathom.
Faded.
See Fecal.

entry.ety: L. faex, pl. faeces, dregs
entry.def: Excrement; ordure; also, settlings; sediment after infusion or distillation.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: See Fecula.
Fairy.

entry.ety: Cf. Famble Maffle
entry.def: To stammer.
A knot or coarse part in cloth.
a male homosexual; -- always used disparagingly and considered offensive. Shortened form of faggot.

cs.cd: to become untwisted or frayed, as the end of a rope, or the edge of canvas.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fagged făgd; p. pr. & vb. n. Fagging făg"gĭng
entry.ety: Cf. LG. fakk wearied, weary, vaak slumber, drowsiness, OFries. fai, equiv. to fāch devoted to death, OS. fēgi, OHG. feigi, G. feig feige, cowardly, Icel. feigr fated to die, AS. fǣge, Scot. faik, to fail, stop, lower the price; or perh. the same word as E. flag to droop

sn.def: To become weary; to tire.
sn.q: Creighton withheld his force till the Italian began to fag.

sn.def: To labor to wearness; to work hard; to drudge.
sn.q: Read, fag, and subdue this chapter.

sn.def: To act as a fag, or perform menial services or drudgery, for another, as in some English schools.

entry.cs: Brain fag. Med See Cerebropathy.

sn.def: To tire by labor; to exhaust; as, he was almost fagged out.
Anything that fatigues.
sn.q: It is such a fag, I came back tired to death.

entry.def: a natural family of chiefly monoecious trees and shrubs, including beeches, chestnuts, and oaks; it includes the genera Castanea; Castanopsis; Chrysolepis; Fagus; Lithocarpus; Nothofagus; and Quercus.

sn.def: An end of poorer quality, or in a spoiled condition, as the coarser end of a web of cloth, the untwisted end of a rope, etc.
The refuse or meaner part of anything.
sn.q: The fag-end of business.

sn.def: same as burned-out, 1.
sn.syn: burned-out(prenominal), burnt-out(prenominal), burned out(predicate), burnt out(predicate), exhausted, fatigued, played-out(prenominal), played out(predicate), spent, washed-out(prenominal), washed out(predicate), worn-out(prenominal), worn out(predicate).

entry.def: Laborious drudgery; esp., the acting as a drudge for another at an English school.

entry.ety: perh. from fagot{5, a shriveled old woman
entry.def: a male homosexual; -- always used disparagingly and considered offensive.
entry.syn: fagot, fag, fairy, pansy, queer, poof, poove, pouf.

sn.def: a bundle of sticks and branches bound together; -- same as fagot{1.

entry.def: a genus of plants of the buckwheat family, including the buckwheat Fagopyrum esculentum; in some classifications included in the genus Polygonum.

cs.cd: iron, in bars or masses, manufactured from fagots.
the vote of a person who has been constituted a voter by being made a landholder, for party purposes.

entry.ety: F., prob. aug. of L. fax facis, torch, perh. orig., a bundle of sticks; cf. Gr. fa`kelos bundle, fagot. Cf. Fagotto

sn.def: A bundle of sticks, twigs, or small branches of trees, used for fuel, for raising batteries, filling ditches, or other purposes in fortification; a fascine.
A bundle of pieces of wrought iron to be worked over into bars or other shapes by rolling or hammering at a welding heat; a pile.
A bassoon. See Fagotto.
A person hired to take the place of another at the muster of a company.
An old shriveled woman.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fagoted; p. pr. & vb. n. Fagoting
entry.def: To make a fagot of; to bind together in a fagot or bundle; also, to collect promiscuously.

entry.ety: It. See Fagot
entry.def: The bassoon; -- so called from being divided into parts for ease of carriage, making, as it were, a small fagot.
The leaves of an orchid (Angraecum fragrans), of the islands of Bourbon and Mauritius, used (in France) as a substitute for Chinese tea.

entry.ety: G., fr. fahl dun-colored + band a band
entry.def: A stratum in crystalline rock, containing metallic sulphides.

entry.ety: G. fahlerz; fahl dun-colored, fallow + erz ore
entry.def: Same as Tetrahedrite.

entry.ety: From Fahlun, a place in Sweden
entry.def: A hydrated silica of alumina, resulting from the alteration of iolite.
an abbreviation of Fahrenheit; -- used in designating temperatures; as, 72° Fahr. Used as an alternative to celsius.

entry.note: ☞ The Fahrenheit thermometer is so graduated that the freezing point of water is at 32 degrees above the zero of its scale, and the boiling point at one atmosphere of pressure is 212 degrees. It is commonly used in the United States and in England.
entry.ety: G
entry.def: Conforming to the scale used by Gabriel Daniel Fahrenheit in the graduation of his thermometer; of or relating to Fahrenheit's thermometric scale. Used as an alternative to celsius.

def2.def: The Fahrenheit thermometer or scale.

entry.ety: F., fr. Faenza, a town in Italy, the original place of manufacture
entry.def: Glazed earthenware; esp., a fine variety that which is decorated with colorful designs in an opaque glaze.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Failed fāld; p. pr. & vb. n. Failing
entry.ety: F. failir, fr. L. fallere falsum, to deceive, akin to E. fall. See Fail, and cf. Fallacy False Fault

sn.def: To be wanting; to fall short; to be or become deficient in any measure or degree up to total absence; to cease to be furnished in the usual or expected manner, or to be altogether cut off from supply; to be lacking; as, streams fail; crops fail.
sn.q: As the waters fail from the sea.
Till Lionel's issue fails, his should not reign.

sn.def: To be affected with want; to come short; to lack; to be deficient or unprovided; -- used with of.
sn.q: If ever they fail of beauty, this failure is not be attributed to their size.

sn.def: To fall away; to become diminished; to decline; to decay; to sink.
sn.q: When earnestly they seek Such proof, conclude they then begin to fail.

sn.def: To deteriorate in respect to vigor, activity, resources, etc.; to become weaker; as, a sick man fails .
To perish; to die; -- used of a person.
sn.q: Had the king in his last sickness failed.

sn.def: To be found wanting with respect to an action or a duty to be performed, a result to be secured, etc.; to miss; not to fulfill expectation.
sn.q: Take heed now that ye fail not to do this.
Either my eyesight fails, or thou look'st pale.

sn.def: To come short of a result or object aimed at or desired ; to be baffled or frusrated.
sn.q: Our envious foe hath failed.

sn.def: To err in judgment; to be mistaken.
sn.q: Which ofttimes may succeed, so as perhaps Shall grieve him, if I fail not.

sn.def: To become unable to meet one's engagements; especially, to be unable to pay one's debts or discharge one's business obligation; to become bankrupt or insolvent; as, many credit unions failed in the late 1980's.
To be wanting to ; to be insufficient for; to disappoint; to desert.
sn.q: There shall not fail thee a man on the throne.

sn.def: To miss of attaining; to lose.
sn.q: Though that seat of earthly bliss be failed.

entry.ety: OF. faille, from failir. See Fail v. i.

sn.def: Miscarriage; failure; deficiency; fault; -- mostly superseded by failure or failing, except in the phrase without fail.
sn.q: His highness'failof issue.

sn.def: Death; decease.

entry.ety: Of. faillance, fr. faillir
entry.def: Fault; failure; omission.
unsuccessful. Opposite of successful.

sn.def: A failing short; a becoming deficient; failure; deficiency; imperfection; weakness; lapse; fault; infirmity; as, a mental failing .
sn.q: And ever in her mind she cast about For that unnoticed failing in herself.

sn.def: The act of becoming insolvent of bankrupt.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A soft silk, heavier than a foulard and not glossy.

entry.ety: From Fail

sn.def: Cessation of supply, or total defect; a failing; deficiency; as, failure of rain; failure of crops.
Omission; nonperformance; as, the failure to keep a promise.
Want of success; the state of having failed.
Decay, or defect from decay; deterioration; as, the failure of memory or of sight.
A becoming insolvent; bankruptcy; suspension of payment; as, failure in business.
A failing; a slight fault.

entry.ety: OE. fain fagen, AS. fægen; akin to OS. fagan, Icel. faginn glad; AS. fægnian to rejoice, OS. faganōn, Icel. fagna, Goth. faginōn, cf. Goth. fahēds joy; and fr. the same root as E. fair. Srr Fair a., and cf. Fawn to court favor

sn.def: Well-pleased; glad; apt; wont; fond; inclined.
sn.q: Men and birds are fain of climbing high.
To a busy man, temptation is fainto climb up together with his business.

sn.def: Satisfied; contented; also, constrained.
sn.q: The learned Castalio was fain to make trechers at Basle to keep himself from starving.

entry.def: With joy; gladly; -- with wold.
entry.q: He would fain have filled his belly with the husks that the swine did eat.
Fain Would I woo her, yet I dare not.

entry.def: To be glad ; to wish or desire.
entry.q: Whoso fair thing does fain to see.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. faineance. See Fainéant
entry.def: Do-nothingness; inactivity; indolence.
entry.q: The mask of sneering faineance was gone.

entry.ety: F.; fait he does + néant nothing
entry.def: Doing nothing; shiftless; disinclined to work or exertion.
entry.syn: bone-idle, bone-lazy, do-nothing(prenominal), indolent, lazy, otiose, shiftless, slothful, workshy, work-shy.

entry.def: A do-nothing; an idle fellow; a sluggard.

entries.entry: Fainéant deity. A deity recognized as real but conceived as not acting in human affairs, hence not worshiped.

entry.ety: OE. feint faint, false, faint, F. feint, p. p. of feindre to feign, suppose, hesitate. See Feign, and cf. Feint

sn.def: Lacking strength; weak; languid; inclined to swoon; as, faint with fatigue, hunger, or thirst.
Wanting in courage, spirit, or energy; timorous; cowardly; dejected; depressed; as, “Faint heart ne'er won fair lady.”
Lacking distinctness; hardly perceptible; striking the senses feebly; not bright, or loud, or sharp, or forcible; weak; as, a faint color, or sound.
Performed, done, or acted, in a weak or feeble manner; not exhibiting vigor, strength, or energy; slight; as, faint efforts; faint resistance.
sn.q: The faint prosecution of the war.

entry.def: The act of fainting, or the state of one who has fainted; a swoon. R See Fainting n.
entry.q: The saint, Who propped the Virgin in her faint.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fainted; p. pr. & vb. n. Fainting

sn.def: To become weak or wanting in vigor; to grow feeble; to lose strength and color, and the control of the bodily or mental functions; to swoon; -- sometimes with away. See Fainting n.
sn.q: Hearing the honor intended her, she fainted away.
If I send them away fasting . . . they will faint by the way.

sn.def: To sink into dejection; to lose courage or spirit; to become depressed or despondent.
sn.q: If thou faint in the day of adversity, thy strength is small.

sn.def: To decay; to disappear; to vanish.
sn.q: Gilded clouds, while we gaze upon them, faint before the eye.

entry.def: To cause to faint or become dispirited; to depress; to weaken.
entry.q: It faints me to think what follows.

entry.def: Wanting in courage; depressed by fear; easily discouraged or frightened; cowardly; timorous; dejected.
entry.q: Fear not, neither be faint-hearted.

cs.cd: a fainting or swoon; syncope.

entry.def: Syncope, or loss of consciousness owing to a sudden arrest of the blood supply to the brain, the face becoming pallid, the respiration feeble, and the heat's beat weak.
Slightly faint; somewhat faint.
Timorous; feeble-minded.
entry.q: Afainting, silly creature.

entry.def: In a faint, weak, or timidmanner.

sn.def: The state of being faint; loss of strength, or of consciousness, and self-control.
Want of vigor or energy.
Feebleness, as of color or light; lack of distinctness; as, faintness of description.
Faint-heartedness; timorousness; dejection.
sn.q: I will send a faintness into their hearts.

entry.def: The impure spirit which comes over first and last in the distillation of whisky; -- the former being called the strong faints, and the latter, which is much more abundant, the weak faints. This crude spirit is much impregnated with fusel oil.
Feeble; languid.

entry.cs: Fair ball. Baseball A ball passing over the home base at the height called for by the batsman, and delivered by the pitcher while wholly within the lines of his position and facing the batsman. A batted ball that falls inside the foul lines; -- called also a fair hit. Fair maid. Zoöl The European pilchard (Clupea pilchardus) when dried. The southern scup (Stenotomus Gardeni). Virginia Fair one a handsome woman; a beauty, Fair play equitable or impartial treatment; a fair or equal chance; justice. From fair to middling passable; tolerable. Colloq The fair sex the female sex.
entry.ety: OE. fair fayer fager, AS. fæger; akin to OS. & OHG. fagar, Icel. fagr, Sw. fager, Dan. faver, Goth. fagrs fit, also to E. fay, G. fügen, to fit. fegen to sweep, cleanse, and prob. also to E. fang peace pact, Cf. Fang Fain Fay to fit

sn.def: Free from spots, specks, dirt, or imperfection; unblemished; clean; pure.
sn.q: A fair white linen cloth.

sn.def: Pleasing to the eye; handsome; beautiful.
sn.q: Who can not see many a fair French city, for one fair French made.

sn.def: Without a dark hue; light; clear; as, a fair skin.
sn.q: The northern people large and fair-complexioned.

sn.def: Not overcast; cloudless; clear; pleasant; propitious; favorable; -- said of the sky, weather, or wind, etc.; as, a fair sky; a fair day.
sn.q: You wish fair winds may waft him over.

sn.def: Free from obstacles or hindrances; unobstructed; unincumbered; open; direct; -- said of a road, passage, etc.; as, a fair mark; in fair sight; a fair view.
sn.q: The caliphs obtained a mighty empire, which was in a fair way to have enlarged.

sn.def: Without sudden change of direction or curvature; smooth; flowing; -- said of the figure of a vessel, and of surfaces, water lines, and other lines.

Characterized by frankness, honesty, impartiality, or candor; open; upright; free from suspicion or bias; equitable; just; -- said of persons, character, or conduct; as, a fair man; fair dealing; a fair statement.
sn.q: I would call itfairplay.

sn.def: Pleasing; favorable; inspiring hope and confidence; -- said of words, promises, etc.
sn.q: When fair words and good counsel will not prevail on us, we must be frighted into our duty.

sn.def: Distinct; legible; as, fair handwriting.
Free from any marked characteristic; average; middling; as, a fair specimen.
sn.q: The news is very fair and good, my lord.
sn.syn: Candid; open; frank; ingenuous; clear; honest; equitable; impartial; reasonable. See Candid.

entry.cs: Fair and square justly; honestly; equitably; impartially. Colloq To bid fair. See under Bid. To speak fair to address with courtesy and frankness. Archaic
entry.def: Clearly; openly; frankly; civilly; honestly; favorably; auspiciously; agreeably.

entry.cs: The fair anything beautiful; women, collectively. “For slander's mark was ever yet the fair.” Shak.

sn.def: Fairness, beauty.
A fair woman; a sweetheart.
sn.q: I have found out a gift for my fair.

sn.def: Good fortune; good luck.
sn.q: Now fair befall thee !

sn.def: To make fair or beautiful.
sn.q: Fairing the foul.

sn.def: To make smooth and flowing, as a vessel's lines.

cs.cd: Too late.

entry.ety: OE. feire, OF. feire, F. foire, fr. L. fariae, pl., days of rest, holidays, festivals, akin to festus festal. See Feast

sn.def: A gathering of buyers and sellers, assembled at a particular place with their merchandise at a stated or regular season, or by special appointment, for trade.
A festival, and sale of fancy articles. erc., usually for some charitable object; as, a Grand Army fair; a church fair .
A competitive exhibition of wares, farm products, etc., not primarily for purposes of sale; as, the Mechanics' fair; an agricultural fair.

an exhibition by a number of organizations, including governmental organizations, for the purpose of acquainting people with such organizations or their members, not primarily for commercial purposes; as, the 1939 World's Fair.

q.au: Song (1904: words by Andrew B. Sterling, music by Kerry Mills, popularized by Billy Murray. Prominent in the movie "Meet Me In St. Louis", 1944)

sn.q: Meet me in St. Louis, Louis Meet me at the fair Don't tell me the lights are shining Anyplace but there.

entry.def: justly; honestly; equitably; impartially. Opposite of unfairly.
fair and honest; just. Opposite of unfair.

entries.entry: Fair catch. Football A catch made by a player on side who makes a prescribed signal that he will not attempt to advance the ball when caught. He must not then be interfered with.

entry.def: an open area for holding fairs or exhibitions or circuses. Often used in plural.
same as fairground.

sn.def: Having fair or light-colored hair.
favorite; considered especially talented or promising; as, the fair-haired boy of the literary set.

entry.def: Fairness; beauty.
In the manner of a fairy.
entry.q: Numerous as shadows haunting fairily The brain.

cs.cd: a box receiving savings or small sums of money.

entry.def: A present; originally, one given or purchased at a fair.
Tolerably fair.
A block, or ring, serving as a guide for the running rigging or for any rope.

sn.def: In a fair manner; clearly; openly; plainly; fully; distinctly; frankly.
sn.q: Even the nature of Mr. Dimmesdale's disease had never fairly been revealed to him.

sn.def: Favorably; auspiciously; commodiously; as, a town fairly situated for foreign trade.
Honestly; properly.
sn.q: Such means of comfort or even luxury, as lay fairly within their grasp.

sn.def: Softly; quietly; gently.

entry.def: Unprejudiced; just; judicial; honest.
Well-disposed.
entry.q: Afair-naturedprince.

entry.def: The state of being fair, or free form spots or stains, as of the skin; honesty, as of dealing; candor, as of an argument, etc.
Using fair speech, or uttered with fairness; bland; civil; courteous; plausible.
entry.q: A marvelousfair-spokenman.

sn.def: The navigable part of a river, bay, etc., through which vessels enter or depart; the part of a harbor or channel ehich is kept open and unobstructed for the passage of vessels.
That part of a golf course between the tee and the green which is of closely mowed grass, as contrasted to the rough.

cs.cd: a make-believe or inexperienced sailor; -- the nautical equivalent of carpet knight.

sn.def: Made or done in pleasant weather, or in circumstances involving but little exposure or sacrifice; as, a fair-weather voyage.
Appearing only when times or circumstances are prosperous; as, a fair-weather friend.

entry.def: State of prosperity.
entry.q: They think it was never fair-world with them since.

entries.entry:
Fair"y
Fairy of the mine an imaginary being supposed to inhabit mines, etc. German folklore tells of two species; one fierce and malevolent, the other gentle, See Kobold.
n.; pl.Fairies #. OE. fairie faierie, enchantment, fairy folk, fairy, OF. faerie enchantment, F. féer, fr. LL. Fata one of the goddesses of fate. See Fate, and cf. Fay a fairy
faëry
Enchantment; illusion. Obs The God of her has made an end, And fro this worlde's fairy Hath taken her into company.
The country of the fays; land of illusions. Obs He [Arthur] is a king y-crowned in Fairy.
An imaginary supernatural being or spirit, supposed to assume a human form (usually diminutive), either male or female, and to meddle for good or evil in the affairs of mankind; a fay. See Elf, and Demon. The fourth kind of spirit [is] called the Fairy. And now about the caldron sing, Like elves and fairies in a ring.
An enchantress. Obs No goblin or swart fairy of the mine Hath hurtful power over true virginity.

entry.cs:
Fairy bird Zoöl the Euoropean little tern (Sterna minuta); -- called also sea swallow, and hooded tern. Fairy bluebird. Zoöl See under Bluebird. Fairy martin Zoöl a European swallow (Hirrundo ariel) that builds flask-shaped nests of mud on overhanging cliffs.
Fairy ringsorFairy circles
the circles formed in grassy lawns by certain fungi (as Marasmius Oreades), formerly supposed to be caused by fairies in their midnight dances; also, the mushrooms themselves. Such circles may have diameters larger than three meters. Fairy shrimp Zoöl a European fresh-water phyllopod crustacean (Chirocephalus diaphanus); -- so called from its delicate colors, transparency, and graceful motions. The name is sometimes applied to similar American species. Fairy stone Paleon an echinite.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to fairies.
Given by fairies; as, fairy money.

entry.def: The imaginary land or abode of fairies.
Resembling a fairy, or what is made or done be fairies; as, fairylike music.
a rare north temperate bog orchid (Calypso bulbosa) bearing a solitary white to pink flower marked with purple at the tip of an erect reddish stalk above one basal leaf.

sn.def: a story about magical or mythological creatures, such as fairies, elves, goblins, trolls, orcs, unicorns, wizards, dragons, etc., usually composed for the amusement of children; called also a fairy story.
a false story intended to deceive or mislead, especially one involving unlikely events or situations; called also a fairy story.

entry.cs:
Act of faith. See Auto-da-fé.
Breach of faith Confession of faith
etc. See under Breach Confession, etc. Faith cure a method or practice of treating diseases by prayer and the exercise of faith in God. In good faith with perfect sincerity.
entry.ety: OE. feith fayth fay, OF. feid feit fei, F. foi, fr. L. fides; akin to fidere to trust, Gr. pei`qein to persuade. The ending th is perhaps due to the influence of such words as truth health wealth. See Bid Bide, and cf. Confide Defy Fealty

sn.def: Belief; the assent of the mind to the truth of what is declared by another, resting solely and implicitly on his authority and veracity; reliance on testimony.

The assent of the mind to the statement or proposition of another, on the ground of the manifest truth of what he utters; firm and earnest belief, on probable evidence of any kind, especially in regard to important moral truth.
sn.q: Faith, that is, fidelity, -- the fealty of the finite will and understanding to the reason.

sd.def: The belief in the historic truthfulness of the Scripture narrative, and the supernatural origin of its teachings, sometimes called historical and speculative faith.

The belief in the facts and truth of the Scriptures, with a practical love of them; especially, that confiding and affectionate belief in the person and work of Christ, which affects the character and life, and makes a man a true Christian, -- called a practical evangelical, or saving faith.
sd.q: Without faith it is impossible to please him [God].
The faith of the gospel is that emotion of the mind which is called “trust” or “confidence” exercised toward the moral character of God, and particularly of the Savior.
Faith is an affectionate, practical confidence in the testimony of God.

sn.def: That which is believed on any subject, whether in science, politics, or religion; especially Theol, a system of religious belief of any kind; as, the Jewish or Mohammedan faith; the Christian faith ; also, the creed or belief of a Christian society or church.
sn.q: Which to believe of her, Must be a faith that reason without miracle Could never plant in me.
Now preacheth the faith which once he destroyed.

sn.def: Fidelity to one's promises, or allegiance to duty, or to a person honored and beloved; loyalty.
sn.q: Children in whom is no faith.
Whose failing, while her faith to me remains, I should conceal.

sn.def: Word or honor pledged; promise given; fidelity; as, he violated his faith .
sn.q: For you alone I broke me faith with injured Palamon.

sn.def: Credibility or truth.
sn.q: The faith of the foregoing narrative.

entry.def: By my faith; in truth; verily.
Having faith or a faith; honest; sincere.
entry.q: Make thy wordsfaithed.

cs.cd: the adherents of any system of religious belief; esp. used as an epithet of the followers of Mohammed.

sn.def: Full of faith, or having faith; disposed to believe, especially in the declarations and promises of God.
sn.q: You are not faithful, sir.

sn.def: Firm in adherence to promises, oaths, contracts, treaties, or other engagements.
sn.q: The faithful God, which keepeth covenant and mercy with them that love him.

sn.def: True and constant in affection or allegiance to a person to whom one is bound by a vow, by ties of love, gratitude, or honor, as to a husband, a prince, a friend; firm in the observance of duty; loyal; of true fidelity; as, a faithful husband or servant.
sn.q: So spake the seraph Abdiel, faithful found, Among the faithless, faithful only he.

sn.def: Worthy of confidence and belief; conformable to truth ot fact; exact; accurate; as, a faithful narrative or representation.
sn.q: It is a faithful saying.
sn.syn: Trusty; honest; upright; sincere; veracious; trustworthy.

entry.def: the trait of being faithful.

sn.def: Not believing; not giving credit.
sn.q: Be not faithless, but believing.

sn.def: Not believing on God or religion; specifically, not believing in the Christian religion.
Not observant of promises or covenants.
Not true to allegiance, duty, or vows; perfidious; trecherous; disloyal; not of true fidelity; inconstant, as a husband or a wife.
sn.q: A most unnatural and faithless service.

sn.def: Serving to disappoint or deceive; delusive; unsatisfying.
sn.q: Yonderfaithlessphantom.

entry.ety: OF. faitor a doer, L. factor. See Factor
entry.def: A doer or actor; particularly, an evil doer; a scoundrel.
entry.q: Lo! faitour, there thy meed unto thee take.

entry.ety: Cf. Scot. faik fold, stratum of stone, AS. fæc space, interval, G. fach compartment, partition, row, and E. fay to fit
entry.def: One of the circles or windings of a cable or hawser, as it lies in a coil; a single turn or coil.

cs.cd: a box in which a long rope is faked; used in the life-saving service for a line attached to a shot.

entry.def: To coil (a rope, line, or hawser), by winding alternately in opposite directions, in layers usually of zigzag or figure of eight form,, to prevent twisting when running out.

entry.ety: Cf. Gael. faigh to get, acquire, reach, or OD. facken to catch or gripe

sn.def: To cheat; to swindle; to steal; to rob.
To make; to construct; to do.
To manipulate fraudulently, so as to make an object appear better or other than it really is; as, to fake a bulldog, by burning his upper lip and thus artificially shortening it.

entry.def: A trick; a swindle.
same as fakir.

entry.ety: Sometimes erroneously written fakir

sn.def: One who fakes something;

sd.def: a thief.
a peddler of petty things.
a workman who dresses things up.

sn.def: a person who makes deceitful pretenses.
sn.syn: imposter, impostor, pretender, fake, fraud, sham, pseudo, pseud, role player.

entry.ety: Ar. faqīr poor
entry.def: an Oriental Muslim or Hindu religious ascetic or begging monk who is regarded as a holy man or a wonder worker.

entry.ety: Prob. confused with Fakir an oriental ascetic
entry.def: See Faker.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A viverrine mammal of Madagascar (Eupleres Goudotii), allied to the civet; -- called also Falanouc.

entry.ety: F., ultimately fr. L. falx falcis, a sickle or scythe
entry.def: The action of a horse, when he throws himself on his haunches two or three times, bending himself, as it were, in very quick curvets.

entry.ety: L. falcatus, fr. falx falcis, a sickle or scythe
entry.def: Hooked or bent like a sickle; as, a falcate leaf; a falcate claw; -- said also of the moon, or a planet, when horned or crescent-formed.
The state of being falcate; a bend in the form of a sickle.

entry.ety: From L. falx falcis, a sickle
entry.def: One of the mandibles of a spider.

entry.ety: OE. fauchon, OF. fauchon, LL. fälcio, fr. L. falx falcis, a sickle, cf. Gr. ������ a ship's rib, ������ bandy-legged; perh, akin to E. falcon; cf. It. falcione. Cf. Defalcation

sn.def: A broad-bladed sword, slightly curved, shorter and lighter than the ordinary sword; -- used in the Middle Ages.
A name given generally and poetically to a sword, especially to the swords of Oriental and fabled warriors.

cs.cd: a law by which a testator was obliged to leave at least a fourth of his estate to the heir.

entry.ety: L. Falcidius
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Publius Falcidius, a Roman tribune.

entry.ety: L. falx falcis, a sickle + -form: cf. F. falciforme
entry.def: Having the shape of a scithe or sickle; resembling a reaping hook; as, the falciform ligatment of the liver.

entry.cs: Chanting falcon. Zoöl See under Chanting.
entry.ety: OE. faucon faucoun, OF. faucon falcon, �. faucon, fr. LL. falco, perh. from L. falx, falcis, a sickle or scythe, and named from its curving talons. Cf. Falchion

sd.def: One of a family (Falconidæ) of raptorial birds, characterized by a short, hooked beak, strong claws, and powerful flight.
Any species of the genus Falco, distinguished by having a toothlike lobe on the upper mandible; especially, one of this genus trained to the pursuit of other birds, or game.
sd.q: In the language of falconry, the female peregrine (Falco peregrinus) is exclusively called the falcon.

sn.def: An ancient form of cannon.

entry.ety: OE. fauconer, OF. falconier fauconier, F. fauconnier. See Falcon
entry.def: A person who breeds or trains hawks for taking birds or game; one who follows the sport of fowling with hawks.

entry.ety: Dim. of falcon: cf. F. fauconneau, LL. falconeta, properly, a young falcon

sn.def: One of the smaller cannon used in the 15th century and later.

sd.def: One of several very small Asiatic falcons of the genus Microhierax.
One of a group of Australian birds of the genus Falcunculus, resembling shrikes and titmice.

entry.ety: F. faucon-gentil. See Falcon, and Genteel

sn.def: any female falcon;
a female peregrine falcon (Falco peregrinus).
The female or young of the goshawk (Accipiter gentilis, formerly Astur palumbarius).

entry.def: Like a falcon or hawk; belonging to the Falconidæ

entry.ety: Cf. F. fauconnerie. See Falcon

sn.def: The art of training falcons or hawks to pursue and attack wild fowl or game.
The sport of taking wild fowl or game by means of falcons or hawks.

entry.ety: L., a small sickle, a billhook
entry.def: A curved and sharp-pointed claw.
Curved and sharppointed, like a falcula, or claw of a falcon.

entry.ety: LL. faldagium, fr. AS. fald, E. fold. Cf. Foldage
entry.def: A privilege of setting up, and moving about, folds for sheep, in any fields within manors, in order to manure them; -- often reserved to himself by the lord of the manor.

sn.def: Nonsense; foolish talk.
a knickknack; a gew-gaw.

entry.ety: AS. faldE.fold) + E. fee. See Faldage
entry.def: A fee or rent paid by a tenant for the privilege of faldage on his own ground.
A frieze or rough-napped cloth.

entry.ety: LL. faldistorium faldestorium, from OHG. faldstuol; faldan faltan, to fold (G. falten) + stuol stool. So called because it could be folded or laid together. See Fold, and Stool, and cf. Faldstool Fauteuil
entry.def: The throne or seat of a bishop within the chancel.

entry.note: ☞ In the modern practice of the Church of England, the term faldstool is given to the reading desk from which the litany is read. This esage is a relic of the ancient use of a lectern folding like a camp stool.
entry.ety: See Faldistory
entry.def: A folding stool, or portable seat, made to fold up in the manner of a camo stool. It was formerly placed in the choir for a bishop, when he offciated in any but his own cathedral church.
Of or pertaining to Mount Falernus, in Italy; as, Falernianwine.
The razorbill.

entry.cs:
To fall abroad of Naut to strike against; -- applied to one vessel coming into collision with another. To fall among to come among accidentally or unexpectedly. To fall astern Naut to move or be driven backward; to be left behind; as, a ship falls astern by the force of a current, or when outsailed by another. To fall away. To lose flesh; to become lean or emaciated; to pine. To renounce or desert allegiance; to revolt or rebel. To renounce or desert the faith; to apostatize. “These . . . for a while believe, and in time of temptation fall away.” Luke viii. 13. To perish; to vanish; to be lost. “How . . . can the soul . . . fall away into nothing?” Addison. To decline gradually; to fade; to languish, or become faint. “One color falls away by just degrees, and another rises insensibly.” Addison. To fall back. To recede or retreat; to give way. To fail of performing a promise or purpose; not to fulfill.
To fall back uponorTo fall back on . Mil To retreat for safety to (a stronger position in the rear, as to a fort or a supporting body of troops). To have recourse to (a reserved fund, a more reliable alternative, or some other available expedient or support). To fall calm to cease to blow; to become calm. To fall down. To prostrate one's self in worship. “All kings shall fall down before him.” Ps. lxxii. 11. To sink; to come to the ground. “Down fell the beauteous youth.” Dryden. To bend or bow, as a suppliant. Naut To sail or drift toward the mouth of a river or other outlet. To fall flat to produce no response or result; to fail of the intended effect; as, his speech fell flat. To fall foul of. Naut To have a collision with; to become entangled with To attack; to make an assault upon. To fall from to recede or depart from; not to adhere to; as, to fall from an agreement or engagement; to fall from allegiance or duty. To fall from grace M. E. Ch to sin; to withdraw from the faith. To fall home Ship Carp to curve inward; -- said of the timbers or upper parts of a ship's side which are much within a perpendicular. To fall in. To sink inwards; as, the roof fell in. Mil To take one's proper or assigned place in line; as, to fall in on the right. To come to an end; to terminate; to lapse; as, on the death of Mr. B., the annuuity, which he had so long received, fell in . To become operative. “The reversion, to which he had been nominated twenty years before, fell in.” Macaulay. To fall into one's hands to pass, often suddenly or unexpectedly, into one's ownership or control; as, to spike cannon when they are likely to fall into the hands of the enemy. To fall in with. To meet with accidentally; as, to fall in with a friend. Naut To meet, as a ship; also, to discover or come near, as land. To concur with; to agree with; as, the measure falls in with popular opinion. To comply; to yield to. “You will find it difficult to persuade learned men to fall in with your projects.” Addison. To fall off. To drop; as, fruits fall off when ripe. To withdraw; to separate; to become detached; as, friends fall off in adversity. “Love cools, friendship falls off, brothers divide.” Shak. To perish; to die away; as, words fall off by disuse. To apostatize; to forsake; to withdraw from the faith, or from allegiance or duty. Those captive tribes . . . fell off From God to worship calves. Milton. To forsake; to abandon; as, his customers fell off. To depreciate; to change for the worse; to deteriorate; to become less valuable, abundant, or interesting; as, a falling off in the wheat crop; the magazine or the review falls off . “O Hamlet, what a falling off was there!” Shak. Naut To deviate or trend to the leeward of the point to which the head of the ship was before directed; to fall to leeward. To fall on. To meet with; to light upon; as, we have fallen on evil days. To begin suddenly and eagerly. “Fall on, and try the appetite to eat.” Dryden. To begin an attack; to assault; to assail. “Fall on fall on, and hear him not.” Dryden. To drop on; to descend on. To fall out. To quarrel; to begin to contend. A soul exasperated in ills falls out With everything, its friend, itself. Addison. To happen; to befall; to chance. “There fell out a bloody quarrel betwixt the frogs and the mice.” L'Estrange. Mil To leave the ranks, as a soldier. To fall over. To revolt; to desert from one side to another. To fall beyond. Shak. To fall short to be deficient; as, the corn falls short; they all fall short in duty. To fall through to come to nothing; to fail; as, the engageent has fallen through. To fall to to begin. “Fall to, with eager joy, on homely food.” Dryden. To fall under. To come under, or within the limits of; to be subjected to; as, they fell under the jurisdiction of the emperor. To come under; to become the subject of; as, this point did not fall under the cognizance or deliberations of the court; these things do not fall under human sight or observation.
To come within; to be ranged or reckoned with; to be subordinate to in the way of classification; as, these substances fall under a different class or order.
To fall upon. To attack.See To fall on To attempt; to have recourse to. “I do not intend to fall upon nice disquisitions.” Holder. To rush against.
entry.note: ☞ Fall primarily denotes descending motion, either in a perpendicular or inclined direction, and, in most of its applications, implies, literally or figuratively, velocity, haste, suddenness, or violence. Its use is so various, and so mush diversified by modifying words, that it is not easy to enumerate its senses in all its applications.
entry.vmorph: imp. Fell fĕl; p. p. Fallen f�l"'n; p. pr. & vb. n. Falling
entry.ety: AS. feallan; akin to D. vallen, OS. & OHG. fallan, G. fallen, Icel. Falla, Sw. falla, Dan. falde, Lith. pulti, L. fallere to deceive, Gr. sfa`llein to cause to fall, Skr. sphal sphul, to tremble. Cf. Fail Fell v. t., to cause to fall

sn.def: To Descend, either suddenly or gradually; particularly, to descend by the force of gravity; to drop; to sink; as, the apple falls; the tide falls; the mercury falls in the barometer.
sn.q: I beheld Satan as lightning fall from heaven.

sn.def: To cease to be erect; to take suddenly a recumbent posture; to become prostrate; to drop; as, a child totters and falls; a tree falls; a worshiper falls on his knees.
sn.q: I fell at his feet to worship him.

sn.def: To find a final outlet; to discharge its waters; to empty; -- with into; as, the river Rhone falls into the Mediterranean.
To become prostrate and dead; to die; especially, to die by violence, as in battle.
sn.q: A thousand shall fall at thy side.
He rushed into the field, and, foremost fighting, fell.

sn.def: To cease to be active or strong; to die away; to lose strength; to subside; to become less intense; as, the wind falls .
To issue forth into life; to be brought forth; -- said of the young of certain animals.

To decline in power, glory, wealth, or importance; to become insignificant; to lose rank or position; to decline in weight, value, price etc.; to become less; as, the price falls; stocks fell two points.
sn.q: I am a poor fallen man, unworthy now To be thy lord and master.
The greatness of these Irish lords suddenly fell and vanished.

sn.def: To be overthrown or captured; to be destroyed.
sn.q: Heaven and earth will witness, If Rome must fall, that we are innocent.

sn.def: To descend in character or reputation; to become degraded; to sink into vice, error, or sin; to depart from the faith; to apostatize; to sin.
sn.q: Let us labor therefore to enter into that rest, lest any man fall after the same example of unbelief.

sn.def: To become insnared or embarrassed; to be entrapped; to be worse off than before; as, to fall into error; to fall into difficulties.
To assume a look of shame or disappointment; to become or appear dejected; -- said of the countenance.
sn.q: Cain was very wroth, and his countenance fell.
I have observed of late thy looks are fallen.

sn.def: To sink; to languish; to become feeble or faint; as, our spirits rise and fall with our fortunes.
To pass somewhat suddenly, and passively, into a new state of body or mind; to become; as, to fall asleep; to fall into a passion; to fall in love; to fall into temptation.
To happen; to to come to pass; to light; to befall; to issue; to terminate.
sn.q: The Romans fell on this model by chance.
Sit still, my daughter, until thou know how the matter will fall.
They do not make laws, they fall into customs.

sn.def: To come; to occur; to arrive.
sn.q: The vernal equinox, which at the Nicene Council fell on the 21st of March, falls now [1694] about ten days sooner.

sn.def: To begin with haste, ardor, or vehemence; to rush or hurry; as, they fell to blows.
sn.q: They now no longer doubted, but fell to work heart and soul.

sn.def: To pass or be transferred by chance, lot, distribution, inheritance, or otherwise; as, the estate fell to his brother; the kingdom fell into the hands of his rivals.
To belong or appertain.
sn.q: If to her share some female errors fall, Look on her face, and you'll forget them all.

sn.def: To be dropped or uttered carelessly; as, an unguarded expression fell from his lips; not a murmur fell from him.
To let fall; to drop.
sn.q: For every tear he falls, a Trojan bleeds.

sn.def: To sink; to depress; as, to fall the voice.
To diminish; to lessen or lower.
