sn.q: Upon lessening interest to four per cent, you fall the price of your native commodities.

sn.def: To bring forth; as, to fall lambs.
To fell; to cut down; as, to fall a tree.

cs.cd: a herring of the Atlantic (Clupea mediocris); -- also called tailor herring, and hickory shad.
to try a bout at wrestling.

sn.def: The act of falling; a dropping or descending be the force of gravity; descent; as, a fall from a horse, or from the yard of ship.
The act of dropping or tumbling from an erect posture; as, he was walking on ice, and had a fall .
Death; destruction; overthrow; ruin.
sn.q: They thy fall conspire.
Pride goeth before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.

sn.def: Downfall; degradation; loss of greatness or office; termination of greatness, power, or dominion; ruin; overthrow; as, the fall of the Roman empire.
sn.q: Beholds thee glorious only in thy fall.

sn.def: The surrender of a besieged fortress or town ; as, the fall of Sebastopol.
Diminution or decrease in price or value; depreciation; as, the fall of prices; the fall of rents.
A sinking of tone; cadence; as, the fall of the voice at the close of a sentence.
Declivity; the descent of land or a hill; a slope.
Descent of water; a cascade; a cataract; a rush of water down a precipice or steep; -- usually in the plural, sometimes in the singular; as, the falls of Niagara.
The discharge of a river or current of water into the ocean, or into a lake or pond; as, the fall of the Po into the Gulf of Venice.
Extent of descent; the distance which anything falls; as, the water of a stream has a fall of five feet.
The season when leaves fall from trees; autumn.
sn.q: What crowds of patients the town doctor kills, Or how, last fall, he raised the weekly bills.

sn.def: That which falls; a falling; as, a fall of rain; a heavy fall of snow.
The act of felling or cutting down.
sn.q: Thefallof timber.

sn.def: Lapse or declension from innocence or goodness. Specifically: The first apostasy; the act of our first parents in eating the forbidden fruit; also, the apostasy of the rebellious angels.
Formerly, a kind of ruff or band for the neck; a falling band; a faule.
That part (as one of the ropes) of a tackle to which the power is applied in hoisting.

entry.ety: L. fallaciosus, fr. fallacia: cf. F. fallacieux. See Fallacy
entry.def: Embodying or pertaining to a fallacy; illogical; fitted to deceive; misleading; delusive; as, fallacious arguments or reasoning.

sn.def: result of a fallacy or error in reasoning.

entries.entry:
Fal"la*cy
Fallacy Sophistry. A fallacy is an argument which professes to be decisive, but in reality is not; sophistry is also false reasoning, but of so specious and subtle a kind as to render it difficult to expose its fallacy. Many fallacies are obvious, but the evil of sophistry lies in its consummate art. “Men are apt to suffer their minds to be misled by fallacies which gratify their passions. Many persons have obscured and confounded the nature of things by their wretched sophistry; though an act be never so sinful, they will strip it of its guilt.” South.
făl"lȧ*s� n.; pl.Fallacies făl"lȧ*sĭz. OE. fallace fallas, deception, F. fallace, fr. L. fallacia, fr. fallax deceitful, deceptive, fr. fallere to deceive. See Fail
Deceptive or false appearance; deceitfulness; that which misleads the eye or the mind; deception. Winning by conquest what the first man lost, By fallacy surprised.
Logic An argument, or apparent argument, which professes to be decisive of the matter at issue, while in reality it is not; a sophism. Deception; deceit; mistake.

entry.def: Gay ornaments; frippery; gewgaws.

entry.ety: L. fallax deceptive. See Fallacy
entry.def: Cavillation; a caviling.

sn.def: The act or process of falling back.
Something or someone to which one resorts as an alternative to a failed resource or method.

entry.def: Dropped; prostrate; degraded; ruined; decreased; dead.
entry.q: Some ruined temple or fallen monument.

entry.ety: LL. fallentia, L. fallens p. pr of fallere
entry.def: An exception.

sn.def: One who, or that which, falls.
A part which acts by falling, as a stamp in a fulling mill, or the device in a spinning machine to arrest motion when a thread breaks.

entry.def: A fresh-water fish of the United States (Semotilus bullaris); -- called also silver chub, and Shiner. The name is also applied to other allied species.
The state of being fallible; liability to deceive or to be deceived; as, the fallibity of an argument or of an adviser.

entry.ety: LL. fallibilis, fr. L. fallere to deceive: cf. F. faillible. See Fail
entry.def: Liable to fail, mistake, or err; liable to deceive or to be deceived; as, all men are fallible; our opinions and hopes are fallible.
In a fallible manner.

entry.cs:
Falling away Falling off , etc. See To fall away To fall off, etc., under Fall v. i.
Falling band the plain, broad, linen collar turning down over the doublet, worn in the early part of the 17th century. Falling sickness Med epilepsy. Shak. Falling star. Astron See Shooting star. Falling stone a stone falling through the atmosphere; a meteorite; an aërolite. Falling tide the ebb tide. Falling weather a rainy season. Colloq Bartlett.
entry.def: from Fall v. i.
a noticeable decline in performance; as, a falloff in automobile sales.

entry.ety: From Fallopius, or Fallopio, a physician of Modena, who died in 1562
entry.def: Pertaining to, or discovered by, Fallopius; as, the Fallopian tubes or oviducts, the ducts or canals which conduct the ova from the ovaries to the uterus.

sn.def: the radioactive particles that settle to the ground after a nuclear explosion.
the falling to the ground of radioactive particles lifted into the atmosphere by a nuclear explosion.

an incidental or unexpected effect, especially one which is undesirable, consequent to an event or process; ; -- usually used only in the singular; as, the fallout from the disclosure of the Lewinsky tapes made trouble for the President for months after the event; fallout from the stock market crash caused property prices to decline in the New York area.
one selected from a group by some criterion.

q.au: H. Gill Cryer et al. (Journal of Trauma, Injury, Infection, and Critical Care. Vol 41, no. 3, 1996).

sn.q: Corrective action was taken in 97 of the 418 fallouts from 3,787 patients at risk.

sn.def: one who fails to maintain the same pace as and lags behind a group of which s/he is a member.

q.au: Lt. Col. William C. David (Preparing a Battalion for Combat: Physical Fitness and Mental Toughness. Army University After Next - Virtual Research Library).

sn.q: The executive officer's group noted all fallouts by name and policed them into a group to complete the run at a slower pace.

cs.cd: a small European bird, the wheatear (Saxicola œnanthe). See Wheatear.

entry.ety: AS. fealu fealo, pale yellow or red; akin to D. vaal fallow, faded, OHG. falo, G. falb fahl, Icel. fölr, and prob. to Lith. palvas, OSlav. plavŭ white, L. pallidus pale, pallere to be pale, Gr. polio`s gray, Skr. palita. Cf. Pale Favel a. Favor

sn.def: Pale red or pale yellow; as, a fallow deer or greyhound.
Left untilled or unsowed after plowing; uncultivated; as, fallow ground.

cs.cd: the crop taken from a green fallow.
fallow whereby land is rendered mellow and clean from weeds, by cultivating some green crop, as turnips, potatoes, etc.

entry.ety: So called from the fallow, or somewhat yellow, color of naked ground; or perh. akin to E. felly n., cf. MHG. valgen to plow up, OHG. felga felly, harrow

sn.def: Plowed land.
sn.q: Who . . . pricketh his blind horse over the fallows.

sn.def: Land that has lain a year or more untilled or unseeded; land plowed without being sowed for the season.
sn.q: The plowing of fallows is a benefit to land.

sn.def: The plowing or tilling of land, without sowing it for a season; as, summer fallow, properly conducted, has ever been found a sure method of destroying weeds.
sn.q: Be a complete summer fallow, land is rendered tender and mellow. The fallow gives it a better tilth than can be given by a fallow crop.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fallowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Fallowing
entry.ety: From Fallow n.
entry.def: To plow, harrow, and break up, as land, without seeding, for the purpose of destroying weeds and insects, and rendering it mellow; as, it is profitable to fallow cold, strong, clayey land.

entries.entry: Fal"low deer`. So called from its fallow or pale yellow color Zoöl A European species of deer (Cervus dama), much smaller than the red deer. In summer both sexes are spotted with white. It is common in England, where it is often domesticated in the parks.

entry.def: One who favors the practice of fallowing land.
A well or opening, through the successive floors of a warehouse or manufactory, through which goods are raised or lowered.
The larva of any moth of the genus Hyphantria, which spins a web around the foliage on which it feeds.

entry.ety: L. falsarius, fr. falsus. See False a.
entry.def: A falsifier of evidence.

entry.cs:
False arch Arch a member having the appearance of an arch, though not of arch construction. False attic an architectural erection above the main cornice, concealing a roof, but not having windows or inclosing rooms. False bearing any bearing which is not directly upon a vertical support; thus, the weight carried by a corbel has a false bearing. False cadence an imperfect or interrupted cadence. False conception Med an abnormal conception in which a mole, or misshapen fleshy mass, is produced instead of a properly organized fetus. False croup Med a spasmodic affection of the larynx attended with the symptoms of membranous croup, but unassociated with the deposit of a fibrinous membrane.
False doororFalse window
Arch the representation of a door or window, inserted to complete a series of doors or windows or to give symmetry. False fire a combustible carried by vessels of war, chiefly for signaling, but sometimes burned for the purpose of deceiving an enemy; also, a light on shore for decoying a vessel to destruction. False galena. See Blende. False imprisonment Law the arrest and imprisonment of a person without warrant or cause, or contrary to law; or the unlawful detaining of a person in custody. False keel Naut the timber below the main keel, used to serve both as a protection and to increase the shio's lateral resistance. False key a picklock. False leg. Zoöl See Proleg. False membrane Med the fibrinous deposit formed in croup and diphtheria, and resembling in appearance an animal membrane. False papers Naut documents carried by a ship giving false representations respecting her cargo, destination, etc., for the purpose of deceiving. False passage Surg an unnatural passage leading off from a natural canal, such as the urethra, and produced usually by the unskillful introduction of instruments. False personation Law the intentional false assumption of the name and personality of another. False pretenses Law false representations concerning past or present facts and events, for the purpose of defrauding another. False rail Naut a thin piece of timber placed on top of the head rail to strengthen it. False relation Mus a progression in harmony, in which a certain note in a chord appears in the next chord prefixed by a flat or sharp. False return Law an untrue return made to a process by the officer to whom it was delivered for execution. False ribs Anat the asternal rebs, of which there are five pairs in man. False roof Arch the space between the upper ceiling and the roof. Oxford Gloss. False token a false mark or other symbol, used for fraudulent purposes. False scorpion Zoöl any arachnid of the genus Chelifer. See Book scorpion. False tack Naut a coming up into the wind and filling away again on the same tack. False vampire Zoöl the Vampyrus spectrum of South America, formerly erroneously supposed to have blood-sucking habits; -- called also vampire, and ghost vampire. The genuine blood-sucking bats belong to the genera Desmodus and Diphylla. See Vampire. False window. Arch See False door, above. False wing. Zoöl See Alula, and Bastard wing, under Bastard. False works Civil Engin construction works to facilitate the erection of the main work, as scaffolding, bridge centering, etc.
entry.ety: L. falsus, p. p. of fallere to deceive; cf. OF. faus fals, F. faux, and AS. fals fraud. See Fail Fall

sn.def: Uttering falsehood; unveracious; given to deceit; dishnest; as, a false witness.
Not faithful or loyal, as to obligations, allegiance, vows, etc.; untrue; treacherous; perfidious; as, a false friend, lover, or subject; false to promises.
sn.q: I to myself was false, ere thou to me.

sn.def: Not according with truth or reality; not true; fitted or likely to deceive or disappoint; as, a false statement.
Not genuine or real; assumed or designed to deceive; counterfeit; hypocritical; as, false tears; false modesty; false colors; false jewelry.
sn.q: False face must hide what the false heart doth know.

sn.def: Not well founded; not firm or trustworthy; erroneous; as, a false claim; a false conclusion; a false construction in grammar.
sn.q: Whose false foundation waves have swept away.

sn.def: Not essential or permanent, as parts of a structure which are temporary or supplemental.
Not in tune.

entry.def: Not truly; not honestly; falsely.
entry.q: You play mefalse.

entry.ety: L. falsare to falsify, fr. falsus: cf. F. fausser. See False a.

sn.def: To report falsely; to falsify.
To betray; to falsify.
sn.q: He] hath his truthe falsed in this wise.

sn.def: To mislead by want of truth; to deceive.
sn.q: In his falsed fancy.

sn.def: To feign; to pretend to make.
sn.q: Andfalsedoft his blows.

entry.def: Hypocritical.
False-hearted.
Hollow or unsound at the core; treacherous; deceitful; perfidious.

entry.ety: False + -hood

sn.def: Want of truth or accuracy; an untrue assertion or representation; error; misrepresentation; falsity.
sn.q: Though it be a lie in the clock, it is but a falsehood in the hand of the dial when pointing at a wrong hour, if rightly following the direction of the wheel which moveth it.

sn.def: A deliberate intentional assertion of what is known to be untrue; a departure from moral integrity; a lie.
Treachery; deceit; perfidy; unfaithfulness.
sn.q: Betrayed by falsehood of his guard.

sn.def: A counterfeit; a false appearance; an imposture.
sn.q: For his molten image is falsehood.
No falsehood can endure Touch of celestial temper.
sn.syn: Falsity; lie; untruth; fiction; fabrication. See Falsity.

entry.def: In a false manner; erroneously; not truly; perfidiously or treacherously.
entry.q: Ofalsely falselymurdered.
Oppositions of science, falsely so called.
Will ye steal, murder . . . and swear falsely ?

entry.def: The state of being false; contrariety to the fact; inaccuracy; want of integrity or uprightness; double dealing; unfaithfulness; treachery; perfidy; as, the falseness of a report, a drawing, or a singer's notes; the falseness of a man, or of his word.
A deceiver.

entries.entry:
Fal*set"to n.; pl.Falsettos #. It. falsetto, dim. fr. L. falsus. See False
A false or artificial voice; that voice in a man which lies above his natural voice; the male counter tenor or alto voice. See Head voice, under Voice.

‖Fal"si*cri"men ☞ This term in the Roman law included not only forgery, but every species of fraud and deceit. It never has been used in so extensive a sense in modern common law, in which its predominant significance is forgery, though it also includes perjury and offenses of a like character.. L Civ. Law The crime of falsifying.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. falsifiable

sn.def: Capable of being falsified, counterfeited, or corrupted.
able to be proven false, and therefore testable; as, most religious beliefs are not falsifiable, and are therefor outside the scope of experimental science.

entry.ety: Cf. F. falsification

sn.def: The act of falsifying, or making false; a counterfeiting; the giving to a thing an appearance of something which it is not.
sn.q: To counterfeit the living image of king in his person exceedeth all falsifications.

sn.def: Willful misstatement or misrepresentation.
sn.q: Extreme necessity . . . forced him upon this bold and violent falsification of the doctrine of the alliance.

sn.def: The showing an item of charge in an account to be wrong.

entry.ety: Cf. F. falsificateur
entry.def: A falsifier.
One who falsifies, or gives to a thing a deceptive appearance; a liar.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Falsified; p. pr. & vb. n. Falsifying
entry.ety: L. falsus false + -ly: cf. F. falsifier. See False a.

sn.def: To make false; to represent falsely.
sn.q: The Irish bards use to forge and falsify everything as they list, to please or displease any man.

sn.def: To counterfeit; to forge; as, to falsify coin.
To prove to be false, or untrustworthy; to confute; to disprove; to nullify; to make to appear false.
sn.q: By how much better than my word I am, By so much shall I falsify men's hope.
Jews and Pagans united all their endeavors, under Julian the apostate, to baffle and falsify the prediction.

sn.def: To violate; to break by falsehood; as, to falsify one's faith or word.
To baffle or escape; as, to falsify a blow.
To avoid or defeat; to prove false, as a judgment.
To show, in accounting, (an inem of charge inserted in an account) to be wrong.
To make false by multilation or addition; to tamper with; as, to falsify a record or document.

entry.def: To tell lies; to violate the truth.
entry.q: It is absolutely and universally unlawful to lie and falsify.
South.

entry.def: That which is evidently false; an assertion or statement the falsity of which is plainly apparent; -- opposed to truism.

entries.entry:
Fal"si*ty
Falsity Falsehood Lie. Falsity denotes the state or quality of being false. A falsehood is a false declaration designedly made. A lie is a gross, unblushing falsehood. The falsity of a person's assertion may be proved by the evidence of others and thus the charge of falsehood be fastened upon him. n.;pl.Falsities #. L. falsitas: cf. F. fausseté, OF. also, falsité. See False a.
The quality of being false; coutrariety or want of conformity to truth. Probability does not make any alteration, either in the truth or falsity of things.
That which is false; falsehood; a lie; a false assertion. Men often swallow falsities for truths. Falsehood; lie; deceit.

entry.note: ☞ Shakespeare found the name of John Oldcastle in the ... older play of "Henry V."; in the Chronicle he found a John Oldcastle, who was page to the Duke of Norfolk who plays a part in "Richard II."; and this, according to Shakespeare, his FalstaffOldcastle) had been in his youth. When the poet wrote his "Henry IV." he knew not who this Oldcastle was, whom he had rendered so distinct with the designation as Norfolk's page; he was a Lord Cobham [Sir John Oldcastle, known as the good lord Cobham], who had perished as a Lollard and Wickliffite in the persecution of the church under Henry V. The Protestants regarded him as a holy martyr, the Catholics as a heretic; the latter seized with eagerness this description of the fat poltroon, and gave it out as a portrait of Lord Cobham, who was indeed physically and mentally his contrast. The family complained of this misuse of a name dear to them, and Shakespeare declared in the epilogue to "Henry IV." that Cobham was in his sight also a martyr, and that "this was not the man." At the same time, he changed the name to Falstaff, but this was of little use; in spite of the express retraction, subsequent Catholic writers on church history still declared Falstaff to be a portrait of the heretic Cobham. But it is a strange circumstance that even now under the name of Falstaff another historical character is again sought for, just as if it were impossible for such a vigorous form not to be a being of reality. It was referred to John Fastolfe, whose cowardice is more stigmatised in "Henry VI." than history justifies; and this too met with public blame, although Shakespeare could have again asserted that he intended Fastolfe as little as Cobham. Gervinus, Shakespeare Commentaries (tr. by K E. Bunnett, [ed. 1880), p. 800.
entry.def: Sir John Falstaff, a celebrated character in Shakespeare's historical play " Henry IV." (1st and 2d parts), and also in " The Merry Wives of Windsor." He is a very fat, sensual, and witty old knight; a swindler, drunkard, and good-tempered liar; and something of a coward. Falstaff was originally called Sir John Oldcastle. The first actor of the part was John Heminge.
of or pertaining to Falstaff, a character in Shakespeare's plays.
To thrash in the chaff; also, to cleanse or sift, as barley.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Faltered; p. pr. & vb. n. Faltering
entry.ety: OE. falteren faltren, prob. from fault. See Fault v. & n.

sn.def: To hesitate; to speak brokenly or weakly; to stammer; as, his tongue falters .
sn.q: With faltering speech and visage incomposed.

sn.def: To tremble; to totter; to be unsteady.
sn.q: He found his legsfalter.

sn.def: To hesitate in purpose or action.
sn.q: Ere her native king Shall falter under foul rebellion's arms.

sn.def: To fail in distinctness or regularity of exercise; -- said of the mind or of thought.
sn.q: Here indeed the power of disinct conception of space and distance falters.

entry.def: To utter with hesitation, or in a broken, trembling, or weak manner.
entry.q: And here he faltered forth his last farewell.
Mde me most happy, faltering “I am thine.”

entry.ety: See Falter v. i.
entry.def: Hesitation; trembling; feebleness; an uncertain or broken sound; as, a slight falter in her voice.
entry.q: The falter of an idle shepherd's pipe.

entry.def: Hesitating; trembling.
entry.q: Withfalteringspeech.

def2.def: Falter; halting; hesitation.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A series of strata, of the Middle Tertiary period, of France, abounding in shells, and used by Lyell as the type of his Miocene subdivision.
Fallow.

entry.ety: L., a sickle
entry.def: A curved fold or process of the dura mater or the peritoneum; esp., one of the partitionlike folds of the dura mater which extend into the great fissures of the brain.

entry.ety: OE. falmelen; cf. SW. famla to grope, Dan. famle to grope, falter, hesitate, Icel. fālma to grope. Cf. Famble
entry.def: To stammer.

entry.ety: Cf. Famble v.
entry.def: A hand.
entry.q: We clap ourfambles.

entry.ety: OF. fame, L. fama, fr. fari to speak, akin to Gr. ���� a saying, report, fa`nai to speak. See Ban, and cf. Fable Fate Euphony Blame

sn.def: Public report or rumor.
sn.q: The fame thereof was heard in Pharaoh's house.

sn.def: Report or opinion generally diffused; renown; public estimation; celebrity, either favorable or unfavorable; as, the fame of Washington .
sn.q: I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Famed,; p. pr. & vb. n. Faming

sn.def: To report widely or honorably.
sn.q: The field where thou art famed To have wrought such wonders.

sn.def: To make famous or renowned.
sn.q: Those Hesperian gardens famed of old.

entry.def: Without fame or renown.

sn.def: relating to or having the characteristics of a family; as, children of the same familial background; familial aggregation.
tending to occur among members of a family, usually by hereditary transmission; familial traits.

cs.cd: a demon or evil spirit supposed to attend at call.

entry.ety: OE. familer familier, F. familier, fr. L. familiaris, fr. familia family. See Family

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a family; domestic.
sn.q: Familiarfeuds.

sn.def: Closely acquainted or intimate, as a friend or companion; well versed in, as any subject of study; as, familiar with the Scriptures.
Characterized by, or exhibiting, the manner of an intimate friend; not formal; unconstrained; easy; accessible.
sn.q: In loose,familiarstrains.
Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar.

sn.def: Well known; well understood; common; frequent; as, a familiar illustration.
sn.q: That war, or peace, or both at once, may be As things acquainted and familiar to us.
There is nothing more familiar than this.

sn.def: Improperly acquainted; wrongly intimate.
An intimate; a companion.
sn.q: All my familiars watched for my halting.

sn.def: An attendant demon or evil spirit.
A confidential officer employed in the service of the tribunal, especially in apprehending and imprisoning the accused.

entry.def: to make familiar or acquainted; same as familiarize.

entries.entry:
Fa*mil`iar"i*ty n.; pl.Familiarities #. OE. familarite, F. familiaritéfr. L. faniliaritas. See Familiar
The state of being familiar; intimate and frequent converse, or association; unconstrained intercourse; freedom from ceremony and constraint; intimacy; as, to live in remarkable familiarity .
Anything said or done by one person to another unceremoniously and without constraint; esp., in the pl., such actions and words as propriety and courtesy do not warrant; liberties. Acquaintance; fellowship; affability; intimacy. See Acquaintance.

entry.def: The act or process of making familiar; the result of becoming familiar; as, familiarization with scenes of blood.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Familiarized; p. pr. & vb. n. Familiarizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. familiariser

sn.def: To make familiar or intimate; to habituate; to accustom; to make well known by practice or converse; as, to familiarize one's self with scenes of distress; we familiarized ourselves with the new surroundings.
To make acquainted, or skilled, by practice or study; as, to familiarize one's self with a business, a book, or a science.

entry.def: having become familiar.
serving to familiarize.
In a familiar manner.
Familiarity.

entry.ety: L. familiaris. See Familiar
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a family or household; domestic.
The tenets of the Familists.

entry.ety: From Family
entry.def: One of a fanatical Antinomian sect originating in Holland, and existing in England about 1580, called the Family of Love, who held that religion consists wholly in love.

entries.entry:
Fam"i*lis*ter*y n.; pl.Familisteries. F. familistère
A community in which many persons unite as in one family, and are regulated by certain communistic laws and customs.

entry.def: Pertaining to Familists.

entries.entry:
Fam"i*ly
Family circle. See under Circle. Family man. A man who has a family; esp., one who has a wife and children living with him and dependent upon him. A man of domestic habits. “The Jews are generally, when married, most exemplary family men.” Mayhew.
Family of curvesorFamily of surfaces
Geom a group of curves or surfaces derived from a single equation. In a family way like one belonging to the family. “Why don't we ask him and his ladies to come over in a family way, and dine with some other plain country gentlefolks?” Thackeray. In the family way pregnant. Colloq. euphemism
n.; pl.Families #. L. familia, fr. famulus servant; akin to Oscan famel servant, cf. faamat he dwells, Skr. dhāman house, fr. dhāto set, make, do: cf. F. famille. Cf. Do v. t. Doom Fact Feat
The collective body of persons who live in one house, and under one head or manager; a household, including parents, children, and servants, and, as the case may be, lodgers or boarders.
The group comprising a husband and wife and their dependent children, constituting a fundamental unit in the organization of society. The welfare of the family underlies the welfare of society.
Those who descend from one common progenitor; a tribe, clan, or race; kindred; house; as, the human family; the family of Abraham; the father of a family.
Go ! and pretend your family is young.
Course of descent; genealogy; line of ancestors; lineage.
Honorable descent; noble or respectable stock; as, a man of family .
A group of kindred or closely related individuals; as, a family of languages; a family of States; the chlorine family.
Biol A group of organisms, either animal or vegetable, related by certain points of resemblance in structure or development, more comprehensive than a genus, because it is usually based on fewer or less pronounced points of likeness. In zoölogy a family is less comprehesive than an order; in botany it is often considered the same thing as an order.

cs.cd: typhus fever.

entry.ety: F. famine, fr. L. fames hunger; cf. Gr. ����� want, need, Skr. hāni loss, lack, hā to leave
entry.def: General scarcity of food; dearth; a want of provisions; destitution.
entry.q: Worn withfamine.
There was a famine in the land.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Famished; p. pr. & vb. n. Famishing
entry.ety: OE. famen; cf. OF. afamer, L. fames. See Famine, and cf. Affamish

sn.def: To starve, kill, or destroy with hunger.
To exhaust the strength or endurance of, by hunger; to distress with hanger.
sn.q: And when all the land of Egypt was famished, the people cried to Pharaoh for bread.
The pains of famished Tantalus he'll feel.

sn.def: To kill, or to cause to suffer extremity, by deprivation or denial of anything necessary.
sn.q: And famish him of breath, if not of bread.

sn.def: To force or constrain by famine.
sn.q: He had famished Paris into a surrender.

sn.def: To die of hunger; to starve.
To suffer extreme hunger or thirst, so as to be exhausted in strength, or to come near to perish.
sn.q: You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

sn.def: To suffer extremity from deprivation of anything essential or necessary.
sn.q: The Lord will not suffer the soul of the righteous to famish.

entry.def: State of being famished.

entry.ety: L. famositas infamy: cf. F. famosité. See Famous
entry.def: The state or quality of being famous.

entry.usage: Famous Renowned Illustrious. Famous is applied to a person or thing widely spoken of as extraordinary; renowned is applied to those who are named again and again with honor; illustrious, to those who have dazzled the world by the splendor of their deeds or their virtues. See Distinguished.
entry.ety: L. famosus, fr. fama fame: cf. F. fameux. See Fame
entry.def: Celebrated in fame or public report; renowned; mach talked of; distinguished in story; -- used in either a good or a bad sense, chiefly the former; often followed by for; as, famous for erudition, for eloquence, for military skill; a famous pirate.
entry.q: Famous for a scolding tongue.
entry.syn: Noted; remarkable; signal; conspicuous; celebrated; renowned; illustrious; eminent; transcendent; excellent.

entry.def: Renowned.
In a famous manner; in a distinguished degree; greatly; splendidly.
entry.q: Then this land was famously enriched With politic grave counsel.

entry.def: The state of being famous.

entry.ety: Cf. L. famularis of servants
entry.def: Domestic; familiar.

entry.ety: L. famulatus, p. p. of famulari to serve, fr. famulus servant
entry.def: To serve.

entry.ety: L. famulus servant
entry.def: A collegian of inferior rank or position, corresponding to the sizar at Cambridge.

entry.cs: Fan blower a wheel with vanes fixed on a rotating shaft inclosed in a case or chamber, to create a blast of air (fan blast) for forge purposes, or a current for draft and ventilation; a fanner. Fan cricket Zoöl a mole cricket. Fan light Arch a window over a door; -- so called from the semicircular form and radiating sash bars of those windows which are set in the circular heads of arched doorways. Fan shell Zoöl any shell of the family Pectinidæ. See Scallop n., 1. Fan tracery Arch the decorative tracery on the surface of fan vaulting. Fan vaulting Arch an elaborate system of vaulting, in which the ribs diverge somewhat like the rays of a fan, as in Henry VII.'s chapel in Westminster Abbey. It is peculiar to English Gothic. Fan wheel the wheel of a fan blower. Fan window. Same as Fan lightabove). electric fan. a fan having revolving blades for propelling air, powered by an electric motor.
entry.ety: AS. fann, fr. L. vannus fan, van for winnowing grain; cf. F. van. Cf. Van a winnowing machine, Winnow
entry.sn:
An instrument used for producing artificial currents of air, by the wafting or revolving motion of a broad surface; as: An instrument for cooling the person, made of feathers, paper, silk, etc., and often mounted on sticks all turning about the same pivot, so as when opened to radiate from the center and assume the figure of a section of a circle.
Mach Any revolving vane or vanes used for producing currents of air, in winnowing grain, blowing a fire, ventilation, etc., or for checking rapid motion by the resistance of the air; a fan blower; a fan wheel.
An instrument for winnowing grain, by moving which the grain is tossed and agitated, and the chaff is separated and blown away.
Something in the form of a fan when spread, as a peacock's tail, a window, etc.
A small vane or sail, used to keep the large sails of a smock windmill always in the direction of the wind. Clean provender, which hath been winnowed with the shovel and with the fan.

sn.def: That which produces effects analogous to those of a fan, as in exciting a flame, etc.; that which inflames, heightens, or strengthens; as, it served as a fan to the flame of his passion.
A quintain; -- from its form.

cs.cd: a machine for separating seed from chaff, etc., by a blast of air; a fanner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fanned; p. pr. & vb. n. Fanning
entry.ety: Cf. OF. vanner, L. vannere. See Fan n. Van a winnowing machine

sn.def: To move as with a fan.
sn.q: The air . . . fanned with unnumbered plumes.

sn.def: To cool and refresh, by moving the air with a fan; to blow the air on the face of with a fan.
To ventilate; to blow on; to affect by air put in motion.
sn.q: Calm as the breath which fans our eastern groves.

sn.def: To winnow; to separate chaff from, and drive it away by a current of air; as, to fan wheat.
To excite or stir up to activity, as a fan excites a flame; to stimulate; as, this conduct fanned the excitement of the populace.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A lighthouse, or the apparatus placed in it for giving light.

entry.ety: L. fanaticus inspired by divinity, enthusiastic, frantic, fr. fanum fane: cf. F. fanatique. See Fane
entry.def: Pertaining to, or indicating, fanaticism; extravagant in opinions; ultra; unreasonable; excessively enthusiastic, especially on religious subjects; as, fanatic zeal; fanatic notions.
entry.q: But Faith, fanatic Faith, once wedded fast To some dear falsehood, hugs it to the last.

entry.def: A person affected by excessive enthusiasm, particularly on religious subjects; one who indulges wild and extravagant notions of religion.
entry.q: There is a new word, coined within few months, called fanatics, which, by the close stickling thereof, seemeth well cut out and proportioned to signify what is meant thereby, even the sectaries of our age.
Fanatics are governed rather by imagination than by judgment.

entries.entry:
Fa*nat"ic*al
Fa*nat"ic*al*ly adv. Fa*nat"ic*al*ness n.
a. Characteristic of, or relating to, fanaticism; fanatic. -

entry.ety: Cf. Fanatism
entry.def: Excessive enthusiasm, unreasoning zeal, or wild and extravagant notions, on any subject, especially religion, politics or ideology; religious frenzy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fanaticized; p. pr. & vb. n. Fanaticizing
entry.def: To cause to become a fanatic.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fanatisme. Cf. Fanaticism
entry.def: Fanaticism.

entry.ety: From Fancy v. t.
entry.def: Formed or conceived by the fancy; unreal; as, a fancied wrong.

sn.def: One who is governed by fancy.
sn.q: Not reasoners, butfanciers.

sn.def: One who fancies or has a special liking for, or interest in, a particular object or class or objects; hence, one who breeds and keeps for sale birds and animals; as, bird fancier, dog fancier, etc.

entry.usage: Fanciful Fantastical Visionary. We speak of that as fanciful which is irregular in taste and judgment; we speak of it as fantastical when it becomes grotesque and extravagant as well as irregular; we speak of it as visionary when it is wholly unfounded in the nature of things. Fanciful notions are the product of a heated fancy, without any tems are made up of oddly assorted fancies, aften of the most whimsical kind; visionary expectations are those which can never be realized in fact.

sn.def: Full of fancy; guided by fancy, rather than by reason and experience; whimsical; as, a fanciful man forms visionary projects.
Conceived in the fancy; not consistent with facts or reason; abounding in ideal qualities or figures; as, a fanciful scheme; a fanciful theory.
Curiously shaped or constructed; as, she wore a fanciful headdress.
sn.q: Gather up all fancifullest shells.
sn.syn: Imaginative; ideal; visionary; capricious; chimerical; whimsical; fantastical; wild.

entry.def: Having no fancy; without ideas or imagination.
entry.q: A pert or bluff important wight, Whose brain is fanciless, whose blood is white.

entries.entry:
Fan"cy
The fancy all of a class who exhibit and cultivate any peculiar taste or fancy; hence, especially, sporting characters taken collectively, or any specific class of them, as jockeys, gamblers, prize fighters, etc.
făn"s� n.; pl.Fancies #. Contr. fr. fantasy, OF. fantasie fantaisie, F. fantaisie, L. phantasia, fr. Gr. �������� appearance, imagination, the power of perception and presentation in the mind, fr. �������� to make visible, to place before one's mind, fr. ������� to show; akin to ����, ���, light, Skr. bhāto shine. Cf. Fantasy Fantasia Epiphany Phantom
The faculty by which the mind forms an image or a representation of anything perceived before; the power of combining and modifying such objects into new pictures or images; the power of readily and happily creating and recalling such objects for the purpose of amusement, wit, or embellishment; imagination. In the soul Are many lesser faculties, that serve Reason as chief. Among these fancy next Her office holds.
An image or representation of anything formed in the mind; conception; thought; idea; conceit. How now, my lord ! why do you keep alone, Of sorriest fancies your companoins making ?
An opinion or notion formed without much reflection; caprice; whim; impression. I have always had a fancy that learning might be made a play and recreation to children.
Inclination; liking, formed by caprice rather than reason; as, to strike one's fancy ; hence, the object of inclination or liking. To fit your fancies to your father's will.
That which pleases or entertains the taste or caprice without much use or value. London pride is a pretty fancy for borders.
A sort of love song or light impromptu ballad. Obs At a great book sale in London, which had congregated all the fancy. Imagination; conceit; taste; humor; inclination; whim; liking. See Imagination.

sn.def: To figure to one's self; to believe or imagine something without proof.
sn.q: If our search has reached no farther than simile and metaphor, we rather fancy than know.

sn.def: To love.
To form a conception of; to portray in the mind; to imagine.
sn.q: He whom I fancy, but can ne'er express.

sn.def: To have a fancy for; to like; to be pleased with, particularly on account of external appearance or manners.
sn.q: Wefancynot the cardinal.

sn.def: To believe without sufficient evidence; to imagine (something which is unreal).
sn.q: He fancied he was welcome, because those arounde him were his kinsmen.

cs.cd: a ball in which porsons appear in fanciful dresses in imitation of the costumes of different persons and nations.
a fair at which articles of fancy and ornament are sold, generally for some charitable purpose.
fabrics of various colors, patterns, etc., as ribbons, silks, laces, etc., in distinction from those of a simple or plain color or make.
a line rove through a block at the jaws of a gaff; -- used to haul it down.
a clothed cylinder (usually having straight teeth) in front of the doffer.
a species of stocks which afford great opportunity for stock gambling, since they have no intrinsic value, and the fluctuations in their prices are artificial.
one where articles of fancy and ornament are sold.
the more rare and expensive furniture woods, as mahogany, satinwood, rosewood, etc.

sn.def: Adapted to please the fancy or taste, especially when of high quality or unusually appealing; ornamental; as, fancy goods; fancy clothes.
Extravagant; above real value.
sn.q: This anxiety never degenerated into a monomania, like that which led his [Frederick the Great's] father to pay fancy prices for giants.

entry.def: Free from the power of love.
entry.q: In maiden meditation,fancy-free.

entry.def: A lovemonger; a whimsical lover.
Love-sick.
Ornamental work with a needle or hook, as embroidery, crocheting, netting, etc.
imp. of Find.

entries.entry:
Fan*dan"go n.; pl.Fandangoes #. Sp. A name brought, together with the dance, from the West Indies to Spain
A lively dance, in 3-8 or 6-8 time, much practiced in Spain and Spanish America. Also, the tune to which it is danced.
A ball or general dance, as in Mexico. Colloq

entry.ety: L. fanum a place dedicated to some deity, a sanctuary, fr. fari to speak. See Fame
entry.def: A temple; a place consecrated to religion; a church.
entry.q: Such to this British Isle, her Christian fanes.

entry.ety: See Vane
entry.def: A weathercock.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: A dry measure in Spain and Spanish America, varying from 1� to 2� bushels; also, a measure of land.

entry.ety: F. Cf. Fanfaron
entry.def: A flourish of trumpets, as in coming into the lists, etc.; also, a short and lively air performed on hunting horns during the chase.
entry.q: The fanfare announcing the arrival of the various Christian princes.

entry.ety: F., fr. Sp. fanfarron; cf. It. fanfano, and OSp. fanfa swaggering, boasting, also Ar. farfār talkative
entry.def: A bully; a hector; a swaggerer; an empty boaster.

entry.ety: F. fanfaronnade, fr. Sp. fanfarronada. See Fanfaron
entry.def: A swaggering; vain boasting; ostentation; a bluster.
A species of gecko having the toes expanded into large lobes for adhesion. The Egyptian fanfoot (Phyodactylus gecko) is believed, by the natives, to have venomous toes.
Any moth of the genus Polypogon.

entry.ety: OE. fangen fongen fong orig. only in p. p. and imp. tense), AS. fōn; akin to D. vangen, OHG. fāhan, G. fahen fangen, Icel. fā, Sw. få fånga, Dan. fange faae, Goth. fahan, and prob. to E. fair peace pact. Cf. Fair a.

sn.def: To catch; to seize, as with the teeth; to lay hold of; to gripe; to clutch.
sn.q: He's in the law's clutches; you see he's fanged.

sn.def: To enable to catch or tear; to furnish with fangs.
sn.q: Chariotsfangedwith scythes.

entry.cs: In a fang fast entangled. To lose the fang said of a pump when the water has gone out; hence: To fang a pump to supply it with the water necessary to make it operate. Scot
entry.ety: From Fang v. t.; cf. AS. fang a taking, booty, G. fang

sn.def: The tusk of an animal, by which the prey is seized and held or torn; a long pointed tooth; esp., one of the usually erectile, venomous teeth of serpents. Also, one of the falcers of a spider.
sn.q: Since I am a dog, beware my fangs.

sn.def: Any shoot or other thing by which hold is taken.
sn.q: The protuberant fangs of the yucca.

sn.def: The root, or one of the branches of the root, of a tooth. See Tooth.
A niche in the side of an adit or shaft, for an air course.
A projecting tooth or prong, as in a part of a lock, or the plate of a belt clamp, or the end of a tool, as a chisel, where it enters the handle.

sd.def: The valve of a pump box.
A bend or loop of a rope.

entry.def: Having fangs or tusks; as, a fanged adder. Also used figuratively.

entry.ety: From Fang v. t.; hence, prop., a taking up a new thing
entry.def: Something new-fashioned; a foolish innovation; a gewgaw; a trifling ornament.
To fashion.
entry.q: To control and new fangle the Scripture.

entry.def: New made; hence, gaudy; showy; vainly decorated. Obs., except with the prefix new See Newfangled.
entry.q: Ourfangledworld.

entry.def: Quality of being fangled.
entry.q: He them in new fangleness did pass.

entry.def: Destitute of fangs or tusks.
entry.q: Afanglesslion.

entry.ety: Cf. It. fagotto fangotto, a bundle. Cf. Fagot
entry.def: A quantity of wares, as raw silk, etc., from one hundred weight.

entry.ety: See Fanon

sn.def: A small flag sometimes carried at the head of the baggage of a brigade.
A small flag for marking the stations in surveying.

entry.def: Resembling a fan;
folded up like a fan, as certain leaves; plicate.

entry.ety: Dim., from same source as fanon
entry.def: Same as Fanon.

sn.def: One who fans.
A fan wheel; a fan blower. See under Fan.

entry.def: Having the nerves or veins arranged in a radiating manner; -- said of certain leaves, and of the wings of some insects.

entry.ety: F. fanon, LL. fano, fr. OHG. fano banner cloth, G. fahne banner. See Vane, and cf. Fanion Gonfalon
entry.def: A term applied to various articles,
A peculiar striped scarf worn by the pope at mass, and by eastern bishops.
A maniple.

entries.entry: Fan" palm`. Bot Any palm tree having fan-shaped or radiate leaves; as the Chamærops humilis of Southern Europe; the species of Sabal and Thrinax in the West Indies, Florida, etc.; and especially the great talipot tree (Corypha umbraculifera) of Ceylon and Malaya. The leaves of the latter are often eighteen feet long and fourteen wide, and are used for umbrellas, tents, and roofs. When cut up, they are used for books and manuscripts.

entry.def: see fantod.
A variety of the domestic pigeon, so called from the shape of the tail.
Any bird of the Australian genus Rhipidura, in which the tail is spread in the form of a fan during flight. They belong to the family of flycatchers.
the fantail goldfish.
Having an expanded, or fan-shaped, tail; as, the fan-tailed pigeon.

a type of goldfish bred artificially, having a realtively short oval body and a tail with four lobes arrayed somewhat like a folding fan, as though forming a part of the surface of a cone. Called also fantail.

entry.ety: Chinese (of Canton) in an-tan-kun gambling house

sn.def: A Chinese gambling game in which coins or other small objects are placed upon a table, usually under a cup, and the players bet as to what remainder will be left when the sum of the counters is divided by four.
A game with playing cards in which the cards are played in sequences upon the table, the one who first gets rid of his cards being the winner.

entry.ety: It. See Fancy
entry.def: A continuous composition, not divided into what are called movements, or governed by the ordinary rules of musical design, but in which the author's fancy roves unrestricted by set form.

entry.ety: From Fantasy
entry.def: Filled with fancies or imaginations.

entry.ety: See Phantasm Fancy
entry.def: Same as Phantasm.
One whose manners or ideas are fantastic.

entry.ety: F. fantastique, fr. Gr. ����������� able to represent, fr. ��������� to make visible. See Fancy

sn.def: Existing only in imagination; fanciful; imaginary; not real; chimerical.
Having the nature of a phantom; unreal.
Indulging the vagaries of imagination; whimsical; full of absurd fancies; capricious; as, fantastic minds; a fantastic mistress.
Resembling fantasies in irregularity, caprice, or eccentricity; irregular; oddly shaped; grotesque.
sn.q: There at the foot of yonder nodding beech, That wreathes its old fantastic roots so high.
sn.syn: Fanciful; imaginative; ideal; visionary; capricious; chimerical; whimsical; queer. See Fanciful.

entry.def: A person given to fantastic dress, manners, etc.; an eccentric person; a fop.
entry.q: Our fantastics, who, having a fine watch, take all ocasions to draw it out to be seen.

entry.def: Fanciful; unreal; whimsical; capricious; fantastic.
Fantastically.
In a fantastic manner.
entry.q: the letter A, in scarlet, fantastically embroidered with gold thread, upon her bosom.

entry.def: The quality of being fantastic.
The quality of being fantastical; fancifulness; whimsicality.
Fantastically.
Fantasticalness.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: A fantastic.

entries.entry:
Fan"ta*sy n.; pl.Fantasies #. See Fancy
Fancy; imagination; especially, a whimsical or fanciful conception; a vagary of the imagination; whim; caprice; humor. Is not this something more than fantasy ? A thousand fantasies Begin to throng into my memory.
Fantastic designs. Embroidered with fantasies and flourishes of gold thread.

entry.def: To have a fancy for; to be pleased with; to like; to fancy.
entry.q: Which he doth most fantasy.

entry.ety: Cf. Fantod
entry.def: State of worry or excitment; fidget; ill humor.

entry.ety: It., dim. fr. fante child
entry.def: Puppets caused to perform evolutions or dramatic scenes by means of machinery; also, the representations in which they are used.

entry.ety: Cf. Fantigue
entry.def: State of worry or excitement; fidget; fuss; also, indisposition; pet; sulks.

cs.cd: phantom corn.

entry.def: See Phantom.
a common aquatic plant (Cabomba caroliniana) of eastern North America having floating and submerged leaves and white yellow-spotted flowers.
Fuddled.
See Fakir.

entry.ety: See Farrow
entry.def: A young pig, or a litter of pigs.

entry.note: ☞ The distinction between the adjectival and adverbial use of far is sometimes not easily discriminated.
entry.cs: By far by much; by a great difference. Far between with a long distance (of space or time) between; at long intervals. “The examinations are few and far between.” Farrar.
entry.amorph: Farther # and Farthest # are used as the compar. and superl. of far, although they are corruptions arising from confusion with further and furthest. See Further
entry.ety: OE. fer feor, AS. feor; akin to OS. fer, D. ver, OHG. ferro, adv., G. fern a., Icel. fjarri, Dan. fjirn, Sw. fjerran, adv., Goth. faīrra, adv., Gr. ����� beyond, Skr. paras, adv., far, and prob. to L. per through, and E. prefix for-, as in forgive, and also to fare. Cf. Farther Farthest

sn.def: Distant in any direction; not near; remote; mutually separated by a wide space or extent.
sn.q: They said, . . . We be come from a far country.
The nations far and near contend in choice.

sn.def: Remote from purpose; contrary to design or wishes; as, far be it from me to justify cruelty.
Remote in affection or obedience; at a distance, morally or spiritually; t enmity with; alienated.
sn.q: They that are far from thee ahsll perish.

sn.def: Widely different in nature or quality; opposite in character.
sn.q: He was far from ill looking, though he thought himself still farther.

sn.def: The more distant of two; as, the far side (called also off side) of a horse, that is, the right side, or the one opposite to the rider when he mounts.

entry.cs: As far as to the extent, or degree, that. See As far as, under As. Far off. At a great distance, absolutely or relatively. Distant in sympathy or affection; alienated. “But now, in Christ Jesus, ye who some time were far off are made nigh by the blood of Christ.” Eph. ii. 13. Far other different by a great degree; not the same; quite unlike. Pope. Far and near at a distance and close by; throughout a whole region. Far and wide distantly and broadly; comprehensively. “Far and wide his eye commands.” Milton. From far from a great distance; from a remote place.
entry.note: ☞ Far often occurs in self-explaining compounds, such as far-extended, far-reaching, far-spread.

sn.def: To a great extent or distance of space; widely; as, we are separated far from each other.
To a great distance in time from any point; remotely; as, he pushed his researches far into antiquity.
In great part; as, the day is far spent.
In a great proportion; by many degrees; very much; deeply; greatly.
sn.q: Who can find a virtuous woman ? for her price is far above rubies.

entry.def: A going out of the way; a digression.

entry.ety: From Michael Faraday, the English electrician
entry.def: The standard unit of electrical capacity; the capacity of a condenser whose charge, having an electro-motive force of one volt, is equal to the amount of electricity which, with the same electromotive force, passes through one ohm in one second; the capacity, which, charged with one coulomb, gives an electro-motive force of one volt.

entry.ety: From Michael Faraday, the English electrician
entry.def: the quantity of electric charge that, passed though an ionic solution, will cause electrolysis of one equivalent of ions; it is equal to about 96,490 coulombs. The number of univalent metal ions (such as silver in a silver nitrate solution) which would be deposited as free metal by such a current is Avogadro's number, 6.023 x 1023 .

Of or pertaining to Michael Faraday, the distinguished electrician; -- applied especially to induced currents of electricity, as produced by certain forms of inductive apparatus, on account of Faraday's investigations of their laws.
The treatment with faradic or induced currents of electricity for remedial purposes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Faradized; p. pr. & vb. n. Faradizing
entry.def: To stimulate with, or subject to, faradic, or inducted, electric currents.
See Farrand n.
A fabrik made of silk and wool or hair.

entry.ety: F. farandole, Pr. farandoulo
entry.def: A rapid dance in six-eight time in which a large number join hands and dance in various figures, sometimes moving from room to room. It originated in Provence.
entry.q: I have pictured them dancing a sort of farandole.

entry.ety: See Farrand
entry.def: Orderly; comely; respectable.

entry.ety: F. Farcir, L. farcire; akin to Gr. �������� to fence in, stop up. Cf. Force to stuff, Diaphragm Frequent Farcy Farse

sn.def: To stuff with forcemeat; hence, to fill with mingled ingredients; to fill full; to stuff.
sn.q: The first principles of religion should not be farced with school points and private tenets.
His tippet was aye farsed full of knives.

sn.def: To render fat.
sn.q: If thou wouldst farce thy lean ribs.

sn.def: To swell out; to render pompous.
sn.q: Farcing his letter with fustian.

entry.ety: F. farce, from L. farsusalso sometimes farctus), p. p. pf farcire. See Farce v. t.

sn.def: Stuffing, or mixture of viands, like that used on dressing a fowl; forcemeat.
A low style of comedy; a dramatic composition marked by low humor, generally written with little regard to regularity or method, and abounding with ludicrous incidents and expressions.
sn.q: Farce is that in poetry which “grotesque” is in a picture: the persons and action of a farce are all unnatural, and the manners false.

sn.def: Ridiculous or empty show; as, a mere farce .
sn.q: Thefarceof state.

entry.def: Stuffing; forcemeat.
entry.q: They spoil a good dish with . . . unsavory farcements.

entry.def: Pertaining to farce; appropriated to farce; ludicrous; unnatural; unreal.
entry.q: They deny the characters to be farcical, because they are ��tually in in nature.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the disease called farcy. See Farcy n.

entry.ety: Farce+-lite
entry.def: Pudding stone.
Same as Farcy.
Stuffing; forcemeat.

entry.ety: L. farctus, p. p. of farcire. See Farce v. t.
entry.def: Stuffed; filled solid; as, a farctate leaf, stem, or pericarp; -- opposed to tubular or hollow.

entry.note: ☞ Farcy, although more common in horses, is communicable to other animals and to human beings.

cs.cd: a hard, prominent swelling occurring upon the cutaneous surface in farcy, due to the obstruction and inflammation of the lymphatic vessels, and followed by ulceration.

entry.ety: F. farcin; cf. L. farciminum a disease of horses, fr. farcire. See Farce
entry.def: A contagious disease of horses, associated with painful ulcerating enlargements, esp. upon the head and limbs. It is of the same nature as glanders, and is often fatal. Called also farcin, and farcimen.

entry.ety: F., prob. fr. OHG. gifarit, gifarwit p. p. of farwjan to color, tinge, fr. farawa color, G. farbe
entry.def: Paint used on the face.
entry.q: Painted with Frenchfard.

entry.ety: F. farder to paint one's face
entry.def: To paint; -- said esp. of one's face.

entry.ety: F. See Fardel
entry.def: See Dunnage.

entry.ety: OF. fardel, F. fardeau; cf. Sp. fardel fardillo fardo, LL. fardellus; prob. fr. Ar. fard one of the two parts of an object divisible into two, hence, one of the two parts of a camel's load. Cf. Furl
entry.def: A bundle or little pack; hence, a burden.
entry.q: A fardel of never-ending misery and suspense.

entry.def: To make up in fardels.

entry.ety: Of uncertain origin; cf. Fardel
entry.def: The upper stomach of a cow, or other ruminant animal; the rumen.
A farthingale.

entry.ety: See Farthing, and Deal a part
entry.def: The fourth part of an acre of land.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fared; p. pr. & vb. n. Faring
entry.ety: AS. faran to travel, fare; akin to OS., Goth., & OHG. faran to travel, go, D. varen, G. fahren, OFries., Icel., & Sw. fara, Dan. fare, Gr. ����� a way through, ������� a ferry, strait, �������� to convey, ���������� to go, march, ����� beyond, on the other side, ����� to pass through, L. peritus experienced, portus port, Skr. par to bring over. √78. Cf. Chaffer Emporium Far Ferry Ford Peril Port a harbor, Pore n.

sn.def: To go; to pass; to journey; to travel.
sn.q: So on he fares, and to the border comes Of Eden.

sn.def: To be in any state, or pass through any experience, good or bad; to be attended with any circummstances or train of events, fortunate or unfortunate; as, he fared well, or ill.
sn.q: So fares the stag among the enraged hounds.
I bid you most heartily well to fare.
So fared the knight between two foes.

sn.def: To be treated or entertained at table, or with bodily or social comforts; to live.
sn.q: There was a certain rich man which . . . fared sumptuously every day.

sn.def: To happen well, or ill; -- used impersonally; as, we shall see how it will fare with him.
sn.q: So fares it when with truth falsehood contends.

sn.def: To behave; to conduct one's self.
sn.q: She ferdefared] as she would die.

entry.cs:
Bill of fare. See under Bill.
Fare indicatoror Fare register
a device for recording the number of passengers on a street car, etc. Fare wicket. A gate or turnstile at the entrance of toll bridges, exhibition grounds, etc., for registering the number of persons passing it. An opening in the door of a street car for purchasing tickets of the driver or passing fares to the conductor. Knight.
entry.ety: AS. faru journey, fr. faran. See Fare v.

sn.def: A journey; a passage.
sn.q: That nought might stay his fare.

sn.def: The price of passage or going; the sum paid or due for conveying a person by land or water; as, the fare for crossing a river; the fare in a coach or by railway.
Ado; bustle; business.
sn.q: The warder chid and made fare.

sn.def: Condition or state of things; fortune; hap; cheer.
sn.q: What fare? what news abroad ?

sn.def: Food; provisions for the table; entertainment; as, coarse fare; delicious fare.
sn.q: Philosophicfare.

sn.def: The person or persons conveyed in a vehicle; as, a full fare of passengers.
The catch of fish on a fishing vessel.

entry.def: p. p. of Fare v. i.
state of perfection; the utmost degree; as, they polished the furniture to a fare-thee-well .

entry.note: ☞ The primary accent is sometimes placed on the first syllable, especially in poetry.
entry.ety: Farethou, you) + well
entry.def: Go well; good-by; adieu; -- originally applied to a person departing, but by custom now applied both to those who depart and those who remain. It is often separated by the pronoun; as, fare you well ; and is sometimes used as an expression of separation only; as, farewell the year; farewell, ye sweet groves; that is, I bid you farewell.
entry.q: So farewell hope, and with hope, farewell fear.
Fare thee well! and if forever, Still forever fare thee well.

sn.def: A wish of happiness or welfare at parting; the parting compliment; a good-by; adieu.
Act of departure; leave-taking; a last look at, or reference to something.
sn.q: And takes her farewell of the glorious sun.
Before I take my farewell of the subject.

cs.cd: the Millstone grit; -- so called because no coal is found worth working below this stratum. It is used for hearths of furnaces, having power to resist intense heat.

entry.def: Parting; valedictory; final; as, a farewell discourse; his farewell bow.
entry.q: Leans in his spear to take his farewell view.

entry.ety: Far + fet p. p. of Fette
entry.def: Farfetched.
entry.q: York with his farfet policy.

entry.ety: Far + fetch
entry.def: To bring from far; to seek out studiously.
entry.q: To farfetch the name of Tartar from a Hebrew word.

entry.def: Anything brought from far, or brought about with studious care; a deep strategem.
entry.q: Politicfarfetches.

sn.def: Brought from far, or from a remote place.
sn.q: Every remedy contained a multitude of farfetched and heterogeneous ingredients.

sn.def: Studiously sought; not easily or naturally deduced or introduced; forced; strained; hence, implausible or improbable.

entry.def: widely spread or distributed; as, the far-flung corners of the Empire.

entry.ety: L., meal, flour, fr. far a sort of grain, spelt; akin to E. barley

sn.def: A fine flour or meal made from cereal grains or from the starch or fecula of vegetables, extracted by various processes, and used in cookery.
Pollen.

entry.ety: L. farinaceus

sn.def: Consisting or made of meal or flour; as, a farinaceous diet.
Yielding farina or flour; as, ffarinaceous seeds.
Like meal; mealy; pertaining to meal; as, a farinaceous taste, smell, or appearance.

entry.ety: L. farinosus: cf. F. farineux

sn.def: Yielding farina; as, farinose substances.
Covered with a sort of white, mealy powder, as the leaves of some poplars, and the body of certain insects; mealy.

entry.def: Same as Furl.

entry.ety: OE. ferlish wonder, as adj., strange, sudden, fearful, AS. fǣrlīc sudden. See Fear
entry.def: An unusual or unexpected thing; a wonder. See Fearly.

entry.note: ☞ In English the ideas of a lease, a term, and a rent, continue to be in a great degree inseparable, even from the popular meaning of a farm, as they are entirely so from the legal sense.
entry.ety: OE. ferme rent, lease, F. ferme, LL. firma, fr. L. firmus firm, fast, firmare to make firm or fast. See Firm a. & n.

sn.def: The rent of land, -- originally paid by reservation of part of its products.
The term or tenure of a lease of land for cultivation; a leasehold.
sn.q: It is great willfulness in landlords to make any longer farms to their tenants.

sn.def: The land held under lease and by payment of rent for the purpose of cultivation.
Any tract of land devoted to agricultural purposes, under the management of a tenant or the owner.
A district of country leased (or farmed) out for the collection of the revenues of government.
sn.q: The province was devided into twelve farms.

sn.def: A lease of the imposts on particular goods; as, the sugar farm, the silk farm .
sn.q: Whereas G. H. held the farm of sugars upon a rent of 10,000 marks per annum.

cs.cd: to lease on rent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Farmed; p. pr. & vb. n. Farming

sn.def: To lease or let for an equivalent, as land for a rent; to yield the use of to proceeds.
sn.q: We are enforced to farm our royal realm.

sn.def: To give up to another, as an estate, a business, the revenue, etc., on condition of receiving in return a percentage of what it yields; as, to farm the taxes.
sn.q: To farm their subjects and their duties toward these.

sn.def: To take at a certain rent or rate.
To devote (land) to agriculture; to cultivate, as land; to till, as a farm.

entry.def: To engage in the business of tilling the soil; to labor as a farmer.
Capable of being farmed.

entries.entry:
Farm"er
Farmer-general F. fermier-general
one to whom the right of levying certain taxes, in a particular district, was farmed out, under the former French monarchy, for a given sum paid down. Farmers' satin a light material of cotton and worsted, used for coat linings. McElrath. The king's farmer O. Eng. Law one to whom the collection of a royal revenue was farmed out. Burrill.
färm"ẽr n. Cf. F. fermier
One who farms; as: One who hires and cultivates a farm; a cultivator of leased ground; a tenant. Smart. One who is devoted to the tillage of the soil; one who cultivates a farm; an agriculturist; a husbandman. One who takes taxes, customs, excise, or other duties, to collect, either paying a fixed annuual rent for the privilege; as, a farmer of the revenues. Mining The lord of the field, or one who farms the lot and cope of the crown.

entry.def: A woman who farms.
a woman working on a farm; a farmeress.
Skill in farming.
The buildings and yards necessary for the business of a farm; a homestead.
A dwelling house on a farm; a farmer's residence.
Pertaining to agriculture; devoted to, adapted to, or engaged in, farming; as, farming tools; farming land; a farming community.
The business of cultivating land.
a rural area where farming is practiced; land actually under cultivation or capable of supporting crops.
Most distant; farthest.
entry.q: A spacious cave within its farmost part.

entry.def: a farm together with its buildings.
A farm with the building upon it; a homestead on a farm.
entry.q: With its pleasant groves and farmsteads.

entry.def: A farmstead.
The yard or inclosure attached to a barn, or the space inclosed by the farm buildings.

entry.ety: From Far a.
entry.def: The state of being far off; distance; remoteness.

cs.cd: the capital which the proprietor of a faro table ventures in the game; also, the place where a game of faro is played.

entry.ety: Said to be so called because the Egyptian king Pharaoh was formerly represented upon one of the cards
entry.def: A gambling game at cards, in which all the other players play against the dealer or banker, staking their money upon the order in which the cards will lie and be dealt from the pack.
An inhabitant, or, collectively, inhabitants, of the Faroe islands.

sn.def: Remote; as, the far-off distance; troops landing on far-off shores. Cf. Far-off, under Far, adv.
remote in time; as, far-off happier times.

entry.def: strikingly unconventional.

entry.ety: See Farrago
entry.def: Formed of various materials; mixed; as, a farraginous mountain.
entry.q: A farraginous concurrence of all conditions, tempers, sexes, and ages.

entry.ety: L. farrago -aginis, mixed fodder for cattle, mash, medley, fr. far a sort of grain. See Farina
entry.def: A mass composed of various materials confusedly mixed; a medley; a mixture.
entry.q: A confounded farrago of doubts, fears, hopes, wishes, and all the flimsy furniture of a country miss's brain.

entry.ety: OE. farand beautiful; cf. Gael. farranta neat, stout, stately; or perh. akin to E. fare
entry.def: Manner; custom; fashion; humor.
having a wide range or effect; as, far-reachingor extensive) forests; a far-reaching reform.

entry.ety: L. farreatio
entry.def: Same as Confarreation.

entry.ety: OE. farrour ferrer, OF. ferreor ferrier, LL. Ferrator ferrarius equorum, from ferrare to shoe a horse, ferrum a horseshoe, fr. L. ferrum iron. Cf. Ferreous

sn.def: A shoer of horses; a veterinary surgeon.

entry.def: To practice as a farrier; to carry on the trade of a farrier.

sn.def: The art of shoeing horses.
The art of preventing, curing, or mitigating diseases of horses and cattle; the veterinary art.
The place where a smith shoes horses.

entry.def: extremely conservative politically.

entry.ety: AS. fearh a little pig; a akin to OHG. farh farah, pig, dim. farheli little pig, G. fercel, D. varken pig, Lith. parszas OIr. orc, L. porcus, Gr. po`rkos. Cf. Pork
entry.def: A litter of pigs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Farrowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Farrowing
entry.def: To bring forth (young); -- said only of swine.

entry.note: ☞ If a cow has had a calf, but fails in a subsequent year, she is said to be farrow, or to go farrow.
entry.ety: Cf. Scot. ferry cow a cow that is not with calf, D. vaarkoe vaars, heifer, G. färse, AS. fearr bull, G. farre. Cf. Heifer
entry.def: Not producing young in a given season or year; -- said only of cows.
A farrow.

entry.ety: See Farce n.
entry.def: An addition to, or a paraphrase of, some part of the Latin service in the vernacular; -- common in English before the Reformation.

sn.def: Able to see to a great distance; farsighted.
Having foresight as regards the future.
Seeing to great distance; hence, of good judgment regarding the remote effects of actions; sagacious.
Hypermetropic.
Quality of bbeing farsighted.
Hypermetropia.

entry.def: Stretched beyond ordinary limits.

entry.ety: For farrer, OE. ferrer, compar. of far; confused with further. Cf. Farthest

sn.def: More remote; more distant than something else.
Tending to a greater distance; beyond a certain point; additional; further.
sn.q: Before our farther way the fates allow.
Let me add a farther Truth.
Some farther change awaits us.

cs.cd: used elliptically for) go no farther; say no more, etc.
cs.q: It will be dangerous to go on. No farther !

sn.def: At or to a greater distance; more remotely; beyond; as, let us rest with what we have, without looking farther .
Moreover; by way of progress in treating a subject; as, farther, let us consider the probable event.

entry.def: To help onward. R See Further.
See Furtherance.
See Furthermore.
Most remote; farthest.

entry.ety: See Farther and cf. Furthest
entry.def: Most distant or remote; as, the farthest degree. See Furthest.
At or to the greatest distance. See Furthest.

entry.ety: OE. furthing, AS. feórðung, fr. feórða fourth, feór feówer, four. See Four

sn.def: The fourth of a penny; a small copper coin of Great Britain, being a cent in United States currency.
A very small quantity or value.
sn.q: In her cup was no farthing seen of grease.

sn.def: A division of land.
sn.q: Thirty acres make a farthing land; nine farthings a Cornish acre; and four Cornish acres a knight's fee.

entry.ety: OE. vardingale fardingale, fr. OF. vertugale verdugade, F. vertugade vertugadin, from Sp. verdugado, being named from its hoops, fr. verdugo a young shoot of tree, fr. verde green, fr. L. viridis. See Verdant
entry.def: A hoop skirt or hoop petticoat, or other light, elastic material, used to extend the petticoat.
entry.q: We'll revel it as bravely as the best, . . . With ruffs and cuffs, and farthingales and things.

entry.ety: L., pl. of fascis bundle; cf. fascia a band, and Gr. fa`kelos a bundle
entry.def: A bundle of rods, having among them an ax with the blade projecting, borne before the Roman magistrates as a badge of their authority.

A wire basket on the end of a rod to carry glass bottles, etc., to the annealing furnace; also, an iron rod to be thrust into the mouths of bottles, and used for the same purpose; -- called also pontee and punty.

entries.entry:
‖Fas"ci*a n.; pl.Fasciæ #. L., a band: cf. It. fascia. See Fasces, and cf. Fess
A band, sash, or fillet; especially, in surgery, a bandage or roller.
Arch A flat member of an order or building, like a flat band or broad fillet; especially, one of the three bands which make up the architrave, in the Ionic order. See Illust. of Column.
Anat The layer of loose tissue, often containing fat, immediately beneath the skin; the stronger layer of connective tissue covering and investing all muscles; an aponeurosis.
Zoöl A broad well-defined band of color.

sn.def: Pertaining to the fasces.
Relating to a fascia.

entry.ety: L. fasciatus, p. p. of fasciare to envelop with bands, fr. fascia band. See Fasces

sn.def: Bound with a fillet, sash, or bandage.

sd.def: Banded or compacted together.
Flattened and laterally widened, as are often the stems of the garden cockscomb.

sn.def: Broadly banded with color.

entry.def: The act or manner of binding up; bandage; also, the condition of being fasciated.

entry.ety: L. fasciculus, dim. of fascis. See Fasces

sn.def: A small bundle or collection; a compact cluster; as, a fascicle of fibers; a fascicle of flowers or roots.
One of the divisions of a book published in parts; fasciculus.

entry.def: Growing in a bundle, tuft, or close cluster; as, the fascicled leaves of the pine or larch; the fascicled roots of the dahlia; fascicled muscle fibers; fascicled tufts of hair.
Pertaining to a fascicle; fascicled; as, a fascicular root.
In a fascicled manner.
Grouped in a fascicle; fascicled.

entry.ety: See Fascicle
entry.def: A small bunch or bundle; a fascicle; as, a fascicule of fibers, hairs, or spines.

entries.entry:
‖Fas*cic"u*lus n.; pl.Fasciculi #. L. See Fascicle
A little bundle; a fascicle.
A division of a book.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fascinated p. pr. & vb. n.. Fascinating
entry.ety: L. fascinare; cf. Gr. ���������� to slander, bewitch

sn.def: To influence in an uncontrollable manner; to operate on by some powerful or irresistible charm; to bewitch; to enchant.
sn.q: It has been almost universally believed that . . . serpents can stupefy and fascinate the prey which they are desirous to obtain.

sn.def: To excite and allure irresistibly or powerfully; to charm; to captivate, as by physical or mental charms.
sn.q: There be none of the passions that have been noted to fascinate or bewitch but love and envy.
sn.syn: To charm; enrapture; captivate; enchant; bewitch; attract.

sn.def: having the attention fixed by a sense of wonder.
sn.syn: hypnotized, hypnotised, mesmerized, mesmerised, spellbound, transfixed.

sn.def: intensely interested in or attracted by; as, I'm very interested in birds; in fact I'm fascinated by them.
capable of holding the attention; as, a fascinating story.
capturing interest as if by a spell; as, a fascinating woman.

entry.ety: L. fascinatio; cf. F. fascination

sn.def: The act of fascinating, bewitching, or enchanting; enchantment; witchcraft; the exercise of a powerful or irresistible influence on the affections or passions; unseen, inexplicable influence.
sn.q: The Turks hang old rags . . . upon their fairest horses, and other goodly creatures, to secure them against fascination.

sn.def: The state or condition of being fascinated.
That which fascinates; a charm; a spell.
sn.q: There is a certain bewitchery or fascination in words.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. fascina a bundle of sticks, fr. fascis. See Fasces
entry.def: A cylindrical bundle of small sticks of wood, bound together, used in raising batteries, filling ditches, strengthening ramparts, and making parapets; also in revetments for river banks, and in mats for dams, jetties, etc.

entry.ety: L. fascinum witchcraft, akin to fascinare. See Fascinate
entry.def: Caused or acting by witchcraft.
entry.q: Fascinousdiseases.

entries.entry:
‖Fas*ci"o*la n.;pl.Fasciolæ #. See Fasciole
Anat A band of gray matter bordering the fimbria in the brain; the dentate convolution.

entry.ety: L. fasciola a little bandage. See Fascia
entry.def: A band of minute tubercles, bearing modified spines, on the shells of spatangoid sea urchins. See Spatangoidea.

sn.def: a political theory advocating an authoritarian hierarchical government; -- opposed to democracy and liberalism.

an authoritarian system of government under absolute control of a single dictator, allowing no political opposition, forcibly suppressing dissent, and rigidly controlling most industrial and economic activities. Such regimes usually try to achieve popularity by a strongly nationalistic appeal, often mixed with racism.
Specifically, the Fascist movement led by Benito Mussolini in Italy from 1922 to 1943.
broadly, a tendency toward or support of a strongly authoritarian or dictatorial control of government or other organizations; -- often used pejoratively in this sense.

entry.def: an adherent of fascism or similar right-wing authoritarian views.

sn.def: of or pertaining to fascism; resembling fascism; as, fascist propaganda.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fashed; p. pr. & vb. n. Fashing
entry.ety: OF. faschier, F. f�cher, to anger, vex; cf. Pr. fasticar fastigar, fr. L. fastidium dilike. See Fastidious
entry.def: To vex; to tease; to trouble.
Vexation; anxiety; care.
entry.q: Without further fash on my part.

cs.cd: to a certain extent; of a sort; sort of.
one of the timbers which terminate the transom, and define the shape of the stern.
a pictorial design showing the prevailing style or a new style of dress.

entry.ety: OE. fasoun facioun, shape, manner, F. facon, orig., a making, fr. L. factio a making, fr. facere to make. See Fact Feat, and cf. Faction

sn.def: The make or form of anything; the style, shape, appearance, or mode of structure; pattern, model; as, the fashion of the ark, of a coat, of a house, of an altar, etc.; workmanship; execution.
sn.q: The fashion of his countenance was altered.
I do not like the fashion of your garments.

sn.def: The prevailing mode or style, especially of dress; custom or conventional usage in respect of dress, behavior, etiquette, etc.; particularly, the mode or style usual among persons of good breeding; as, to dress, dance, sing, ride, etc., in the fashion .
sn.q: The innocent diversions in fashion.
As now existing, fashion is a form of social regulation analogous to constitutional government as a form of political regulation.

sn.def: Polite, fashionable, or genteel life; social position; good breeding; as, men of fashion .
Mode of action; method of conduct; manner; custom; sort; way.
sn.q: After his sourfashion.

cs.cd: a needle used for widening or narrowing the work and thus shaping it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fashioned; p. pr. & vb. n. Fashioning
entry.ety: Cf. F. faconner

sn.def: To form; to give shape or figure to; to mold.
sn.q: Here the loud hammer fashions female toys.
Ingenious art . . . Steps forth to fashion and refine the age.

sn.def: To fit; to adapt; to accommodate; -- with to.
sn.q: Laws ought to be fashioned to the manners and conditions of the people.

sn.def: To make according to the rule prescribed by custom.
sn.q: Fashioned plate sells for more than its weight.

sn.def: To forge or counterfeit.
Conforming to the fashion or established mode; according with the prevailing form or style; as, a fashionable dress.
Established or favored by custom or use; current; prevailing at a particular time; as, the fashionable philosophy; fashionable opinions.
Observant of the fashion or customary mode; dressing or behaving according to the prevailing fashion; as, a fashionable man.
Genteel; well-bred; as, fashionable society.
sn.q: Time is like a fashionable host That slightly shakes his parting guest by the hand.

entry.def: A person who conforms to the fashions; -- used chiefly in the plural.
State of being fashionable.
In a fashionable manner.
Having a certain style or fashion; as, old-fashioned; new-fashioned .
One who fashions, forms, ar gives shape to anything.
entry.q: The fashioner had accomplished his task, and the dresses were brought home.

entry.def: An obsequious follower of the modes and fashions.
Having no fashion.
One who studies the fashions; a fop; a dandy.
Behaving like a fashion-monger.
A variety of pyroxene, from the valley of Fassa, in the Tyrol.

cs.cd: a fast day; a day of fasting.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Fasting
entry.ety: AS. fæstan; akin to D. vasten, OHG. fastēn, G. fasten, Icel. & Sw. fasta, Dan. faste, Goth. fastan to keep, observe, fast, and prob. to E. fast firm

sn.def: To abstain from food; to omit to take nourishment in whole or in part; to go hungry.
sn.q: Fasting he went to sleep, and fasting waked.

sn.def: To practice abstinence as a religious exercise or duty; to abstain from food voluntarily for a time, for the mortification of the body or appetites, or as a token of grief, or humiliation and penitence.
sn.q: Thou didst fast and weep for the child.

cs.cd: a day appointed for fasting, humiliation, and religious offices as a means of invoking the favor of God.
to put an end to a period of abstinence by taking food; especially, to take one's morning meal; to breakfast.

entry.ety: OE. faste fast; cf. AS. fæsten, OHG. fasta, G. faste. See Fast v. i.
