sn.def: A form of seam joining two pieces of cloth, the edges being folded together and the stitches taken through both thicknesses.
The end of a web, formed by the last thread of the weft.

entry.def: Fit to be felled.

entries.entry: ‖Fel"lah n.; pl. Ar. Fellahin #, E. Fellahs #. Ar A peasant or cultivator of the soil among the Egyptians, Syrians, etc.

entry.def: a form of sexual activity between two persons in which the penis of one is stimulated by the other's mouth, especially until orgasm is achieved. It is a form of oral sex. Compare cunnilingus. The act is also called by the slang term blow job.
One who, or that which, fells, knocks or cuts down; a machine for felling trees.
An appliance to a sewing machine for felling a seam.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. fealafor, and E. fieldfare
entry.def: The fieldfare.

entry.ety: L. fellifuus; fel gall + fluere to flow
entry.def: Flowing with gall.

entry.ety: L. fel fellis, gall
entry.def: Of, relating to, or derived from, bile or gall; as, fellinic acid.
A dealer in fells or sheepskins, who separates the wool from the pelts.

entry.ety: See Fell cruel
entry.def: The quality or state of being fell or cruel; fierce barbarity.
See Felly.
Variant of Felon.
entry.q: Those two were foes the fellonest on ground.

entry.note: ☞ Commonly used of men, but sometimes of women.

☞ Fellow is often used in compound words, or adjectively, signifying associate companion, or sometimes equal. Usually, such compounds or phrases are self-explanatory; as, fellow-citizen, or fellow citizen; fellow-student, or fellow student; fellow-workman, or fellow workman; fellow-mortal, or fellow mortal; fellow-sufferer; bedfellow; playfellow; workfellow.
entry.ety: OE. felawe felaghe, Icel. fēlagi, fr. fēlag companionship, prop., a laying together of property; fē property + lag a laying, pl. lög law, akin to liggja to lie. See Fee, and Law Lie to be low

sn.def: A companion; a comrade; an associate; a partner; a sharer.
sn.q: The fellows of his crime.
We are fellows still, Serving alike in sorrow.
That enormous engine was flanked by two fellows almost of equal magnitude.

sn.def: A man without good breeding or worth; an ignoble or mean man.
sn.q: Worth makes the man, and want of it, the fellow.

sn.def: An equal in power, rank, character, etc.
sn.q: It is impossible that ever Rome Should breed thy fellow.

sn.def: One of a pair, or of two things used together or suited to each other; a mate; the male.
sn.q: When they be but heifers of one year, . . . they are let go to the fellow and breed.
This was my glove; here is the fellow of it.

sn.def: A person; an individual.
sn.q: She seemed to be a good sort of fellow.

sn.def: In the English universities, a scholar who is appointed to a foundation called a fellowship, which gives a title to certain perquisites and privileges.
In an American college or university, a member of the corporation which manages its business interests; also, a graduate appointed to a fellowship, who receives the income of the foundation.
A member of a literary or scientific society; as, a Fellow of the Royal Society.
sn.q: Were the great duke himself here, and would lift up My head to fellow pomp amongst his nobles.

entry.def: To suit with; to pair with; to match.
A student at Cambridge University, England, who commons, or dines, at the Fellow's table.
One of the same race or kind; one made by the same Creator.
entry.q: Reason, by which we are raised above our fellow-creatures, the brutes.

entry.def: To share through sympathy; to participate in.

sn.def: Sympathy; a like feeling.
Joint interest.

entry.def: Without fellow or equal; peerless.
entry.q: Whose well-built walls are rare and fellowless.

entry.def: Like a companion; companionable; on equal terms; sympathetic.
Fellowlike.

cs.cd: companionableness; the spirit and disposition befitting comrades.
cs.q: There's neither honesty, manhood, nor good fellowship in thee.

entry.ety: Fellow + -ship

sn.def: The state or relation of being or associate.
Companionship of persons on equal and friendly terms; frequent and familiar intercourse.
sn.q: In a great town, friends are scattered, so that there is not that fellowship which is in less neighborhods.
Men are made for society and mutual fellowship.

entry.sn:
A state of being together; companionship; partnership; association; hence, confederation; joint interest. The great contention of the sea and skies Parted our fellowship.
Fellowship in pain divides not smart. Milton.
Fellowship in woe doth woe assuage. Shak. The goodliest fellowship of famous knights, Whereof this world holds record.

sn.def: Those associated with one, as in a family, or a society; a company.
sn.q: The sorrow of Noah with his fellowship.
With that a joyous fellowship issued Of minstrels.

sn.def: A foundation for the maintenance, on certain conditions, of a scholar called a fellow, who usually resides at the university.
The rule for dividing profit and loss among partners; -- called also partnership, company, and distributive proportion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fellowshiped; p. pr. & vb. n.. Fellowshiping
entry.def: To acknowledge as of good standing, or in communion according to standards of faith and practice; to admit to Christian fellowship.
In a fell or cruel manner; fiercely; barbarously; savagely.

entries.entry:
Fel"ly n.; pl.Fellies. OE. feli felwe felow, AS. felg felge; akin to D. velg, G. felge, OHG. felga felly (also, a harrow, but prob. a different word), Dan. felge
The exterior wooden rim, or a segment of the rim, of a wheel, supported by the spokes.
felloe
Break all the spokes and fellies from her wheel.

‖Fe"lo-de-se` n.; pl.Felos-de-se #. LL. felo, E. felon + de of, concerning + se self Law One who deliberately puts an end to his own existence, or loses his life while engaged in the commission of an unlawful or malicious act; a suicide.

entry.ety: OE., adj., cruel, n., villain, ruffian, traitor, whitlow, F. félon traitor, in OF. also, villain, fr. LL. felo. See Fell, a.

sn.def: A person who has committed a felony.
A person guilty or capable of heinous crime.
A kind of whitlow; a painful imflammation of the periosteum of a finger, usually of the last joint.

entry.def: Characteristic of a felon; malignant; fierce; malicious; cruel; traitorous; disloyal.
entry.q: Vain shows of love to vail his felon hate.

entry.def: Having the quality of felony; malignant; malicious; villainous; traitorous; perfidious; in a legal sense, done with intent to commit a crime; as, felonious homicide.
entry.q: O thievish Night, Why should'st thou, but for some felonious end, In thy dark lantern thus close up the stars?

entry.ety: Cf. OF. feloneus. Cf. Felonious
entry.def: Wicked; felonious.
A body of felons; specifically, the convict population of a penal colony.
The bittersweet nightshade (Solanum Dulcamara). See Bittersweet.

entries.entry:
Fel"o*ny ☞ Forfeiture for crime having been generally abolished in the United States, the term felony, in American law, has lost this point of distinction; and its meaning, where not fixed by statute, is somewhat vague and undefined; generally, however, it is used to denote an offense of a high grade, punishable either capitally or by a term of imprisonment. In Massachusetts, by statute, any crime punishable by death or imprisonment in the state prison, and no other, is a felony; so in New York. the tendency now is to obliterate the distinction between felonies and misdemeanors; and this has been done partially in England, and completely in some of the States of the Union. The distinction is purely arbitrary, and its entire abolition is only a question of time. ☞ There is no lawyer who would undertake to tell what a felony is, otherwise than by enumerating the various kinds of offenses which are so called. originally, the word felony had a meaning: it denoted all offenses the penalty of which included forfeiture of goods; but subsequent acts of Parliament have declared various offenses to be felonies, without enjoining that penalty, and have taken away the penalty from others, which continue, nevertheless, to be called felonies, insomuch that the acts so called have now no property whatever in common, save that of being unlawful and purnishable.
To compound a felony. See under Compound v. t.
n.; pl.Felonies #. OE. felonie cruelty, OF. felonie, F. félonie treachery, malice. See Felon n.
Feudal Law An act on the part of the vassal which cost him his fee by forfeiture.
O.Eng.Law An offense which occasions a total forfeiture either lands or goods, or both, at the common law, and to which capital or other punishment may be added, according to the degree of guilt.
A heinous crime; especially, a crime punishable by death or imprisonment.

entry.ety: Cf. Feldspar
entry.def: A finegrained rock, flintlike in fracture, consisting essentially of orthoclase feldspar with occasional grains of quartz.
relating to, composed of, or containing, felsite.
See Feldspar.
See Feldspathic.

entry.ety: From G. feldstein, in analogy with E. felspar
entry.def: See Felsite.
imp. & p. p. or a. from Feel.

cs.cd: the grain of timber which is transverse to the annular rings or plates; the direction of the medullary rays in oak and some other timber.

entry.ety: AS. felt; akin to D. vilt, G. filz, and possibly to Gr. � hair or wool wrought into felt, L. pilus hair, pileus a felt cap or hat

sn.def: A cloth or stuff made of matted fibers of wool, or wool and fur, fulled or wrought into a compact substance by rolling and pressure, with lees or size, without spinning or weaving.
sn.q: It were a delicate stratagem to shoe A troop of horse with felt.

sn.def: A hat made of felt.
A skin or hide; a fell; a pelt.
sn.q: To know whether sheep are sound or not, see that the felt be loose.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Felted; p. pr. & vb. n. Felting

sn.def: To make into felt, or a feltike substance; to cause to adhere and mat together.
To cover with, or as with, felt; as, to felt the cylinder of a steam engine.

entry.def: To clot or mat together like felt.
entry.q: His feltered locks that on his bosom fell.

sn.def: The material of which felt is made; also, felted cloth; also, the process by which it is made.
The act of splitting timber by the felt grain.

entry.ety: OF. feltre
entry.def: See Felt n.

entry.note: Sometimes it is constructed so that the helm may be used at either end.
entry.ety: It. felucacf. Sp. faluca, Pg. falua), fr. Ar. fulk ship, or harrāqah a sort of ship
entry.def: A small, swift-sailing vessel, propelled by oars and lateen sails, -- once common in the Mediterranean.

entry.ety: Probably a corruption of fieldwort
entry.def: A European herb (Swertia perennis) of the Gentian family.

entry.ety: OE. femel femal, F. femelle, fr. L. femella, dim. of femina woman. See Feminine

sn.def: An individual of the sex which conceives and brings forth young, or (in a wider sense) which has an ovary and produces ova.
sn.q: The male and female of each living thing.

sn.def: A plant which produces only that kind of reproductive organs which are capable of developing into fruit after impregnation or fertilization; a pistillate plant.

cs.cd: double rhymes, or rhymes (called in French feminine rhymes because they end in e weak, or feminine) in which two syllables, an accented and an unaccented one, correspond at the end of each line.
cs.note: ☞ A rhyme, in which the final syllables only agree (strain complain) is called a male rhyme; one in which the two final syllables of each verse agree, the last being short (motion ocean), is called female.
cs.cd: the spiral-threaded cavity into which another, or male, screw turns.
a common species of fern with large decompound fronds (Asplenium Filixfæmina), growing in many countries; lady fern.
cs.note: ☞ The names male fern and female fern were anciently given to two common ferns; but it is now understood that neither has any sexual character.

entry.usage: We apply female to the sex or individual, as opposed to male; also, to the distinctive belongings of women; as, female dress, female form, female character, etc.; feminine, to things appropriate to, or affected by, women; as, feminine studies, employments, accomplishments, etc. “Female applies to sex rather than gender, and is a physiological rather than a grammatical term. Feminine applies to gender rather than sex, and is grammatical rather than physiological.”

sn.def: Belonging to the sex which conceives and gives birth to young, or (in a wider sense) which produces ova; not male.
sn.q: As patient as the female dove When that her golden couplets are disclosed.

sn.def: Belonging to an individual of the female sex; characteristic of woman; feminine; as, female tenderness.
sn.q: Femaleusurpation.
To the generous decision of a female mind, we owe the discovery of America.

sn.def: Having pistils and no stamens; pistillate; or, in cryptogamous plants, capable of receiving fertilization.

entry.def: A gallant.
entry.q: Courting her smoothly like a femalist.

entry.def: To make, or to describe as, female or feminine.

cs.cd: a married woman. See Covert a., 3.
a single or unmarried woman; a woman who has never been married, or who has been divorced, or whose husband is dead.
a married woman, who, by the custom of London, engages in business on her own account, inpendently of her husband.

entry.ety: OF. feme, F. femme
entry.def: A woman.
See Femerell.

entry.ety: OF. fumeraille part of a chimney. See Fume
entry.def: A lantern, or louver covering, placed on a roof, for ventilation or escape of smoke.
Feminine.
Feminity.

entry.ety: L. feminatus effeminate
entry.def: Feminine.

entry.ety: L. femineus womanly
entry.def: Womanliness; femininity.

entry.cs: Feminine rhyme. Pros See Female rhyme, under Female a.
entry.ety: L. femininus, fr. femina woman; prob. akin to L. fetus, or to Gr. qh^sqai to suck, qh^sai to suckle, Skr. dhā to suck; cf. AS. fǣmme woman, maid: cf. F. féminin. See Fetus

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a woman, or to women; characteristic of a woman; womanish; womanly.
sn.q: Her letters are remarkably deficient in feminine ease and grace.

sn.def: Having the qualities of a woman; becoming or appropriate to the female sex; as, in a good sense, modest, graceful, affectionate, confiding; or, in a bad sense, weak, nerveless, timid, pleasure-loving, effeminate.
sn.q: Her heavenly form Angelic, but more soft and feminine.
Ninus being esteemed no man of war at all, but altogether feminine, and subject to ease and delicacy.

sn.def: A woman.
sn.q: They guide the feminines toward the palace.

sn.def: Any one of those words which are the appellations of females, or which have the terminations usually found in such words; as, actress songstress abbess executrix.
sn.q: There are but few true feminines in English.

entry.def: In a feminine manner.
The quality of being feminine; womanliness; womanishness.

sn.def: The quality or nature of the female sex; womanliness.
The female form.
sn.q: O serpent under femininitee.

entry.def: Womanliness; femininity.
entry.q: Trained up in truefeminity.

entry.def: The act of feminizing, or the state of being feminized.

entry.ety: Cf. F. féminiser

entry.ety: OF. femenie feminie, the female sex, realm of women

entry.q: The reign offeminye.

entry.cs: Femme de chambre. F A lady's maid; a chambermaid.

entry.def: Pertaining to the femur or thigh; as, the femoral artery.

entry.def: The thigh bone; same as femur.

entries.entry: ‖Fe"mur fē"mŭr n.; pl.Femora fĕm"�*rȧ. L. thigh Anat The thigh bone; -- it is the longest and thickest bone of the human skeleton, which extends from the pelvis to the knee. The proximal segment of the hind limb containing the thigh bone; the thigh. See Coxa.

entry.note: ☞ Fen is used adjectively with the sense of belonging to, or of the nature of a fen or fens.

cs.cd: a boat of light draught used in marshes.
a wild duck inhabiting fens; the shoveler.
any water fowl that frequent fens.
the graylag goose of Europe.
swamp land.

entry.ety: AS. fen fenn, marsh, mud, dirt; akin to D. veen, OFries. fenne fene, OHG. fenna, G. fenn, Icel. fen, Goth. fani mud
entry.def: Low land overflowed, or covered wholly or partially with water, but producing sedge, coarse grasses, or other aquatic plants; boggy land; moor; marsh.
entry.q: 'Mid reedy fens wide spread.

entry.note: ☞ In England a hedge, ditch, or wall, as well as a structure of boards, palings, or rails, is called a fence.
entry.cs: Fence month Forest Law the month in which female deer are fawning, when hunting is prohibited. Bullokar. Fence roof a covering for defense. “They fitted their shields close to one another in manner of a fence roof.” Holland. Fence time the breeding time of fish or game, when they should not be killed. Rail fence a fence made of rails, sometimes supported by posts. Ring fence a fence which encircles a large area, or a whole estate, within one inclosure. Worm fence a zigzag fence composed of rails crossing one another at their ends; -- called also snake fence, or Virginia rail fence. To be on the fence to be undecided or uncommitted in respect to two opposing parties or policies. Colloq
entry.ety: Abbrev. from defence

sn.def: That which fends off attack or danger; a defense; a protection; a cover; security; shield.
sn.q: Let us be backed with God and with the seas, Which he hath given for fence impregnable.
A fence betwixt us and the victor's wrath.

sn.def: An inclosure about a field or other space, or about any object; especially, an inclosing structure of wood, iron, or other material, intended to prevent intrusion from without or straying from within.
sn.q: Leaps o'er the fence with ease into the fold.

sn.def: A projection on the bolt, which passes through the tumbler gates in locking and unlocking.
Self-defense by the use of the sword; the art and practice of fencing and sword play; hence, skill in debate and repartee. See Fencing.
sn.q: Enjoy your dear wit, and gay rhetoric, That hath so well been taught her dazzing fence.
Of dauntless courage and consummate skill in fence.

sn.def: A receiver of stolen goods, or a place where they are received.

cs.cd: to make a solemn address to those who present themselves to commune at the Lord's supper, on the feelings appropriate to the service, in order to hinder, so far as possible, those who are unworthy from approaching the table.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fenced fĕnst; p. pr. & vb. n. Fencing fĕn"sĭng

sn.def: To fend off danger from; to give security to; to protect; to guard.
sn.q: To fence my ear against thy sorceries.

sn.def: To inclose with a fence or other protection; to secure by an inclosure.
sn.q: O thou wall! . . . dive in the earth, And fence not Athens.
A sheepcote fenced about with olive trees.

sn.def: To make a defense; to guard one's self of anything, as against an attack; to give protection or security, as by a fence.
sn.q: Vice is the more stubborn as well as the more dangerous evil, and therefore, in the first place, to be fenced against.

sn.def: To practice the art of attack and defense with the sword or with the foil, esp. with the smallsword, using the point only.
sn.q: He will fence with his own shadow.

sn.def: Hence, to fight or dispute in the manner of fencers, that is, by thrusting, guarding, parrying, etc.
sn.q: They fence and push, and, pushing, loudly roar; Their dewlaps and their sides are bat�ed in gore.
As when a billow, blown against, Falls back, the voice with which I fenced A little ceased, but recommenced.

entry.def: Affording defense; defensive.
Without a fence; uninclosed; open; unguarded; defenseless.
One who fences; one who teaches or practices the art of fencing with sword or foil.
entry.q: As blunt as the fencer's foils.

entry.def: Capable of being defended, or of making or affording defense.
entry.q: No fort so fencible, nor walls so strong.

entry.def: A soldier enlisted for home service only; -- usually in the pl.

sn.def: The art or practice of attack and defense with the sword, esp. with the smallsword. See Fence v. i., 2.
Disputing or debating in a manner resembling the art of fencers.
The materials used for building fences.
The act of building a fence.
The aggregate of the fences put up for inclosure or protection; as, the fencing of a farm.

entry.q: With fern beneath to fend the bitter cold.

entry.def: To act on the defensive, or in opposition; to resist; to parry; to shift off.
entry.q: The dexterous management of terms, and being able to fend . . . with them, passes for a great part of learning.

entries.entry:
Fen"der n. From Fend v. t. & i., cf. Defender
One who or that which defends or protects by warding off harm; as: A screen to prevent coals or sparks of an open fire from escaping to the floor. Anything serving as a cushion to lessen the shock when a vessel comes in contact with another vessel or a wharf. A screen to protect a carriage from mud thrown off the wheels: also, a splashboard. Anything set up to protect an exposed angle, as of a house, from damage by carriage wheels.

entry.def: Fiendlike.

entry.ety: L. faeneratus, p. p. of faenerari lend on interest, fr. faenus interest
entry.def: To put money to usury; to lend on interest.

entry.note: ☞ Ferments are of two kinds: (a) Formed or organized ferments. (b) Unorganized or structureless ferments. The latter are now called enzymes and were formerly called soluble ferments or chemical ferments. Ferments of the first class are as a rule simple microscopic vegetable organisms, and the fermentations which they engender are due to their growth and development; as, the acetic ferment, the butyric ferment, etc. See Fermentation. Ferments of the second class, on the other hand, are chemical substances; as a rule they are proteins soluble in glycerin and precipitated by alcohol. In action they are catalytic and, mainly, hydrolytic. Good examples are pepsin of the dastric juice, ptyalin of the salvia, and disease of malt. Before 1960 the term "ferment" to mean "enzyme" fell out of use. Enzymes are now known to be globular proteins, capable of catalyzing a wide variety of chemical reactions, not merely hydrolytic. The full set of enzymes causing production of ethyl alcohol from sugar has been identified and individually purified and studied. See enzyme.

cs.cd: volatile oils produced by the fermentation of plants, and not originally contained in them. These were the quintessences of the alchemists.

entry.note: In industrial microbiology fermentation usually refers to the production of chemical substances by use of microorganisms.
entry.cs:
Acetous fermentationorAcetic fermentation
a form of oxidation in which alcohol is converted into vinegar or acetic acid by the agency of a specific fungus (Mycoderma aceti) or series of enzymes. The process involves two distinct reactions, in which the oxygen of the air is essential. An intermediate product, acetaldehyde, is formed in the first process.1.C2H6O + O → H2O + C2H4O Alcohol. Water. Acetaldehyde.2.C2H4O + O → C2H4O2 Acetaldehyde. Acetic acid. Alcoholic fermentation the fermentation which saccharine bodies undergo when brought in contact with the yeast plant or Torula. The sugar is converted, either directly or indirectly, into alcohol and carbonic acid, the rate of action being dependent on the rapidity with which the Torulæ develop. Ammoniacal fermentation the conversion of the urea of the urine into ammonium carbonate, through the growth of the special urea ferment. CON2H4 + 2H2O = (NH4)2CO3 Urea. Water. Ammonium carbonate. Whenever urine is exposed to the air in open vessels for several days it undergoes this alkaline fermentation. Butyric fermentation the decomposition of various forms of organic matter, through the agency of a peculiar worm-shaped vibrio, with formation of more or less butyric acid. It is one of the many forms of fermentation that collectively constitute putrefaction. See Lactic fermentation.
enzymatic fermentationorFermentation by an unorganized ferment . Fermentations of this class are purely chemical reactions, in which the enzyme acts as a simple catalytic agent. Of this nature are the decomposition or inversion of cane sugar into levulose and dextrose by boiling with dilute acids, the conversion of starch into dextrin and sugar by similar treatment, the conversion of starch into like products by the action of diastase of malt or ptyalin of saliva, the conversion of albuminous food into peptones and other like products by the action of pepsin-hydrochloric acid of the gastric juice or by the ferment of the pancreatic juice. Fermentation theory of disease Biol. & Med the theory that most if not all, infectious or zymotic disease are caused by the introduction into the organism of the living germs of ferments, or ferments already developed (organized ferments), by which processes of fermentation are set up injurious to health. See Germ theory. Glycerin fermentation the fermentation which occurs on mixing a dilute solution of glycerin with a peculiar species of schizomycetes and some carbonate of lime, and other matter favorable to the growth of the plant, the glycerin being changed into butyric acid, caproic acid, butyl, and ethyl alcohol. With another form of bacterium (Bacillus subtilis) ethyl alcohol and butyric acid are mainly formed. Lactic fermentation the transformation of milk sugar or other saccharine body into lactic acid, as in the souring of milk, through the agency of a special bacterium (Bacterium lactis of Lister). In this change the milk sugar, before assuming the form of lactic acid, presumably passes through the stage of glucose. C12H22O11.H2O --> 4C3H6O3 Hydrated milk sugar. Lactic acid. In the lactic fermentation of dextrose or glucose, the lactic acid which is formed is very prone to undergo butyric fermentation after the manner indicated in the following equation: 2C3H6O3 (lactic acid) --> C4H8O2 (butyric acid) + 2CO2 (carbonic acid) + 2H2 (hydrogen gas).
Putrefactive fermentation. See Putrefaction.

entry.note: Laboratiory and industrial fermenters are usually equipped with a means of stirring the contained liquid so as to avoid settling of the fermenting organisms, and often have other, sometimes elaborate, mechanisms to control conditions of the fermentation, such as temperature, degree of aeration, or pH. The main structures of large industrial fermenters are typically made of steel.

entry.usage: When these words are applied to human feelings or conduct, ferocious describes the disposition; fierce, the haste and violence of an act; barbarous, the coarseness and brutality by which it was marked; savage, the cruel and unfeeling spirit which it showed. A man is ferocious in his temper, fierce in his actions, barbarous in the manner of carrying out his purposes, savage in the spirit and feelings expressed in his words or deeds.

She was the first woman to be nominated by a major U. S. political party for the office of Vice President.

entries.entry: Fer"ris wheel Ferris wheels are often found at traveling fairs and at permanent amusement parks. The Reisenrad in Vienna is one of the world's largest and most famous Ferris wheels.. An amusement device consisting of a giant power-driven vertically oriented steel wheel, revolvable on its horizontal stationary axle, and carrying a number of balanced passenger cars or open seats around its rim; the seats are suspended so as to remain horizontal as the wheel rotates, and, depending on the size of the wheel, the passengers when they reach the top may have a grand vista of the surrounding area; -- so called after G. W. G. Ferris, American engineer, who erected the first of its kind for the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893.
Fer"ro-. Chem A prefix, or combining form, indicating ferrous iron as an ingredient; as, ferrocyanide.

entry.ety: Ferro- + calcite

Concrete strengthened by a core or foundation skeleton of iron or steel bars, strips, etc. Floors, columns, piles, water pipes, etc., have been successfully made of it. Called also armored concrete steel, and most commonly reenforced concrete.

It is obtained by strongly heating together potash, scrap iron, and animal matter containing nitrogen, as horn, leather, blood, etc., in iron pots.

entry.ety: L., iron rust, fr. ferrum iron
entry.def: A disease of plants caused by fungi, commonly called the rust, from its resemblance to iron rust in color.

entry.ety: Formerly verrel, F. virole, fr. L. viriola little bracelet, dim. of viriae, pl., bracelets; prob. akin to viere to twist, weave, and E. withe. The spelling with f is due to confusion with L. ferrum iron

sn.def: A ring or cap of metal put round a cane, tool, handle, or other similar object, to strengthen it, or prevent splitting and wearing.
Any of various circular or cylindrical metal objects used at joints in a tube, pipe, or rod, especially to assist making a tight seal at a joint.
A bushing for expanding the end of a flue to fasten it tightly in the tube plate, or for partly filling up its mouth.
A bushing used at the joints of metal tubing in HPLC equipment to make a tight seal.
One of several small rings at the top of a casting rod which holds the fishing line.

entry.ety: L. ferruminatus, p. p. of ferruminare to cement, solder, fr. ferrumen cement, fr. ferrum iron
entry.def: To solder or unite, as metals.

entry.ety: L. ferruminatio: cf. F. ferrumination
entry.def: The soldering or uniting of metals.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ferried -rĭd; p. pr. & vb. n. Ferrying
entry.ety: OE. ferien to convey, AS. ferian, from faran to go; akin to Icel. ferja to ferry, Goth. farjan to sail. See Fare

sn.def: To carry or transport over a river, strait, or other narrow water, in a boat.
To convey back and forth regularly between two points in a vehicle; as, part of her day was spent ferrying the kids to and from school.

entry.def: To pass over water in a boat or by a ferry.
entry.q: They ferry over this Lethean sound Both to and fro.

entries.entry:
Fer"ry
Ferry bridge a ferryboat adapted in its structure for the transfer of railroad trains across a river or bay. Ferry railway. See under Railway.
n.; pl.Ferries #. OE. feri; akin to Icel. ferja, Sw. färja, Dan. færge, G. fähre. See Ferry v. t.
A place where persons or things are carried across a river, arm of the sea, etc., in a ferryboat. It can pass the ferry backward into light. To row me o'er the ferry.
A vessel in which passengers and goods are conveyed over narrow waters; a ferryboat; a wherry.
A franchise or right to maintain a vessel for carrying passengers and freight across a river, bay, etc., charging tolls.

entry.def: A vessel for conveying passengers, merchandise, etc., usually across streams, rivers, bays, and other narrow waters.

entries.entry: Fer"ry*man n.; pl.Ferrymen. One who maintains or attends a ferry.

entry.def: Fierce.
Fourth.

entry.usage: Fertile implies the inherent power of production; fruitful, the act. The prairies of the West are fertile by nature, and are turned by cultivation into fruitful fields. The same distinction prevails when these words are used figuratively. A man of fertile genius has by nature great readiness of invention; one whose mind is fruitful has resources of thought and a readiness of application which enable him to think and act effectively.
entry.ety: L. fertilis, fr. ferre to bear, produce: cf. F. fertile. See Bear to support

sn.def: Producing fruit or vegetation in abundance; fruitful; able to produce abundantly; prolific; fecund; productive; rich; inventive; as, fertile land or fields; a fertile mind or imagination.
sn.q: Though he in a fertile climate dwell.

sd.def: Capable of producing fruit; fruit-bearing; as, fertile flowers.
Containing pollen; -- said of anthers.

sn.def: produced in abundance; plenteous; ample.
sn.q: Henceforth, my early care . . . Shall tend thee, and the fertile burden ease Of thy full branches.

entry.def: In a fertile or fruitful manner.
Fertility.
To fertilize; to fecundate.

entry.ety: L. fertilitas: cf. F. fertilité
entry.def: The state or quality of being fertile or fruitful; fruitfulness; productiveness; fecundity; richness; abundance of resources; fertile invention; quickness; readiness; as, the fertility of soil, or of imagination.
entry.q: fertilityof resource.
And all her husbandry doth lie on heaps Corrupting in its own fertility.
Thy very weeds are beautiful; thy waste More rich than other climes' fertility.

cs.cd: the fertilization of pistils by pollen derived from the stamens of the same blossom.
fertilization by pollen from some other blossom. See under Cross a.

sn.def: The act or process of rendering fertile.

The act of fecundating or impregnating animal or vegetable germs; esp., the process by which in flowers the pollen renders the ovule fertile, or an analogous process in flowerless plants; fecundation; impregnation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fertilized; p. pr. & vb. n. Fertilizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. fertiliser

sn.def: To make fertile or enrich; to supply with nourishment for plants; to make fruitful or productive; as, to fertilize land, soil, ground, and meadows.
sn.q: And fertilize the field that each pretends to gain.

sn.def: To fecundate; as, to fertilize flower.
united with a male gamete to begin the development of an individual embryo; -- of female gametes.
made more suitable for growth of crops by addition of fertilizer{2}; -- of soil.
One who fertilizes; the agent that carries the fertilizing principle, as a moth to an orchid.
That which renders fertile; a general name for commercial substances which make plants grow better, as manure, guano, phosphate of lime, ammonium nitrate, etc.

entry.ety: L. ferula giant fennel (its stalks were used in punishing schoolboys), rod, whip, fr. ferire to strike; akin to OHG. berjan, Icel. berja. Cf. Ferule

sn.def: A ferule.
The imperial scepter in the Byzantine or Eastern Empire.

entry.ety: L. ferulaceus, fr. ferula rod: cf. F. férulacé
entry.def: Pertaining to reeds and canes; having a stalk like a reed; as, ferulaceous plants.
A ferule.

entry.ety: L. ferula: cf. F. férule. See Ferula

sn.def: A flat piece of wood, used for striking, children, esp. on the hand, in punishment.
A ferrule.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Feruled; p. pr. & vb. n. Feruling
entry.def: To punish with a ferule.
Pertaining to, or derived from, asafetida (Ferula asafœtida); as, ferulic acid.
Heat; fervency.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. fervence. See Fervent
entry.def: The state of being fervent or warm; ardor; warmth of feeling or devotion; eagerness.
entry.q: When you pray, let it be with attention, with fervency, and with perseverance.

entry.ety: F. fervent, L. fervens -entis. p. pr. of fervere o the boiling hot, to boil, glow

sn.def: Hot; glowing; boiling; burning; as, a fervent summer.
sn.q: The elements shall melt with fervent heat.

sn.def: Warm in feeling; ardent in temperament; earnest; full of fervor; zealous; glowing.
sn.q: Not slothful in business; fervent in spirit.
So spake the fervent angel.
A fervent desire to promote the happiness of mankind.
Laboring fervently for you in prayers.

entry.ety: L. fervescens, p. pr. of fervescere to become boiling hot, incho., fr. fervere. See Fervent
entry.def: Growing hot.

entry.ety: L. fervidus, fr. fervere. See Fervent

sn.def: Very hot; burning; boiling.
sn.q: The mounted sun Shot down direct his fervid rays.

sn.def: Ardent; vehement; zealous.
sn.q: The fervid wishes, holy fires.

entry.usage: Fervor is a boiling heat, and ardor is a burning heat. Hence, in metaphor, we commonly use fervor and its derivatives when we conceive of thoughts or emotions under the image of ebullition, or as pouring themselves forth. Thus we speak of the fervor of passion, fervid declamation, fervid importunity, fervent supplication, fervent desires, etc. Ardent is used when we think of anything as springing from a deepseated glow of soul; as, ardent friendship, ardent zeal, ardent devotedness; burning with ardor for the fight.
entry.ety: OF. fervor fervour, F. ferveur, L. fervor, fr. fervere. See Fervent

sn.def: Heat; excessive warmth.
sn.q: The fevor of ensuing day.

sn.def: Intensity of feeling or expression; glowing ardor; passion; holy zeal; earnestness.
sn.q: Winged with fervor of her love.

entry.ety: L. Fescenninus, fr. Fescennia, a city of Etruria
entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, the Fescennines.

def2.def: A style of low, scurrilous, obscene poetry originating in fescennia.

cs.cd: a genus of grasses (Festuca) containing several species of importance in agriculture. Festuca ovina is sheep's fescue; F. elatior is meadow fescue.

entry.ety: OE. festu, OF. festu, F. fétu, fr. L. festuca stalk, straw

sn.def: A straw, wire, stick, etc., used chiefly to point out letters to children when learning to read.
sn.q: Pedanticfescue.
To come under the fescue of an imprimatur.

sn.def: An instrument for playing on the harp; a plectrum.
The style of a dial.
A grass of the genus Festuca.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fescued; p. pr. & vb. n. Fescuing
entry.def: To use a fescue, or teach with a fescue.

entry.ety: Written also fasels
entry.def: See Phasel.

cs.cd: the exact center of the escutcheon. See Escutcheon.

entry.ety: OF. fesse faisse, F. fasce, fr. L. fascia band. See Fascia
entry.def: A band drawn horizontally across the center of an escutcheon, and containing in breadth the third part of it; one of the nine honorable ordinaries.

entry.ety: L. fessus wearied, fatigued
entry.def: Weariness.
In the manner of fess.

entry.ety: See Fist
entry.def: The fist.
A feast.

entry.ety: L. festum holiday, feast. See feast
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a holiday or a feast; joyous; festive.
entry.q: You bless with choicer wine the festal day.

entry.def: Joyously; festively; mirthfully.
A fescennine.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Festered; p. pr. & vb. n. Festering
entry.ety: OE. festern, fr. fester n.; or fr. OF. festrir, fr. festre n. See Fester n.

sn.def: To generate pus; to become imflamed and suppurate; as, a sore or a wound festers .
sn.q: Wounds immedicable Rankle, and fester, and gangrene.
Unkindness may give a wound that shall bleed and smart, but it is treachery that makes it fester.
Hatred . . . festered in the hearts of the children of the soil.

sn.def: To be inflamed; to grow virulent, or malignant; to grow in intensity; to rankle.

entry.def: To cause to fester or rankle.
entry.q: For which I burnt in inward, swelt'ring hate, And festered ranking malice in my breast.

entry.ety: OF. festre, L. fistula a sort of ulcer. Cf. Fistula

sn.def: A small sore which becomes inflamed and discharges corrupt matter; a pustule.
A festering or rankling.
sn.q: The fester of the chain their necks.

entry.def: A festering.

entry.ety: OF. festier festeer, F. festoyer
entry.def: To feast; to entertain.

entry.ety: L. festinatus, p. p. of festinare to hasten
entry.def: Hasty; hurried.

entry.ety: L. festinatio
entry.def: Haste; hurry.

entry.ety: OF. festival, fr. L. festivum festive jollity, fr. festivus festive, gay. See Festive
entry.def: Pertaining to a fest; festive; festal; appropriate to a festival; joyous; mirthful.
entry.q: I cannot woo in festival terms.

entry.def: A time of feasting or celebration; an anniversary day of joy, civil or religious.
entry.q: The morning trumpets festival proclaimed.

entry.ety: L. festivus, fr. festum holiday, feast. See feast, and cf. Festivous
entry.def: Pertaining to, or becoming, a feast; festal; joyous; gay; mirthful; sportive.
entry.q: The glad circle round them yield their souls To festive mirth and wit that knows no gall.

entries.entry:
Fes*tiv"i*ty n.; pl.Festivities #. L. festivitas: cf. F. festivité
The condition of being festive; social joy or exhilaration of spirits at an entertaintment; joyfulness; gayety. The unrestrained festivity of the rustic youth.
A festival; a festive celebration.

entry.ety: See Festive
entry.def: Pertaining to a feast; festive.

entry.ety: See Feast n.
entry.def: Festive; fond of festive occasions.
entry.q: Afestlichman.

entry.ety: F. festoncf. Sp. feston, It. festone), prob. fr. L. festum festival. See Feast

sn.def: A garland or wreath hanging in a depending curve, used in decoration for festivals, etc.; anything arranged in this way.
A carved ornament consisting of flowers, and leaves, intermixed or twisted together, wound with a ribbon, and hanging or depending in a natural curve. See Illust. of Bucranium.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Festooned; p. pr. & vb. n. Festooning
entry.def: To form in festoons, or to adorn with festoons.
Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, festoons.

entry.ety: L. festula stalk, straw. Cf. Fescue
entry.def: Of a straw color; greenish yellow.
entry.q: A little insect of a festucine or pale green.

entry.def: Formed or consisting of straw.

entry.ety: See Fescue
entry.def: A straw; a fescue.

entry.ety: Cf. feat, F. fait, and It. fett� slice, G. fetzen rag, Icel. fat garment
entry.def: A piece.

entry.ety: OE. fetten feten, AS. fetian; akin to AS. fæt a journey, and to E. foot; cf. G. fassen to seize. √ 77. See Foot, and cf. Fetch
entry.def: To fetch.
entry.q: And from the other fifty soon the prisoner fet.

entries.entry: Fet p. p. of Fette . Fetched. Obs

entry.ety: From Fetus
entry.def: Pertaining to, or connected with, a fetus; as, fetal circulation; fetal membranes.
The formation of a fetus in the womb; pregnancy.

entry.cs:
To fetch a compass Naut to make a circuit; to take a circuitous route going to a place. To fetch a pump to make it draw water by pouring water into the top and working the handle.
To fetch headwayorTo fetch sternway
Naut to move ahead or astern. To fetch out to develop. “The skill of the polisher fetches out the colors [of marble]” Addison. To fetch up. To overtake. Obs “Says [the hare], I can fetch up the tortoise when I please.” L'Estrange. To stop suddenly.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fetched 2; p. pr. & vb. n.. Fetching
entry.ety: OE. fecchen, AS. feccan, perh. the same word as fetian; or cf. facian to wish to get, OFries. faka to prepare. √77. Cf. Fet v. t.

sn.def: To bear toward the person speaking, or the person or thing from whose point of view the action is contemplated; to go and bring; to get.
sn.q: Time will run back and fetch the age of gold.

He called to her, and said, Fetch me, I pray thee, a little water in a vessel, that I may drink. And as she was going to fetch it he called to her, and said, Bring me, I pray thee, a morsel of bread in thine hand.

sn.def: To obtain as price or equivalent; to sell for.
sn.q: Our native horses were held in small esteem, and fetched low prices.

sn.def: To recall from a swoon; to revive; -- sometimes with to; as, to fetch a man to.
sn.q: Fetching men again when they swoon.

sn.def: To reduce; to throw.
sn.q: The sudden trip in wrestling that fetches a man to the ground.

sn.def: To bring to accomplishment; to achieve; to make; to perform, with certain objects; as, to fetch a compass; to fetch a leap; to fetch a sigh.
sn.q: I'll fetch a turn about the garden.
He fetches his blow quick and sure.

sn.def: To bring or get within reach by going; to reach; to arrive at; to attain; to reach by sailing.
sn.q: Meantine flew our ships, and straight we fetched The siren's isle.

sn.def: To cause to come; to bring to a particular state.
sn.q: They could n't fetch the butter in the churn.

cs.cd: to break loose; to roll or slide to leeward.
to serve obsequiously, like a trained spaniel.

entry.def: To bring one's self; to make headway; to veer; as, to fetch about; to fetch to windward.

cs.cd: a light seen at night, superstitiously believed to portend a person's death.

sn.def: A stratagem by which a thing is indirectly brought to pass, or by which one thing seems intended and another is done; a trick; an artifice.
sn.q: Every little fetch of wit and criticism.

sn.def: The apparation of a living person; a wraith.
sn.q: The very fetch and ghost of Mrs. Gamp.

sn.def: The unobstructed region of the ocean over which the wind blows to generate waves.
The length of such a region.

entry.def: One who fetches or brings.
drawing favorable attention; as, a fetching new hat.

entry.ety: See feat
entry.def: A feat.

entry.ety: See Foot
entry.def: Feet.

cs.cd: a festival or entertainment in the open air; a rural festival.

entry.ety: F. See Feast
entry.def: A festival.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fêted; p. pr. & vb. n. Fêting
entry.ety: Cf. F. fêter
entry.def: To feast; to honor with a festival.

entry.ety: F. fétiche, from Pg. feiti�o, adj., n., sorcery, charm, fr. L. facticius made by art, artifical, factitious. See Factitious

sn.def: A material object supposed among certain African tribes to represent in such a way, or to be so connected with, a supernatural being, that the possession of it gives to the possessor power to control that being.
Any object to which one is excessively devoted.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fétichisme

sn.def: The doctrine or practice of belief in fetiches.
Excessive devotion to one object or one idea; abject superstition; blind adoration.
sn.q: The real and absolute worship of fire falls into two great divisions, the first belonging rather to fetichism, the second to polytheism proper.

entry.def: A believer in fetiches.
entry.q: He was by nature a fetichist.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or involving, fetichism.
entry.q: A man of the fifteenth century, inheriting its strange web of belief and unbelief, of epicurean levity and fetichistic dread.

entry.ety: Fetus + L. caedere to kill
entry.def: The act of killing the fetus in the womb; the offense of procuring an abortion.
See Fetichism.

entry.ety: L. fetidus foetidus, fr. fetere foetere, to have an ill smell, to stink: cf. F. fétide
entry.def: Having an offensive smell; stinking.
entry.q: Most putrefactions . . . smell either fetid or moldy.

entry.def: Fetidness.
The quality or state of being fetid.

entry.ety: Fetus + -ferous
entry.def: Producing young, as animals.

entry.ety: OF. fetis faitis. Cf. Factitious
entry.def: Neat; pretty; well made; graceful.
entry.q: Full fetis was her cloak, as I was ware.

entry.def: Neatly; gracefully; properly.
See Fetich n. Fetichism n. Fetichistic a.

entry.ety: OE. fetlak fitlock, cf. Icel. fet pace, step, fit webbed foot of water birds, akin to E. foot. √ 77. See Foot
entry.def: The cushionlike projection, bearing a tuft of long hair, on the back side of the leg above the hoof of the horse and similar animals. Also, the joint of the limb at this point (between the great pastern bone and the metacarpus), or the tuft of hair.
entry.q: Their wounded steeds Fret fetlock deep in gore.

entry.ety: L. fetor foetor. See Fetid
entry.def: A strong, offensive smell; stench; fetidness.

entry.ety: See Fet v. t.
entry.def: To fetch.

entry.ety: AS. fetor feter; akin to OS. feterōs, pl., OD. veter, OHG. fezzera, Icel. fjöturr, L. pedica, Gr. pe`dh, and to E. foot. √ 77. See Foot
entry.mark: Chiefly used in the plural, fetters

sn.def: A chain or shackle for the feet; a chain by which an animal is confined by the foot, either made fast or disabled from free and rapid motion; a bond; a shackle.
sn.q: They] bound him with fetters of brass.

sn.def: Anything that confines or restrains; a restraint.
sn.q: Passion's too fierce to be in fetters bound.

entry.ety: imp. & p. p. Fettered; p. pr. & vb. n. Fettering

sn.def: To put fetters upon; to shackle or confine the feet of with a chain; to bind.
sn.q: My heels are fettered, but my fist is free.

sn.def: To restrain from motion; to impose restraints on; to confine; to enchain; as, fettered by obligations.
sn.q: My conscience! thou art fettered More than my shanks and wrists.

sn.def: An ornamental evergreen shrub (Pieris floribunda) of the Southeastern U. S. having small white bell-shaped flowers.
sn.syn: mountain fetterbush, mountain andromeda, Pieris floribunda.

sn.def: A showy evergreen shrub (Lyonia lucida) of the Southeastern U. S. with shiny leaves and angled branches and umbel-like clusters of pink to reddish flowers.
sn.syn: fetter bush, shiny lyonia, Lyonia lucida.

entry.def: Seeming as if fettered, as the feet of certain animals which bend backward, and appear unfit for walking.
One who fetters.
Free from fetters.

entry.ety: OE. & Prov. E., to fettle (in sense 1), fettle n., order, repair, preparation, dress; prob. akin to E. fit. See Fit a.

sn.def: To repair; to prepare; to put in order.
To cover or line with a mixture of ore, cinders, etc., as the hearth of a puddling furnace.

entry.def: To make preparations; to put things in order; to do trifling business.

cs.cd: in good spirits.

entry.def: The act of fettling.

entry.note: It is commonly called fix in the United States

sn.def: A mixture of ore, cinders, etc., used to line the hearth of a puddling furnace.
The operation of shaving or smoothing the surface of undried clay ware.

entry.def: Neat; feat.

entries.entry:
Fe"tus fē"tŭs n.; pl.Fetuses fē"tŭs*ĕz. L. fetus foetus, a bringing forth, brood, offspring, young ones, cf. fetus fruitful, fructified, that is or was filled with young; akin to E. fawn a deer, fecundity felicity feminine female, and prob. to do, or according to others, to be
The young or embryo of a vertebrate animal in the womb, or in the egg; often restricted to the later stages in the development of viviparous and oviparous animals. showing the main recognizable features of the mature animal, embryo being applied to the earlier stages.
fœtus

entry.ety: Ar
entry.def: A written decision of a Turkish mufti some point of law; also applied to opinions by certain other Islamic religious authorities on points of Islamic law, such as in Iran.

entry.ety: See 2d Feud, and Fee
entry.def: A free and gratuitous right to lands made to one for service to be performed by him; a tenure where the vassal, in place of military services, makes a return in grain or in money.

entry.ety: From Feu
entry.def: One who holds a feu.

entry.ety: OE. feide, AS. fǣhð, fr. fāh hostile; akin to OHG. fēhida, G. fehde, Sw. fejd, D. feide; prob. akin to E. fiend. See Foe

sn.def: A combination of kindred to avenge injuries or affronts, done or offered to any of their blood, on the offender and all his race.
A contention or quarrel; especially, an inveterate strife between families, clans, or parties; deadly hatred; contention satisfied only by bloodshed.
sn.q: Mutual feuds and battles betwixt their several tribes and kindreds.
sn.syn: Affray; fray; broil; contest; dispute; strife.

entry.ety: LL. feudum feodum prob. of same origin as E. fief. See Fief Fee
entry.def: A stipendiary estate in land, held of a superior, by service; the right which a vassal or tenant had to the lands or other immovable thing of his lord, to use the same and take the profits thereof hereditarily, rendering to his superior such duties and services as belong to military tenure, etc., the property of the soil always remaining in the lord or superior; a fief; a fee.

entry.ety: F. féodal, or LL. feudalis

sn.def: Of or pertaining to feuds, fiefs, or fees; as, feudal rights or services; feudal tenures.
Consisting of, or founded upon, feuds or fiefs; embracing tenures by military services; as, the feudal system.

entry.ety: Cf. F. féodalisme
entry.def: The feudal system; a system by which the holding of estates in land is made dependent upon an obligation to render military service to the king or feudal superior; feudal principles and usages.
An upholder of feudalism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. féodalité
entry.def: The state or quality of being feudal; feudal form or constitution.
The act of reducing to feudal tenure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Feudalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Feudalizing
entry.def: To reduce to a feudal tenure; to conform to feudalism.
In a feudal manner.

entry.ety: LL. feudarius, fr. feudum. See 2d Feud
entry.def: Held by, or pertaining to, feudal tenure.

sn.def: A tenant who holds his lands by feudal service; a feudatory.
A feodary. See Feodary.

entry.ety: LL. feudatarius: cf. F. feudataire
entry.def: See Feudatory.

entries.entry: Feu"da*to*ry n.; pl.Feudatories. A tenant or vassal who held his lands of a superior on condition of feudal service; the tenant of a feud or fief. The grantee . . . was styled the feudatory or vassal. He] had for feudatories great princes.

entry.def: Held from another on some conditional tenure; as, a feudatory title.

entries.entry: ‖Feu` de joie" ‖Feu` de joie". F., lit., fire of joy A fire kindled in a public place in token of joy; a bonfire; a firing of guns in token of joy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. feudiste
entry.def: A writer on feuds; a person versed in feudal law.
A reformed branch of the Bernardines, founded in 1577 at Feuillans, near Toulouse, in France.

entry.ety: F. feuille morte a dead leaf
entry.def: Having the color of a faded leaf.

entry.ety: F., from feulle leaf
entry.def: A part of a French newspaper (usually the bottom of the page), devoted to light literature, criticism, etc.; also, the article or tale itself, thus printed.

entry.ety: F. feuilletoniste
entry.def: A writer of feuilletons.

entry.ety: OE. feutre rest for a lance, OF. feutre fautre feltre, felt, cushion, rest for a lance, fr. LL. filtrum feltrum; of German origin, and akin to E. felt. See Felt, and cf. Filter
entry.def: To set close; to fix in rest, as a spear.

entry.ety: Either fr. G. fütterer feeder, or corrupted fr. OF. vautrier vaultrier; fr. vaultre, viautre, a kind of hound, fr. L. vertragus vertraga, a greyhound. The last is of Celtic origin
entry.def: A dog keeper.

entry.note: ☞ Remitting fevers subside or abate at intervals; intermitting fevers intermit or entirely cease at intervals; continued or continual fevers neither remit nor intermit.
entry.cs:
Brain fever Continued fever
etc. See under Brain Continued, etc. Fever and ague a form of fever recurring in paroxysms which are preceded by chills. It is of malarial origin. Fever blister Med a blister or vesicle often found about the mouth in febrile states; a variety of herpes. Fever bush Bot the wild allspice or spice bush. See Spicewood. Fever powder. Same as Jame's powder. Fever root Bot an American herb of the genus Triosteum Triosteum perfoliatum); -- called also feverwort and horse gentian. Fever sore a carious ulcer or necrosis. Miner.
entry.ety: OE. fever fefer, AS. fefer fefor, L. febris: cf. F. fièvre. Cf. Febrile

sn.def: A diseased state of the system, marked by increased heat, acceleration of the pulse, and a general derangement of the functions, including usually, thirst and loss of appetite. Many diseases, of which fever is the most prominent symptom, are denominated fevers; as, typhoid fever; yellow fever.
Excessive excitement of the passions in consequence of strong emotion; a condition of great excitement; as, this quarrel has set my blood in a fever .
sn.q: An envious fever Of pale and bloodless emulation.
After life's fitful fever he sleeps well.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fevered fē"vẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Fevering
entry.def: To put into a fever; to affect with fever; as, a fevered lip.
entry.q: The white hand of a lady fever thee.

entry.def: Highly excited; as, a fevered imagination.
A slight fever.

entry.ety: AS. feferfuge, fr. L. febrifugia. See fever Fugitive, and cf. Febrifuge
entry.def: A perennial plant (Pyrethrum Parthenium, or Chrysanthemum Parthenium) allied to camomile, having finely divided leaves and white blossoms; -- so named from its supposed febrifugal qualities.

sn.def: Having a fever; suffering from, or affected with, a moderate degree of fever; showing increased heat and thirst; as, the patient is feverish .
Indicating, or pertaining to, fever; characteristic of a fever; as, feverish symptoms.
Hot; sultry.
sn.q: Thefeverishnorth.

sn.def: Disordered as by fever; excited; restless; as, the feverish condition of the commercial world.
sn.q: Strive to keep up a frail and feverish being.

entry.ety: Cf.F. fiévreux

sn.def: Affected with fever or ague; feverish.
sn.q: His heart, love's feverous citadel.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or having the nature of, fever; as, a feverous pulse.
sn.q: All maladies . . . all feverous kinds.

sn.def: Having the tendency to produce fever; as, a feverous disposition of the year.

entry.def: Feverishly.
See Fever root, under Fever.
Feverish.

entry.note: ☞ Few is often used partitively; as, few of them.

cs.cd: a small number.
in a few words; briefly.
not few; more than a few; many.
the minority; -- opposed to the many or the majority.

entry.ety: OE. fewe feawe, AS. feá, pl. feáwe; akin to OS. fāh, OHG. fō fao, Icel. fār, Sw. få, pl., Dan. faa, pl., Goth. faus, L. paucus, cf. Gr. pay^ros. Cf. Paucity
entry.def: Not many; small, limited, or confined in number; -- indicating a small portion of units or individuals constituting a whole; often, by ellipsis of a noun, a few people.
entry.q: Are not my daysfew?
Few know and fewer care.

entry.ety: See Fuel
entry.def: Fuel.
See Fumet.

sn.def: The state of being few; smallness of number; paucity.
Brevity; conciseness.

entry.ety: AS. fǣga, Icel. feigr, OHG. feigi
entry.def: Fated; doomed.

entry.ety: See Fay faith
entry.def: Faith.

entry.ety: Cf. Feague
entry.def: To cleanse; to clean out.
To feign.
A fair or market.

entry.ety: F., fr. the town of Fez in Morocco
entry.def: A felt or cloth cap, usually red and having a tassel, -- a variety of the tarboosh. See Tarboosh.

entry.ety: acronym from Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation
entry.def: a corporation authorized by Congress to provide a secondary market for residential mortgages. It is called Freddie Mac in the jargon of the finance industry.
entry.syn: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, Freddie Mac.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A kind of French hackney coach.

entry.ety: F. fiancer. See Affiance
entry.def: To betroth; to affiance.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A betrothed man.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A betrothed woman.

entry.ety: F. fiente dung
entry.def: The dung of the fox, wolf, boar, or badger.

entry.ety: See Feuar

sn.def: One in whom the property of an estate is vested, subject to the estate of a life renter.
sn.q: I am fiar of the lands; she a life renter.

sn.def: The price of grain, as legally fixed, in the counties of Scotland, for the current year.

entries.entry: ‖Fi*as"co n.; pl.Fiascoes #. It A complete or ridiculous failure, esp. of a musical performance, or of any pretentious undertaking.

cs.cd: irredeemable paper currency, not resting on a specie basis, but deriving its purchasing power from the declaratory fiat of the government issuing it.

entry.ety: L., let it be done, 3d pers. sing., subj. pres., fr. fieri, used as pass. of facere to make. Cf. Be

sn.def: An authoritative command or order to do something; an effectual decree.
sn.q: His fiat laid the corner stone.

sd.def: A warrant of a judge for certain processes.
An authority for certain proceedings given by the Lord Chancellor's signature.

entry.def: Commission; fiat; order; decree.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. fable; cf. Prov. E. fibble-fabble nonsense
entry.def: A falsehood; a lie; -- used euphemistically.
entry.q: They are very serious; they don't tell fibs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fibbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Fibbing
entry.def: To speak falsely.
To tell a fib to.
One who tells fibs.

cs.cd: a kind of steam gun for converting, wood, straw, etc., into fiber. The material is shut up in the gun with steam, air, or gas at a very high pressure which is afterward relieved suddenly by letting a lid at the muzzle fly open, when the rapid expansion separates the fibers.
plants capable of yielding fiber useful in the arts, as hemp, flax, ramie, agave, etc.

entry.ety: F. fibre, L. fibra

sn.def: One of the delicate, threadlike portions of which the tissues of plants and animals are in part constituted; as, the fiber of flax or of muscle.
Any fine, slender thread, or threadlike substance; as, a fiber of spun glass; especially, one of the slender rootlets of a plant.
the inherent complex of attributes that determine a person's moral and ethical actions and reactions; sinew; strength; toughness; as, a man of real fiber .
sn.q: Yet had no fibers in him, nor no force.

sn.def: A general name for the raw material, such as cotton, flax, hemp, etc., used in textile manufactures.

that portion of food composed of carbohydrates which are completely or partly indigestible, such as cellulose or pectin; it may be in an insoluble or a soluble form. It provides bulk to the solid waste and stimulates peristalsis in the intestine. It is found especially in grains, fruits, and vegetables. There is some medical evidence which indicates that diets high in fiber reduce the risk of colon cancer and reduce cholesterol levels in the blood. It is also called dietary fiber roughage, or bulk.
a leatherlike material made by compressing layers of paper or cloth.

entry.def: a type of wallboard composed of wood chips or shavings bonded together with resin and compressed into rigid sheets, calle also particle board.
Having fibers; made up of fibers.
Having a visible fiber embodied in the surface of; -- applied esp. to a kind of paper for checks, drafts, etc.

a material made of fine glass fibers woven into a fabric-like form, and used in applications requiring heat resistance; it is also embedded in resins to make a pliable but strong composite material used as the main component of fishing rods and boat hulls, and replacing the sheet metal in some automobile bodies.
Having no fibers; destitute of fibers or fiber.

entry.note: Light transmission through optical fibers has become an important means of data and telephone signal transmission, in some areas superseding the carrying of vioce and data signals through electrical pulses over copper wire. It is also used for directly carrying images from otherwise inaccessible locations, as from inside the body, for medical procedures. Light transmission via fiber optics for data transmission uses an optical fiber made of specially purified glass with low light absorption characteristics.
entry.def: that branch of optics which studies the transmission of light through thin transparent fibers.
an instrument used to examine internal organs.
Same as fiber.
Same as fiberboard.
Same as fiberglass.

entry.ety: L. fibra a fiber + -form
entry.def: Having the form of a fiber or fibers; resembling a fiber.

entry.ety: F. fibrille, dim. of fibre, L. fibra
entry.def: A small fiber; the branch of a fiber; a very slender thread; a fibrilla.

entries.entry:
‖Fi*bril"la n.; pl.FibrillÆ #. NL. See Fibril
A minute thread or fiber, as one of the fibrous elements of a muscular fiber; a fibril.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to fibrils or fibers; as, fibrillar twitchings.
Of of pertaining to fibrils.
Furnished with fibrils; fringed.
The state of being reduced to fibers.
Covered with hairlike appendages, as the under surface of some lichens; also, composed of little strings or fibers; as, fibrillose appendages.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fibraleux
entry.def: Pertaining to, or composed of, fibers.

cs.cd: the albuminous bodies, paraglobulin and fibrinigen in the blood, which, by the action of the fibrin ferment, are changed into fibrin, in coagulation.
a ferment which makes its appearance in the blood shortly after it is shed, and is supposed to be the active agent in causing coagulation of the blood, with formation of fibrin.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fibrine. See Fiber

sn.def: A white, albuminous, fibrous substance, formed in the coagulation of the blood either by decomposition of fibrinogen, or from the union of fibrinogen and paraglobulin which exist separately in the blood. It is insoluble in water, but is readily digestible in gastric and pancreatic juice.
The white, albuminous mass remaining after washing lean beef or other meat with water until all coloring matter is removed; the fibrous portion of the muscle tissue; flesh fibrin.
An albuminous body, resembling animal fibrin in composition, found in cereal grains and similar seeds; vegetable fibrin.

entry.def: The state of acquiring or having an excess of fibrin.
Belonging to the fibers of plants.

entry.ety: Fibrin + -gen
entry.def: An albuminous substance existing in the blood, and in other animal fluids, which either alone or with fibrinoplastin or paraglobulin forms fibrin, and thus causes coagulation.
Possessed of properties similar to fibrinogen; capable of forming fibrin.
Like fibrinoplastin; capable of forming fibrin when brought in contact with fibrinogen.

entry.ety: Fibrin + Gr. � to form, mold
entry.def: An albuminous substance, existing in the blood, which in combination with fibrinogen forms fibrin; -- called also paraglobulin.
Having, or partaking of the properties of, fibrin; as, fibrious exudation.

entry.ety: L. fibra a fiber + E. cartilage
entry.def: A kind of cartilage with a fibrous matrix and approaching fibrous connective tissue in structure.

entry.ety: L. fibra a fiber + gr. � cartilage + � bone
entry.def: Partly fibrous, partly cartilaginous, and partly osseous.

cs.cd: a form of degeneration in which organs or tissues are converted into fibroid tissue.
a form of pulmonary consumption associated with the formation of fibrous tissue in the lungs, and the gradual atrophy of the lungs, from the pressure due to the contraction of this tissue.

entry.ety: L. fibra a fiber + -oid
entry.def: Resembling or forming fibrous tissue; made up of fibers; as, fibroid tumors.

def2.def: A fibroid tumor; a fibroma.

entry.ety: L. fibra a fiber
entry.def: A variety of gelatin; the chief ingredient of raw silk, extracted as a white amorphous mass.

entry.ety: L. fibra a fiber + -lite: cf. F. fibrolithe
entry.def: A silicate of alumina, of fibrous or columnar structure. It is like andalusite in composition; -- called also sillimanite, and bucholizite.

entry.ety: NL. See Fiber, and -oma
entry.def: A tumor consisting mainly of fibrous tissue, or of same modification of such tissue.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. fibra a fiber + spongia a sponge
entry.def: An order of sponges having a fibrous skeleton, including the commercial sponges.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fibreux
entry.def: Containing, or consisting of, fibers; as, the fibrous coat of the cocoanut; the fibrous roots of grasses.

entry.ety: L. fibra a fiber + E. vascular
entry.def: Containing woody fiber and ducts, as the stems of all flowering plants and ferns; -- opposed to cellular.
One who tells fibs.

entries.entry:
‖Fib"u*la n.; pl.FibulÆ #. L., clasp, buckle
A brooch, clasp, or buckle. Mere fibulæ, without a robe to clasp.
Anat The outer and usually the smaller of the two bones of the leg, or hind limb, below the knee.
Surg A needle for sewing up wounds.

entry.def: Pertaining to the fibula.

entries.entry:
‖Fib`u*la"re n.; pl.Fibularia #. NL. See Fibula
Anat The bone or cartilage of the tarsus, which articulates with the fibula, and corresponds to the calcaneum in man and most mammals.

entry.def: A small dog; -- written also fise fyce fiste, etc.
See FitchÉ.
A white crystallized mineral resin from the Fichtelgebirge, Bavaria.

entry.ety: F., neckerchief
entry.def: A light cape, usually of lace, worn by women, to cover the neck and throat, and extending to the shoulders.

entry.ety: OE. fikel untrustworthy, deceitful, AS. ficol, fr. fic gefic, fraud, deceit; cf. fācen deceit, OS. f�kn, OHG. feichan, Icel. feikn portent. Cf. Fidget
entry.def: Not fixed or firm; liable to change; unstable; of a changeable mind; not firm in opinion or purpose; inconstant; capricious; as, Fortune's fickle wheel.
entry.q: They know how fickle common lovers are.
entry.syn: Wavering; irresolute; unsettled; vacillating; unstable; inconsonant; unsteady; variable; mutable; changeful; capricious; veering; shifting.

entry.def: The quality of being fickle; instability; inconsonancy.
In a fickle manner.

entries.entry:
‖Fi"co n.; pl.Ficoes #. It., a fig, fr. L.ficus. See Fig
A fig; an insignificant trifle, no more than the snap of one's thumb; a sign of contempt made by the fingers, expressing. A fig for you. Steal! foh, a fico for the phrase.

cs.cd: ware made of any material which is molded or shaped while soft; hence, pottery of any sort.

entry.ety: L. fictilis. See Fiction
entry.def: Molded, or capable of being molded, into form by art; relating to pottery or to molding in any soft material.
entry.q: Fictile earth is more fragile than crude earth.
The earliest specimens of Italian fictile art.

entry.usage: Fiction Fabrication. Fiction is opposed to what is real; fabrication to what is true. Fiction is designed commonly to amuse, and sometimes to instruct; a fabrication is always intended to mislead and deceive. In the novels of Sir Walter Scott we have fiction of the highest order. The poems of Ossian, so called, were chiefly fabrications by Macpherson.
entry.ety: F. fiction, L. fictio, fr. fingere fictum to form, shape, invent, feign. See Feign

sn.def: The act of feigning, inventing, or imagining; as, by a mere fiction of the mind.
That which is feigned, invented, or imagined; especially, a feigned or invented story, whether oral or written. Hence: A story told in order to deceive; a fabrication; -- opposed to fact, or reality.
sn.q: The fiction of those golden apples kept by a dragon.
When it could no longer be denied that her flight had been voluntary, numerous fictions were invented to account for it.

sn.def: Fictitious literature; comprehensively, all works of imagination; specifically, novels and romances.
sn.q: The office of fiction as a vehicle of instruction and moral elevation has been recognized by most if not all great educators.

sn.def: An assumption of a possible thing as a fact, irrespective of the question of its truth.
Any like assumption made for convenience, as for passing more rapidly over what is not disputed, and arriving at points really at issue.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or characterized by, fiction; fictitious; romantic.
entry.q: Fictionalrather than historical.

entry.def: A writer of fiction.
Fictitious.

entry.ety: L. fictitius. See Fiction
entry.def: Feigned; imaginary; not real; fabulous; counterfeit; false; not genuine; as, fictitious fame.
entry.q: The human persons are as fictitious as the airy ones.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fictif
entry.def: Feigned; counterfeit.
entry.q: The fount offictivetears.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: An artist who models or forms statues and reliefs in any plastic material.

entry.note: ☞ Ficus Indica is the banyan tree; F. religiosa, the peepul tree; F. elastica, the India-rubber tree.
entry.ety: L., a fig
entry.def: A genus of trees or shrubs, one species of which (F. Carica) produces the figs of commerce; the fig tree.

entry.note: ☞ There are hand fids and standing fidswhich are larger than the others, and stand upon a flat base). An iron implement for this purpose is called a marline spike.
entry.ety: Prov. E. fid a small, thick lump

sn.def: A square bar of wood or iron, used to support the topmast, being passed through a hole or mortise at its heel, and resting on the trestle trees.
A wooden or metal bar or pin, used to support or steady anything.
A pin of hard wood, tapering to a point, used to open the strands of a rope in splicing.
A block of wood used in mounting and dismounting heavy guns.

entry.ety: Pg. See Hidalgo
entry.def: The lowest title of nobility in Portugal, corresponding to that of Hidalgo in Spain.

entry.cs:
Fiddle beetle Zoöl a Japanese carabid beetle (Damaster blaptoides); -- so called from the form of the body. Fiddle block Naut a long tackle block having two sheaves of different diameters in the same plane, instead of side by side as in a common double block. Knight. Fiddle bow fiddlestick. Fiddle fish Zoöl the angel fish. Fiddle head See fiddle head in the vocabulary. Fiddle pattern a form of the handles of spoons, forks, etc., somewhat like a violin. Scotch fiddle, the itch. (Low) To play first fiddleorTo play second fiddle
to take a leading or a subordinate part. Colloq
entry.ety: OE. fidele fithele, AS. fiðele; akin to D. vedel, OHG. fidula, G. fiedel, Icel. fiðla, and perh. to E. viol. Cf. Viol

sn.def: A stringed instrument of music played with a bow; a violin; a kit.
A kind of dock (Rumex pulcher) with fiddle-shaped leaves; -- called also fiddle dock.
A rack or frame of bars connected by strings, to keep table furniture in place on the cabin table in bad weather.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fiddled; p. pr. & vb. n. Fiddling

sn.def: To play on a fiddle.
sn.q: Themistocles . . . said he could not fiddle, but he could make a small town a great city.

sn.def: To keep the hands and fingers actively moving as a fiddler does; to move the hands and fingers restlessy or in busy idleness; to trifle.
sn.q: Talking, and fiddling with their hats and feathers.

entry.def: To play (a tune) on a fiddle.
An exclamatory word or phrase, equivalent to nonsense!
the symbol for the element Fermium.
A trifle; trifling talk; nonsense.
To talk nonsense.

sn.def: any of several tall ferns of northern temperate regions having graceful arched fronds and sporophylls resembling ostrich plumes.
sn.syn: ostrich fern, shuttlecock fern, Matteuccia struthiopteris Pteretis struthiopteris Onoclea struthiopteris.

sn.def: New World fern (Osmunda cinnamonea) having woolly cinnamon-colored spore-bearing fronds in early spring later surrounded by green fronds, called also fiddlehead fern; the early uncurling fronds are edible, and sometimes considered as a vegetable delicacy.
sn.syn: cinnamon fern, fiddlehead fern, Osmunda cinnamonea.

sn.def: an ornament on a ship's bow, curved like the volute or scroll at the head of a violin. Sometimes it serves the function of a billhead.

entry.def: hairy annual plant (Phacelia tanacetifolia) of California to Mexico with crowded cymes of small blue to lilac or mauve flowers.
shaped like a fiddle; -- of a leaf shape.

entry.cs: Fiddler crab. Zoöl See Fiddler n., 2.
entry.ety: AS. fiðelere

sn.def: One who plays on a fiddle or violin.

A burrowing crab of the genus Gelasimus, of many species. The male has one claw very much enlarged, and often holds it in a position similar to that in which a musician holds a fiddle, hence the name; -- called also fiddler crab calling crab soldier crab, and fighting crab.
The common European sandpiper (Tringoides hypoleucus); -- so called because it continually oscillates its body.

entry.def: Inversely ovate, with a deep hollow on each side.
The bow, strung with horsehair, used in playing the fiddle; a fiddle bow.
One of the catgut strings of a fiddle.

entry.ety: Corrupted fr. F. bois-fidèle, lit., faithful wood; -- so called from its durability.]
entry.def: The wood of several West Indian trees, mostly of the genus Citharexylum.

entry.ety: L. fidejussio, from fidejubere to be surety or bail; fides faith + jubere to order: cf. F. fidéjussion
entry.def: The act or state of being bound as surety for another; suretyship.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. fidéjusseur
entry.def: A surety; one bound for another, conjointly with him; a guarantor.

entries.entry:
Fi*del"i*ty n. L. fidelitas: cf. F. fidélité. See Fealty
Faithfulness; adherence to right; careful and exact observance of duty, or discharge of obligations. Especially: Adherence to a person or party to which one is bound; loyalty. Whose courageous fidelity was proof to all danger. The best security for the fidelity of men is to make interest coincide with duty. Adherence to the marriage contract. Adherence to truth; veracity; honesty. The principal thing required in a witness is fidelity. Faithfulness; honesty; integrity; faith; loyalty; fealty.

entry.ety: L., faith
entry.def: Faith personified as a goddess; the goddess of faith.
See Fidget.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fidgeted; p. pr. & vb. n. Fodgeting
entry.ety: From Fidge; cf. OE. fiken to fidget, to flatter, Icel. fika to hasten, Sw. fika to hunt after, AS. befician to deceive. Cf. Fickle
entry.def: To move uneasily one way and the other; to move irregularly, or by fits and starts.

sn.def: Uneasiness; restlessness.
A general nervous restlessness, manifested by incessant changes of position; dysphoria.

entry.def: Quality of being fidgety.
Restless; uneasy.

entry.ety: NL., prob. fr. L. fidus trusty
entry.def: A genus of small beetles, of which one species (the grapevine Fidia, F. longipes) is very injurious to vines in America.

entry.ety: L. fidicinus, fr. fidicen -inis, a lute player
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a stringed instrument.

cs.cd: the straight edge of the alidade or ruler along which a straight line is to be drawn.
a line or point of reference, as for setting a graduated circle or scale used for measurments.

entry.ety: L. fiducia trust, confidence; akin to fides faith. See Faith

sn.def: Having faith or trust; confident; undoubting; firm.
sn.q: Fiducialreliance on the promises of God.

sn.def: Having the nature of a trust; fiduciary; as, fiducial power.

entry.def: With confidence.

entry.ety: L. fiduciarus, fr. fiducia: cf. F. fiduciaire. See Fiducial

sn.def: Involving confidence or trust; confident; undoubting; faithful; firm; as, in a fiduciary capacity.
sn.q: Fiduciaryobedience.

sn.def: Holding, held, or founded, in trust.
One who holds a thing in trust for another; a trustee.
sn.q: Instrumental to the conveying God's blessing upon those whose fiduciaries they are.

sn.def: One who depends for salvation on faith, without works; an Antinomian.

entry.ety: OE. fi; cf. D. fif. G. pfui, Icel. f�, Sw. & Dan. fy, F. fi, L. fi phy
entry.def: An exclamation denoting contempt or dislike. See Fy.

entry.ety: F. fief; of German origin, and the same word as E. fee. See Fee, and cf. Feud, a tief
entry.def: An estate held of a superior on condition of military service; a fee; a feud. See under Benefice n., 2.

entry.note: ☞ Field is often used adjectively in the sense of belonging to, or used in the fields; especially with reference to the operations and equipments of an army during a campaign away from permanent camps and fortifications. In most cases such use of the word is sufficiently clear; as, field battery; field fortification; field gun; field hospital, etc. A field geologist, naturalist, etc., is one who makes investigations or collections out of doors. A survey uses a field book for recording field notes, i.e., measurment, observations, etc., made in field work (outdoor operations). A farmer or planter employs field hands, and may use a field roller or a field derrick. Field sports are hunting, fishing, athletic games, etc.
entry.cs:
Coal field Geol See under Coal. Field artillery light ordnance mounted on wheels, for the use of a marching army. Field basil Bot a plant of the Mint family (Calamintha Acinos); -- called also basil thyme. Field colors Mil small flags for marking out the positions for squadrons and battalions; camp colors. Field cricket Zoöl a large European cricket (Gryllus campestric), remarkable for its loud notes. Field day. A day in the fields. Mil A day when troops are taken into the field for instruction in evolutions. Farrow. A day of unusual exertion or display; a gala day. Field driver in New England, an officer charged with the driving of stray cattle to the pound. Field duck Zoöl the little bustard (Otis tetrax), found in Southern Europe. Field glass. Optics A binocular telescope of compact form; a lorgnette; a race glass. A small achromatic telescope, from 20 to 24 inches long, and having 3 to 6 draws. See Field lens. Field lark. Zoöl The skylark. The tree pipit. Field lens Optics that one of the two lenses forming the eyepiece of an astronomical telescope or compound microscope which is nearer the object glass; -- called also field glass. Field madder Bot a plant (Sherardia arvensis) used in dyeing. Field marshal Mil the highest military rank conferred in the British and other European armies. Field officer Mil an officer above the rank of captain and below that of general.
