Field officer's court U.S.Army a court-martial consisting of one field officer empowered to try all cases, in time of war, subject to jurisdiction of garrison and regimental courts. Farrow. Field plover Zoöl the black-bellied plover (Charadrius squatarola); also sometimes applied to the Bartramian sandpiper (Bartramia longicauda). Field spaniel Zoöl a small spaniel used in hunting small game. Field sparrow. Zoöl A small American sparrow (Spizella pusilla). The hedge sparrow. Eng Field staff Mil a staff formerly used by gunners to hold a lighted match for discharging a gun. Field vole Zoöl the European meadow mouse. Field of ice a large body of floating ice; a pack.
FieldorField of view
in a telescope or microscope, the entire space within which objects are seen. Field magnet. see under Magnet. Magnetic field. See Magnetic.
To back the fieldorTo bet on the field. See under Back v. t.
To keep the field . Mil To continue a campaign. To maintain one's ground against all comers.
To lay against the fieldorTo back against the field
to bet on (a horse, etc.) against all comers. To take the field Mil to enter upon a campaign.
entry.ety: OE. feld fild, AS. feld; akin to D. veld, G. feld, Sw. fält, Dan. felt, Icel. fold field of grass, AS. folde earth, land, ground, OS. folda

sn.def: Cleared land; land suitable for tillage or pasture; cultivated ground; the open country.
A piece of land of considerable size; esp., a piece inclosed for tillage or pasture.
sn.q: Fields which promise corn and wine.

sn.def: A place where a battle is fought; also, the battle itself.
sn.q: In this glorious and well-foughten field.
What though the field be lost?

entry.sn:
An open space; an extent; an expanse. Esp.: Any blank space or ground on which figures are drawn or projected.
The space covered by an optical instrument at one view. Without covering, save yon field of stars. Ask of yonder argent fields above.

sn.def: The whole surface of an escutcheon; also, so much of it is shown unconcealed by the different bearings upon it. See Illust. of Fess, where the field is represented as gules (red), while the fess is argent (silver).
An unresticted or favorable opportunity for action, operation, or achievement; province; room.
sn.q: Afforded a clear field for moral experiments.

sn.def: A collective term for all the competitors in any outdoor contest or trial, or for all except the favorites in the betting.
That part of the grounds reserved for the players which is outside of the diamond; -- called also outfield.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fielded; p. pr. & vb. n. Fielding

sn.def: To take the field.
To stand out in the field, ready to catch, stop, or throw the ball.

entry.def: To catch, stop, throw, etc. (the ball), as a fielder.
Engaged in the field; encamped.
entry.q: To help fielded friends.

entry.def: Consisting of fields.
entry.q: The fielden country also and plains.

entry.def: A ball payer who stands out in the field to catch or stop balls.

entry.ety: OE. feldfare, AS. feldfare; field + faran to travel
entry.def: a small thrush (Turdus pilaris) which breeds in northern Europe and winters in Great Britain. The head, nape, and lower part of the back are ash-colored; the upper part of the back and wing coverts, chestnut; -- called also fellfare.
The act of playing as a fielder.

sn.def: any nocturnal Old World mouse of the genus Apodemus inhabing woods and fields and gardens.
any mouse inhabiting fields, as the campagnol and the deer mouse. See Campagnol, and Deer mouse.

entry.def: A cannon mounted on wheels, for the use of a marching army; a piece of field artillery; -- called also field gun.
a member of the cricket team that is fielding rather than batting.

to test something in the field, i. e. under the actual conditions under which it will be used; as, The Army field-tested the new tanks. Used in contrast with testing in a laboratory or under controlled conditions.
Any temporary fortification thrown up by an army in the field; -- commonly in the plural.
entry.q: All works which do not come under the head of permanent fortification are called fieldworks.

entry.def: Open, like a field.

entry.ety: OE. fend find fiend feond, fiend, foe, AS. feónd; akin to OS. fīond, D. vijand enemy, OHG. fīant, G. feind, Icel. fjānd, Sw. & Dan. fiende, Goth. fijands; orig. p. pr. of a verb meaning to hate, AS. feón feógan, OHG. fī�n, Goth. fijan, Skr. pīy to scorn; prob. akin to E. feud a quarrel. √81. Cf. Foe Friend
entry.def: An implacable or malicious foe; one who is diabolically wicked or cruel; an infernal being; -- applied specifically to the devil or a demon.
entry.q: Into this wild abyss the wary fiend Stood on the brink of Hell and looked a while.
O woman! woman! when to ill thy mind Is bent, all hell contains no fouler fiend.

entry.def: Full of fiendish spirit or arts.
Like a fiend; diabolically wicked or cruel; infernal; malignant; devilish; hellish.
Fiendish; diabolical.

entry.ety: AS. feóndlic
entry.def: Fiendlike; monstrous; devilish.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A genus of small, slender fishes, remarkable for their habit of living as commensals in other animals. One species inhabits the gill cavity of the pearl oyster near Panama; another lives within an East Indian holothurian.

entry.ety: OE. fers fiers, OF. fier, nom. fiers, fierce, savage, cruel, F. fier proud, from L. ferus wild, savage, cruel; perh. akin to E. bear the animal. Cf. Feral Ferocity

sn.def: Furious; violent; unrestrained; impetuous; as, a fierce wind.
sn.q: His fierce thunder drove us to the deep.

sn.def: Vehement in anger or cruelty; ready or eager to kill or injure; of a nature to inspire terror; ferocious.
sn.q: Afiercewhisper.
Afiercetyrant.
The fierce foe hung upon our broken rear.
Thou huntest me as a fierce lion.

sn.def: Excessively earnest, eager, or ardent.
sn.syn: Ferocious; savage; cruel; vehement; impetuous; barbarous; fell. See Ferocious.

entry.def: the quality of being fierce; ferocity; fury; vehemence.
entry.syn: ferocity, furiousness, fury, vehemence, violence, wildness, strength.

entries.entry: ‖Fi"e*ri fa"ci*as. L., cause it to be done Law A judicial writ that lies for one who has recovered in debt or damages, commanding the sheriff that he cause to be made of the goods, chattels, or real estate of the defendant, the sum claimed.

entry.def: The quality of being fiery; heat; acrimony; irritability; as, a fieriness of temper.

cs.cd: a cross constructed of two firebrands, and pitched upon the point of a spear; formerly in Scotland borne by a runner as a signal for the clan to take up arms.

entry.ety: Formerly written firy, fr. fire

sn.def: Consisting of, containing, or resembling, fire; as, the fiery gulf of Etna; a fiery appearance.
sn.q: And fiery billows roll below.

sn.def: Vehement; ardent; very active; impetuous.
sn.q: Hath thy fiery heart so parched thine entrails?
The fiery spirit of his forefathers.

sn.def: Passionate; easily provoked; irritable.
sn.q: You know the fiery quality of the duke.

sn.def: Unrestrained; fierce; mettlesome; spirited.
sn.q: One curbed the fiery steed.

sn.def: heated by fire, or as if by fire; burning hot; parched; feverish.
sn.q: The sword which is made fiery.

entry.ety: Sp. See Feast n.

sn.def: Among Spanish, a religious festival; a saint's day or holiday; also, a holiday or festivity.
sn.q: Even . . . a bullfight is a fiesta.
Some fiesta, when all the surrounding population were expected to turn out in holiday dress for merriment.

sn.def: an organized series of acts and performances.

entry.cs: Fife major Mil a noncommissioned officer who superintends the fifers of a regiment. Fife rail. Naut A rail about the mast, at the deck, to hold belaying pins, etc. A railing around the break of a poop deck.
entry.ety: F. fifre, OHG. pfīfa, LL. pipa pipe, pipare to play on the pipe, fr. L. pipire pipare, to peep, pip, chirp, as a chiken. See Pipe
entry.def: A small shrill pipe, resembling the piccolo flute, used chiefly to accompany the drum in military music.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fifed; p. pr. & vb. n. fifing
entry.def: To play on a fife.
One who plays on a fife.

entry.ety: acronym, First In First Out

sn.def: an accounting method in which goods in inventory are valued at the price of the most recent acquisition of each type of goods, and those used up from inventory are valued at the cost of those first acquired.

entry.ety: OE. fiftene, AS. fīftȳne fīftēne. See Five, and Ten, and cf. Fifty
entry.def: Five and ten; one more than fourteen.

sn.def: The sum of five and ten; fifteen units or objects.
A symbol representing fifteen units, as 15, or xv.

entry.ety: OE. fiftenthe; cf. fiftethe, AS. fīfteōða. See Fifteen

sn.def: Next in order after the fourteenth; -- the ordinal of fifteen.
Consisting of one of fifteen equal parts or divisions of a thing.
One of fifteen equal parts or divisions; the quotient of a unit divided by fifteen.
A species of tax upon personal property formerly laid on towns, boroughs, etc., in England, being one fifteenth part of what the personal property in each town, etc., had been valued at.

sd.def: A stop in an organ tuned two octaves above the diaposon.
An interval consisting of two octaves.

cs.cd: a fanatical sect in England, of the time of the commonwealth, who maintained that there would be a fifth universal monarchy, during which Christ would reign on earth a thousand years.
a horizontal wheel or segment above the fore axle of a carriage and beneath the body, forming an extended support to prevent careening.

entry.ety: OE. fifte fifthe, AS. fīfta. See Five

sn.def: Next in order after the fourth; -- the ordinal of five.
Consisting of one of five equal divisions of a thing.
The quotient of a unit divided by five; one of five equal parts; a fifth part.
The interval of three tones and a semitone, embracing five diatonic degrees of the scale; the dominant of any key.

entry.ety: from a statement during the Spanish Civil War (1936) that the Falange had four columns of soldiers marching on the city, and a fifth column “already there” (i.e. sympathizers inside the Republican lines)

sn.def: a group of persons inside the battle lines of a territory engaged in a conflict, who secretly sympathize with the enemy, and who engage in espionage or sabotage; -- sometimes also referred to as a trojan horse.
Hence, any faction of persons within a group who secretly sympathize with an enemy, especially those who engage in activities harmful to the group; an enemy in one's midst; a group of traitors.

entry.def: In the fifth place; as the fifth in order.

sn.def: the decade from 1950 to 1959.
the time of life between 50 and 60.

entry.ety: AS. fīftigoða. See Fifty

sn.def: Next in order after the forty-ninth; -- the ordinal of fifty.
Consisting of one of fifty equal parts or divisions.

entry.def: One of fifty equal parts; the quotient of a unit divided by fifty.

entry.ety: AS. fīftig; akin to OHG. finfzug fimfzuc, G. fünfzig funfzig, Goth. fimftigjus. See Five, and Ten, and cf. Fifteen
entry.def: Five times ten; as, fifty men.

entries.entry:
Fif"ty n.; pl.Fifties.
The sum of five tens; fifty units or objects.
A symbol representing fifty units, as 50, or l.

entry.def: equally large; -- of probabilities.
a lottery in which the organizers retain fifty percent of the money wagered, and distribute fifty percent of the wagered money to the winner.

entry.note: ☞ The fruit of a fig tree is really the hollow end of a stem, and bears numerous achenia inside the cavity. Many species have little, hard, inedible figs, and in only a few does the fruit become soft and pulpy. The fruit of the cultivated varieties is much prized in its fresh state, and also when dried or preserved. See Caprification.
entry.cs: Cochineal fig. See Conchineal fig. Fig dust a preparation of fine oatmeal for feeding caged birds. Fig faun one of a class of rural deities or monsters supposed to live on figs. “Therefore shall dragons dwell there with the fig fauns.” Jer. i. 39. (Douay version). Fig gnat Zoöl a small fly said to be injurious to figs. Fig leaf the leaf tree; hence, in allusion to the first clothing of Adam and Eve (Genesis iii.7), a covering for a thing that ought to be concealed; esp., an inadequate covering; a symbol for affected modesty. Fig marigold Bot the name of several plants of the genus Mesembryanthemum, some of which are prized for the brilliancy and beauty of their flowers. Fig tree Bot any tree of the genus Ficus, but especially F. Carica which produces the fig of commerce.
entry.ety: F. figue the fruit of the tree, Pr. figa, fr. L. ficus fig tree, fig. Cf. Fico

sn.def: A small fruit tree (Ficus Carica) with large leaves, known from the remotest antiquity. It was probably native from Syria westward to the Canary Islands.
The fruit of a fig tree, which is of round or oblong shape, and of various colors.
A small piece of tobacco.
The value of a fig, practically nothing; a fico; -- used in scorn or contempt.
sn.q: Afigfor Peter.

entry.ety: See Fico Fig n.

sn.def: To insult with a fico, or contemptuous motion. See Fico.
sn.q: When Pistol lies, do this, and fig me like The bragging Spaniard.

sn.def: To put into the head of, as something useless o� contemptible.

entry.def: Figure; dress; array.
entry.q: Were they all in full fig, the females with feathers on their heads, the males with chapeaux bras?

entry.ety: From the name of the barber in Beaumarchais' “Barber of Seville.”
entry.def: An adroit and unscrupulous intriguer.

entry.ety: Corrupted fr. vagary
entry.def: A frolic; a vagary; a whim.
A large beetle (Allorhina nitida) which in the Southern United States destroys figs. The elytra are velvety green with pale borders.
A bird. See Figpecker.
Fidgety; restless.
entry.q: Such a little figent thing.

sn.def: The leaf from a fig tree.

An ornamental design shaped like the leaf of a fig tree, used in architecture; also, a design shaped like a fig leaf to cover genitalia in sculpture or paintings -- in reference to the biblical story in Genesis of Adam and Eve, who covered their privates with fig leaves.
Anything used to conceal what is considered embarrassing or indecent. See sense 2.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A juggler's trick; conjuring.
entry.q: The devil is the author of wicked figgum.

cs.cd: to avoid meeting fairly or at close quarters; to keep out of reach.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fought f�t; p. pr. & vb. n. Fighting
entry.ety: OE. fihten fehten, AS. feohtan; akin to D. vechten, OHG. fehtan, G. fechten, Sw. fäkta, Dan. fegte, and perh. to E. fist; cf. L. pugnare to fight, pugnus fist

sn.def: To strive or contened for victory, with armies or in single combat; to attempt to defeat, subdue, or destroy an enemy, either by blows or weapons; to contend in arms; -- followed by with or against.
sn.q: You do fight against your country's foes.
To fight with thee no man of arms will deign.

sn.def: To act in opposition to anything; to struggle against; to contend; to strive; to make resistance.

cs.cd: to fight until a decisive and conclusive result is reached.

sn.def: To carry on, or wage, as a conflict, or battle; to win or gain by struggle, as one's way; to sustain by fighting, as a cause.
sn.q: He had to fight his way through the world.
I have fought a good fight.

sn.def: To contend with in battle; to war against; as, they fought the enemy in two pitched battles; the sloop fought the frigate for three hours.
To cause to fight; to manage or maneuver in a fight; as, to fight cocks; to fight one's ship.

cs.cd: a fight in which the enemy is continually chased; also, one which continues without definite end or result.

entry.ety: OE. fight feht, AS. feoht. See Fight v. i.

sn.def: A battle; an engagement; a contest in arms; a combat; a violent conflict or struggle for victory, between individuals or between armies, ships, or navies, etc.
sn.q: Who now defies thee thrice to single fight.

sn.def: A struggle or contest of any kind.
Strength or disposition for fighting; pugnacity; as, he has a great deal of fight in him.
A screen for the combatants in ships.
sn.q: Up with your fights, and your nettings prepare.
sn.syn: Combat; engagement; contest; struggle; encounter; fray; affray; action; conflict. See Battle.

entry.ety: AS. feohtere

sn.def: One who fights; a combatant; a warrior.
A boxer; a pugilist.
A person with the determination and will to persist through great difficulty to achieve a goal; one with the courage to fight and resist an opponent, and to struggle with all one's powers.

A military aircraft designed to seek out and destroy enemy aircraft; it is usually smaller and more maneuvarable than aircraft designed specifically for bombing. However, hybrid fighter-bomber aircraft that perform both functions also are used.

cs.cd: one dependent upon the issue of a struggle.
the fiddler crab.
a remarkably pugnacious East Indian fish (Betta pugnax), reared by the Siamese for spectacular fish fights.

sn.def: Qualified for war; fit for battle.
sn.q: An host of fighting men.

sn.def: Occupied in war; being the scene of a battle; as, a fighting field.

entry.def: Pugnaciously.

entry.ety: Fight + wite
entry.def: A mulct or fine imposed on a person for making a fight or quarrel to the disturbance of the peace.

entry.ety: L. figmentum, fr. fingere to form, shape, invent, feign. See Feign
entry.def: An invention; a fiction; something feigned or imagined.
entry.q: Social figments, feints, and formalism.
It carried rather an appearance of figment and invention . . . than of truth and reality.

entry.def: The European garden warbler (Sylvia hortensisorCurrica, hortensis); -- called also beccafico and greater pettychaps.
A marine univalve shell of the genus Pyrula, or Ficula, resembling a fig in form.

entry.ety: L. figulatus, p. p. of figulare to shape, fr. figulus potter, fr. fingere to shape
entry.def: Made of potter's clay; molded; shaped.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. figulina pottery, fr. figulus. See Figulate
entry.def: A piece of pottery ornamented with representations of natural objects.
entry.q: Whose figulines and rustic wares Scarce find him bread from day to day.

entry.ety: L. figulinus. See Figulate

sn.def: Suitable for the making of pottery; fictile; -- said of clay.
Made of clay, as by the potter; -- said of vessels, ornamental figures, or the like; as, figuline ware.

entry.ety: Cf. F. figurabilité
entry.def: The quality of being figurable.

entry.ety: L. figurare to form, shape, fr. figura figure: cf. F. figurable. See Figure
entry.def: Capable of being brought to a fixed form or shape.
entry.q: Lead is figurable, but water is not.

entry.cs: Figural numbers. See Figurate numbers, under Figurate.
entry.ety: From Figure

sn.def: Represented by figure or delineation; consisting of figures; as, figural ornaments.
Figurate. See Figurate.

entry.ety: F., prop. p. pr. of figurer figure, represent, make a figure
entry.def: One who dances at the opera, not singly, but in groups or figures; an accessory character on the stage, who figures in its scenes, but has nothing to say; hence, one who figures in any scene, without taking a prominent part.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A female figurant; esp., a ballet girl.

cs.cd: that which is not simple, or in which the parts do not move together tone for tone, but in which freer movement of one or more parts mingles passing discords with the harmony; -- called also figural figurative, and figured counterpoint or descantalthough the term figured is more commonly applied to a bass with numerals written above or below to indicate the other notes of the harmony).

numbers, or series of numbers, formed from any arithmetical progression in which the first term is a unit, and the difference a whole number, by taking the first term, and the sums of the first two, first three, first four, etc., as the successive terms of a new series, from which another may be formed in the same manner, and so on, the numbers in the resulting series being such that points representing them are capable of symmetrical arrangement in different geometrical figures, as triangles, squares, pentagons, etc.
cs.note: In the following example, the two lower lines are composed of figurate numbers, those in the second line being triangular, and represented thus: . 1, 2, 3, 4, etc. . . . 1, 3, 6, 10, etc. . . . . . . . etc. 1, 4, 10, 20, etc . . . . . . . . . . . .

entry.ety: L. figuratus, p. p. of figurare. See Figure

sn.def: Of a definite form or figure.
sn.q: Plants are all figurate and determinate, which inanimate bodies are not.

sn.def: Figurative; metaphorical.
Florid; figurative; involving passing discords by the freer melodic movement of one or more parts or voices in the harmony; as, figurate counterpoint or descant.

entry.def: Having a determinate form.
In a figurate manner.

entry.ety: L. figuratio

sn.def: The act of giving figure or determinate form; determination to a certain form.
Mixture of concords and discords.

entry.cs: Figurative counterpointorFigurative descant . See under Figurate.
entry.ety: L. figurativus: cf. F. figuratif. See Figurative

sn.def: Representing by a figure, or by resemblance; typical; representative.
sn.q: This, they will say, was figurative, and served, by God's appointment, but for a time, to shadow out the true glory of a more divine sanctity.

sn.def: Used in a sense that is tropical, as a metaphor; not literal; -- applied to words and expressions.
Abounding in figures of speech; flowery; florid; as, a highly figurative description.
Relating to the representation of form or figure by drawing, carving, etc. See Figure n., 2.
sn.q: They belonged to a nation dedicated to the figurative arts, and they wrote for a public familiar with painted form.

entry.note:
☞ Figures are often written upon the staff in music to denote the kind of measure. They are usually in the form of a fraction, the upper figure showing how many notes of the kind indicated by the lower are contained in one measure or bar. Thus, 2/4 signifies that the measure contains two quarter notes. The following are the principal figures used for this purpose:
2/2 2/4 2/8 4/2 2/4 4/8 3/2 3/4 3/8 6/4 6/4 6/8
entry.cs:
Academy figure Canceled figures Lay figure, etc. See under Academy Cancel Lay, etc.
Figure casterorFigure flinger
an astrologer. “This figure caster.” Milton. Figure flinging the practice of astrology. Figure-of-eight knot a knot shaped like the figure 8. See Illust. under Knot. Figure painting a picture of the human figure, or the act or art of depicting the human figure. Figure stone Min agalmatolite. Figure weaving the art or process of weaving figured fabrics. To cut a figure to make a display. Colloq Sir W. Scott.
entry.ety: F., figure, L. figura; akin to fingere to form, shape, feign. See Feign

sn.def: The form of anything; shape; outline; appearance.
sn.q: Flowers have all exquisite figures.

sn.def: The representation of any form, as by drawing, painting, modeling, carving, embroidering, etc.; especially, a representation of the human body; as, a figure in bronze; a figure cut in marble.
sn.q: A coin that bears the figure of an angel.

sn.def: A pattern in cloth, paper, or other manufactured article; a design wrought out in a fabric; as, the muslin was of a pretty figure .

A diagram or drawing, made to represent a magnitude or the relation of two or more magnitudes; a surface or space inclosed on all sides; -- called superficial when inclosed by lines, and solid when inclosed by surfaces; any arrangement made up of points, lines, angles, surfaces, etc.
The appearance or impression made by the conduct or career of a person; as, a sorry figure .
sn.q: I made some figure there.
Gentlemen of the best figure in the county.

sn.def: Distinguished appearance; magnificence; conspicuous representation; splendor; show.
sn.q: That he may live in figure and indulgence.

sn.def: A character or symbol representing a number; a numeral; a digit; as, 1, 2,3, etc.
Value, as expressed in numbers; price; as, the goods are estimated or sold at a low figure .
sn.q: With nineteen thousand a year at the very lowest figure.

sn.def: A person, thing, or action, conceived of as analogous to another person, thing, or action, of which it thus becomes a type or representative.
sn.q: Who is the figure of Him that was to come.

sn.def: A mode of expressing abstract or immaterial ideas by words which suggest pictures or images from the physical world; pictorial language; a trope; hence, any deviation from the plainest form of statement. Also called a figure of speech.
sn.q: To represent the imagination under the figure of a wing.

sn.def: The form of a syllogism with respect to the relative position of the middle term.
Any one of the several regular steps or movements made by a dancer.
A horoscope; the diagram of the aspects of the astrological houses.

sd.def: Any short succession of notes, either as melody or as a group of chords, which produce a single complete and distinct impression.
A form of melody or accompaniment kept up through a strain or passage; a musical phrase or motive; a florid embellishment.

cs.cd: to solve; to compute or find the result of.
to add; to reckon; to compute the amount of.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Figured; p. pr. & vb. n. Figuring
entry.ety: F. figurer, L. figurare, fr. figura. See Figure n.

sn.def: To represent by a figure, as to form or mold; to make an image of, either palpable or ideal; also, to fashion into a determinate form; to shape.
sn.q: If love, alas! be pain I bear,
No thought can figure, and no tongue declare.Prior.

sn.def: To embellish with design; to adorn with figures.
sn.q: The vaulty top of heavenFigured quite o'er with burning meteors.

sn.def: To indicate by numerals; also, to compute.
sn.q: As through a crystal glass the figured hours are seen.

sn.def: To represent by a metaphor; to signify or symbolize.
sn.q: Whose white vestments figure innocence.

sn.def: To prefigure; to foreshow.
sn.q: In this the heaven figures some event.

sd.def: To write over or under the bass, as figures or other characters, in order to indicate the accompanying chords.
To embellish.

cs.cd: a phrase used by itself as an interjection to mean “How can one explain that?”, or to express puzzlement over some seeming contradiction.

sn.def: To make a figure; to be distinguished or conspicious; as, the envoy figured at court.
sn.q: Sociable, hospitable, eloquent, admired, figuring away brilliantly.

sn.def: To calculate; to contrive; to scheme; as, he is figuring to secure the nomination.

entry.cs: Figured bass. See Continued bass, under Continued.

sn.def: Adorned with figures; marked with figures; as, figured muslin.
Not literal; figurative.

sd.def: Free and florid; as, a figured descant. See Figurate, 3.
Indicated or noted by figures.

sn.def: The figure, statue, or bust, on the prow of a ship.
A person who allows his name to be used to give standing to enterprises in which he has no responsible interest or duties; a nominal, but not real, head or chief.

entry.def: Represented by figure or delineation.

entry.ety: F., dim. of figure
entry.def: A very small figure, whether human or of an animal; especially, one in terra cotta or the like; -- distinguished from statuette, which is applied to small figures in bronze, marble, etc.
One who uses or interprets figurative expressions.
A genus of herbaceous plants (Scrophularia), mostly found in the north temperate zones. See Brownwort.
Of or pertaining to the Fiji islands or their inhabitants.

def2.def: A native of the Fiji islands.

entry.def: See Fyke.
imp. of Fall v. i. Fell.

entry.ety: L. filum thread
entry.def: Composed of threads.

entry.ety: OE. filace a file, or thread, on which the records of the courts of justice were strung, F. filasse tow of flax or hemp, fr. L. filum thread
entry.def: A former officer in the English Court of Common Pleas; -- so called because he filed the writs on which he made out process.

entry.ety: F. filament, fr. L. filum thread. See File a row
entry.def: A thread or threadlike object or appendage; a fiber;
the threadlike part of the stamen supporting the anther.
Having the character of, or formed by, a filament.

entry.ety: Filament + -oid
entry.def: Like a filament.

entry.ety: Cf. F. filamenteux
entry.def: Like a thread; consisting of threads or filaments.
A species of kangaroo (Macropus Brunii), inhabiting New Guinea.

entry.ety: F. filandres, fr. L. filum thread
entry.def: A disease in hawks, characterized by the presence of small threadlike worms, also of filaments of coagulated blood, from the rupture of a vein; -- called also backworm.

entry.ety: L. filum a thread
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a thread or line; characterized by threads stretched across the field of view; as, a filar microscope; a filar micrometer.

entries.entry: Fi*la"ri*a n.; pl.filariae. NL., fr. L. filum a thread Zoöl a small, slender nematode worm of the family Onchocercidae Filariidae) of many species, parasitic when adult in various animals, including man. They may live within the blood, or in other bodily fluids, or within tissues or cavities of the body. Infection with such organisms may be transmitted by blood-sucking arthropods.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. filum a thread
entry.def: a former genus comprised of certain nematodes, now classed as belonging to several genera within the family Onchocercidae. See Onchocerca and Guinea worm.

sn.def: Of, pertaining to, or caused by, filariæ and allied parasitic worms.
Straight, as if in a line; as, the filarial flight of birds.

entry.ety: NL

sn.def: the presence of filariae within the body of an organism; infection with filariae. It is mostly found in tropical and subtropical regions.

a disease caused by nematodes in the blood or tissues of the body causing blockage of lymphatic vessels. Death of the adult worms may lead to inflammation and permanent fibrosis; the condition may lead to serious symptoms, such as elephantiasis or blindness. See river blindness

entry.def: of or pertaining to family Filariidae.
a natural family consisting of threadlike roundworms, called filariae.

entry.ety: F., fr. fil thread, L. filum
entry.def: Vegetable fiber, as jute or ramie, prepared for manufacture.

entry.ety: LL. filatorium place for spinning, fr. filare to spin, fr. L. filum a thread
entry.def: A machine for forming threads.

entry.ety: LL. filatura, fr. filare to spin: cf. F. filature. See Filatory

sn.def: A drawing out into threads; hence, the reeling of silk from cocoons.
A reel for drawing off silk from cocoons; also, an establishment for reeling silk.

entry.note: ☞ In England filberts are usually large hazelnuts, especially the nuts from selected and cultivated trees. The American hazelnuts are of two other species, Corylus Americana and Corylus cornuta, and are also sometimes called filberts.

cs.cd: a gall resembling a filbert in form, growing in clusters on grapevines. It is produced by the larva of a gallfly (Cecidomyia).

entry.ety: Perh. fr. fill + bread, as filling the bread or husk; cf. G. bartnusslit., bread nut) filbert; or perh. named from a St.Philibert, whose day, Aug. 22, fell in the nutting season

sn.def: The fruit of the Corylus Avellana or Corylus maxima, also called the hazel; the hazelnut. It is an oval nut, containing a kernel that has a mild, farinaceous, oily taste, agreeable to the palate.
The tree bearing the filbert; the hazelnut tree.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Filched fĭlcht; p. pr. & vb. n. Filching
entry.ety: Cf. AS. feolan to stick to, OHG. felhan felahan, to hide, Icel. fela, Goth. filhan to hide, bury, Prov. E. feal to hide slyly, OE. felen
entry.def: To steal or take privily (commonly, that which is of little value); to pilfer.
entry.q: Fain would they filch that little food away.
But he that filches from me my good name, Robs me of that which not enriches him, And makes me poor indeed.

entry.def: One who filches; a thief.
By pilfering or petty stealing.

entry.note: ☞ The number of files in a company describes its width, as the number of ranks does its depth; thus, 100 men in “fours deep” would be spoken of as 25 files in 4 ranks. Farrow.
entry.cs:
File firing the act of firing by file, or each file independently of others. File leader the soldier at the front of any file, who covers and leads those in rear of him. File marching the marching of a line two deep, when faced to the right or left, so that the front and rear rank march side by side. Brande & C.
Indian fileorSingle file
a line of people marching one behind another; a single row. Also used adverbially; as, to march Indian file. On file preserved in an orderly collection; recorded in some database. Rank and file. The body of soldiers constituting the mass of an army, including corporals and privates. Wilhelm. Those who constitute the bulk or working members of a party, society, etc., in distinction from the leaders.
entry.ety: F. file row (cf. Pr., Sp., Pg., & It. fila), LL. fila, fr. L. filum a thread. Cf. Enfilade Filament Fillet
entry.sn:
An orderly succession; a line; a row; as: Mil A row of soldiers ranged one behind another; -- in contradistinction to rank, which designates a row of soldiers standing abreast; a number consisting the depth of a body of troops, which, in the ordinary modern formation, consists of two men, the battalion standing two deep, or in two ranks.
An orderly collection of papers, arranged in sequence or classified for preservation and reference; as, files of letters or of newspapers; this mail brings English files to the 15th instant.
The line, wire, or other contrivance, by which papers are put and kept in order. It is upon a file with the duke's other letters.
A roll or list. Afileof all the gentry.

sn.def: Course of thought; thread of narration.
sn.q: Let me resume the file of my narration.

sn.def: a collection of data on a digital recording medium treated as a unit for the purpose of recording, reading, storage, or indexing; -- such a file is typically accessible by computer programs by the use of a file name. The data may be of any type codable digitally, such as simple ASCII-coded text, complex binary-coded data, or an executable program, or may be itself a collection of other files.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Filed; p. pr. & vb. n. Filing

sn.def: To set in order; to arrange, or lay away, esp. as papers in a methodical manner for preservation and reverence; to place on file; to insert in its proper place in an arranged body of papers.
sn.q: I would have my several courses and my dishes well filed.

sn.def: To bring before a court or legislative body by presenting proper papers in a regular way; as, to file a petition or bill.
To put upon the files or among the records of a court; to note on (a paper) the fact date of its reception in court.
sn.q: To file a paper, on the part of a party, is to place it in the official custody of the clerk. To file, on the part of the clerk, is to indorse upon the paper the date of its reception, and retain it in his office, subject to inspection by whomsoever it may concern.

cs.cd: to follow closely, as one soldier after another in file; to keep pace.

entry.ety: Cf. F. filer
entry.def: To march in a file or line, as soldiers, not abreast, but one after another; -- generally with off.
entry.q: My endeavors Have ever come too short of my desires, Yet filed with my abilities.

entry.note: ☞ A file differs from a rasp in having the furrows made by straight cuts of a chisel, either single or crossed, while the rasp has coarse, single teeth, raised by the pyramidal end of a triangular punch.

cs.cd: etc. See under Bastard Cross, etc.
a file having two sets of teeth crossing obliquely.
a steel blank shaped and ground ready for cutting to form a file.
a maker of files.
a file having teeth of a grade next finer than bastard.
a file having only one set of parallel teeth; a float.
a file having teeth so fine as to make an almost smooth surface.

entry.ety: AS. feól; akin to D. viji, OHG. fīla fīhala, G. feile, Sw. fil, Dan. fiil, cf. Icel. þēl, Russ. pila, and Skr. piç to cut out, adorn; perh. akin to E. paint

sn.def: A steel instrument, having cutting ridges or teeth, made by indentation with a chisel, used for abrading or smoothing other substances, as metals, wood, etc.
Anything employed to smooth, polish, or rasp, literally or figuratively.
sn.q: Mock the nice touches of the critic's file.

sn.def: A shrewd or artful person.
sn.q: Will is an old file in spite of his smooth face.

sn.def: To rub, smooth, or cut away, with a file; to sharpen with a file; as, to file a saw or a tooth.
To smooth or polish as with a file.
sn.q: File your tongue to a little more courtesy.

entry.ety: OE. fulen filen foulen, AS. f�lan, fr. f�l foul. See Foul, and cf. Defile v. t.
entry.def: To make foul; to defile.
entry.q: All his hairy breast with blood was filed.
For Banquo's issue have I filed my mind.

entries.entry: File" clos`er. Mil A commissioned or noncommissioned officer posted in the rear of a line, or on the flank of a column, of soldiers, to rectify mistakes and insure steadiness and promptness in the ranks.

entry.def: Any plectognath fish of the genera Monacanthus Alutera balistes, and allied genera; -- so called on account of the roughly granulated skin, which is sometimes used in place of sandpaper.
See Feullemort.
One who works with a file.

entry.ety: L. filialis, fr. filius son, filia daughter; akin to e. female feminine. Cf. Fitz

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a son or daughter; becoming to a child in relation to his parents; as, filial obedience.
Bearing the relation of a child.
sn.q: And thus the filial Godhead answering spoke.

entry.def: In a filial manner.
To adopt as son or daughter; to establish filiation between.

entry.ety: LL. filiatio, fr. L. filius son: cf. F. filiation. See Filial

sn.def: The relationship of a son or child to a parent, esp. to a father.
sn.q: The relation of paternity and filiation.

sn.def: The assignment of a bastard child to some one as its father; affiliation.
Descent from, or as if from, a parent; relationship like that of a son; as, to determine the filiation of a language.
One that is derived from a parent or source; an offshoot; as, the filiations are from a common stock.

entry.ety: Gael. feileadhbeagi. e., little kilt; feileadh kilt + beag little, small; cf. filleadh a plait, fold
entry.def: Same as Kilt.

entry.ety: Sp. flibuster flibustero, corrupted fr. E. freebooter. See Freebooter
entry.def: A lawless military adventurer, especially one in quest of plunder; a freebooter; -- originally applied to buccaneers infesting the Spanish American coasts, but introduced into common English to designate the followers of Lopez in his expedition to Cuba in 1851, and those of Walker in his expedition to Nicaragua, in 1855.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fillibustered; p. pr. & vb. n. Filibustering

sn.def: To act as a filibuster, or military freebooter.
To delay legislation, by dilatory motions or other artifices.

entry.def: The characteristics or practices of a filibuster.
Belonging to the Filices, r ferns.

entry.ety: L. filix -icis, a fern
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, ferns; as, filicic acid.

entry.ety: L. filius son, filia daughter + caedere to kill
entry.def: The act of murdering a son or a daughter; also, parent who commits such a murder.

entry.ety: L. filix -icis, fern + -form: cf. F. filiciforme
entry.def: Shaped like a fern or like the parts of a fern leaf.

entry.ety: L. filix -icis, fern + -oid: cf. F. filicoiïde
entry.def: Fernlike, either in form or in the nature of the method of reproduction.
A fernlike plant.

entry.ety: L. filietas
entry.def: The relation of a son to a father; sonship; -- the correlative of paternity.

entry.ety: L. filum a thread + -ferous
entry.def: Producing threads.

entry.ety: L. filum thread + -form: cf. F. filiforme
entry.def: Having the shape of a thread or filament; as, the filiform papillæ of the tongue; a filiform style or peduncle. See Illust. of AntennÆ.

entry.ety: Sp. filigranacf. It. filigrana, E. filigrane), fr. L. filuma thread + granum grain. See File a row, and Grain, and cf. Filigree
entry.def: Filigree.
entry.q: With her head . . . touches the crown of filigrane.

entry.def: See Filigreed.

entry.ety: Corrupted fr. filigrane
entry.def: Ornamental work, formerly with grains or breads, but now composed of fine wire and used chiefly in decorating gold and silver to which the wire is soldered, being arranged in designs frequently of a delicate and intricate arabesque pattern.
Relating to, composed of, or resembling, work in filigree; as, a filigree basket. Hence: Fanciful; unsubstantial; merely decorative.
entry.q: You ask for reality, not fiction and filigree work.

entry.def: Adorned with filigree.
A fragment or particle rubbed off by the act of filing; as, iron filings .

The Latin for, “and from the Son,” equivalent to et filio, inserted by the third council of Toledo (a. d. 589) in the clause qui ex Patre proceditwho proceedeth from the Father) of the Niceno-Constantinopolitan Creed (a. d. 381), which makes a creed state that the Holy Ghost proceeds from the Son as well as from the Father. Hence, the doctrine itself (not admitted by the Eastern Church).

entry.ety: L. filum a thread + pendulus hanging, fr. pendēre to hang
entry.def: Suspended by, or strung upon, a thread; -- said of tuberous swellings in the middle or at the extremities of slender, threadlike rootlets.

sn.def: of or relating to the Philippines or its people or customs.
of or relating to the language of the Philippines.

entries.entry:
Fil`i*pi"no n.; pl. Filipinos # . Sp A native or inhabitant of the Philippine Islands, specif. one of Spanish descent or of mixed blood. wns=1 Then there are Filipinos, -- “children of the country,” they are called, -- who are supposed to be pure-blooded descendants of Spanish settlers. But there are few of them without some touch of Chinese or native blood.
the official language of the Philippines, based on Tagalog. It draws its lexicon from other Philippine languages. wns=2 Philippine.

cs.cd: a thill horse.

entry.ety: See Thill
entry.def: One of the thills or shafts of a carriage.

entry.cs: To fill in to insert; as, he filled in the figures. To fill out to extend or enlarge to the desired limit; to make complete; as, to fill out a bill. To fill up to make quite full; to fill to the brim or entirely; to occupy completely; to complete. “The bliss that fills up all the mind.” Pope. “And fill up that which is behind of the afflictions of Christ.” Col. i. 24.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Filled; p. pr. & vb. n. Filling
entry.ety: OE. fillen fullen, AS. fyllan, fr. full full; akin to D. vullen, G. füllen, Icel. fylla, Sw. fylla, Dan. fylde, Goth. fulljan. See Full a.

sn.def: To make full; to supply with as much as can be held or contained; to put or pour into, till no more can be received; to occupy the whole capacity of.
sn.q: The rain also filleth the pools.
Jesus saith unto them, Fill the waterpots with water. Anf they filled them up to the brim.

sn.def: To furnish an abudant supply to; to furnish with as mush as is desired or desirable; to occupy the whole of; to swarm in or overrun.
sn.q: And God blessed them, saying. Be fruitful, and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas.
The Syrians filled the country.

sn.def: To fill or supply fully with food; to feed; to satisfy.
sn.q: Whence should we have so much bread in the wilderness, as to fillso great a multitude?
Things that are sweet and fat are more filling.

sn.def: To possess and perform the duties of; to officiate in, as an incumbent; to occupy; to hold; as, a king fills a throne; the president fills the office of chief magistrate; the speaker of the House fills the chair.
To supply with an incumbent; as, to fill an office or a vacancy.

sd.def: To press and dilate, as a sail; as, the wind filled the sails.
To trim (a yard) so that the wind shall blow on the after side of the sails.

sn.def: To make an embankment in, or raise the level of (a low place), with earth or gravel.

entry.cs: To back and fill. See under Back v. i. To fill up to grow or become quite full; as, the channel of the river fills up with sand.

sn.def: To become full; to have the whole capacity occupied; to have an abundant supply; to be satiated; as, corn fills well in a warm season; the sail fills with the wind.
To fill a cup or glass for drinking.
sn.q: Give me some wine; fill full.

entry.ety: AS. fyllo. See Fill v. t.

sn.def: A full supply, as much as supplies want; as much as gives complete satisfaction.
sn.q: Ye shall eat yourfill.
I'll bear thee hence, where I may weep my fill.

sn.def: That which fills; filling; filler; specif., an embankment, as in railroad construction, to fill a hollow or ravine; also, the place which is to be filled.

entries.entry: Filled cheese. An inferior kind of cheese made from skim milk with a fatty “filling,” such as oleomargarine or lard, to replace the fat removed in the cream.

entry.def: variant spelling of filigree.
a young unmarried woman.
entry.syn: girl, filly, miss, missy, gal, young lady, young woman.

entry.sn: containing as much or as many as is possible or normal; as, filled to overflowing. Opposite of empty.Narrower terms: abounding in(predicate), abounding with(predicate), bristling with(predicate), full of(predicate), overflowing, overflowing with(predicate), rich in(predicate), rife with(predicate), thick with(predicate; brimful, brimful of(predicate), brimfull, brimfull of(predicate), brimming, brimming with(predicate; chockablock(predicate), chock-full(predicate), chockfull(predicate), chockful(predicate), choke-full(predicate), chuck-full(predicate), cram full; congested, engorged; crawling with(predicate), overrun with, swarming, swarming with(predicate), teeming, teeming with(predicate; flooded, inundated, swamped ; glutted, overfull; heavy with(predicate; laden, loaded ; overladen, overloaded ; stuffed ; stuffed; well-lined full.

sn.def: entirely of one substance with no holes inside. Opposite of hollow.
having appointments throughout the course of a period; -- of an appointment schedule; as, My calendar is filled for the week. Opposite of unoccupied and free
One who, or that which, fills; something used for filling.
sn.q: 'T is mere filler, to stop a vacancy in the hexameter.
They have six diggers to four fillers, so as to keep the fillers always at work.

sn.def: A composition, as of powdered silica and oil, used to fill the pores and grain of wood before applying paint, varnish, etc.
Any standing tree or standard higher than the surrounding coppice in the form of forest known as coppice under standards. Chiefly used in the pl.

entry.ety: From 1st Fill
entry.def: A thill horse.

entry.note: ☞ A fillet of beef is the under side of the sirlom; also called tenderloin. A fillet of veal or mutton is the fleshy part of the thigh. A fillet of fish is a slice of flat fish without bone. “Fillet of a fenny snake.”
entry.cs: Arris fillet. See under Arris.
entry.ety: OE. filet felet, fr. OF. filet thread, fillet of meat, dim. of fil a thread, fr. L. filum. See Fille a row

sn.def: A little band, especially one intended to encircle the hair of the head.
sn.q: A belt her waist, a fillet binds her hair.

sn.def: A piece of lean meat without bone; sometimes, a long strip rolled together and tied.
A thin strip or ribbon; esp.: A strip of metal from which coins are punched. A strip of card clothing. A thin projecting band or strip.
A concave filling in of a reëntrant angle where two surfaces meet, forming a rounded corner.
A narrow flat member; especially, a flat molding separating other moldings; a reglet; also, the space between two flutings in a shaft. See Illust. of Base, and Column.
An ordinary equaling in breadth one fourth of the chief, to the lowest portion of which it corresponds in position.
The thread of a screw.
A border of broad or narrow lines of color or gilt.
The raised molding about the muzzle of a gun.
Any scantling smaller than a batten.
A fascia; a band of fibers; applied esp. to certain bands of white matter in the brain.
The loins of a horse, beginning at the place where the hinder part of the saddle rests.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Filleted; p. pr. & vb. n. Filleting
entry.def: To bind, furnish, or adorn with a fillet.

sn.def: The protecting of a joint, as between roof and parapet wall, with mortar, or cement, where flashing is employed in better work.
The material of which fillets are made; also, fillets, collectively.

entry.def: A kilt. See Filibeg.
See Filibuster.

entry.cs: Back filling. Arch See under Back a.

sn.def: That which is used to fill a cavity or any empty space, or to supply a deficiency; as, filling for a cavity in a tooth, a depression in a roadbed, the space between exterior and interior walls of masonry, the pores of open-grained wood, the space between the outer and inner planks of a vessel, etc.
The woof in woven fabrics.
Prepared wort added to ale to cleanse it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Filliped; p. pr. & vb. n. Filliping
entry.ety: For filp flip. Cf. Flippant

sn.def: To strike with the nail of the finger, first placed against the ball of the thumb, and forced from that position with a sudden spring; to snap with the finger.
sn.q: Youfillipme o' the head.

sn.def: To snap; to project quickly.
sn.q: The use of the elastic switch to fillip small missiles with.

sn.def: A jerk of the finger forced suddenly from the thumb; a smart blow.
Something serving to rouse or excite.
sn.q: I take a glass of grog for a filip.

entry.def: See Philopena.

cs.cd: a short cylindrical screw head, having a convex top.

sn.def: The rabbet on the outer edge of a sash bar to hold the glass and the putty.
A plane for making a rabbet.

entries.entry:
Fil"ly n.; pl.Fillies #. Cf. Icel. fylia fr. foli foal. See Foal
Zoöl A female foal or colt; a young mare. Cf. Colt Foal. Neighing in likeness of a filly foal.
A lively, spirited young girl. Colloq

cs.cd: a thin flexible sheet of celluloid, coated with a sensitized emulsion of gelatin, and used as a substitute for photographic plates.
a celluloid film cut into pieces suitable for use in a camera.

entry.ety: AS. film skin, fr. fell skin; akin to fylmen membrane, OFries. filmene skin. See Fell skin

sn.def: A thin skin; a pellicle; a membranous covering, causing opacity.
sn.q: He from thick films shall purge the visual ray.

sn.def: hence, any thin layer covering a surface.
A slender thread, as that of a cobweb.
sn.q: Her whip of cricket's bone, the lash of film.

sn.def: The layer, usually of gelatin or collodion, containing the sensitive salts of photographic plates.

a flexible sheet of celluloid or other plastic material to which a light-sensitive layer has been applied, used for recording images by the processes of photography. It is commonly used in rolls mounted within light-proof canisters suitable for simple insertion into cameras designed for such canisters. On such rolls, varying numbers of photographs may be taken before the canister needs to be replaced.
a motion picture.
the art of making motion pictures; -- used mostly in the phrase the film.
a thin transparent sheet of plastic, used for wrapping objects; as, polyethylene film .
To cover with a thin skin or pellicle.
sn.q: It will but skin and film the ulcerous place.

sn.def: to make a motion picture of (any event or literary work); to record with a movie camera; as, to film the inauguration ceremony; to film Dostoevsky's War and Peace.

entry.def: readily adaptable to motion picture form; -- of books, plays, and other works of literature.
recorded on film.
State of being filmy.
to make films; be a film maker.
Composed of film or films.
entry.q: Whose filmy cord should bind the struggling fly.

entry.def: Having the structure of a filoplume.

entry.ety: L. filum a thread � pluma a soft feather
entry.def: A hairlike feather; a father with a slender scape and without a web in most or all of its length.

entry.ety: L. filum a thread
entry.def: Terminating in a threadlike process.

entry.ety: F., floss silk
entry.def: A kind of silk thread less glossy than floss, and spun from coarser material. It is much used in embroidery instead of floss.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. filius. See Filial
entry.def: Son; -- sometimes used after a French proper name to distinguish a son from his father, as, Alexandre Dumas, fils .

cs.cd: a pond, the bottom of which is a filter composed of sand gravel.
an underground gallery or tunnel, alongside of a stream, to collect the water that filters through the intervening sand and gravel; -- called also infiltration gallery.

entry.ety: F. filtre, the same word as feutre felt, LL. filtrum feltrum, felt, fulled wool, this being used for straining liquors. See Feuter
entry.def: Any porous substance, as cloth, paper, sand, or charcoal, through which water or other liquid may passed to cleanse it from the solid or impure matter held in suspension; a chamber or device containing such substance; a strainer; also, a similar device for purifying air.

cs.cd: a porous unsized paper, for filtering.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Filtered; p. pr. & vb. n. Filtering
entry.ety: Cf. F. filter. See Filter n., and cf. Filtrate
entry.def: To purify or defecate, as water or other liquid, by causing it to pass through a filter.
To pass through a filter; to percolate.
Same as Philter.
having a tip designed to filter the smoke; -- of a cigarette or cigar; as, filter-tipped cigarettes.

cs.cd: a disease supposed to be due to pollution of the soil or water.

entry.ety: OE. filthe fulðe, AS. fȳlð, fr. fūl foul; akin to OHG. fūlida. See Foul, and cf. File

sn.def: Foul matter; anything that soils or defiles; dirt; nastiness.
Anything that sullies or defiles the moral character; corruption; pollution.
sn.q: To purify the soul from the dross and filth of sensual delights.

entry.def: In a filthy manner; foully.

sn.def: The state of being filthy.
sn.q: Let us cleanse ourselves from all filthiness of the flesh and spirit.

sn.def: That which is filthy, or makes filthy; foulness; nastiness; corruption; pollution; impurity.
sn.q: Carry forth the filthiness out of the holy place.

entry.def: Defiled with filth, whether material or moral; nasty; dirty; polluted; foul; impure; obscene.
entry.q: In thefilthy-mantled pool.
He which is filthy let him be filthy still.
entry.syn: Nasty; foul; dirty; squalid; unclean; sluttish; gross; vulgar; licentious. See Nasty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Filtrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Filtrating.
entry.ety: Cf. LL. filtrare. See Filter
entry.def: To filter; to defecate; as liquid, by straining or percolation.
That which has been filtered; the liquid which has passed through the filter in the process of filtration. Contrasted with retentate, the material remaining on the filter.

entry.ety: Cf. F. filtration
entry.def: The act or process of filtering; the mechanical separation of a liquid from the undissolved particles floating in it.

entry.ety: Corrupted from female hemp
entry.def: Light summer hemp, that bears no seed.

entries.entry:
‖Fim"bri*a
Fim"bri*al # a.
n.; pl.Fimbriæ #. L., fringe. See Fringle
Anat pl. A fringe, or fringed border. A band of white matter bordering the hippocampus in the brain.

entry.ety: L. fimbriatus fibrous, fringed, fr. fimbria fiber, fringe. See Fringe
entry.def: Having the edge or extremity bordered by filiform processes thicker than hairs; fringed; as, the fimbriate petals of the pink; the fimbriate end of the Fallopian tube.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fimbriated; p. pr. & vb. n. Fimbriating
entry.def: To hem; to fringe.

sn.def: Having a fringed border; fimbriate.
Having a very narrow border of another tincture; -- said esp. of an ordinary or subordinary.
Fringed; jagged; fimbriate.
fringed, on one side only, by long, straight hairs, as the antennæ of certain insects.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Finned; p. pr. & vb. n. Finning
entry.ety: Cf. Fin of a fish
entry.def: To carve or cut up, as a chub.

entry.ety: See Fine n.
entry.def: End; conclusion; object.
entry.q: She knew eke thefinof his intent.

entry.note: ☞ Fishes move through the water chiefly by means of the caudal fin or tail, the principal office of the other fins being to balance or direct the body, though they are also, to a certain extent, employed in producing motion.
entry.cs:
Apidose fin. Zoöl See under Adipose a.
Fin ray Anat one of the hornlike, cartilaginous, or bony, dermal rods which form the skeleton of the fins of fishes. Fin whale Zoöl a finback. Paired fins Zoöl the pectoral and ventral fins, corresponding to the fore and hind legs of the higher animals.
Unpaired finsorMedian fins
Zoöl the dorsal, caudal, and anal fins.
entry.ety: OE. finne fin, AS. finn; akin to D. vin, G. & Dan. finne, Sw. fena, L. pinna penna, a wing, feather. Cf. pen a feather

sn.def: An organ of a fish, consisting of a membrane supported by rays, or little bony or cartilaginous ossicles, and serving to balance and propel it in the water.
A membranous, finlike, swimming organ, as in pteropod and heteropod mollusks.

entry.sn:
A finlike organ or attachment; a part of an object or product which protrudes like a fin, as: The hand. Slang
Com A blade of whalebone. Eng
Mech A mark or ridge left on a casting at the junction of the parts of a mold.
Mech The thin sheet of metal squeezed out between the collars of the rolls in the process of rolling.
Mech A feather; a spline.

sn.def: A finlike appendage, as to submarine boats.
A fixed stabilizing surface, usually vertical, similar in purpose to a bilge keel on a ship.

entry.ety: From Fine
entry.def: Liable or subject to a fine; as, a finable person or offense.
to achieve something by means of trickery or devious methods.

entry.cs: Final cause. See under Cause.
entry.usage: Final is now appropriated to that which brings with it an end; as, a final adjustment; the final judgment, etc. Conclusive implies the closing of all discussion, negotiation, etc.; as, a conclusive argument or fact; a conclusive arrangement. In using ultimate, we have always reference to something earlier or proceeding; as when we say, a temporary reverse may lead to an ultimate triumph. The statements which a man finally makes at the close of a negotiation are usually conclusive as to his ultimate intentions and designs.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. finalis, fr. finis boundary, limit, end. See Finish

sn.def: Pertaining to the end or conclusion; last; terminating; ultimate; as, the final day of a school term.
sn.q: Yet despair not of his final pardon.

sn.def: Conclusive; decisive; as, a final judgment; the battle of Waterloo brought the contest to a final issue.
Respecting an end or object to be gained; respecting the purpose or ultimate end in view.

entries.entry:
‖Fi*na"le f�*nä"l� n. It. See Final
Close; termination; as: Mus The last movement of a symphony, sonata, concerto, or any instrumental composition. The last composition performed in any act of an opera. The closing part, piece, or scene in any public performance or exhibition.

entry.def: same as finalization.
Any of the players who meet in the final round of a tournament in which the losers in any round do not play again.

entries.entry:
Fi*nal"i*ty n.; pl.Finalities #. L. finalitas the being last
The state of being final, finished, or complete; a final or conclusive arrangement; a settlement.
The relation of end or purpose to its means.

entry.def: the act of finalizing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. finalized; p. pr. & vb. n. finalizing
entry.def: to put the last touches on; put into final form.

sn.def: At the end or conclusion; ultimately; lastly; as, the contest was long, but the Romans finally conquered.
sn.q: Whom patience finally must crown.

sn.def: Completely; beyond recovery.
sn.q: Not any house of noble English in Ireland was utterly destroyed or finally rooted out.

entry.ety: F., fr. LL. financia payment of money, money, fr. finare to pay a fine or subsidy (cf. OF. finer to finish, pay), fr. L. finis end. See Fine n. Finish

sn.def: The income of a ruler or of a state; revenue; public money; sometimes, the income of an individual; often used in the plural for funds; available money; resources.
sn.q: All the finances or revenues of the imperial crown.

sn.def: The science of raising and expending the public revenue.
sn.q: Versed in the details offinance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Financed; p. pr. & vb. n. Financing
entry.def: To conduct the finances of; to provide for, and manage, the capital for; to financier.
entry.q: Securing foreign capital to finance multitudinous undertakings.

entry.def: assets in the form of money.
entry.syn: funds, monetary resource, cash in hand, pecuniary resource.

entry.def: Pertaining to finance.
entry.q: Ourfinancialand commercial system.

entry.def: A financier.
In a financial manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. financier

sn.def: One charged with the administration of finance; an officer who administers the public revenue; a treasurer.
One skilled in financial operations; one acquainted with money matters.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Financiered; p. pr. & vb. n. Financiering
entry.def: To conduct financial operations.
See Finery.
Conclusive; decisive; definitive; final.

Any whale of the genera Sibbaldius Balænoptera, and allied genera, of the family Balænopteridæ, characterized by a prominent fin on the back. The common finbacks of the New England coast are Sibbaldius tectirostris and S. tuberosus.

entries.entry: Fin"bat kite. same as Eddy kite. Eng

Finch ☞ The word is often used in composition, as in chaffinch, goldfinch, grassfinch, pinefinch, etc.
Bramble finch. See Brambling. Canary finch the canary bird. Copper finch. See Chaffinch. Diamond finch. See under Diamond. Finch falcon Zoöl one of several very small East Indian falcons of the genus Hierax. To pull a finch to swindle an ignorant or unsuspecting person. Obs “Privily a finch eke could he pull.” Chaucer.
fĭnch n.; pl.Finches fĭnch"ĕz. AS. finc; akin to D. vink, OHG. fincho, G. fink; cf. W. pinc a finch; also E. spink
Zoöl A small singing bird of many genera and species, belonging to the family Fringillidæ.

entry.def: Streaked or spotted on the back; -- said of cattle.
Same as Finchbacked.

entry.cs: To find out to detect (a thief); to discover (a secret) -- to solve or unriddle (a parable or enigma); to understand. “Canst thou by searching find out God?” Job. xi. 7. “We do hope to find out all your tricks.” Milton. To find fault with to blame; to censure. To find one's self to be; to fare; -- often used in speaking of health; as, how do you find yourself this morning?
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Found found; p. pr. & vb. n. Finding
entry.ety: AS. findan; akin to D. vinden, OS. & OHG. findan, G. finden, Dan. finde, icel. & Sw. finna, Goth. finþan; and perh. to L. petere to seek, Gr. pi`ptein to fall, Skr. pat to fall, fly, E. petition

sn.def: To meet with, or light upon, accidentally; to gain the first sight or knowledge of, as of something new, or unknown; hence, to fall in with, as a person.
sn.q: Searching the window for a flint, I found This paper, thus sealed up.
In woods and forests thou art found.

sn.def: To learn by experience or trial; to perceive; to experience; to discover by the intellect or the feelings; to detect; to feel.
sn.q: Ifindyou passing gentle.
The torrid zone is now found habitable.

sn.def: To come upon by seeking; as, to find something lost.

sd.def: To discover by sounding; as, to find bottom.
To discover by study or experiment direct to an object or end; as, water is found to be a compound substance.
To gain, as the object of desire or effort; as, to find leisure; to find means.
To attain to; to arrive at; to acquire.
sd.q: Every mountain now hath found a tongue.

sn.def: To provide for; to supply; to furnish; as, to find food for workemen; he finds his nephew in money.
sn.q: Wages £14 and all found.
Nothing a day and find yourself.

sn.def: To arrive at, as a conclusion; to determine as true; to establish; as, to find a verdict; to find a true bill (of indictment) against an accused person.
sn.q: To find his title with some shows of truth.

entry.def: To determine an issue of fact, and to declare such a determination to a court; as, the jury find for the plaintiff.
Anything found; a discovery of anything valuable; especially, a deposit, discovered by archæologists, of objects of prehistoric or unknown origin.
Capable of being found; discoverable.

sn.def: One who, or that which, finds;
a small telescope of low power and large field of view, attached to a larger telescope, for the purpose of finding an object more readily, called also a finder telescope or finder scope.
A slide ruled in squares, so as to assist in locating particular points in the field of vision.

entries.entry: ‖Fin` de siè"cle As the twentieth century comes to a close, the meaning may change.. F Lit., end of the century; -- mostly used adjectively in English to signify: belonging to, or characteristic of, the close of the 19th century. At that time the phrase was also intended to imply “modern” or “up-to-date;” as, fin-de-siècle ideas.

entry.def: A censurer or caviler.
Apt to censure or cavil; faultfinding; captious.

sn.def: That which is found, come upon, or provided; esp. (pl.), that which a journeyman artisan finds or provides for himself; as tools, trimmings, etc.
sn.q: When a man hath been laboring . . . in the deep mines of knowledge, hath furnished out his findings in all their equipage.

sn.def: Support; maintenance; that which is provided for one; expence; provision.
The result of a judicial examination or inquiry, especially into some matter of fact; a verdict; as, the finding of a jury.
sn.q: After his friends finding and his rent.

entry.ety: AS. finding heavy; cf. Dan. fyndig strong, energetical, fynd strength, energy, emphasis
entry.def: Full; heavy; firm; solid; substantial.
entry.q: A cold May and a windy Makes the barn fat and findy.

entry.note: ☞ Fine is often compounded with participles and adjectives, modifying them adverbially; a, fine-drawn, fine-featured, fine-grained, fine-spoken, fine-spun, etc.
entry.cs: Fine arch Glass Making the smaller fritting furnace of a glasshouse. Knight. Fine arts. See the Note under Art. Fine cut fine cut tobacco; a kind of chewing tobacco cut up into shreds. Fine goods woven fabrics of fine texture and quality. McElrath. Fine stuff lime, or a mixture of lime, plaster, etc., used as material for the finishing coat in plastering. To sail fine Naut to sail as close to the wind as possible.
entry.usage: When used as a word of praise, finebeing opposed to coarse) denotes no “ordinary thing of its kind.” It is not as strong as beautiful, in reference to the single attribute implied in the latter term; but when we speak of a fine woman, we include a greater variety of particulars, viz., all the qualities which become a woman, -- breeding, sentiment, tact, etc. The term is equally comprehensive when we speak of a fine garden, landscape, horse, poem, etc.; and, though applied to a great variety of objects, the word has still a very definite sense, denoting a high degree of characteristic excellence.
entry.ety: F. fin, LL. finus fine, pure, fr. L. finire to finish; cf. finitus, p. p., finished, completed (hence the sense accomplished perfect.) See Finish, and cf. Finite

sn.def: Finished; brought to perfection; refined; hence, free from impurity; excellent; superior; elegant; worthy of admiration; accomplished; beautiful.
sn.q: The gain thereof [is better] than fine gold.
A cup of wine that's brisk and fine.
Not only the finest gentleman of his time, but one of the finest scholars.
To soothe the sick bed of so fine a being [Keats].

sn.def: Aiming at show or effect; loaded with ornament; overdressed or overdecorated; showy.
sn.q: He gratified them with occasional . . . fine writing.

sn.def: Nice; delicate; subtle; exquisite; artful; skillful; dexterous.
sn.q: The spider's touch, how exquisitely fine!
The nicest and most delicate touches of satire consist in fine raillery.
He has as fine a hand at picking a pocket as a woman.

entry.sn:
Not coarse, gross, or heavy; as: Not gross; subtile; thin; tenous. The eye standeth in the finer medium and the object in the grosser.
Not coarse; comminuted; in small particles; as, fine sand or flour.
Not thick or heavy; slender; filmy; as, a fine thread.
Thin; attenuate; keen; as, a fine edge.
Made of fine materials; light; delicate; as, fine linen or silk.

sn.def: Having (such) a proportion of pure metal in its composition; as, coins nine tenths fine .
Used ironically
sn.q: Ye have made a fine hand, fellows.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fined fīnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Fining
entry.ety: From Fine a.

sn.def: To make fine; to refine; to purify, to clarify; as, to fine gold.
sn.q: It hath been fined and refined by . . . learned men.

sn.def: To make finer, or less coarse, as in bulk, texture, etc.; as. to fine the soil.
To change by fine gradations; as Naut, to fine down a ship's lines, to diminish her lines gradually.
sn.q: I often sate at home On evenings, watching how they fined themselves With gradual conscience to a perfect night.

entry.cs: Fine for alienation Feudal Law a sum of money paid to the lord by a tenant whenever he had occasion to make over his land to another. Burrill. Fine of lands a species of conveyance in the form of a fictitious suit compromised or terminated by the acknowledgment of the previous owner that such land was the right of the other party. Burrill. See Concord n., 4.In fine in conclusion; by way of termination or summing up.
entry.ety: OE. fin, L. finis end, also in LL., a final agreement or concord between the lord and his vassal; a sum of money paid at the end, so as to make an end of a transaction, suit, or prosecution; mulct; penalty; cf. OF. fin end, settlement, F. fin end. See Finish, and cf. Finance

sn.def: End; conclusion; termination; extinction.
sn.q: To see their fatalfine.
Is this the fine of his fines?

sn.def: A sum of money paid as the settlement of a claim, or by way of terminating a matter in dispute; especially, a payment of money imposed upon a party as a punishment for an offense; a mulct.

sd.def: A final agreement concerning lands or rents between persons, as the lord and his vassal.
A sum of money or price paid for obtaining a benefit, favor, or privilege, as for admission to a copyhold, or for obtaining or renewing a lease.

entry.ety: From Fine n.
entry.def: To impose a pecuniary penalty upon for an offense or breach of law; to set a fine on by judgment of a court; to punish by fine; to mulct; as, the trespassers were fined ten dollars.
To pay a fine. See Fine n., 3 .
entry.q: Men fined for the king's good will; or that he would remit his anger; women fined for leave to marry.

entry.ety: OF. finer, F. finir. See Finish v. t.
entry.def: To finish; to cease; or to cause to cease.

sn.def: Finely; well; elegantly; fully; delicately; mincingly.
In a manner so that the driven ball strikes the object ball so far to one side as to be deflected but little, the object ball being driven to one side.

cs.cd: gradually to become fine; to diminish; to dwindle.
cs.q: I watched her [the ship] . . . gradually fining down in the westward until I lost of her hull.

entry.def: To become fine (in any one of various senses); as, the ale will fine; the weather fined .
liable to a fine.
subjected to punishment by a fine.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Finedrawn; p. pr. & vb. n. Finedrawing
entry.def: To sew up, so nicely that the seam is not perceived; to renter.
One who finedraws.
Drawn out with too much subtilty; overnice; as, finedrawn speculations.
To run in debt by getting goods made up in a way unsuitable for the use of others, and then threatening not to take them except on credit.
To veneer.

sn.def: consisting of fine particles.
dense or compact in structure or texture, as a wood composed of small-diameter cells.
involving careful consideration of details and fine distinctions; -- of conceptual schemas; as, fine-grained distinctions.

entry.ety: Fine end + -less
entry.def: Endless; boundless.

entries.entry: fine-looking adj. pleasing in appearance especially by reason of conformity to ideals of form and proportion; as, a fine-looking woman.Narrower terms: beautiful (vs. ugly good-looking, better-looking, handsome, well-favored, well-favoured.

entry.def: In a fine or finished manner.

entry.note: ☞ The fineness of United States coin is nine tenths, that of English gold coin is eleven twelfths, and that of English silver coin is 925/1000.
entry.ety: From Fine a.

sn.def: The quality or condition of being fine.
Freedom from foreign matter or alloy; clearness; purity; as, the fineness of liquor.
sn.q: The fineness of the gold, and chargeful fashion.

sn.def: The proportion of pure silver or gold in jewelry, bullion, or coins.
Keenness or sharpness; as, the fineness of a needle's point, or of the edge of a blade.

entry.def: One who fines or purifies.

sn.def: Fineness; beauty.
sn.q: Don't choose your place of study by the finery of the prospects.

sn.def: Ornament; decoration; especially, excecially decoration; showy clothes; jewels.
sn.q: Her mistress' cast-off finery.

sn.def: A charcoal hearth or furnace for the conversion of cast iron into wrought iron, or into iron suitable for puddling.

entry.def: Spun so as to be fine; drawn to a fine thread; attenuated; hence, unsubstantial; visionary; as, finespun theories.

entry.ety: F., fr. fin fine. See Fine a.

sn.def: Subtilty of contrivance to gain a point; artifice; stratagem.
sn.q: This is the artificialest piece of finesse to persuade men into slavery.

sn.def: The act of finessing. See Finesse v. i., 2.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Finessed; p. pr. & vb. n. Finessing

sn.def: To use artifice or stratagem.
To attempt, when second or third player, to make a lower card answer the purpose of a higher, when an intermediate card is out, risking the chance of its being held by the opponent yet to play.

entry.def: To distill, as spirit from molasses or some saccharine preparation.
One who finestills.
having fine teeth set close together; as, a fine-tooth comb.
to adjust carefully and precisely so as to achieve optimum performance or efficiency; as, The mechanic fine-tuned the engine.

entry.ety: See Fenowed
entry.def: Moldiness.
A finback whale.
True fish, as distinguished from shellfish.
A South American bird (Heliornis fulica) allied to the grebes. The name is also applied to several related species of the genus Podica.
Having palmate feet.
Having lobate toes, as the coot and grebe.

entry.cs:
Ear finger the little finger. Finger alphabet. See Dactylology. Finger bar the horizontal bar, carrying slotted spikes, or fingers, through which the vibratory knives of mowing and reaping machines play. Finger board Mus the part of a stringed instrument against which the fingers press the strings to vary the tone; the keyboard of a piano, organ, etc.; manual.
Finger bowl Finger glass
a bowl or glass to hold water for rinsing the fingers at table. Finger flower Bot the foxglove. Finger grass Bot a kind of grass (Panicum sanguinale) with slender radiating spikes; common crab grass. See Crab grass, under Crab. Finger nut a fly nut or thumb nut. Finger plate a strip of metal, glass, etc., to protect a painted or polished door from finger marks. Finger post a guide post bearing an index finger. Finger reading reading printed in relief so as to be sensible to the touch; -- so made for the blind. Finger shell Zoöl a marine shell (Pholas dactylus) resembling a finger in form. Finger sponge Zoöl a sponge having finger-shaped lobes, or branches. Finger stall a cover or shield for a finger. Finger steel a steel instrument for whetting a currier's knife.
To burn one's fingers. See under Burn. To have a finger in to be concerned in. Colloq To have at one's fingers' ends to be thoroughly familiar with. Colloq
entry.ety: AS. finger; akin to D. vinger, OS. & OHG. fingar, G. finger, Icel. fingr, Sw. & Dan. finger, Goth. figgrs; of unknown origin; perh. akin to E. fang

sn.def: One of the five terminating members of the hand; a digit; esp., one of the four extremities of the hand, other than the thumb.
Anything that does the work of a finger; as, the pointer of a clock, watch, or other registering machine;
a small projecting rod, wire, or piece, which is brought into contact with an object to effect, direct, or restrain a motion.

The breadth of a finger, or the fourth part of the hand; a measure of nearly an inch; also, the length of finger, a measure in domestic use in the United States, of about four and a half inches or one eighth of a yard.
sn.q: A piece of steel three fingers thick.

sn.def: Skill in the use of the fingers, as in playing upon a musical instrument.
sn.q: She has a good finger.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fingered; p. pr. & vb. n. Fingering

sn.def: To touch with the fingers; to handle; to meddle with.
sn.q: Let the papers lie; You would be fingering them to anger me.

sn.def: To touch lightly; to toy with.

sd.def: To perform on an instrument of music.
To mark the notes of (a piece of music) so as to guide the fingers in playing.

sn.def: To take thievishly; to pilfer; to purloin.
To execute, as any delicate work.

entry.def: To use the fingers in playing on an instrument.

sn.def: a guidepost resembling a hand with a pointing index finger.
a bank of keys on a musical instrument.
a narrow strip of wood on the neck of some stringed instruments (violin or cello or guitar etc) where the strings are held against the wood with the fingers.

entry.def: the length or breadth of a finger used as a linear measure.
a close-fitting sheath worn at the end of a finger, for protection of the finger or to avoid soiling the object touched.

sn.def: Having fingers.
Having leaflets like fingers; digitate.
Marked with figures designating which finger should be used for each note.

entry.def: One who fingers; a pilferer.

sn.def: The act or process of handling or touching with the fingers.
sn.q: The mere sight and fingering of money.

sn.def: The manner of using the fingers in playing or striking the keys of an instrument of music; movement or management of the fingers in playing on a musical instrument, in typewriting, etc.
The marking of the notes of a piece of music to guide or regulate the action or use of the fingers.
Delicate work made with the fingers.

entry.ety: Finger + -ling
entry.def: A young salmon. See Parr.

A type of paint having the consistency of a thin paste or jelly, which is applied to a surface by dipping fingers into the paint and smearing the paint on the surface, usually in artistic patterns. It is used primarily by children.
To paint{1} with fingerpaint.
Creating pictures using finger paint.
a guidepost resembling a hand with a pointing index finger.

entry.note: Fingerprints left by persons who have committed crimes are considered as reliable physical evidence linking an individual with a crime, because each person's fingerprints are distinctively different from those of others, allowing identification of a person with high confidence.
entry.ety: Finger + print

sn.def: an impression of the pattern of ridges on the skin of the last joint of a person's finger, left on a surface after a person has touched the surface.
a fingerprint{1} made intentionally in ink on a paper form for the purpose of identification of the individual.

any distinctive pattern of characteristics or properties of an object which can serve to identify that object; as, the distinctive fingerprint of eugenol in the mass spectrum allowed easy recognition of its presence in the sample.
a smudge made by a (dirty) finger.

entry.def: to take an impression of the fingerprints of (a person); as, to fingerprint applicants for a gun permit.
The procedure of taking inked impressions of a person's fingerprints.
