sn.def: The flat part, or side, of anything; as, the broad side of a blade, as distinguished from its edge.
A floor, loft, or story in a building;
a floor of a house, which forms a complete residence in itself; an apartment taking up a whole floor. In this latter sense, the usage is more common in British English.
A horizontal vein or ore deposit auxiliary to a main vein; also, any horizontal portion of a vein not elsewhere horizontal.
A dull fellow; a simpleton; a numskull.
sn.q: Or if you can not make a speech, Because you are a flat.

sn.def: A character [♭] before a note, indicating a tone which is a half step or semitone lower.
A homaloid space or extension.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flatted; p. pr. & vb. n. Flatting

sn.def: To make flat; to flatten; to level.
To render dull, insipid, or spiritless; to depress.
sn.q: Passions are allayed, appetites are flatted.

sn.def: To depress in tone, as a musical note; especially, to lower in pitch by half a tone.

cs.cd: to fail from a promising beginning; to make a bad ending; to disappoint expectations.

sn.def: To become flat, or flattened; to sink or fall to an even surface.
To fall form the pitch.

entry.def: Any bird of the genus Flatyrynchus. They belong to the family of flycatchers.
A boat with a flat bottom and square ends; -- used for the transportation of bulky freight, especially in shallow waters.
Having an even lower surface or bottom; as, a flat-bottomed boat.
A kind of low-crowned cap formerly worn by all classes in England, and continued in London after disuse elsewhere; -- hence, a citizen of London.
a railroad car without permanent sides or roof.

Any fish of the family Pleuronectidæ; esp., the winter flounder (Pleuronectes Americanus). The flatfishes have the body flattened, swim on the side, and have eyes on one side, as the flounder, turbot, and halibut. See Flounder.

entries.entry: flat" foot` flat"foot` . Med A foot in which the arch of the instep is flattened so that the entire sole of the foot rests upon the ground; also, the deformity, usually congential, exhibited by such a foot; splayfoot.

entry.def: a police officer, especially a foot patrolman.

cs.cd: to catch (a person) unprepared; to catch (a person) by surprise.

sn.def: Having a flat foot, with little or no arch of the instep; suffering from fallen arches.
Firm-footed; determined.
clumsy; amateurish; pedestrian; unimaginative; plodding; as, flatfooted prose.
Without reservation; without evasion or compromise; firm; as, a flat-footed refusal; a flatfooted denial.
With feet flat on the ground; not tiptoe.
Unprepared and unable to react quickly; as, the new product caught their competitors flat-footed .

entry.def: Characterized by flatness of head, especially that produced by artificial means, as a certain tribe of American Indians.
A Chinook Indian. See Chinook n., 1.
Having a head with a flattened top; as, a flat-headed nail.
An iron with a flat, smooth surface for ironing clothes.

entry.ety: L. flare flatum to blow
entry.def: Producing wind; flatulent.

entry.ety: Flat a. + adverbial suff. -ling
entry.def: With the flat side, as of a sword; flatlong; in a prostrate position.
With the flat side downward; not edgewise.

sn.def: In a flat manner; evenly; horizontally; without spirit; dully; frigidly.
sn.q: He that does the works of religion slowly, flatly, and without appetite.

sn.def: peremptorily; positively; plainly; forthrightly.
sn.q: Heflatlyrefused his aid.

entry.def: someone who shares an apartment with a person.

sn.def: The quality or state of being flat.
Eveness of surface; want of relief or prominence; the state of being plane or level.
Want of vivacity or spirit; prostration; dejection; depression.
Want of variety or flavor; dullness; insipidity.
Depression of tone; the state of being below the true pitch; -- opposed to sharpness or acuteness.

entry.ety: OF
entry.def: A flatterer.
downright; plain; unqualified; as, a flat-out lie.

cs.cd: to set it more nearly fore-and-aft of the vessel.
in glass making, a heated chamber in which split glass cylinders are flattened for window glass.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flattened; p. pr. & vb. n. Flattening
entry.ety: From Flat a.

sn.def: To reduce to an even surface or one approaching evenness; to make flat; to level; to make plane.
To throw down; to bring to the ground; to prostrate; hence, to depress; to deject; to dispirit.
To make vapid or insipid; to render stale.
To lower the pitch of; to cause to sound less sharp; to let fall from the pitch.

entry.def: To become or grow flat, even, depressed, dull, vapid, spiritless, or depressed below pitch.

sn.def: shaped like a thin sheet.
flattened laterally along the whole length e.g. certain leafstalks or flatfishes.
One who, or that which, makes flat or flattens.

sd.def: A flat-faced fulling hammer.
A drawplate with a narrow, rectangular orifice, for drawing flat strips, as watch springs, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flattered; p. pr. & vb. n. Flattering
entry.ety: OE. flateren, cf. OD. flatteren; akin to G. flattern to flutter, Icel. flaðra to fawn, flatter: cf. F. flatter. Cf. Flitter Flutter Flattery

sn.def: To treat with praise or blandishments; to gratify or attempt to gratify the self-love or vanity of, esp. by artful and interested commendation or attentions; to blandish; to cajole; to wheedle.
sn.q: When I tell him he hates flatterers, He says he does, being then most flattered.
A man that flattereth his neighbor, spreadeth a net for his feet.
Others he flattered by asking their advice.

sn.def: To raise hopes in; to encourage or favorable, but sometimes unfounded or deceitful, representations.
To portray too favorably; to give a too favorable idea of; as, his portrait flatters him.

entry.def: To use flattery or insincere praise.
entry.q: If it may stand him more in stead to lie, Say and unsay, feign, flatter, or adjure.

entry.def: One who flatters.
entry.q: The most abject flaterers degenerate into the greatest tyrants.

entry.def: That flatters (in the various senses of the verb); as, a flattering speech.
entry.q: Lay not that flattering unction to your soul.
A flattering painter, who made it his care, To draw men as they ought be, not as they are.

entry.def: With flattery.

entries.entry:
Flat"ter*y n.; pl.Flatteries #. OE. flaterie, OF. flaterie, F. flaterie, fr. flater to flatter, F. flatter; of uncertain origin. See Flatter v. t.
The act or practice of flattering; the act of pleasing by artful commendation or compliments; adulation; false, insincere, or excessive praise. Just praise is only a debt, but flattery is a present.
Flattery corrupts both the receiver and the giver. Adulation; compliment; obsequiousness. See Adulation.

entry.cs: Flatting coat a coat of paint so put on as to have no gloss. Flatting furnace. Same as flattening oven, under Flatten. Flatting mill. A rolling mill producing sheet metal; esp., in mints, the mill producing the ribbon from which the planchets are punched. A mill in which grains of metal are flatted by steel rolls, and reduced to metallic dust, used for purposes of ornamentation.

sn.def: The process or operation of making flat, as a cylinder of glass by opening it out.
A mode of painting,in which the paint, being mixed with turpentine, leaves the work without gloss.
A method of preserving gilding unburnished, by touching with size.
The process of forming metal into sheets by passing it between rolls.

entry.def: Somewhat flat.

sn.def: having a flat or flattened upper surface.

entry.def: An aircraft carrier.

entry.ety: Cf. F. flatulence
entry.def: The state or quality of being flatulent.

entry.ety: L. flatus a blowing, flatus ventris windiness, flatulence, fr. flare to blow: cf. F. flatulent. See Blow

sn.def: Affected with flatus{2} or gases generated in the alimentary canal; windy.
Generating, or tending to generate, wind in the stomach.
sn.q: Vegetables abound more with aërial particles than animal substances, and therefore are more flatulent.

sn.def: Turgid with flatus; as, a flatulent tumor.
Pretentious without substance or reality; puffy; empty; vain; as, a flatulent vanity.
sn.q: He is too flatulent sometimes, and sometimes too dry.

entry.def: In a flatulent manner; with flatulence.

entry.ety: Cf. F. flatuosité
entry.def: Flatulence.

entry.ety: Cf. F. flatueux
entry.def: Windy; generating wind.

entries.entry:
‖Fla"tus n.; pl. E. Flatuses #, L. Flatus. L., fr. flare to blow
A breath; a puff of wind.
Gas generated in the stomach, intestine, or other cavities of the body.

entry.def: eating utensils such as knives, forks, and spoons, considered collectively.
With the flat side downward, or next to another object; not edgewise.
Ironing that can be done mechanically.
Any worm belonging to the Platyhelminthes; also, sometimes applied to the planarians.
Flemish.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flaunted; p. pr. & vb. n.. Flaunting
entry.ety: Cf. dial. G. flandern to flutter, wave; perh. akin to E. flatter flutter
entry.def: To throw or spread out; to flutter; to move ostentatiously; as, a flaunting show.
entry.q: You flaunt about the streets in your new gilt chariot.
One flaunts in rags, one flutters in brocade.

entry.def: To display ostentatiously; to make an impudent show of.
entry.q: If you've got it,flauntit.

entry.def: Anything displayed for show.
entry.q: In these my borrowed flaunts.

entry.def: In a flaunting way.

entry.ety: It. flauto a flute See Flute
entry.def: A player on the flute; a flutist.

cs.cd: an octave flute.
the German flute, held laterally, instead of being played, like the old flûte à bec, with a mouth piece at the end.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: A flute.

entry.ety: L. flavus yellow + E. aniline
entry.def: A yellow, crystalline, organic dyestuff, C16H14N2, of artifical production. It is a strong base, and is a complex derivative of aniline and quinoline.

entry.ety: L. flavescens, p. pr. of flavescere to turn yellow
entry.def: Turning yellow; yellowish.

entry.ety: L. flavicomus; flavus yellow + coma hair
entry.def: Having yellow hair.

entry.ety: L. flavus yellow
entry.def: A yellow, vegetable dyestuff, resembling quercitron.
A yellow, crystalline, organic base, C13H12N2O, obtained artificially.

entry.ety: L. flavus yellow + -oil
entry.def: A yellow, crystalline substance, obtained from anthraquinone, and regarded as a hydroxyl derivative of it.

entry.ety: OF. fleur flaurtwo syllables), odor, cf. F. fleurer to emit an odor, It. flatore a bad odor, prob. fr. L. flare to bow, whence the sense of exhalation. Cf. Blow

sn.def: That quality of anything which affects the smell; odor; fragrances; as, the flavor of a rose.
That quality of anything which affects the taste; that quality which gratifies the palate; relish; zest; savor; as, the flavor of food or drink.
That which imparts to anything a peculiar odor or taste, gratifying to the sense of smell, or the nicer perceptions of the palate; a substance which flavors.
That quality which gives character to any of the productions of literature or the fine arts.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flavored; p. pr. & vb. n. Flavoring
entry.def: To give flavor to; to add something (as salt or a spice) to, to give character or zest.
Having a distinct flavor; as, high-flavored wine.
tasteful; having a good taste; -- of food.
entry.syn: flavourful, flavorous, flavourous, flavorsome, flavoursome, sapid, saporous.

entry.def: something added to food primarily for the savor it imparts.
Without flavor; tasteless. Opposite of flavorful.
Imparting flavor; pleasant to the taste or smell; sapid.
same as flavor v. and n..
same as flavored; -- of foods.
same as flavoring.
same as flavorful.
entry.syn: flavorful, flavorous, flavourous, flavorsome, flavoursome, sapid, saporous.

entry.def: same as flavoring.
same as flavorless.
same as flavorful.
entry.syn: flavorful, flavourful, flavorous, flavorsome, flavoursome, sapid, saporous.

entry.def: same as flavorful.
entry.syn: flavorful, flavourful, flavorous, flavourous, flavorsome, sapid, saporous.

entry.ety: L. flavus
entry.def: Yellow.

entry.ety: OE. flai flaw flake; cf. Sw. flaga flaw, crack, breach, flake, D. vlaag gust of wind, Norw. flage flaag, and E. flag a flat stone

sn.def: A crack or breach; a gap or fissure; a defect of continuity or cohesion; as, a flaw in a knife or a vase.
sn.q: This heart Shall break into a hundered thousand flaws.

sn.def: A defect; a fault; as, a flaw in reputation; a flaw in a will, in a deed, or in a statute.
sn.q: Has not this also its flaws and its dark side?

sn.def: A sudden burst of noise and disorder; a tumult; uproar; a quarrel.
sn.q: And deluges of armies from the town Came pouring in; I heard the mighty flaw.

sn.def: A sudden burst or gust of wind of short duration.
sn.q: Snow, and hail, and stormy gust and flaw.
Like flaws in summer laying lusty corn.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flawed; p. pr. & vb. n. Flawing

sn.def: To crack; to make flaws in.
sn.q: The brazen caldrons with the frosts are flawed.

sn.def: To break; to violate; to make of no effect.
sn.q: France hath flawed the league.

entry.def: having flaws or imperfections; not perfect; -- applied broadly; as, a flawed vase; a flawed performance; a flawed character.
Free from flaws.

entry.ety: OF. flaon, F. flan, LL. flado, fr. OHG. flado, G. fladen, a sort of pancake; cf. Gr. � broad. See Place
entry.def: A sort of flat custard or pie.

entry.ety: Cf. Flay
entry.def: To scrape or pare, as a skin.

sn.def: Full of flaws or cracks; broken; defective; faulty.
Subject to sudden flaws or gusts of wind.

entry.cs: Earth flax Min amianthus. Flax brake a machine for removing the woody portion of flax from the fibrous. Flax comb a hatchel, hackle, or heckle. Flax cotton the fiber of flax, reduced by steeping in bicarbonate of soda and acidulated liquids, and prepared for bleaching and spinning like cotton. Knight. Flax dresser one who breaks and swingles flax, or prepares it for the spinner. Flax mill a mill or factory where flax is spun or linen manufactured. Flax puller a machine for pulling flax plants in the field. Flax wench. A woman who spins flax. Obs A prostitute. Obs Shak. Mountain flax Min amianthus. New Zealand flax Bot See Flax-plant.
entry.ety: AS. fleax; akin to D. vlas OHG. flahs, G. flachs, and prob. to flechten to braid, plait,m twist, L. plectere to weave, plicare to fold, Gr. � to weave, plait. See Ply

sn.def: A plant of the genus Linum, esp. the L. usitatissimum, which has a single, slender stalk, about a foot and a half high, with blue flowers. The fiber of the bark is used for making thread and cloth, called linen cambric lawn lace, etc. Linseed oil is expressed from the seed.
The skin or fibrous part of the flax plant, when broken and cleaned by hatcheling or combing.

entry.def: Made of flax; resembling flax or its fibers; of the color of flax; of a light soft straw color; fair and flowing, like flax or tow; as, flaxen thread; flaxen hair.

A plant in new Zealand (Phormium tenax), allied to the lilies and aloes. The leaves are two inches wide and several feet long, and furnish a fiber which is used for making ropes, mats, and coarse cloth.
The seed of the flax; linseed.
See Toadflax.
Like flax; flaxen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flayed flād; p. pr. & vb. n. Flaying
entry.ety: OE. flean flan, AS. fleán; akin to D. vlaen, Icel. flā, Sw. flå, Dan. flaae, cf. Lith. pleszti to tear, plyszti, v.i., to burst, tear; perh. akin to E. flag a flat stone, flaw
entry.def: To skin; to strip off the skin or surface of; as, to flay an ox; to flay the green earth.
entry.q: With her nails She 'll flay thy wolfish visage.

entry.def: One who strips off the skin.

entry.ety: See Flay
entry.def: To flay.
entry.q: He will be fleaed first And horse collars made of's skin.

cs.cd: an unwelcome hint or unexpected reply, annoying like a flea; an irritating repulse; as, to put a flea in one's ear; to go away with a flea in one's ear.
etc. See under Beach, etc.

entry.ety: OE. fle flee, AS. fleá fleáh; akin to D. vtoo, OHG. flōh, G. floh, Icel. flō, Russ. blocha; prob. from the root of E. flee. √84. See Flee
entry.def: An insect belonging to the genus Pulex, of the order Aphaniptera. Fleas are destitute of wings, but have the power of leaping energetically. The bite is poisonous to most persons. The human flea (Pulex irritans), abundant in Europe, is rare in America, where the dog flea (Ctenocephalides canis, formerly Pulex canis) and the smaller cat flea (Ctenocephalides felis) take its place. See Aphaniptera, and Dog flea. See Illustration in Appendix.
One of various plants, supposed to have efficacy in driving away fleas. They belong, for the most part, to the genera Conyza Erigeron, and Pulicaria.

A small beetle of the family Halticidæ, of many species. They have strong posterior legs and leap like fleas. The turnip flea-beetle (Phyllotreta vittata) and that of the grapevine (Graptodera chalybea) are common injurious species.

sn.def: The bite of a flea, or the red spot caused by the bite.
A trifling wound or pain, like that of the bite of a flea.
Bitten by a flea; as, a flea-bitten face.
White, flecked with minute dots of bay or sorrel; -- said of the color of a horse.
same as creaky, 1.

entry.def: imp. of Fly.
A flake; a thread or twist.
entry.q: Little long fleaks or threads of hemp.

entry.def: A light covering of reeds, over which the main covering is laid, in thatching houses.
A jumping plant louse of the family Psyllidæ, of many species. That of the pear tree is Psylla pyri.

cs.cd: a tooth of a saw shaped like an isosceles triangle; a peg tooth.

entry.ety: F. flamme, OF. flieme, fr. LL. flevotomum phlebotomum; cf. D. vlijm. See Phlebotomy
entry.def: A sharp instrument used for opening veins, lancing gums, etc.; a kind of lancet.
Bloody; clotted.
entry.q: Foamy bubbling of a fleamy brain.

entry.def: See Fleer.
An herb used in medicine (Plantago Psyllium), named from the shape of its seeds.

entry.ety: F. flèche, prop., an arrow
entry.def: A simple fieldwork, consisting of two faces forming a salient angle pointing outward and open at the gorge.
A flake; also, a lock, as of wool.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. flekkr; akin to Sw. fläck, D. vlek, G. fleck, and perh. to E. flitch
entry.def: A spot; a streak; a speckle.
entry.q: A sunnyfleck.
Life is dashed with flecks of sin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flecked; p. pr. & vb. n. Flecking
entry.ety: Cf. Icel. flekka, Sw. fläcka, D. vlekken vlakken, G. flecken. See Fleck n.
entry.def: To spot; to streak or stripe; to variegate; to dapple.
entry.q: Both flecked with white, the true Arcadian strain.
A bird, a cloud, flecking the sunny air.

entry.def: To fleck.
Without spot or blame.
entry.q: My consnience will not count me fleckless.

entry.ety: See Flexion

sn.def: The act of bending, or state of being bent.
The variation of words by declension, comparison, or conjugation; inflection.

entry.def: Capable of, or pertaining to, flection or inflection.
entry.q: A flectional word is a phrase in the bud.

entry.def: A flexor.
imp. & p. p. of Flee.

entry.ety: OE. flegge flygge; akin to D. vlug, G. flügge flücke, OHG. flucchi, Icel. fleygr, and to E. fly. √84. See Fly v. i.
entry.def: Feathered; furnished with feathers or wings; able to fly.
entry.q: His shoulders, fledge with wings.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fledged; p. pr. & vb. n. Fledging

sn.def: To furnish with feathers; to supply with the feathers necessary for flight.
sn.q: The birds were not as yet fledged enough to shift for themselves.

sn.def: To furnish or adorn with any soft covering.
sn.q: Your master, whose chin is not yet fledged.

entry.sn: having developed feathers or plumage; often used in combination; -- of birds.Narrower terms: fledgling(prenominal), fledgeling(prenominal unfledged mature.

sn.def: equipped with feathers; -- of an arrow.

entry.def: not equipped with feathers; -- of an arrow.
a new member of a group.
entry.syn: newcomer, fledgeling, starter, neophyte, freshman, entrant.

sn.def: A young bird just fledged.
having just acquired its flight feathers; -- of a young bird; as, a fledgling robin.
young and inexperienced; as, a fledgling enterprise; a fledgling skier.

entry.note: ☞ When great speed is to be indicated, we commonly use fly, not flee; as, fly hence to France with the utmost speed. “Whither shall I fly to 'scape their hands?” Shak. See Fly v. i., 5.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fled flĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Fleeing
entry.ety: OE. fleon fleen, AS. fleón imperf. fleáh); akin to D. vlieden, OHG. & OS. fliohan, G. fliehen, Icel. flȳjaimperf. flȳði), Dan. flye, Sw. flyimperf. flydde), Goth. þliuhan. √84. Cf. Flight
entry.def: To run away, as from danger or evil; to avoid in an alarmed or cowardly manner; to hasten off; -- usually with from. This is sometimes omitted, making the verb transitive.
entry.q: He] cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke.
Flee fornication.
So fled his enemies my warlike father.

entry.cs: Fleece wool wool shorn from the sheep. Golden fleece. See under Golden.
entry.ety: OE. flees, AS. fleós; akin to D. flies vlies

sn.def: The entire coat of wool that covers a sheep or other similar animal; also, the quantity shorn from a sheep, or animal, at one time.
sn.q: Who shore me Like a tame wether, all my precious fleece.

sn.def: Any soft woolly covering resembling a fleece.
The fine web of cotton or wool removed by the doffing knife from the cylinder of a carding machine.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fleeced; p. pr. & vb. n. Fleecing

sn.def: To deprive of a fleece, or natural covering of wool.
To strip of money or other property unjustly, especially by trickery or fraud; to bring to straits by oppressions and exactions.
sn.q: Whilst pope and prince shared the wool betwixt them, the people were finely fleeced.

sn.def: To spread over as with wool.
Furnished with a fleece; as, a sheep is well fleeced .
Stripped of a fleece; plundered; robbed.

entry.def: Without a fleece.
One who fleeces or strips unjustly, especially by trickery or fraund.
Covered with, made of, or resembling, a fleece.
entry.q: Fleecyflocks.

entry.def: Obs. pl. of Flea.
One who flees.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. fleered flērd; p. pr. & vb. n. fleering
entry.ety: OE. flerien; cf. Scot. fleyr, Norw. flira to titter, giggle, laugh at nothing, MHG. vlerre vlarre, a wide wound

sn.def: To make a wry face in contempt, or to grin in scorn; to deride; to sneer; to mock; to gibe; as, to fleer and flout.
sn.q: To fleer and scorn at our solemnity.

sn.def: To grin with an air of civility; to leer.
sn.q: Grinning and fleering as though they went to a bear baiting.

entry.def: To mock; to flout at.

sn.def: A word or look of derision or mockery.
sn.q: And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorn.

sn.def: A grin of civility; a leer.
sn.q: A sly, treacherous fleer on the face of deceivers.

entry.def: One who fleers.
In a fleering manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. fleeted; p. pr. & vb. n. fleeting
entry.ety: OE. fleten fleoten, to swim, AS. fleótan to swim, float; akin to D. vlieten to flow, OS. fliotan, OHG. fliozzan, G. fliessen, Icel. fljōta to float, flow, Sw. flyta, D. flyde, L. pluere to rain, Gr. plei^n to sail, swim, float, Skr. plu to swim, sail. √84. Cf. Fleet n. & a. Float Pluvial Flow

sn.def: To sail; to float.
sn.q: And in frail wood on Adrian Gulf doth fleet.

sn.def: To fly swiftly; to pass over quickly; to hasten; to flit as a light substance.
sn.q: All the unaccomplished works of Nature's hand, . . . Dissolved on earth, fleet hither.

sn.def: To slip on the whelps or the barrel of a capstan or windlass; -- said of a cable or hawser.
To move or change in position; -- said of persons; as, the crew fleeted aft.
To pass over rapidly; to skin the surface of; as, a ship that fleets the gulf.
To hasten over; to cause to pass away lighty, or in mirth and joy.
sn.q: Many young gentlemen flock to him, and fleet the time carelessly.

sd.def: To draw apart the blocks of; -- said of a tackle.
To cause to slip down the barrel of a capstan or windlass, as a rope or chain.

sn.def: To move or change in position; used only in special phrases; as, of fleet aft the crew.
sn.q: We got the long “stick” . . . down and “fleeted” aft, where it was secured.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. fljōtr quick. See Fleet v. i.

sn.def: Swift in motion; moving with velocity; light and quick in going from place to place; nimble.
sn.q: In mail their horses clad, yet fleet and strong.

sn.def: Light; superficially thin; not penetrating deep, as soil.

cs.cd: the senior aid of the admiral of a fleet, when a captain.

entry.ety: OE. flete fleote, AS. fleót ship, fr. fleótan to float, swim. See Fleet v. i. and cf. Float
entry.def: A number of vessels in company, especially war vessels; also, the collective naval force of a country, etc.

cs.cd: a clergyman of low character, in, or in the vicinity of, the Fleet prison, who was ready to unite persons in marriage (called Fleet marriage) at any hour, without public notice, witnesses, or consent of parents.

entry.ety: AS. fleót a place where vessels float, bay, river; akin to D. vliet rill, brook, G. fliess. See Fleet v. i.

sn.def: A flood; a creek or inlet; a bay or estuary; a river; -- obsolete, except as a place name, -- as Fleet Street in London.
sn.q: Together wove we nets to entrap the fish In floods and sedgy fleets.

sn.def: A former prison in London, which originally stood near a stream, the Fleetnow filled up).

entry.ety: AS. flēt cream, fr. fleótan to float. See Fleet v. i.
entry.def: To take the cream from; to skim.

entry.cs: Fleeten face a face of the color of fleeten, i. e., blanched; hence, a coward. “You know where you are, you fleeten face.” Beau. & Fl.
entry.def: Fleeted or skimmed milk.
Swift of foot.
Passing swiftly away; not durable; transient; transitory; as, the fleeting hours or moments.
In a fleeting manner; swiftly.
A mixture of buttermilk and boiling whey; curds.
In a fleet manner; rapidly.
Swiftness; rapidity; velocity; celerity; speed; as, the fleetness of a horse or of time.
imp. of Fly.

entry.ety: AS. flēman flȳman
entry.def: To banish; to drive out; to expel.
entry.q: Appetiteflemeth discretion.

entry.def: One who, or that which, banishes or expels.
A native or inhabitant of Flanders.

entry.cs: Flemish accounts Naut short or deficient accounts. Humorous Ham. Nav. Encyc. Flemish beauty Bot a well known pear. It is one of few kinds which have a red color on one side. Flemish bond. Arch See Bond n., 8. Flemish brick a hard yellow paving brick. Flemish coil a flat coil of rope with the end in the center and the turns lying against, without riding over, each other. Flemish eye Naut an eye formed at the end of a rope by dividing the strands and lying them over each other. Flemish horse Naut an additional footrope at the end of a yard.
entry.def: Pertaining to Flanders, or the Flemings.

def2.def: The language or dialect spoken by the Flemings; also, collectively, the people of Flanders.

entry.def: Same as Flence.

entry.ety: Cf. Dan. flense, D. vlensen vlenzen, Scot. flinch
entry.def: To strip the blubber or skin from, as from a whale, seal, etc.
entry.q: the flensed carcass of a fur seal.

entry.note: ☞ In composition it is mainly proteinaceous, but contains in adition a large number of low-molecular-weight subtances, such as creatin, xanthin, hypoxanthin, carnin, etc. It is also rich in potassium phosphate.
☞ Flesh is often used adjectively or self-explaining compounds; as, flesh broth or flesh-broth; flesh brush or fleshbrush; flesh tint or flesh-tint; flesh wound.
entry.cs: After the flesh after the manner of man; in a gross or earthly manner. “Ye judge after the flesh.” John viii. 15. An arm of flesh human strength or aid. Flesh and blood. See under Blood. Flesh broth broth made by boiling flesh in water. Flesh fly Zoöl one of several species of flies whose larvæ or maggots feed upon flesh, as the bluebottle fly; -- called also meat fly carrion fly, and blowfly. See Blowly. Flesh meat animal food. Swift. Flesh side the side of a skin or hide which was next to the flesh; -- opposed to grain side. Flesh tint Painting a color used in painting to imitate the hue of the living body. Flesh worm Zoöl any insect larva of a flesh fly. See Flesh flyabove). Proud flesh. See under Proud. To be one flesh to be closely united as in marriage; to become as one person. Gen. ii. 24.
entry.ety: OE. flesch flesc, AS. flǣsc; akin to OFries. flāsk, D. vleesch, OS. flēsk, OHG. fleisc, G. fleisch, Icel. & Dan. flesk lard, bacon, pork, Sw. fläsk

sn.def: The aggregate of the muscles, fat, and other tissues which cover the framework of bones in man and other animals; especially, the muscles.
Animal food, in distinction from vegetable; meat; especially, the body of beasts and birds used as food, as distinguished from fish.
sn.q: With roasted flesh, or milk, and wastel bread.

sn.def: The human body, as distinguished from the soul; the corporeal person.
sn.q: As if this flesh, which walls about our life, Were brass impregnable.

sn.def: The human eace; mankind; humanity.
sn.q: All flesh had corrupted his way upon the earth.

entry.sn:
Human nature: In a good sense, tenderness of feeling; gentleness. There is no flesh in man's obdurate heart.
In a bad sense, tendency to transient or physical pleasure; desire for sensual gratification; carnality.
Theol The character under the influence of animal propensities or selfish passions; the soul unmoved by spiritual influences.

sn.def: Kindred; stock; race.
sn.q: He is our brother and our flesh.

sn.def: The soft, pulpy substance of fruit; also, that part of a root, fruit, and the like, which is fit to be eaten.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fleshed; p. pr. & vb. n. Fleshing

sn.def: To feed with flesh, as an incitement to further exertion; to initiate; -- from the practice of training hawks and dogs by feeding them with the first game they take, or other flesh. Hence, to use upon flesh (as a murderous weapon) so as to draw blood, especially for the first time.
sn.q: Full bravely hast thou fleshed Thy maiden sword.
The wild dog Shall flesh his tooth on every innocent.

sn.def: To glut; to satiate; hence, to harden, to accustom.
sn.q: Fleshedin triumphs.
Old soldiersFleshed in the spoils of Germany and France.

sn.def: To remove flesh, membrance, etc., from, as from hides.
Corpulent; fat; having flesh.
Glutted; satiated; initiated.
sn.q: Fleshed with slaughter.

sn.def: A butcher.
sn.q: A flesher on a block had laid his whittle down.

sn.def: A two-handled, convex, blunt-edged knife, for scraping hides; a fleshing knife.

entry.def: The state or condition of having a form of flesh; incarnation.
entry.q: Thou, who hast thyself Endured this fleshhood.

entry.def: The state of being fleshy; plumpness; corpulence; grossness.
Flesh-colored tights, worn by actors and dancers.
Destitute of flesh; lean.
The state of being fleshly; carnal passions and appetites.
A person devoted to fleshly things.

entry.ety: AS. flǣsclīc

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the flesh; corporeal.
sn.q: Fleshlybondage.

sn.def: Animal; not vegetable.
Human; not celestial; not spiritual or divine.
sn.q: Fleshlywisdom.
Much ostentation vain of fleshly arm And fragile arms.

sn.def: Carnal; wordly; lascivious.
sn.q: Abstain from fleshly lusts, which war against the soul.

entry.def: In a fleshly manner; carnally; lasciviously.
The act of fleshing, or the excitement attending a successful beginning.

entry.ety: AS. flǣsc mangere
entry.def: One who deals in flesh; hence, a pimp; a procurer; a pander.

sn.def: A pot or vessel in which flesh is cooked.
sn.q: In the land of Egypt . . . we sat by the fleshpots, and . . . did eat bread to the full.

sn.def: plenty; high living.
Places providing opportunity to indulge in amusements or pleasures without moral restraints.

entry.def: A quaking or trembling of the flesh; a quiver.

sn.def: Full of, or composed of, flesh; plump; corpulent; fat; gross.
sn.q: The sole of his foot is fleshy.

sn.def: Human.
sn.q: Fleshytabernacle.

sn.def: Composed of firm pulp; succulent; as, the houseleek, cactus, and agave are fleshy plants.

entries.entry: Flet p. p. of Fleet . Skimmed. Obs

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fletched; p. pr. & vb. n. Fletching
entry.ety: F. flèche arrow
entry.def: To feather, as an arrow.
entry.q: Congressfletched their complaint, by adding: “America loved his brother.”

entry.ety: OF. flechier
entry.def: One who fletches or feathers arrows; a manufacturer of bows and arrows.

entry.ety: See Fleet v. i.
entry.def: To float; to swim.
entry.q: Whether I sink orflete.

entry.ety: L. fletifer; fletus a weeping (from flere fletum, to weep) + ferre to bear
entry.def: Producing tears.

entries.entry:
‖Fleur`-de-lis` n.; pl.Fleurs-de-lis #. F., flower of the lily. Cf. Flower-de-luce Lily
Bot The iris. See Flower-de-luce.
A conventional flower suggested by the iris, and having a form which fits it for the terminal decoration of a scepter, the ornaments of a crown, etc. It is also a heraldic bearing, and is identified with the royal arms and adornments of France.

entry.ety: F., fr. OF. floron. Cf. Floroon
entry.def: A flower-shaped ornament, esp. one terminating an object or forming one of a series, as a knob of a cover to a dish, or a flower-shaped part in a necklace.

entry.ety: F. fleuri covered with flowers, p. p. of fleurir. See Flourish
entry.def: Finished at the ends with fleurs-de-lis; -- said esp. of a cross so decorated.
imp. of Fly.
Having large flews.
The pendulous or overhanging lateral parts of the upper lip of dogs, especially prominent in hounds; -- called also chaps. See Illust. of Bloodhound.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flexed; p. pr. & vb. n. Flexing
entry.ety: L. flexus, p. p. of flectere to bend, perh. flectere and akin to falx sickle, E. falchion. Cf. Flinch
entry.def: To bend; as, to flex the arm.
Flax.

entry.ety: L. flexanimus; flectere flexum, to bend + animus mind
entry.def: Having power to change the mind.

entry.ety: L. flexibilitas: cf. F. flexibilite
entry.def: The state or quality of being flexible; flexibleness; pliancy; pliability; as, the flexibility of strips of hemlock, hickory, whalebone or metal, or of rays of light.
entry.q: All the flexibility of a veteran courtier.

entry.ety: L. flexibilis: cf. F. flexible

sn.def: Capable of being flexed or bent; admitting of being turned, bowed, or twisted, without breaking; pliable; yielding to pressure; not stiff or brittle.
sn.q: When the splitting wind Makes flexible the knees of knotted oaks.

sn.def: Willing or ready to yield to the influence of others; not invincibly rigid or obstinate; tractable; manageable; ductile; easy and compliant; wavering.
sn.q: Phocion was a man of great severity, and no ways flexible to the will of the people.
Women are soft, mild, pitiful, and flexible.

sn.def: Capable or being adapted or molded; plastic,; as, a flexible language.
sn.q: This was a principle more flexible to their purpose.
sn.syn: Pliant; pliable; supple; tractable; manageable; ductile; obsequious; inconstant; wavering.

entry.ety: L. flexus bent + E. costate
entry.def: Having bent or curved ribs.

entry.ety: L. flexilis
entry.def: Flexible; pliant; pliable; easily bent; plastic; tractable.

entry.ety: L. flexio: cf. F. flexion

sn.def: The act of flexing or bending; a turning.
A bending; a part bent; a fold.
Syntactical change of form of words, as by declension or conjugation; inflection.
sn.q: Express the syntactical relations by flexion.

sn.def: The bending of a limb or joint; that motion of a joint which gives the distal member a continually decreasing angle with the axis of the proximal part; -- distinguished from extension.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A muscle which bends or flexes any part; as, the flexors of the arm or the hand; -- opposed to extensor.

entry.note: Certain workers prefer to arrive early and leave early, and others prefer to arrive late and leave late. Flex time is a way to accommodate such preferences, presumably improving employee morale, and also helps reduce traffic congestion during commmuting times.
entry.ety: short for flexible time
entry.def: A system of scheduling working hours in places of employment, which allows employees to arrive at and leave work at times of their own choice, providing that they work the required number of hours and usually requiring that they be present during certain hours, called core time.
Flexuous.

entry.ety: L. flexuosus, fr. flexus a bending, turning

sn.def: Having turns, windings, or flexures.
Having alternate curvatures in opposite directions; bent in a zigzag manner.
Wavering; not steady; flickering.

entry.ety: From Flexure
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resulting from, flexure; of the nature of, or characterized by, flexure; as, flexural elasticity.

cs.cd: the bending of a curve towards or from a straight line.

entry.ety: L. flexura

sn.def: The act of flexing or bending; a turning or curving; flexion; hence, obsequious bowing or bending.
sn.q: Will it give place to flexure and low bending?

sn.def: A turn; a bend; a fold; a curve.
sn.q: Varying with the flexures of the valley through which it meandered.

sn.def: The last joint, or bend, of the wing of a bird.

The small distortion of an astronomical instrument caused by the weight of its parts; the amount to be added or substracted from the observed readings of the instrument to correct them for this distortion.

entry.def: A sycophant.
entry.q: Flatterers andflibbergibs.

entry.def: An imp.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A buccaneer; an American pirate. See Filibuster.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flicked flĭkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Flicking
entry.ety: Cf. Flicker

sn.def: To whip lightly or with a quick jerk; to flap; as, to flick a horse; to flick the dirt from boots.
To throw, snap, or toss with a jerk; to flirt; as, to flick a whiplash.
sn.q: Rude boys were flicking butter pats across chaos.

entry.def: A flitch; as, a flick of bacon.

entry.ety: See Flick v. t.

sn.def: A light quick stroke or blow, esp. with something pliant; a flirt; also, the sound made by such a blow.
sn.q: She actually took the whip out of his hand and gave a flick to the pony.

sn.def: A motion picture; as, I went to see a flick on Friday.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flickered flĭk"ẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Flickering
entry.ety: OE. flikeren flekeren, to flutter, AS. flicerian flicorian, cf. D. flikkeren to sparkle. √84. Cf. Flacker

sn.def: To flutter; to flap the wings without flying.
sn.q: And flickering on her nest made short essays to sing.

sn.def: To waver unsteadily, like a flame in a current of air, or when about to expire; as, the flickering light.
sn.q: The shadows flicker to fro.

sn.def: The act of wavering or of fluttering; fluctuation; sudden and brief increase of brightness; as, the last flicker of the dying flame.
The golden-winged woodpecker (Colaptes aurutus); -- so called from its spring note. Called also yellow-hammer high-holder pigeon woodpecker, and yucca.
sn.q: The cackle of the flicker among the oaks.

entry.def: In a flickering manner.
See Flittermouse.
Fledged; fledge.
To become fledged; to fledge.
entry.q: Every day build their nests, every hour flidge.

entry.ety: Form Fly v.; cf. Flyer

sn.def: One who flies or flees; a runaway; a fugitive.
A fly. See Fly n., 9, and 13 .
See Flyer n., 5.
See Flyer n., 4.
An aëroplane or flying machine.

cs.cd: the wing feathers of a bird, including the quills, coverts, and bastard wing. See Bird.
to compel to run away; to force to flee; to rout.
to make a trip in an airplane, especially a scheduled flight{9}.

entry.ety: AS. fliht flyht, a flying, fr. fleógan to fly; cf. flyht a fleeing, fr. fleón to flee, G. flucht a fleeing, Sw. flykt, G. flug a flying, Sw. flygt, D. vlugt a fleeing or flying, Dan. flugt. √84. See Flee Fly

sn.def: The act of flying; a passing through the air by the help of wings; volitation; mode or style of flying.
sn.q: Like the night owl's lazy flight.

sn.def: The act of fleeing; the act of running away, to escape danger or expected evil; hasty departure.
sn.q: Pray ye that your flight be not in the winter.
Fain by flight to save themselves.

sn.def: Lofty elevation and excursion; a mounting; a soaring; as, a flight of imagination, ambition, folly.
sn.q: Could he have kept his spirit to that flight,He had been happy.
His highest flights were indeed far below those of Taylor.

sn.def: A number of beings or things passing through the air together; especially, a flock of birds flying in company; the birds that fly or migrate together; the birds produced in one season; as, a flight of arrows.
sn.q: Swift flights of angels ministrant.
Like a flight of fowl Scattered winds and tempestuous gusts.

sn.def: A series of steps or stairs from one landing to another.
A kind of arrow for the longbow; also, the sport of shooting with it. See Shaft.
sn.q: Challenged Cupid at the flight.
Not a flight drawn home E'er made that haste that they have.

sn.def: The husk or glume of oats.
a trip made by or in a flying vehicle, as an airplane, spacecraft, or aeronautical balloon.
A scheduled flight{8} on a commercial airline; as, the next flight leaves at 8 o'clock.
Taking flight; flying; -- used in composition.
sn.q: Drowsy-flightedsteeds.

sn.def: Feathered; -- said of arrows.

entry.def: A horizontal vane revolving over the surface of wort in a cooler, to produce a circular current in the liquor.
In a flighty manner.
The state or quality of being flighty.
entry.q: The flightness of her temper.
entry.syn: Levity; giddiness; volatility; lightness; wildness; eccentricity. See Levity.

entry.def: The distance to which an arrow or flight may be shot; bowshot, -- about the fifth of a mile.
entry.q: Within a flight-shot it inthe valley.
Half a flight-shot from the king's oak.

sn.def: Fleeting; swift; transient.
sn.q: The flighty purpose never is o'ertook, Unless the deed go with it.

sn.def: Indulging in flights, or wild and unrestrained sallies, of imagination, humor, caprice, etc.; given to disordered fancies and extravagant conduct; volatile; giddy; eccentric; slighty delirious.
sn.q: Proofs of my flighty and paradoxical turn of mind.
A harsh disciplinarian and a flighty enthusiast.

entry.ety: Cf. Flam
entry.def: A freak; a trick; a lie.
In a flimsy manner.
The state or quality of being flimsy.

entry.ety: Cf. W. llymsi naked, bare, empty, sluggish, spiritless. Cf. Limsy
entry.def: Weak; feeble; limp; slight; vain; without strength or solidity; of loose and unsubstantial structure; without reason or plausibility; as, a flimsy argument, excuse, objection.
entry.q: Proud of a vast extent of flimsy lines.
All the flimsy furniture of a country miss's brain.

sn.def: Thin or transfer paper.
A bank note.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flinched; p. pr. & vb. n. Flinching
entry.ety: Prob. fr. OE. flecchen to waver, give way, F. fléchir, fr. L. flectere to bend; but prob. influenced by E. blench. Cf. Flex

sn.def: To withdraw from any suffering or undertaking, from pain or danger; to fail in doing or perserving; to show signs of yielding or of suffering; to shrink; to wince; as, one of the parties flinched from the combat.
sn.q: A child, by a constant course of kindness, may be accustomed to bear very rough usage without flinching or complaining.

sn.def: To let the foot slip from a ball, when attempting to give a tight croquet.

entry.def: The act of flinching.
One who flinches or fails.
In a flinching manner.

entry.ety: OE. vlindre moth (cf. D. vlinder butterfly) + E. mouse. Cf. Flittermouse Flinders
entry.def: A bat; a flittermouse.

entry.ety: Scot. flenders flendris; perh. akin to E. flutter; cf. D. flenters rags, broken pieces
entry.def: Small pieces or splinters; fragments.
entry.q: The tough ash spear, so stout and true, Into a thousand flinders flew.

entry.def: A small genus of Australian timber trees.
A tall Australian timber tree (Flindersia australis) yielding tough hard wood used for staves etc.

entry.cs: To fling about to throw on all sides; to scatter. To fling away to reject; to discard. Cromwell, I charge thee, fling away ambition. Shak. To fling down. To throw to the ground; esp., to throw in defiance, as formerly knights cast a glove into the arena as a challenge. This question so flung down before the guests, . . . Was handed over by consent of all To me who had not spoken. Tennyson. To overturn; to demolish; to ruin. To fling in to throw in; not to charge in an account; as, in settling accounts, one party flings in a small sum, or a few days' work. To fling off to baffle in the chase; to defeat of prey; also, to get rid of. Addison. To fling open to throw open; to open suddenly or with violence; as, to fling open a door. To fling out to utter; to speak in an abrupt or harsh manner; as, to fling out hard words against another. To fling up to relinquish; to abandon; as, to fling up a design.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flung flŭng; p. pr. & vb. n. Flinging
entry.ety: OE. flingen flengen, to rush, hurl; cf. Icel. flengia to whip, ride furiously, OSw. flenga to strike, Sw. flänga to romp, Dan. flenge to slash

sn.def: To cast, send, to throw from the hand; to hurl; to dart; to emit with violence as if thrown from the hand; as, to fing a stone into the pond.
sn.q: 'T is Fate that flings the dice: and, as she flings, Of kings makes peasants, and of peasants kings.
He . . . like Jove, his lighting flung.
I know thy generous temper well.Fling but the appearance of dishonor on it, It straight takes fire.

sn.def: To shed forth; to emit; to scatter.
sn.q: The sun begins to fling His flaring beams.
Every beam new transient colors flings.

sn.def: To throw; to hurl; to throw off or down; to prostrate; hence, to baffle; to defeat; as, to fling a party in litigation.
sn.q: His horse started, flung him, and fell upon him.

cs.cd: to become ugly and intractable; to utter sneers and insinuations.

sn.def: To throw; to wince; to flounce; as, the horse began to kick and fling .
To cast in the teeth; to utter abusive language; to sneer; as, the scold began to flout and fling .
To throw one's self in a violent or hasty manner; to rush or spring with violence or haste.
sn.q: And crop-full, out of doors he flings.
I flung closer to his breast, As sword that, after battle, flings to sheath.

entry.cs: To have one's fling to enjoy one's self to the full; to have a season of dissipation. J. H. Newman. “When I was as young as you, I had my fling. I led a life of pleasure.” D. Jerrold.

sn.def: A cast from the hand; a throw; also, a flounce; a kick; as, the fling of a horse.
A severe or contemptuous remark; an expression of sarcastic scorn; a gibe; a sarcasm.
sn.q: I, who love to have a fling, Both at senate house and king.

sn.def: A kind of dance; as, the Highland fling .
A trifing matter; an object of contempt.
sn.q: England were but a fling Save for the crooked stick and the gray goose wing.

sn.def: a short period during which one indulges one's wishes, whims, or desires in an unrestrained manner.
a love affair.
a casual or brief attempt to accomplish something.
a period during which one tries a new activity; as, he took a fling at playing tennis.

entry.def: One who kicks up the dust; a streetwalker; a low manner.
One who flings; one who jeers.

entry.cs: Flint age. Geol Same as Stone age, under Stone. Flint brick a fire made principially of powdered silex. Flint glass. See in the Vocabulary. Flint implements Archæol tools, etc., employed by men before the use of metals, such as axes, arrows, spears, knives, wedges, etc., which were commonly made of flint, but also of granite, jade, jasper, and other hard stones. Flint mill. Pottery A mill in which flints are ground. Mining An obsolete appliance for lighting the miner at his work, in which flints on a revolving wheel were made to produce a shower of sparks, which gave light, but did not inflame the fire damp. Knight. Flint stone a hard, siliceous stone; a flint. Flint wall a kind of wall, common in England, on the face of which are exposed the black surfaces of broken flints set in the mortar, with quions of masonry. Liquor of flints a solution of silica, or flints, in potash. To skin a flint to be capable of, or guilty of, any expedient or any meanness for making money. Colloq
entry.ety: AS. flint, akin to Sw. flinta, Dan. flint; cf. OHG. flins flint, G. flinte gun (cf. E. flintlock), perh. akin to Gr. � brick. Cf. Plinth

sn.def: A massive, somewhat impure variety of quartz, in color usually of a gray to brown or nearly black, breaking with a conchoidal fracture and sharp edge. It is very hard, and strikes fire with steel.
A piece of flint for striking fire; -- formerly much used, esp. in the hammers of gun locks.
Anything extremely hard, unimpressible, and unyielding, like flint.
sn.q: A heart offlint.

entries.entry: Flint" glass` ☞ The concave or diverging half on an achromatic lens is usually made of flint glass.. Chem A soft, heavy, brilliant glass, consisting essentially of a silicate of lead and potassium. It is used for tableware, and for optical instruments, as prisms, its density giving a high degree of dispersive power; -- so called, because formerly the silica was obtained from pulverized flints. Called also crystal glass. Cf. Glass.

entry.def: Hard-hearted.
The state or quality of being flinty; hardness; cruelty.

sn.def: A lock for a gun or pistol, having a flint fixed in the hammer, which on striking the steel ignites the priming.
A hand firearm fitted with a flintlock; esp., the old-fashioned musket of European and other armies.

entry.def: A superior kind of earthenware into whose composition flint enters largely.
An Australian name for the very hard wood of the Eucalyptus piluralis.

cs.cd: a siliceous slate; -- basanite is here included. See Basanite.

entry.def: Consisting of, composed of, abounding in, or resembling, flint; as, a flinty rock; flinty ground; a flinty heart.

cs.cd: an iron used, when heated, to warm flip.

entry.ety: Cf. Prov. E. flip nimble, flippant, also, a slight blow. Cf. Flippant
entry.def: A mixture of beer, spirit, etc., stirred and heated by a hot iron.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flipped flĭpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Flipping

sn.def: To toss (an object) into the air so as make it turn over one or more times; to fillip; as, to flip up a cent.
sn.q: As when your little ones Do 'twixt their fingers flip their cherry stones.

sn.def: To turn (a flat object) over with a quick motion; as, to flip a card over; to flip a pancake.
To cause (a person) to turn against former colleagues, such as to become a witness for the state, in a criminal prosecution in which the person is a defendant.
To resell (an asset) rapidly to make a quick profit.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flipped flĭpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Flipping
entry.def: To become insane or irrational; -- often used with out; as, seeing her mother killed made the girl flip out .
To turn inside out, or with the leg part back over the foot, as a stocking in pulling off or for putting on.

entry.ety: See Flip, and Flap
entry.def: The repeated stroke of something long and loose.
With repeated strokes and noise, as of something long and loose.

entry.ety: See Flippant
entry.def: The state or quality of being flippant.
entry.q: This flippancy of language.

entry.ety: Prov. E. flip to move nimbly; cf. W. llipa soft, limber, pliant, or Icel. fleipa to babble, prattle. Cf. Flip Fillip Flap Flipper

sn.def: Of smooth, fluent, and rapid speech; speaking with ease and rapidity; having a voluble tongue; talkative.
sn.q: It becometh good men, in such cases, to be flippant and free in their speech.

sn.def: Speaking fluently and confidently, without knowledge or consideration; empty; trifling; inconsiderate; pert; petulant.
sn.q: Flippantepilogues.
To put flippant scorn to the blush.
A sort of flippant, vain discourse.

entry.def: A flippant person.
In a flippant manner.
State or quality of being flippant.

entry.ety: Cf. Flip Flippant

sn.def: A broad flat limb used for swimming, as those of seals, sea turtles, whales, etc.
The hand.

entry.note: They are typically of rubber-like material, and are not worn when walking on land.
entry.ety: By analogy with flipperW13(1)], the limb of an aquatic animal used for locomotion
entry.def: A type of shoe with a paddle-like front extending well beyond the end of the toe, used an aid in swimming (especially underwater).

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flirted; p. pr. & vb. n. Flirting
entry.ety: Cf. AS. fleard trifle, folly, fleardian to trifle

sn.def: To throw with a jerk or quick effort; to fling suddenly; as, they flirt water in each other's faces; he flirted a glove, or a handkerchief.
To toss or throw about; to move playfully to and fro; as, to flirt a fan.
To jeer at; to treat with contempt; to mock.
sn.q: I am ashamed; I am scorned; I am flirted.

sn.def: To run and dart about; to act with giddiness, or from a desire to attract notice; especially, to play the coquette; to play at courtship; to coquet; as, they flirt with the young men.
To utter contemptuous language, with an air of disdain; to jeer or gibe.
A sudden jerk; a quick throw or cast; a darting motion; hence, a jeer.
sn.q: Several little flirts and vibrations.
With many a flirt and flutter.

sn.ety: Cf. LG. flirtje, G. flirtchen. See Flirt v. t.
sn.def: One who flirts; esp., a woman who acts with giddiness, or plays at courtship; a coquette; a pert girl.
sn.q: Several young flirts about town had a design to cast us out of the fashionable world.

entry.def: Pert; wanton.

sn.def: Playing at courtship; coquetry.
sn.q: The flirtations and jealousies of our ball rooms.

entry.def: A woman of light behavior; a gill-flirt.
entry.q: You heard him take me up like a flirt-gill.

entry.def: A wanton, pert girl.
In a flirting manner.
To frisk; to skip; to caper.
entry.q: Thefliskingflies.

entry.def: A caper; a spring; a whim.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Flitting
entry.ety: OE. flitten flutten, to carry away; cf. Icel. flytja, Sw. flytta, Dan. flytte. √84. Cf. Fleet v. i.

sn.def: To move with celerity through the air; to fly away with a rapid motion; to dart along; to fleet; as, a bird flits away; a cloud flits along.
sn.q: A shadow flits before me.

sn.def: To flutter; to rove on the wing.
To pass rapidly, as a light substance, from one place to another; to remove; to migrate.
sn.q: It became a received opinion, that the souls of men, departing this life, did flit out of one body into some other.

sn.def: To remove from one place or habitation to another.
To be unstable; to be easily or often moved.
sn.q: And the free soul to flitting air resigned.

entry.def: Nimble; quick; swift. Obs See Fleet.

entries.entry:
Flitch n.; pl.Flitches #. OE. flicche flikke, AS. flicce, akin to Icel. flikki; cf. Icel. flīk flap, tatter; perh. akin to E. fleck. Cf. Flick n.
The side of a hog salted and cured; a side of bacon.
One of several planks, smaller timbers, or iron plates, which are secured together, side by side, to make a large girder or built beam.
The outside piece of a sawed log; a slab. Eng

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flitched; p. pr. & vb. n. Flitching
entry.ety: See Flitch n.
entry.def: To cut into, or off in, flitches or strips; as, to flitch logs; to flitch bacon.

entry.ety: AS. flītan to strive, contend, quarrel; akin to G. fleiss industry
entry.def: To scold; to quarrel.

entry.ety: AS. flīt. See Flite
entry.def: Strife; dispute; abusive or upbraiding talk, as in fliting; wrangling.
entry.q: The bird of Pallas has also a good “flyte” on the moral side . . . in his suggestion that the principal effect of the nightingale's song is to make women false to their husbands.

entry.def: To flutter.
To flutter; to move quickly; as, to flitter the cards.

entry.ety: Cf. G. flitter spangle, tinsel, flittern to make a tremulous motion, to glitter. Cf. Flitter v. i.
entry.def: A rag; a tatter; a small piece or fragment.

entry.ety: Flitter, v.i. + mouse; cf. G. fledermaus, OHG. fledarmūs. Cf. Flickermouse Flindermouse
entry.def: A bat; -- called also flickermouse flindermouse, and flintymouse.
A term applied to the bark obtained from young oak trees.

entry.ety: From Flitty
entry.def: Unsteadiness; levity; lightness.

sn.def: A flying with lightness and celerity; a fluttering.
A removal from one habitation to another.
sn.q: A neighbor had lent his cart for the flitting, and it was now standing loaded at the door, ready to move away.

entry.def: Contention; strife; scolding; specif., a kind of metrical contest between two persons, popular in Scotland in the 16th century.
entry.q: These “flytings” consisted of alternate torrents of sheer Billingsgate poured upon each other by the combatants.

entry.def: In a flitting manner.

entry.ety: From Flit
entry.def: Unstable; fluttering.

entry.ety: Cf. Flax
entry.def: Down; fur.

cs.cd: the Sisymbrium Sophia, a kind of hedge mustard, formerly used as a remedy for dysentery.

entry.def: The flux; dysentery.

entries.entry:
Flo flō n.; pl.Flon flōn. AS. flā flān
An arrow. Obs

cs.cd: one of the boards fixed radially to the rim of an undershot water wheel or of a steamer's paddle wheel; -- a vane.
a caisson used for lifting a ship.
fine particles of metallic copper or of gold suspended in water, and thus liable to be lost.
water-worn particles of ore; fragments of vein material found on the surface, away from the vein outcrop.
a siliceous stone used to rub stonework or brickwork to a smooth surface.
a valve or cock acted upon by a float. See Float, 1 .

entry.ety: OE. flote ship, boat, fleet, AS. flota ship, fr. fleótan to float; akin to D. vloot fleet, G. floss raft, Icel. floti float, raft, fleet, Sw. flotta. √ 84. See Fleet v. i., and cf. Flotilla Flotsam Plover
entry.sn:
Anything which floats or rests on the surface of a fluid, as to sustain weight, or to indicate the height of the liquid surface, or mark the place of, something. Specifically: A mass of timber or boards fastened together, and conveyed down a stream by the current; a raft.
The hollow, metallic ball of a self-acting faucet, which floats upon the water in a cistern or boiler.
The cork or quill used in angling, to support the bait line, and indicate the bite of a fish.
Anything used to buoy up whatever is liable to sink; an inflated bag or pillow used by persons learning to swim; a life preserver.
The hollow, metallic ball which floats on the fuel in the fuel tank of a vehicle to indicate the level of the fuel surface, and thus the amount of fuel remaining.
A hollow elongated tank mounted under the wing of a seaplane which causes the plane to float when resting on the surface of the water. This reform bill . . . had been used as a float by the conservative ministry.

sn.def: A float board. See Float boardbelow).
A contrivance for affording a copious stream of water to the heated surface of an object of large bulk, as an anvil or die.
The act of flowing; flux; flow.
A quantity of earth, eighteen feet square and one foot deep.
The trowel or tool with which the floated coat of plastering is leveled and smoothed.
A polishing block used in marble working; a runner.
A single-cut file for smoothing; a tool used by shoemakers for rasping off pegs inside a shoe.
A coal cart.
The sea; a wave. See Flote n.

The free use of money for a time between occurrence of a transaction (such as depositing a check or a purchase made using a credit card), and the time when funds are withdrawn to cover the transaction; also, the money made available between transactions in that manner.

a vehicle on which an exhibit or display is mounted, driven or pulled as part of a parade. The float often is based on a large flat platform, and may contain a very elaborate structure with a tableau or people.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Floated; p. pr. & vb. n. Floating
entry.ety: OE. flotien flotten, AS. flotian to float, swim, fr. fleótan. See Float n.

sn.def: To rest on the surface of any fluid; to swim; to be buoyed up.
sn.q: The ark no more now floats, but seems on ground.
Three blustering nights, borne by the southern blast, I floated.

sn.def: To move quietly or gently on the water, as a raft; to drift along; to move or glide without effort or impulse on the surface of a fluid, or through the air.
sn.q: They stretch their broad plumes and float upon the wind.
There seems a floating whisper on the hills.

sn.def: To cause to float; to cause to rest or move on the surface of a fluid; as, the tide floated the ship into the harbor.
sn.q: Had floated that bell on the Inchcape rock.

sn.def: To flood; to overflow; to cover with water.
sn.q: Proud Pactolus floats the fruitful lands.

sn.def: To pass over and level the surface of with a float while the plastering is kept wet.
To support and sustain the credit of, as a commercial scheme or a joint-stock company, so as to enable it to go into, or continue in, operation.

entry.def: That may be floated.
Same as Flotage.
See Flotation.

sn.def: One who floats or swims.
A float for indicating the height of a liquid surface.

sd.def: A voter who shifts from party to party, esp. one whose vote is purchasable.

A person, as a delegate to a convention or a member of a legislature, who represents an irregular constituency, as one formed by a union of the voters of two counties neither of which has a number sufficient to be allowed a (or an extra) representative of its own.

A person who votes illegally in various polling places or election districts, either under false registration made by himself or under the name of some properly registered person who has not already voted.

entry.cs: Floating anchor Naut a drag or sea anchor; drag sail. Floating battery Mil a battery erected on rafts or the hulls of ships, chiefly for the defense of a coast or the bombardment of a place. Floating bridge. A bridge consisting of rafts or timber, with a floor of plank, supported wholly by the water; a bateau bridge. See Bateau. Mil A kind of double bridge, the upper one projecting beyond the lower one, and capable of being moved forward by pulleys; -- used for carrying troops over narrow moats in attacking the outworks of a fort. A kind of ferryboat which is guided and impelled by means of chains which are anchored on each side of a stream, and pass over wheels on the vessel, the wheels being driven by stream power. The landing platform of a ferry dock. Floating cartilage Med a cartilage which moves freely in the cavity of a joint, and often interferes with the functions of the latter. Floating dam. An anchored dam. A caisson used as a gate for a dry dock. Floating derrick a derrick on a float for river and harbor use, in raising vessels, moving stone for harbor improvements, etc. Floating dock. Naut See under Dock. Floating harbor a breakwater of cages or booms, anchored and fastened together, and used as a protection to ships riding at anchor to leeward. Knight. Floating heart Bot a small aquatic plant (Limnanthemum lacunosum) whose heart-shaped leaves float on the water of American ponds. Floating island a dish for dessert, consisting of custard with floating masses of whipped cream or white of eggs. Floating kidney. Med See Wandering kidney, under Wandering. Floating light a light shown at the masthead of a vessel moored over sunken rocks, shoals, etc., to warn mariners of danger; a light-ship; also, a light erected on a buoy or floating stage. Floating liver. Med See Wandering liver, under Wandering. Floating pier a landing stage or pier which rises and falls with the tide. Floating ribs Anat the lower or posterior ribs which are not connected with the others in front; in man they are the last two pairs. Floating screed Plastering a strip of plastering first laid on, to serve as a guide for the thickness of the coat. Floating threads Weaving threads which span several other threads without being interwoven with them, in a woven fabric.

sn.def: Buoyed upon or in a fluid; a, the floating timbers of a wreck; floating motes in the air.
Free or lose from the usual attachment; as, the floating ribs in man and some other animals.
Not funded; not fixed, invested, or determined; as, floating capital; a floating debt.
sn.q: Trade was at an end. Floating capital had been withdrawn in great masses from the island.

sn.def: Floating threads. See Floating threads, above.
The second coat of three-coat plastering.
The process of rendering oysters and scallops plump by placing them in fresh or brackish water; -- called also fattening plumping, and laying out.

entry.def: A charge, lien, etc., that successively attaches to such assets as a person may have from time to time, leaving him more or less free to dispose of or encumber them as if no such charge or lien existed.
In a floating manner.
a plane equipped with pontoons for landing or taking off from water.
Swimming on the surface; buoyant; light.

cs.cd: a rifle adapted to the use of floberts.

entry.def: A small cartridge designed for target shooting; -- sometimes called ball cap.

entry.ety: L. floccus a flock of wool. Cf. Flock of wool
entry.def: A delirious picking of bedclothes by a sick person, as if to pick off flocks of wool; carphology; -- an alarming symptom in acute diseases.

entry.ety: L. floccosus. Cf. 2d Flock n.

sn.def: Spotted with small tufts like wool.
Having tufts of soft hairs, which are often deciduous.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the flocculus.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flocculated; p. pr. & vb. n. Flocculating
entry.def: To aggregate into small lumps.
Furnished with tufts of curly hairs, as some insects.
To convert into floccules or flocculent aggregates; to make granular or crumbly; as, the flocculating of a soil improves its mechanical condition.
entry.q: When applied to clay soils it [lime] binds the small particles together, or flocculates them.

entry.def: The process by which small particles of fine soils and sediments aggregate into larger lumps.

entry.ety: See Flocculus

sn.def: A detached mass of loosely fibrous structure like a shredded tuft of wool.
Specif.: A small particle of an insoluble substance formed in a liquid by the union of smaller particles.

entry.def: The state of being flocculent.

entry.ety: See Flock of wool

sn.def: Clothed with small flocks or flakes; woolly.
Applied to the down of newly hatched or unfledged birds.
Having a structure like shredded wool, as some precipitates.

entries.entry: ‖Floc"cu*lus n.; pl.Flocculi #. NL., dim. of L. floccus a lock or flock of wool Anat A small lobe in the under surface of the cerebellum, near the middle peduncle; the subpeduncular lobe.

‖Floc"cus n.; pl.Flocci #. L., a flock of wool
Zoöl
The tuft of hair terminating the tail of mammals.
A tuft of feathers on the head of young birds.
Bot A woolly filament sometimes occuring with the sporules of certain fungi.

entry.ety: AS. flocc flock, company; akin to Icel. flokkr crowd, Sw. flock, Dan. flok; prob. orig. used of flows, and akin to E. fly. See Fly

sn.def: A company or collection of living creatures; -- especially applied to sheep and birds, rarely to persons or (except in the plural) to cattle and other large animals; as, a flock of ravenous fowl.
sn.q: The heathen . . . came to Nicanor by flocks.

sn.def: A Christian church or congregation; considered in their relation to the pastor, or minister in charge.
sn.q: As half amazed, half frighted all his flock.

cs.cd: the greater scaup duck.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flocked; p. pr. & vb. n. Flocking
entry.def: To gather in companies or crowds.
entry.q: Friends daily flock.

entry.def: To flock to; to crowd.
entry.q: Good fellows, trooping, flocked me so.

entry.cs: Flock bed a bed filled with flocks or locks of coarse wool, or pieces of cloth cut up fine. “Once a flock bed, but repaired with straw.” Pope. Flock paper paper coated with flock fixed with glue or size.
entry.ety: OE. flokke; cf. D. vlok, G. flocke, OHG. floccho, Icel. flōki, perh. akin to E. flicker flacker, or cf. L. floccus, F. floc

sn.def: A lock of wool or hair.
sn.q: I prythee, Tom, beat Cut's saddle, put a few flocks in the point [pommel].

sn.def: Woolen or cotton refuse (sing. or pl.), old rags, etc., reduced to a degree of fineness by machinery, and used for stuffing unpholstered furniture.

Very fine, sifted, woolen refuse, especially that from shearing the nap of cloths, used as a coating for wall paper to give it a velvety or clothlike appearance; also, the dust of vegetable fiber used for a similar purpose.

entry.def: To coat with flock, as wall paper; to roughen the surface of (as glass) so as to give an appearance of being covered with fine flock.
A lamb.
In flocks; in crowds.

entry.ety: AS. flocm�lum. See Meal part
entry.def: In a flock; in a body.
entry.q: That flockmel on a day they to him went.

entry.def: Abounding with flocks; floccose.

cs.cd: a seal (Phoca fœtida).

entry.ety: Cf. Dan. flag af iis, iisflage, Sw. flaga flake, isflaga, isflake. See Flag a flat stone
entry.def: A low, flat mass of floating ice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flogged flŏgd; p. pr. & vb. n. Flogging -gĭng
entry.ety: Cf. Scot. fleg blow, stroke, kick, AS. flocan to strike, or perh. fr. L. flagellare to whip. Cf. Flagellate
entry.def: To beat or strike with a rod or whip; to whip; to lash; to chastise with repeated blows.

sn.def: One who flogs.
A kind of mallet for beating the bung stave of a cask to start the bung.

cs.cd: a large cold chisel, used in chipping castings.
a small sledge hammer used for striking a flogging chisel.

entry.def: from Flog v. t.
See Flo.
imp. & p. p. of Fling.

entry.ety: Of the same origin as flawn flan, a metal disk
entry.def: A compressed mass of paper sheets, forming a matrix or mold for stereotype plates.

cs.cd: , the anchor by which a ship is held while the tide is rising.
a fence so secured that it will not be swept away by a flood.
a gate for shutting out, admitting, or releasing, a body of water; a tide gate.
the mark or line to which the tide, or a flood, rises; high-water mark.
the rising tide; -- opposed to ebb tide.
the deluge in the days of Noah.

entry.ety: OE. flod a flowing, stream, flood, AS. flōd; akin to D. vloed, OS. flōd, OHG. fluot, G. flut, Icel. flōð, Sw. & Dan. flod, Goth. flōdus; from the root of E. flow. √80. See Flow v. i.

sn.def: A great flow of water; a body of moving water; the flowing stream, as of a river; especially, a body of water, rising, swelling, and overflowing land not usually thus covered; a deluge; a freshet; an inundation.
sn.q: A covenant never to destroy The earth again by flood.

sn.def: The flowing in of the tide; the semidiurnal swell or rise of water in the ocean; -- opposed to ebb; as, young flood; high flood.
sn.q: There is a tide in the affairs of men, Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune.

sn.def: A great flow or stream of any fluid substance; as, a flood of light; a flood of lava; hence, a great quantity widely diffused; an overflowing; a superabundance; as, a flood of bank notes; a flood of paper currency.
Menstrual disharge; menses.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flooded; p. pr. & vb. n. Flooding

sn.def: To overflow; to inundate; to deluge; as, the swollen river flooded the valley.

To cause or permit to be inundated; to fill or cover with water or other fluid; as, to flood arable land for irrigation; to fill to excess or to its full capacity; as, to flood a country with a depreciated currency.

entry.def: Inundation.

sn.def: covered or overflowing with water.
filled to overflowing as if with water; as, a desk flooded with applications.

entry.def: One who floods anything.

entries.entry: floodhead n. a wall of water rushing ahead of the flood; as, we were lucky to be safe when the floodheads hit..

entry.def: The filling or covering with water or other fluid; overflow; inundation; the filling anything to excess.

sn.def: An abnormal or excessive discharge of blood from the uterus.

entry.def: Illuminated by means of floodlights.
A fluke of an anchor.
See Flucan.
Fluky.

entry.note: ☞ Instead of he has the floor, the English say, he is in possession of the house.
entry.cs: Floor cloth a heavy fabric, painted, varnished, or saturated, with waterproof material, for covering floors; oilcloth. Floor cramp an implement for tightening the seams of floor boards before nailing them in position. Floor light a frame with glass panes in a floor. Floor plan. Shipbuilding A longitudinal section, showing a ship as divided at the water line. Arch A horizontal section, showing the thickness of the walls and partitions, arrangement of passages, apartments, and openings at the level of any floor of a house.
entry.ety: AS. flōr; akin to D. vloer, G. flur field, floor, entrance hall, Icel. flōr floor of a cow stall, cf. Ir. & Gael. lar floor, ground, earth, W. llawr, perh. akin to L. planus level. Cf. Plain smooth

sn.def: The bottom or lower part of any room; the part upon which we stand and upon which the movables in the room are supported.
The structure formed of beams, girders, etc., with proper covering, which divides a building horizontally into stories. Floor in sense 1 is, then, the upper surface of floor in sense 2.
The surface, or the platform, of a structure on which we walk or travel; as, the floor of a bridge.
A story of a building. See Story.

sd.def: The part of the house assigned to the members.
The right to speak; as, the gentleman from Iowa has the floor .

sn.def: That part of the bottom of a vessel on each side of the keelson which is most nearly horizontal.

sd.def: The rock underlying a stratified or nearly horizontal deposit.
A horizontal, flat ore body.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Floored; p. pr. & vb. n. Flooring

sn.def: To cover with a floor; to furnish with a floor; as, to floor a house with pine boards.
To strike down or lay level with the floor; to knock down; hence, to silence by a conclusive answer or retort; as, to floor an opponent.
sn.q: Floored or crushed by him.

sn.def: To finish or make an end of; as, to floor a college examination.
sn.q: I've floored my little-go work.

entry.def: Floor space.

sn.def: a board in the floor.
the floor of an automobile.

entry.def: a covering for the floor of an automobile.

sn.def: provided with a floor.
knocked down to the floor or ground.
defeated; overwhelmed.
suprised and confounded; nonplused; as, I was floored by the brilliance of the solution.

entry.def: Anything that floors or upsets a person, as a blow that knocks him down; a conclusive answer or retort; a task that exceeds one's abilities.
The upper extermities of the floor of a vessel.
A platform; the bottom of a room; a floor; pavement. See Floor n.

sn.def: Material for the construction of a floor or floors.

entry.def: Having no floor.
One who walks about in a large retail store as an overseer and director.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Flopped flŏpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Flopping
entry.ety: A variant of flap

sn.def: To clap or strike, as a bird its wings, a fish its tail, etc.; to flap.
To turn suddenly, as something broad and flat.
To strike about with something broad and flat, as a fish with its tail, or a bird with its wings; to rise and fall; as, the brim of a hat flops .
To fall, sink, or throw one's self, heavily, clumsily, and unexpectedly on the ground.

entry.def: Act of flopping.
a cheap and usually seedy lodging house or hotel.
Having a tendency to flop or flap; as, a floppy hat brim.
The lapwing.

entry.ety: L., the goddess of flowers, from flos floris, flower. See Flower

sn.def: The goddess of flowers and spring.
The complete system of vegetable species growing without cultivation in a given locality, region, or period; a list or description of, or treatise on, such plants.

cs.cd: the calyx and corolla, one or the other of which (mostly the corolla) may be wanting.

entry.ety: L. Floralis belonging to Flora: cf. F. floral. See Flora

sn.def: Pertaining to Flora, or to flowers; made of flowers; as, floral games, wreaths.
Containing, or belonging to, a flower; as, a floral bud; a floral leaf; floral characters.

entry.def: In a floral manner.

entry.ety: L. flos floris, flower + amorlove
entry.def: The plant love-lies-bleeding.
Tin ore scarcely perceptible in the stone; tin ore stamped very fine.

entry.ety: F. floréal, fr. L. flos floris, flower
entry.def: The eight month of the French republican calendar. It began April 20, and ended May 19. See Vendémiare.

entry.ety: LL. florenus. See Florin
entry.def: A cerain gold coin; a Florence.

entry.cs: Florence flask. See under Flask. Florence oil olive oil prepared in Florence.
entry.ety: From the city of Florence: cf. F. florence a kind of cloth, OF. florin

sn.def: An ancient gold coin of the time of Edward III., of six shillings sterling value.
A kind of cloth.

cs.cd: a mosaic of hard or semiprecious stones, often so chosen and arranged that their natural colors represent leaves, flowers, and the like, inlaid in a background, usually of black or white marble.

entry.ety: L. Florentinus, fr. Florentia Florence: cf. F. florentin
entry.def: Belonging or relating to Florence, in Italy.

sn.def: A native or inhabitant of Florence, a city in Italy.
A kind of silk.
A kind of pudding or tart; a kind of meat pie.
sn.q: Stealing custards, tarts, and florentines.

entry.ety: See Florescent
entry.def: A bursting into flower; a blossoming.

entry.ety: L. florescens, p. pr. of florescere begin to blossom, incho. fr. florere to blossom, fr. flos floris, flower. See Flower
entry.def: Expanding into flowers; blossoming.

entry.ety: OF. florete, F. fleurette, dim. of OF. lor, F. fleur. See Flower, and cf. Floweret, 3d Ferret

sn.def: A little flower; one of the numerous little flowers which compose the head or anthodium in such flowers as the daisy, thistle, and dandelion.
A foil; a blunt sword used in fencing.

entry.ety: L. flos floris, flower
entry.def: Bloom; blossom.
Having floral ornaments; as, floriated capitals of Gothic pillars.

sn.def: Ornamentation by means of flower forms, whether closely imitated or conventionalized.
Any floral ornament or decoration.

entry.ety: L. flos floris, flower + coma hair
entry.def: Having the head adorned with flowers.
Pertaining to the cultivation of flowering plants.

entry.ety: L. flos floris, flower + cultura culture
entry.def: The cultivation of flowering plants.
One skilled in the cultivation of flowers; a florist.

Flowery; ornamental; running in rapid melodic figures, divisions, or passages, as in variations; full of fioriture or little ornamentations.

entry.ety: NL., from L. flos floris, a flower

entry.ety: F. florin, It. florino, orig., a Florentine coin, with a lily on it, fr. flore a flower, fr. L. flos. See Flower, and cf. Floren
entry.def: A silver coin of Florence, first struck in the twelfth century, and noted for its beauty. The name is given to different coins in different countries. The florin of England, first minted in 1849, is worth two shillings, or about 48 cents; the florin of the Netherlands, about 40 cents; of Austria, about 36 cents.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fleuriste floriste, fr. F. fleur flower. See Flower

entry.cs:
Center of flotation. Shipbuilding The center of any given plane of flotation. More commonly, the middle of the length of the load water line. Rankine.
Plane of flotationorLine of flotation
the plane or line in which the horizontal surface of a fluid cuts a body floating in it. See Bearing n., 9 . Surface of flotation Shipbuilding the imaginary surface which all the planes of flotation touch when a vessel rolls or pitches; the envelope of all such planes.
entry.ety: Cf. F. flottation a floating, flottaison water line, fr. flotter to float. See Flotilla
