sn.syn: Fault; imperfection; failing; weakness; infirmity; frailty; defect. See Fault.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foiled foild; p. pr. & vb. n. Foiling
entry.ety: F. fouler to tread or trample under one's feet, to press, oppress. See Full v. t.

sn.def: To tread under foot; to trample.
sn.q: King Richard . . . caused the ensigns of Leopold to be pulled down and foiled under foot.
Whom he did all to pieces breake and foyle, In filthy durt, and left so in the loathely soyle.

sn.def: To render (an effort or attempt) vain or nugatory; to baffle; to outwit; to balk; to frustrate; to defeat.
sn.q: And by � mortal man at length am foiled.
Her long locks that foil the painter's power.

sn.def: To blunt; to dull; to spoil; as, to foil the scent in chase.

entry.ety: See 6th File
entry.def: To defile; to soil.

entry.cs: To run a foil,to lead astray; to puzzle; -- alluding to the habits of some animals of running back over the same track to mislead their pursuers. Brewer.

sn.def: Failure of success when on the point of attainment; defeat; frustration; miscarriage.
sn.q: Nor e'er was fate so near a foil.

sn.def: A blunt weapon used in fencing, resembling a smallsword in the main, but usually lighter and having a button at the point.
sn.q: Blunt as the fencer's foils, which hit, but hurt not.
Isocrates contended with a foil against Demosthenes with a word.

sn.def: The track or trail of an animal.

cs.cd: an imitation of a jewel or precious stone.

entry.ety: OE. foil leaf, OF. foil fuil fueil foille fueille, F. feuille, fr. L. folium, pl. folia; akin to Gr. � , and perh. to E. blade. Cf. Foliage Folio

sn.def: A leaf or very thin sheet of metal; as, brass foil; tin foil; gold foil.

A thin leaf of sheet copper silvered and burnished, and afterwards coated with transparent colors mixed with isinglass; -- employed by jewelers to give color or brilliancy to pastes and inferior stones.
Anything that serves by contrast of color or quality to adorn or set off another thing to advantage.
sn.q: As she a black silk cap on him began To set, for foil of his milk-white to serve.
Hector has a foil to set him off.

sn.def: A thin coat of tin, with quicksilver, laid on the back of a looking-glass, to cause reflection.

The space between the cusps in Gothic architecture; a rounded or leaflike ornament, in windows, niches, etc. A group of foils is called trefoil, quatrefoil, quinquefoil, etc., according to the number of arcs of which it is composed.

entry.def: Capable of being foiled.
One who foils or frustrates.
A foil.

entry.ety: Cf. F. foulées. See 1st Foil
entry.def: The track of game (as deer) in the grass.

entry.ety: F. fouine a marten

sn.def: The beech marten (Mustela foina). See Marten.
A kind of fur, black at the top on a whitish ground, taken from the ferret or weasel of the same name.
sn.q: He came to the stake in a fair black gown furred and faced with foins.

entry.ety: OE. foinen foignen; of uncertain origin; cf. dial. F. fouiner to push for eels with a spear, fr. F. fouine an eelspear, perh. fr. L. fodere to dig, thrust
entry.def: To thrust with a sword or spear; to lunge.
entry.q: He stroke, he soused, he foynd, he hewed, he lashed.
They lash, they foin, they pass, they strive to bore Their corselets, and the thinnest parts explore.

entry.def: To prick; to st?ng.
A pass in fencing; a lunge.
Thrusting with the foil; fencing with the point, as distinguished from broadsword play.
With a push or thrust.

entry.ety: F. foison, fr. L. fusio a pouring, effusion. See Fusion
entry.def: Rich harvest; plenty; abundance.
entry.q: That from the seedness the bare fallow brings To teeming foison.

entry.ety: OF. fuste stick, boat, fr. L. fustis cudgel. Cf. 1st Fust
entry.def: A light and fast-sailing ship.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foisted; p. pr. & vb. n. Foisting
entry.ety: Cf. OD. vysten to fizzle, D. veesten, E. fizz fitchet, bullfist
entry.def: To insert surreptitiously, wrongfully, or without warrant; to interpolate; to pass off (something spurious or counterfeit) as genuine, true, or worthy; -- usually followed by in.
entry.q: Lest negligence or partiality might admit or foist in abuses and corruption.
When a scripture has been corrupted . . . by a supposititious foisting of some words in.

sn.def: A foister; a sharper.
A trick or fraud; a swindle.

entry.def: One who foists something surreptitiously; a falsifier.

entry.ety: See 2d Fust
entry.def: Fusty.
Fustiness; mustiness.
Fusty; musty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Folded; p. pr. & vb. n. Folding
entry.ety: OE. folden falden, AS. fealdan; akin to OHG. faltan faldan, G. falten, Icel. falda, Dan. folde, Sw. fålla, Goth. falþan, cf. Gr. di-pla`sios twofold, Skr. puṭa a fold. Cf. Fauteuil

sn.def: To lap or lay in plaits or folds; to lay one part over another part of; to double; as, to fold cloth; to fold a letter.
sn.q: As a vesture shalt thou fold them up.

sn.def: To double or lay together, as the arms or the hands; as, he folds his arms in despair.
To inclose within folds or plaitings; to envelop; to infold; to clasp; to embrace.
sn.q: A face folded in sorrow.
We will descend and fold him in our arms.

sn.def: To cover or wrap up; to conceal.
sn.q: Nor fold my fault in cleanly coined excuses.

entry.def: To become folded, plaited, or doubled; to close over another of the same kind; to double together; as, the leaves of the door fold .

cs.cd: a kind of net used in catching birds.

entry.ety: From Fold v. In sense 2 AS. -feald, akin to fealdan to fold

sn.def: A doubling,esp. of any flexible substance; a part laid over on another part; a plait; a plication.
sn.q: Mummies . . . shrouded in a number of folds of linen.
Folds are most common in the rocks of mountainous regions.

sn.def: Times or repetitions; -- used with numerals, chiefly in composition, to denote multiplication or increase in a geometrical ratio, the doubling, tripling, etc., of anything; as, fourfold, four times, increased in a quadruple ratio, multiplied by four.
That which is folded together, or which infolds or envelops; embrace.
sn.q: Shall from your neck unloose his amorous fold.

cs.cd: an inclosure for sheep or cattle.

entry.ety: OE. fald fold, AS. fald falod

sn.def: An inclosure for sheep; a sheep pen.
sn.q: Leaps o'er the fence with ease into the fold.

sn.def: A flock of sheep; figuratively, the Church or a church; as, Christ's fold .
sn.q: There shall be one fold and one shepherd.
The very whitest lamb in all my fold.

sn.def: A boundary; a limit.

entry.def: To confine in a fold, as sheep.
To confine sheep in a fold.
entry.q: The star that bids the shepherd fold.

entry.def: Capable of being folded into a more compact form.

entry.ety: See Fold inclosure, Faldage
entry.def: See Faldage.

entries.entry: folded adj. made compact by bending or doubling over.Narrower terms: accordion, plicate ; bifold ; closed ; doubled ; pleated ; rolled, rolled-up(prenominal; sunburst, sunray Also See: collapsible collapsable. Antonym: unfolded

entry.def: One who, or that which, folds; esp., a flat, knifelike instrument used for folding paper.
Nonsense; foolish talk.

cs.cd: a portable boat made by stretching canvas, etc., over jointed framework, used in campaigning, and by tourists, etc.
a chair which may be shut up compactly for carriage or stowage; a camp chair.
one of two or more doors filling a single and hung upon hinges.

sn.def: The act of making a fold or folds; also, a fold; a doubling; a plication.
sn.q: The lower foldings of the vest.

sn.def: The keepig of sheep in inclosures on arable land, etc.

entry.def: Having no fold.

entry.ety: L. foliaceus, fr. folium leaf

sn.def: Belonging to, or having the texture or nature of, a leaf; having leaves intermixed with flowers; as, a foliaceous spike.
Consisting of leaves or thin laminæ; having the form of a leaf or plate; as, foliaceous spar.
Leaflike in form or mode of growth; as, a foliaceous coral.

cs.cd: any plant cultivated for the beauty of its leaves, as many kinds of Begonia and Coleus.

entry.ety: OF. foillage fueillage, F. feuillage, fr. OF. foille fueille fueil, F. feulle, leaf, L. folium. See 3d Foil, and cf. Foliation Filemot

sn.def: Leaves, collectively, as produced or arranged by nature; leafage; as, a tree or forest of beautiful foliage .
A cluster of leaves, flowers, and branches; especially, the representation of leaves, flowers, and branches, in architecture, intended to ornament and enrich capitals, friezes, pediments, etc.

entry.def: To adorn with foliage or the imitation of foliage; to form into the representation of leaves.
Furnished with foliage; leaved; as, the variously foliaged mulberry.

cs.cd: an opening in the fibrovascular system of a stem at the point of origin of a leaf.
a particular fibrovascular bundle passing down into the stem from a leaf.

entry.def: Consisting of, or pertaining to, leaves; as, foliar appendages.

entry.cs: Foliate curve. Geom Same as Folium.
entry.ety: L. foliatus leaved, leafy, fr. folium leaf. See Foliage
entry.def: Furnished with leaves; leafy; as, a foliate stalk.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foliated; p. pr. & vb. n. Foliating

sn.def: To beat into a leaf, or thin plate.
To spread over with a thin coat of tin and quicksilver; as, to foliate a looking-glass.

entry.cs: Foliated telluium. Min See Nagyagite.

sn.def: Having leaves, or leaflike projections; as, a foliated shell.
Containing, or consisting of, foils; as, a foliated arch.
Characterized by being separable into thin plates or folia; as, graphite has a foliated structure.
Laminated, but restricted to the variety of laminated structure found in crystalline schist, as mica schist, etc.; schistose.
Spread over with an amalgam of tin and quicksilver.

entry.ety: Cf. F. foliation

sn.def: The process of forming into a leaf or leaves.
The manner in which the young leaves are dispo�ed within the bud.
sn.q: The . . . foliation must be in relation to the stem.

sn.def: The act of beating a metal into a thin plate, leaf, foil, or lamina.
The act of coating with an amalgam of tin foil and quicksilver, as in making looking-glasses.
The enrichment of an opening by means of foils, arranged in trefoils, quatrefoils, etc.; also, one of the ornaments. See Tracery.

The property, possessed by some crystalline rocks, of dividing into plates or slabs, which is due to the cleavage structure of one of the constituents, as mica or hornblende. It may sometimes include slaty structure or cleavage, though the latter is usually independent of any mineral constituent, and transverse to the bedding, it having been produced by pressure.

entry.ety: L. foliatura foliage

sn.def: Foliage; leafage.
The state of being beaten into foil.

entry.def: Goldsmith's foil.

entry.ety: L. folium leaf+ -ferous: cf. F. foliifère
entry.def: Producing leaves.
Foolishly.

entries.entry:
Fol"io
Folio post a flat writing paper, usually 17 by 24 inches.
n.; pl.Folios #. Ablative of L. folium leaf. See 4th Foil
A leaf of a book or manuscript.
A sheet of paper once folded.
A book made of sheets of paper each folded once (four pages to the sheet); hence, a book of the largest kind. See Note under Paper.
Print The page number. The even folios are on the left-hand pages and the odd folios on the right-hand.
A page of a book; Bookkeeping a page in an account book; sometimes, two opposite pages bearing the same serial number.
Law A leaf containing a certain number of words, hence, a certain number of words in a writing, as in England, in law proceedings 72, and in chancery, 90; in New York, 100 words.

entry.def: To put a serial number on each folio or page of (a book); to page.
Formed of sheets each folded once, making two leaves, or four pages; as, a folio volume. See Folio n., 3.
Of or pertaining to leaflets; -- used in composition; as, bi-foliolate .

entry.ety: Dim. of L. folium leaf: cf. F. foliole
entry.def: One of the distinct parts of a compound leaf; a leaflet.
See Feuillemort.

entry.ety: L. foliosus, fr. folium leaf
entry.def: Having many leaves; leafy.
The ponderousness or bulk of a folio; voluminousness.

entry.ety: See Foliose

sn.def: Like a leaf; thin; unsubstantial.
Foliose.

entries.entry:
Fo"li*um n.; pl. E. Foliums #, L. Folia #. L., a leaf
A leaf, esp. a thin leaf or plate.
Geom A curve of the third order, consisting of two infinite branches, which have a common asymptote. The curve has a double point, and a leaf-shaped loop; whence the name. Its equation is x3 + y3 = axy.

cs.cd: one of a class of songs long popular with the common people.
the speech of the common people, as distinguished from that of the educated class.

entry.ety: AS. folc; akin to D. volk, OS. & OHG. folk, G. volk, Icel. fōlk, Sw. & Dan. folk, Lith. pulkas crowd, and perh. to E. follow

sn.def: In Anglo-Saxon times, the people of a group of townships or villages; a community; a tribe.
sn.q: The organization of each folk, as such, sprang mainly from war.

sn.def: People in general, or a separate class of people; -- generally used in the plural form, and often with a qualifying adjective; as, the old folks; poor folks.
sn.q: In winter's tedious nights, sit by the fire With good old folks, and let them tell thee tales.

sn.def: The persons of one's own family; as, our folks are all well.

entry.ety: Dan. See Folk, and Thing
entry.def: The lower house of the Danish Rigsdag, or Parliament. See Legislature, below.

entry.ety: AS. folcland
entry.def: Land held in villenage, being distributed among the folk, or people, at the pleasure of the lord of the manor, and resumed at his discretion. Not being held by any assurance in writing, it was opposed to bookland or charter land, which was held by deed.

entries.entry: Folk"lore` n.orFolk" lore` . Tales, legends, or superstitions long current among the people; the unwritten literature of a culture, such as stories, proverbs, riddles and songs.

Folk"mote` n. AS. folcmōt folk meeting An assembly of the people; esp. Sax. Law a general assembly of the people to consider and order matters of the commonwealth; also, a local court. Hist To which folkmote they all with one consent Agreed to travel.

entry.def: One who takes part in a folkmote, or local court.

sn.def: same as cracker-barrel.
very informal and familiar; as, a folksy radio commentator; a folksy style.

entry.def: a tale circulated by word of mouth among the common folk, especially one forming part of the tradition of a culture.

entry.ety: L. folliculus a small bag, husk, pod, dim of follis bellows, an inflated ball, a leathern money bag, perh. akin to E. bellows: cf. F. follicule. Cf. 2d Fool

sn.def: A simple podlike pericarp which contains several seeds and opens along the inner or ventral suture, as in the peony, larkspur and milkweed.

sd.def: A small cavity, tubular depression, or sac; as, a hair follicle .
A simple gland or glandular cavity; a crypt.
A small mass of adenoid tissue; as, a lymphatic follicle .

sn.def: Like, pertaining to, or consisting of, a follicles or follicles.
Affecting the follicles; as, follicular pharyngitis.

entry.def: Having follicles.

entry.ety: L. folliculosus full of husks: cf. F. folliculeux
entry.def: Having or producing follicles.
Full of folly.

cs.cd: a board on which the pattern and the flask lie while the sand is rammed into the flask.
to hunt with dogs.
to play a card of the same suit as the leading card; hence, colloquially, to follow an example set.
to pursue indefatigably.

entry.usage: - To Follow Pursue. To followv.t.) denotes simply to go after; to pursue denotes to follow with earnestness, and with a view to attain some definite object; as, a hound pursues the deer. So a person follows a companion whom he wishes to overtake on a journey; the officers of justice pursue a felon who has escaped from prison.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Followed; p. pr. & vb. n. Following
entry.ety: OE. foluwen folwen folgen, AS. folgian fylgean fylgan; akin to D. volgen, OHG. folgēn, G. folgen, Icel. fylgja, Sw. följa, Dan. fölge, and perh. to E. folk

sn.def: To go or come after; to move behind in the same path or direction; hence, to go with (a leader, guide, etc.); to accompany; to attend.
sn.q: It waves me forth again; I'll follow it.

sn.def: To endeavor to overtake; to go in pursuit of; to chase; to pursue; to prosecute.
sn.q: I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians, and they shall follow them.

entry.sn:
To accept as authority; to adopt the opinions of; to obey; to yield to; to take as a rule of action; as, to follow good advice. Approve the best, and follow what I approve. Milton.
Follow peace with all men. It is most agreeable to some men to follow their reason; and to others to follow their appetites.

sn.def: To copy after; to take as an example.
sn.q: We had rather follow the perfections of them whom we like not, than in defects resemble them whom we love.

sn.def: To succeed in order of time, rank, or office.
To result from, as an effect from a cause, or an inference from a premise.

To watch, as a receding object; to keep the eyes fixed upon while in motion; to keep the mind upon while in progress, as a speech, musical performance, etc.; also, to keep up with; to understand the meaning, connection, or force of, as of a course of thought or argument.
sn.q: He followed with his eyes the flitting shade.

sn.def: To walk in, as a road or course; to attend upon closely, as a profession or calling.
sn.q: O, had I but followed the arts!
O Antony! I have followed thee to this.
sn.syn: - To pursue; chase; go after; attend; accompany; succeed; imitate; copy; embrace; maintain.

entry.usage: To followv.i.) means simply to come after; as, a crowd followed . To succeed means to come after in some regular series or succession; as, day succeeds to day, and night to night. To ensue means to follow by some established connection or principle of sequence. As wave follows wave, revolution succeeds to revolution; and nothing ensues but accumulated wretchedness.
entry.def: To go or come after; -- used in the various senses of the transitive verb: To pursue; to attend; to accompany; to be a result; to imitate.
The art or process of following; specif., in some games, as billiards, a stroke causing a ball to follow another ball after hitting it. Also used adjectively; as, follow shot.

entry.ety: OE. folwere, AS. folgere

sn.def: One who follows; a pursuer; an attendant; a disciple; a dependent associate; a retainer.
A sweetheart; a beau.

sd.def: The removable flange, or cover, of a piston. See Illust. of Piston.
A gland. See Illust. of Stuffing box.

sn.def: The part of a machine that receives motion from another part. See Driver.
Among law stationers, a sheet of parchment or paper which is added to the first sheet of an indenture or other deed.
sn.syn: Imitator; copier; disciple; adherent; partisan; dependent; attendant.

sn.def: One's followers, adherents, or dependents, collectively.
Vocation; business; profession.

entry.note: ☞ The four principal directions in the field of a telescope are north south following preceding.

sn.def: Next after; succeeding; ensuing; as, the assembly was held on the following day.

In the field of a telescope) In the direction from which stars are apparently moving (in consequence of the earth's rotation); as, a small star, north following or south following . In the direction toward which stars appear to move is called preceding.

entries.entry: Following edge. Aëronautics See Advancing-edge, above.
Following surface. Aëronautics See Advancing-surface, above.

entry.def: an immediate second innings forced on a cricket team scoring a prescribed number of runs fewer than its opponents in the first innings.
Following as a logical consequence or next step in a process; -- used mostly of voluntary actions.

sn.def: Carrying a process, plan, or project to full completion; as, I appreciated his follow-through on his promise. The term usually is used in reference to the period after some point in time at which the actor is given freedom to pursue the project.
The remainder of a stroke with a club, bat, or racket after the ball has been hit.

entry.note: A follow-up may be of various types. After a medical examination, a second examination (or reexamination) to obtain additional information regarding some fact discovered in the first examination is considered a follow-up. A second visit or phone call in pursuit of a sale or other request would also be a follow-up.

sn.def: a second (or subsequent) action to increase the effectiveness of an initial action. Also used attributively; as a follow-up visit.
A subsequent story providing information discovered or events happening after a first story was published.
Same as sidebar.

entries.entry:
Fol"ly n.; pl.Follies #. OE. folie foli, F. folie, fr. fol fou, foolish, mad. See Fool
The state of being foolish; want of good sense; levity, weakness, or derangement of mind.
A foolish act; an inconsiderate or thoughtless procedure; weak or light-minded conduct; foolery. What folly 'tis to hazard life for ill.
Scandalous crime; sin; specifically, as applied to a woman, wantonness. Achan] wrought folly in Israel. When lovely woman stoops to folly.
The result of a foolish action or enterprise. It is called this man's or that man's “folly,” and name of the foolish builder is thus kept alive for long after years.

entry.def: To follow.

entry.ety: Ar., prop., mouth of the large fish: cf. F. Fomalhaut
entry.def: A star of the first magnitude, in the constellation Piscis Australis, or Southern Fish.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fomented; p. pr. & vb. n. Fomenting
entry.ety: F. fomenter, fr. L. fomentare, fr. fomentumfor fovimentum) a warm application or lotion, fr. fovere to warm or keep warm; perh. akin to Gr. � to roast, and E. bake

sn.def: To apply a warm lotion to; to bathe with a cloth or sponge wet with warm water or medicated liquid.
To cherish with heat; to foster.
sn.q: Which these soft fires . . . foment and warm.

sn.def: To nurse to life or activity; to cherish and promote by excitements; to encourage; to abet; to instigate; -- used often in a bad sense; as, to foment ill humors.
sn.q: But quench the choler you foment in vain.
Exciting and fomenting a religious rebellion.

sn.def: Fomentation.
State of excitation; -- perh. confused with ferment.
sn.q: He came in no conciliatory mood, and the foment was kept up.

entry.ety: �. fomentatio: cf. F. fomentation

sd.def: The act of fomenting; the application of warm, soft, medicinal substances, as for the purpose of easing pain, by relaxing the skin, or of discussing tumors.
The lotion applied to a diseased part.

sn.def: Excitation; instigation; encouragement.
sn.q: Dishonest fomentation of your pride.

entry.def: One who foments; one who encourages or instigates; as, a fomenter of sedition.

entries.entry: ‖Fo"mes fō"mēz n.; pl.Fomites fŏm"ĭ*tēz. L. fomes -itis, touch-wood, tinder Med Any substance supposed to be capable of absorbing, retaining, and transporting contagious or infectious germs; as, woolen clothes are said to be active fomites .

sn.def: Irish) one of a group of sea demons sometimes associated with the hostile power of nature.
Irish) one of a group of sea demons sometimes associated with the hostile power of nature.

entry.ety: Of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. fāni silly, fāna to act silly, Sw. fåne fool. Cf. Fond a.
entry.def: A fool; an idiot.
imp. of Find. Found.

entry.ety: For fonned, p. p. of OE. fonnen to be foolish. See Fon

sn.def: Foolish; silly; simple; weak.
sn.q: Grant I may never prove so fond To trust man on his oath or bond.

sn.def: Foolishly tender and loving; weakly indulgent; over-affectionate.
Affectionate; loving; tender; -- in a good sense; as, a fond mother or wife.
Loving; much pleased; affectionately regardful, indulgent, or desirous; longing or yearning; -- followed by offormerly also by on).
sn.q: More fond on her than she upon her love.
You are as fond of grief as of your child.
A great traveler, and fond of telling his adventures.

sn.def: Doted on; regarded with affection.
sn.q: Nor fix on fond abodes to circumscribe thy prayer.

sn.def: Trifling; valued by folly; trivial.

entry.def: To caress; to fondle.
entry.q: The Tyrian hugs and fonds thee on her breast.

entry.def: To be fond; to dote.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. fundus. See Fund
entry.mark: Obs., or used as a French word

sn.def: Foundation; bottom; groundwork;

sd.def: The ground.
The broth or juice from braised flesh or fish, usually served as a sauce.

sn.def: Fund, stock, or store.

entry.ety: F., lit., melting, p. pr. of fondre to melt, L. fundere. See Found to cast
entry.def: A kind of soft candy, made of a thick creamy sugar paste by boiling solutions to the point of crystallization, and usually molded; as, cherry fondant .

entry.ety: AS. fandian to try
entry.def: To endeavor; to strive; to try.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fondled; p. pr. & vb. n. Fondling
entry.ety: From Fond v.
entry.def: To treat or handle with tenderness or in a loving manner; to caress; as, a nurse fondles a child.
One who fondles.

entry.ety: From Fondle
entry.def: The act of caressing; manifestation of tenderness.
entry.q: Cyrus made no . . . amorous fondling To fan her pride, or melt her guardless heart.

entry.ety: Fond + -ling

sn.def: A person or thing fondled or caressed; one treated with foolish or doting affection.
sn.q: Fondlings are in danger to be made fools.

sn.def: A fool; a simpleton; a ninny.
Foolishly.
sn.q: Make him speak fondly like a frantic man.

sn.def: In a fond manner; affectionately; tenderly.
sn.q: My heart, untraveled, fondly turns to thee.

sn.def: The quality or state of being fond; foolishness.
sn.q: Fondness it were for any, being free, To covet fetters, though they golden be.

sn.def: Doting affection; tender liking; strong appetite, propensity, or relish; as, he had a fondness for truffles.
sn.q: My heart had still some foolish fondness for thee.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fondant flux
entry.def: A large copper vessel used for hot amalgamation.

entry.ety: F. fondu, p.p. of fondre to melt, blend. See Found to cast

sn.def: Blended; gradually changing or passing into each other by subtle gradations; -- said of colors or of the surface or material on which the colors are laid.
Melted.

entry.ety: F. See Fondu; cf. Fondant

sn.def: A dish made of cheese, eggs, butter, etc., often seasoned with kirsch and white wine, melted together, and usually used as a dip for pieces of bread.
A dish consisting of pieces of solid food cooked in or dipped into a hot sauce; as, beef fondue .

entry.ety: F. fondu, p.p. of fondre to melt, blend. See Found to cast
entry.def: Melted.

entry.ety: F. fondu, prop. p. p. of fondre to melt, blend. See Found to cast
entry.def: A style of printing calico, paper hangings, etc., in which the colors are in bands and graduated into each other.

entries.entry: Fone n.; pl. of Foe. Obs

entry.ety: See Fang v. t.
entry.def: To take; to receive.

A fon.

entry.def: A complete assortment of printing type of one size, including a due proportion of all the letters in the alphabet, large and small, points, accents, and whatever else is necessary for printing with that variety of types; a fount.

entry.ety: AS. font fant, fr. L. fons fontis, spring, fountain; cf. OF. font funt, F. fonts fonts baptismaux, pl. See Fount

sn.def: A fountain; a spring; a source.
sn.q: Bathing forever in the font of bliss.

sn.def: A basin or stone vessel in which water is contained for baptizing.
sn.q: That name was given me at the font.

entry.def: Pertaining to a font, fountain, source, or origin; original; primitive.
entry.q: From the fontal light of ideas only can a man draw intellectual power.

entry.note: ☞ In the human fetus there are six fontanels, of which the anterior, or bregmatic, situated at the junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures, is much the largest, and remains open a considerable time after birth.
entry.ety: F. fontanelle, prop., a little fountain, fr. fontaine fountain. See Fountain

sn.def: An issue or artificial ulcer for the discharge of humors from the body.
One of the membranous intervals between the incompleted angles of the parietal and neighboring bones of a fetal or young skull; -- so called because it exhibits a rhythmical pulsation.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Same as Fontanel, 2.

entry.ety: F., from the name of the first wearer, Mlle. de Fontanges, about 1679
entry.def: A kind of tall headdress formerly worn.

entry.note: ☞ In a physiological sense, true aliment is to be distinguished as that portion of the food which is capable of being digested and absorbed into the blood, thus furnishing nourishment, in distinction from the indigestible matter which passes out through the alimentary canal as fæces.

☞ Foods are divided into two main groups: nitrogenous, or proteid, foods, i.e., those which contain nitrogen, and nonnitrogenousi.e., those which do not contain nitrogen. The latter group embraces the fats and carbohydrates, which collectively are sometimes termed heat producers or respiratory foods, since by oxidation in the body they especially subserve the production of heat. The proteids, on the other hand, are known as plastic foods or tissue formers, since no tissue can be formed without them. These latter terms, however, are misleading, since proteid foods may also give rise to heat both directly and indirectly, and the fats and carbohydrates are useful in other ways than in producing heat.
☞ Food is often used adjectively or in self-explaining compounds, as in food fish or food-fish, food supply.
entry.cs: Food vacuole Zoöl one of the spaces in the interior of a protozoan in which food is contained, during digestion. Food yolk. Biol See under Yolk.
entry.ety: OE. fode, AS. fōda; akin to Icel. fæða fæði, Sw. föda, Dan. & LG. föde, OHG. fatunga, Gr. patei^sthai to eat, and perh. to Skr. pā to protect, L. pascere to feed, pasture, pabulum food, E. pasture. √75. Cf. Feed Fodder food, Foster to cherish

sn.def: What is fed upon; that which goes to support life by being received within, and assimilated by, the organism of an animal or a plant; nutriment; aliment; especially, what is eaten by animals for nourishment.
Anything that instructs the intellect, excites the feelings, or molds habits of character; that which nourishes.
sn.q: This may prove food to my displeasure.
In this moment there is life and food For future years.
sn.syn: Aliment; sustenance; nutriment; feed; fare; victuals; provisions; meat.

entry.def: To supply with food.
Full of food; supplying food; fruitful; fertile.
entry.q: Thefoodfulearth.
Bent by its foodful burden [the corn].

entry.def: Without food; barren.
Eatable; fruitful.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fouler to tread, crush. Cf. 1st Foil
entry.def: A compound of gooseberries scalded and crushed, with cream; -- commonly called gooseberry fool.

entry.cs: April fool Court fool, etc. See under April Court, etc. Fool's cap a cap or hood to which bells were usually attached, formerly worn by professional jesters. Fool's errand an unreasonable, silly, profitless adventure or undertaking. Fool's gold iron or copper pyrites, resembling gold in color. Fool's paradise a name applied to a limbo (see under Limbo) popularly believed to be the region of vanity and nonsense. Hence, any foolish pleasure or condition of vain self-satistaction. Fool's parsley Bot an annual umbelliferous plant (Æthusa Cynapium) resembling parsley, but nauseous and poisonous. To make a fool of to render ridiculous; to outwit; to shame. Colloq To play the fool to act the buffoon; to act a foolish part. “I have played the fool, and have erred exceedingly.” 1 Sam. xxvi. 21.
entry.ety: OE. fol, n. & adj., F. fol fou, foolish, mad; a fool, prob. fr. L. follis a bellows, wind bag, an inflated ball; perh. akin to E. bellows. Cf. Folly Follicle

sn.def: One destitute of reason, or of the common powers of understanding; an idiot; a natural.
A person deficient in intellect; one who acts absurdly, or pursues a course contrary to the dictates of wisdom; one without judgment; a simpleton; a dolt.
sn.q: Extol not riches, then, the toil of fools.
Experience keeps a dear school, but fools will learn in no other.

sn.def: One who acts contrary to moral and religious wisdom; a wicked person.
sn.q: The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God.

sn.def: One who counterfeits folly; a professional jester or buffoon; a retainer formerly kept to make sport, dressed fantastically in motley, with ridiculous accouterments.
sn.q: Can they think me . . . their fool or jester?

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fooled; p. pr. & vb. n. Fooling
entry.def: To play the fool; to trifle; to toy; to spend time in idle sport or mirth.
entry.q: Is this a time for fooling?

cs.cd: to get rid of foolishly; to spend in trifles, idleness, folly, or without advantage.

sn.def: To infatuate; to make foolish.
sn.q: For, fooled with hope, men favor the deceit.

sn.def: To use as a fool; to deceive in a shameful or mortifying manner; to impose upon; to cheat by inspiring foolish confidence; as, to fool one out of his money.
sn.q: You are fooled, discarded, and shook off By him for whom these shames ye underwent.

entries.entry: Foo"lahs` n. pl.; sing. Foolah . Ethnol Same as Fulahs.

entry.def: Begotten by a fool.

entries.entry:
Fool"er*y n.; pl.Fooleries.
The practice of folly; the behavior of a fool; absurdity. Folly in fools bears not so strong a note, As foolery in the wise, when wit doth dote.
An act of folly or weakness; a foolish practice; something absurd or nonsensical. That Pythagoras, Plato, or Orpheus, believed in any of these fooleries, it can not be suspected.

entry.def:
The orange filefish
. See Filefish.
The winter flounder. See Flounder.
Lucky, without judgment or contrivance.
The state of being foolhardy; foolhardiness.
In a foolhardy manner.
Courage without sense or judgment; foolish rashness; recklessness.

entry.ety: Fool, F. fol fou + F. hardiesse boldness
entry.def: Foolhardiness.

entry.ety: OF. folhardi. See Fool idiot, and Hardy
entry.def: Daring without judgment; foolishly adventurous and bold.
entry.syn: Rash; venturesome; venturous; precipitate; reckless; headlong; incautious. See Rash.

entry.def: Foolishly hasty.

entry.ety: Fool + -fy
entry.def: To make a fool of; to befool.

sn.def: Marked with, or exhibiting, folly; void of understanding; weak in intellect; without judgment or discretion; silly; unwise.
sn.q: I am a very foolish fond old man.

sn.def: Such as a fool would do; proceeding from weakness of mind or silliness; exhibiting a want of judgment or discretion; as, a foolish act.
Absurd; ridiculous; despicable; contemptible.
sn.q: A foolish figure he must make.
sn.syn: Absurd; shallow; shallow-brained; brainless; simple; irrational; unwise; imprudent; indiscreet; incautious; silly; ridiculous; vain; trifling; contemptible. See Absurd.

entry.def: In a foolish manner.

sn.def: The quality of being foolish.
A foolish practice; an absurdity.
sn.q: The preaching of the cross is to them that perish foolishness.

entry.ety: OF. follarge. See Fool, and Large
entry.def: Foolishly liberal.

entry.ety: See Fool-large Largess
entry.def: Foolish expenditure; waste.

entry.ety: So called from the watermark of a fool's cap and bells used by old paper makers. See Fool's cap, under Fool
entry.def: A writing paper made in sheets, ordinarily 16 x 13 inches, and folded so as to make a page 13 x 8 inches. See Paper.

entries.entry:
Foot ☞ This measure is supposed to be taken from the length of a man's foot. It differs in length in different countries. In the United States and in England it is 304.8 millimeters. ☞ Foot is often used adjectively, signifying of or pertaining to a foot or the feet or to the base or lower part. It is also much used as the first of compounds.
Foot artillery. Mil Artillery soldiers serving in foot. Heavy artillery. Farrow. Foot bank Fort a raised way within a parapet. Foot barracks Mil barracks for infantery. Foot bellows a bellows worked by a treadle. Knight. Foot company Mil a company of infantry. Milton. Foot gear covering for the feet, as stocking, shoes, or boots. Foot hammer Mach a small tilt hammer moved by a treadle. Foot iron. The step of a carriage. A fetter. Foot jaw. Zoöl See Maxilliped. Foot key Mus an organ pedal. Foot level Gunnery a form of level used in giving any proposed angle of elevation to a piece of ordnance. Farrow. Foot mantle a long garment to protect the dress in riding; a riding skirt. Obs Foot page an errand boy; an attendant. Obs Foot passenger one who passes on foot, as over a road or bridge. Foot pavement a paved way for foot passengers; a footway; a trottoir. Foot poet an inferior poet; a poetaster. R Dryden. Foot post. A letter carrier who travels on foot. A mail delivery by means of such carriers.
Fot poundandFoot poundal . Mech See Foot pound and Foot poundal, in the Vocabulary. Foot press Mach a cutting, embossing, or printing press, moved by a treadle. Foot race a race run by persons on foot. Cowper. Foot rail a railroad rail, with a wide flat flange on the lower side. Foot rot an ulcer in the feet of sheep; claw sickness. Foot rule a rule or measure twelve inches long. Foot screw an adjusting screw which forms a foot, and serves to give a machine or table a level standing on an uneven place. Foot secretion. Zoöl See Sclerobase. Foot soldier a soldier who serves on foot. Foot stick Printing a beveled piece of furniture placed against the foot of the page, to hold the type in place. Foot stove a small box, with an iron pan, to hold hot coals for warming the feet. Foot tubercle. Zoöl See Parapodium. Foot valve Steam Engine the valve that opens to the air pump from the condenser. Foot vise a kind of vise the jaws of which are operated by a treadle. Foot waling Naut the inside planks or lining of a vessel over the floor timbers. Totten. Foot wall Mining the under wall of an inclosed vein.
By footorOn foot
by walking; as, to pass a stream on foot. Cubic foot. See under Cubic. Foot and mouth disease a contagious disease Eczema epizoötica of cattle, sheep, swine, etc., characterized by the formation of vesicles and ulcers in the mouth and about the hoofs. Foot of the fine Law the concluding portion of an acknowledgment in court by which, formerly, the title of land was conveyed. See Fine of land, under Fine n.; also Chirograph. (b). Square foot. See under Square. To be on foot to be in motion, action, or process of execution. To keep the foot Script to preserve decorum. “Keep thy foot when thou goest to the house of God.” Eccl. v. 1. To put one's foot down to take a resolute stand; to be determined. Colloq To put the best foot foremost to make a good appearance; to do one's best. Colloq To set on foot to put in motion; to originate; as, to set on foot a subscription.
To put one on his feetorset one on his feet
to put one in a position to go on; to assist to start. Under foot. Under the feet; (Fig.) at one's mercy; as, to trample under foot . Gibbon. Below par. Obs “They would be forced to sell . . . far under foot.” Bacon.
f�t n.; pl.Feet fēt. OE. fot foot, pl. fet feet. AS. fōt, pl. fēt; akin to D. voet, OHG. fuoz, G. fuss, Icel. fōtr, Sw. fot, Dan. fod, Goth. fōtus, L. pes, Gr. poy`s, Skr. pād, Icel. fet step, pace measure of a foot, feta to step, find one's way. √77, 250. Cf. Antipodes Cap-a-pie Expedient Fet to fetch, Fetlock Fetter Pawn a piece in chess, Pedal
Anat The terminal part of the leg of man or an animal; esp., the part below the ankle or wrist; that part of an animal upon which it rests when standing, or moves. See Manus, and Pes.
Zoöl The muscular locomotive organ of a mollusk. It is a median organ arising from the ventral region of body, often in the form of a flat disk, as in snails. See Illust. of Buccinum.
That which corresponds to the foot of a man or animal; as, the foot of a table; the foot of a stocking.
The lowest part or base; the ground part; the bottom, as of a mountain, column, or page; also, the last of a row or series; the end or extremity, esp. if associated with inferiority; as, the foot of a hill; the foot of the procession; the foot of a class; the foot of the bed; ; the foot of the page.
And now at foot Of heaven's ascent they lift their feet.
Fundamental principle; basis; plan; -- used only in the singular. Answer directly upon the foot of dry reason.
Recognized condition; rank; footing; -- used only in the singular. R As to his being on the foot of a servant.
A measure of length equivalent to twelve inches; one third of a yard. See Yard.
Mil Soldiers who march and fight on foot; the infantry, usually designated as the foot, in distinction from the cavalry. Both horse andfoot.
Pros A combination of syllables consisting a metrical element of a verse, the syllables being formerly distinguished by their quantity or length, but in modern poetry by the accent.
Naut The lower edge of a sail.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Footed; p. pr. & vb. n. Footing

sn.def: To tread to measure or music; to dance; to trip; to skip.
To walk; -- opposed to ride or fly.

cs.cd: to walk; also, to dance.

sn.def: To kick with the foot; to spurn.
To set on foot; to establish; to land.
sn.q: What confederacy have you with the traitors Late footed in the kingdom?

sn.def: To tread; as, to foot the green.
To sum up, as the numbers in a column; -- sometimes with up; as, to footor foot up) an account.
To seize or strike with the talon.
To renew the foot of, as of a stocking.
sn.q: If you are for a merry jaunt, I'll try, for once, who can foot it farthest.

sn.def: the amount of film that has been shot.
a rate of charging by the linear foot of work done.

entry.note: The American football is an oblate spheroid, with pointed ends. In other countries, the football is the same as a soccer ball. The games played with the two different balls are different. In the United States, the game played with a soccer ball is called soccer.
entry.def: An inflated ball to be kicked in sport, usually made in India rubber, or a bladder incased in Leather.

sn.def: The game played with a football{1}, by two opposing teams of players moving the ball between goals at opposite ends of a rectangular playing field. Outside the United States football refers to soccer, and in England, also to rugby, but in the United States the shape of the ball and the rules of the game are different.
Soccer or rugby.
Something which is treated in a rough manner, usually as part of a dispute; as, a political football .

entry.def: an athlete who plays football.
A band of foot soldiers.
A bath for the feet; also, a vessel used in bathing the feet.

entry.sn:
A board or narrow platfrom upon which one may stand or brace his feet; as: The platform for the engineer and fireman of a locomotive.
The foot-rest of a coachman's box.

sn.def: A board forming the foot of a bedstead.
A treadle.

entry.def: A page; an attendant in livery; a lackey.
The breadth of a foot; -- used as a measure.
entry.q: Not so much as a footbreadth.

entry.def: A narrow bridge for foot passengers only.

entries.entry: Foot candle. Photom The amount of illumination produced by a standard candle at a distance of one foot.

entry.def: Formerly, a housing or caparison for a horse.

entry.note: ☞ Footed is often used in composition in the sense of having such or so many feet; as, fourfooted beasts.

sn.def: Having a foot or feet; shaped in the foot; as, a footed candlestick.
sn.q: Footedlike a goat.

sn.def: Having a foothold; established.
sn.q: Our king . . . is footed in this land already.

entry.def: a suffix designating something with a length of (so many) feet; -- used only in combinations with a numerical prefix; as, he is a six-footer; the golfer sank a 40-footer; his yacht is a 60-footer .
a person who travels by foot.
A setting down of the foot; a footstep; the sound of a footstep.
entry.q: Seraphim, whose footfalls tinkled on the tufted floor.

entry.def: A conflict by persons on foot; -- distinguished from a fight on horseback.
A kind of stocking.
Infantry soldiers belonging to select regiments called the Guards.
A disease affecting the feet of sheep.
A low hill at the foot of higher hills or mountains.
A holding with the feet; firm standing; that on which one may tread or rest securely; footing.
See Futtock.
Hastily; immediately; instantly; on the spot; hotfoot.
entry.q: Custance have they taken anon, foothot.

cs.cd: one of the courses of masonry at the foot of a wall, broader than the courses above.
to pay a fee on first doing anything, as working at a trade or in a shop.
the tie beam of a roof.

sn.def: Ground for the foot; place for the foot to rest on; firm foundation to stand on.
sn.q: In ascent, every step gained is a footing and help to the next.

sn.def: Standing; position; established place; basis for operation; permanent settlement; foothold.
sn.q: As soon as he had obtained a footing at court, the charms of his manner . . . made him a favorite.

sn.def: Relative condition; state.
sn.q: Lived on a footing of equality with nobles.

sn.def: Tread; step; especially, measured tread.
sn.q: Hark, I hear the footing of a man.

sn.def: The act of adding up a column of figures; the amount or sum total of such a column.
The act of putting a foot to anything; also, that which is added as a foot; as, the footing of a stocking.
A narrow cotton lace, without figures.
The finer refuse part of whale blubber, not wholly deprived of oil.
The thickened or sloping portion of a wall, or of an embankment at its foot.

entry.def: Having no feet.
A sycophant; a fawner; a toady. Cf. Bootlick.

cs.cd: upon the stage; -- hence, in the capacity of an actor.

entry.def: One of a row of lights in the front of the stage in a theater, etc., and on a level therewith.
small and of little importance; as, a footling gesture.
entry.syn: fiddling, lilliputian, little, niggling, paltry, petty, piddling, picayune, small, trivial.

entry.def: a trunk for storing personal possessions; usually kept at the foot of a bed (as in a military barracks).

sn.def: having no commitments or restrictions.
without ties to a particular location; free to roam; wandering.
without dependents or responsibilities.
having no commitments or restrictions.

entries.entry:
Foot"man n.; pl.Footmen.
A soldier who marches and fights on foot; a foot soldier.
A man in waiting; a male servant whose duties are to attend the door, the carriage, the table, etc.
Formerly, a servant who ran in front of his master's carriage; a runner.
A metallic stand with four feet, for keeping anything warm before a fire.
Zoöl A moth of the family Lithosidæ; -- so called from its livery-like colors.

entry.def: Art or skill of a footman.
A footprint; a track or vestige.
A note of reference or comment at the foot{4} of a page.

sn.def: A walking pace or step.
A dais, or elevated platform; the highest step of the altar; a landing in a staircase.

entry.def: A highwayman or robber on foot.

entries.entry: Foot"path` n.; pl.Footpaths. A narrow path or way for pedestrains only; a footway.

entry.def: See Footboard.

entries.entry: Foot" pound`. Mech A unit of energy, or work, being equal to the work done in raising one pound avoirdupois against the force of gravity through a vertical distance of one foot.
Foot" pound`al. Mech A unit of energy or work, equal to the work done in moving a body through one foot against the force of one poundal.

entry.def: The impression of the foot; a trace or footmark; as, “Footprints of the Creator.”
The rope rigged below a yard, upon which men stand when reefing or furling; -- formerly called a horse.
That part of the boltrope to which the lower edge of a sail is sewed.
The settlings of oil, molasses, etc., at the bottom of a barrel or hogshead.
Having sore or tender feet, as by reason of much walking; as, foot-sore cattle.

sn.def: The stalk of a leaf or of flower; a petiole, pedicel, or reduncle.

sd.def: The peduncle or stem by which various marine animals are attached, as certain brachiopods and goose barnacles.
The stem which supports which supports the eye in decapod Crustacea; eyestalk.

sn.def: The lower part of a millstone spindle. It rests in a step.

entry.ety: Cf. Pedestal

sn.def: The stirrup of a woman's saddle.
The plinth or base of a pillar.
The mark or impression of the foot; a track; hence, visible sign of a course pursued; token; mark; as, the footsteps of divine wisdom.
sn.q: How on the faltering footsteps of decay Youth presses.

sn.def: An inclined plane under a hand printing press.

entry.def: The stone at the foot of a grave; -- opposed to headstone.
A low stool to support the feet of one when sitting.

entries.entry: Foot ton. Mech A unit of energy or work, being equal to the work done in raising one ton against the force of gravity through the height of one foot.
Foot valve. Mech A suction valve or check valve at the lower end of a pipe; esp., such a valve in a steam-engine condenser opening to the air pump.

entry.def: A passage for pedestrians only.
Worn by, or weared in, the feet; as, a footworn path; a footworn traveler.

sn.def: Having foots, or settlings; as, footy oil, molasses, etc.
Poor; mean.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foozled; p. pr. & vb. n. Foozling
entry.ety: Cf. G. fuseln to work badly or slowly
entry.def: To bungle; to manage awkwardly; to treat or play unskillfully; as, to foozle a stroke in golf.
entry.q: She foozles all along the course.

sn.def: A stupid fellow; a fogy.
Act of foozling; a bungling stroke, as in golf.

entry.ety: OE. foppe fop, fool; cf. E. fob to cheat, G. foppen to make a fool of one, jeer, D. foppen
entry.def: One whose ambition it is to gain admiration by showy dress; a coxcomb; an inferior dandy.
A stupid or insignificant fellow; a fool; a simpleton.
A petty fop.

entries.entry:
Fop"per*y n.; pl.Fopperies #. From Fop
The behavior, dress, or other indication of a fop; coxcombry; affectation of show; showy folly.
Folly; foolery. Let not the sound of shallow foppery enter My sober house.

entry.def: Foplike; characteristic of a top in dress or manners; making an ostentatious display of gay clothing; affected in manners.

entries.entry: For-. AS. for-; akin to D. & G. ver-, OHG. fir-, Icel. for-, Goth. fra-, cf. Skr. parā- away, Gr. � beside, and E. far, adj. Cf. Fret to rub A prefix to verbs, having usually the force of a negative or privative. It often implies also loss detriment, or destruction, and sometimes it is intensive, meaning utterly quite thoroughly, as in forbathe.

entry.cs:
FororAs for
so far as concerns; as regards; with reference to; -- used parenthetically or independently. See under As.
As for me and my house, we will serve the Lord. Josh. xxiv. 15.
For me, my stormy voyage at an end, I to the port of death securely tend. Dryden. For all that notwithstanding; in spite of. For all the world wholly; exactly. “Whose posy was, for all the world, like cutlers' poetry.” Shak.
For as much asorForasmuch as
in consideration that; seeing that; since. For by. See Forby adv.
For ever eternally; at all times. See Forever.
For meorFor all me
as far as regards me.
For my lifeorFor the life of me
if my life depended on it. Colloq T. Hook.
For that For the reason that
because; since. Obs “For that I love your daughter.” Shak.
For thyorForthy
AS. forðȳ
for this; on this account. Obs “Thomalin, have no care for thy.” Spenser. For to as sign of infinitive, in order to; to the end of. Obs., except as sometimes heard in illiterate speech“What went ye out for to see?” Luke vii. 25. See To prep., 4. O for would that I had; may there be granted; -- elliptically expressing desire or prayer. “O for a muse of fire.” Shak.
Were it not fororIf it were not for
leaving out of account; but for the presence or action of. “Moral consideration can no way move the sensible appetite, were it not for the will.” Sir M. Hale.
entry.ety: AS. for fore; akin to OS. for fora furi, D. voor, OHG. fora, G. vor, OHG. furi, G. für, Icel. fyrir, Sw. för, Dan. for, adv. för, Goth. faúr faúra, L. pro, Gr. �, Skr. pra-. √ 202. Cf. Fore First Foremost Forth Pro-
entry.def: In the most general sense, indicating that in consideration of, in view of, or with reference to, which anything is done or takes place.

sn.def: Indicating the antecedent cause or occasion of an action; the motive or inducement accompanying and prompting to an act or state; the reason of anything; that on account of which a thing is or is done.
sn.q: With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath.
How to choose dogs for scent or speed.
Now, for so many glorious actions done,For peace at home, and for the public wealth, I mean to crown a bowl for Cæsar's health.
That which we, for our unworthiness, are afraid to crave, our prayer is, that God, for the worthiness of his Son, would, notwithstanding, vouchsafe to grant.

sn.def: Indicating the remoter and indirect object of an act; the end or final cause with reference to which anything is, acts, serves, or is done.
sn.q: The oak for nothing ill, The osier good for twigs, the poplar for the mill.
It was young counsel for the persons, and violent counsel for the matters.
Shall I think the worls was made for one, And men are born for kings, as beasts for men, Not for protection, but to be devoured?
For he writes not for money, nor for praise.

sn.def: Indicating that in favor of which, or in promoting which, anything is, or is done; hence, in behalf of; in favor of; on the side of; -- opposed to against.
sn.q: We can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth.
It is for the general good of human society, and consequently of particular persons, to be true and just; and it is for men's health to be temperate.
Aristotle is for poetical justice.

sn.def: Indicating that toward which the action of anything is directed, or the point toward which motion is made; �ntending to go to.
sn.q: We sailed from Peru for China and Japan.

sn.def: Indicating that on place of or instead of which anything acts or serves, or that to which a substitute, an equivalent, a compensation, or the like, is offered or made; instead of, or place of.
sn.q: And if any mischief follow, then thou shalt give life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot.

sn.def: Indicating that in the character of or as being which anything is regarded or treated; to be, or as being.
sn.q: We take a falling meteor for a star.
If a man can be fully assured of anything for a truth, without having examined, what is there that he may not embrace for tru�?
Most of our ingenious young men take up some cried-up English poet for their model.
But let her go for an ungrateful woman.

sn.def: Indicating that instead of which something else controls in the performing of an action, or that in spite of which anything is done, occurs, or is; hence, equivalent to notwithstanding in spite of; -- generally followed by all aught anything, etc.
sn.q: The writer will do what she please for all me.
God's desertion shall, for aught he knows, the next minute supervene.
For anything that legally appears to the contrary, it may be a contrivance to fright us.

sn.def: Indicating the space or time through which an action or state extends; hence, during; in or through the space or time of.
sn.q: For many miles about There 's scarce a bush.
Since, hired for life, thy servile muse sing.
To guide the sun's bright chariot for a day.

sn.def: Indicating that in prevention of which, or through fear of which, anything is done.
sn.q: We 'll have a bib, for spoiling of thy doublet.

entry.cs: For because because. Obs “Nor for because they set less store by their own citizens.” Robynson (More's Utopia). For why. Why; for that reason; wherefore. Obs Because. Obs See Forwhy.

sn.def: Because; by reason that; for that; indicating, in Old English, the reason of anything.
sn.q: And for of long that way had walkéd none, The vault was hid with plants and bushes hoar.
And Heaven defend your good souls, that you think I will your serious and great business scant,For she with me.

sn.def: Since; because; introducing a reason of something before advanced, a cause, motive, explanation, justification, or the like, of an action related or a statement made. It is logically nearly equivalent to since, or because, but connects less closely, and is sometimes used as a very general introduction to something suggested by what has gone before.
sn.q: Give thanks unto the Lord; for he is good; for his mercy endureth forever.
Heaven doth with us as we with torches do, Not light them for themselves; for if our virtues Did not go forth of us, 't were all alike As if we had them not.

entry.cs: The fors and against. those in favor and those opposed; the pros and the cons; the advantages and the disadvantages. Jane Austen.
entry.def: One who takes, or that which is said on, the affrimative side; that which is said in favor of some one or something; -- the antithesis of against, and commonly used in connection with it.

entry.cs: Forage cap. See under Cap. Forage master Mil a person charged with providing forage and the means of transporting it. Farrow.
entry.ety: OF. fourage, F. fourrage, fr. forre fuerre, fodder, straw, F. feurre, fr. LL. foderum fodrum, of German or Scand, origin; cf. OHG. fuotar, G. futter. See Fodder food, and cf. Foray

sn.def: The act of foraging; search for provisions, etc.
sn.q: He [the lion] from forage will incline to play.
One way a band select from forage drives A herd of beeves, fair oxen and fair kine.
Mawhood completed his forage unmolested.

sn.def: Food of any kind for animals, especially for horses and cattle, as grass, pasture, hay, corn, oats.

cs.cd: one of several species of ants of the genus Eciton, very abundant in tropical America, remarkable for marching in vast armies in search of food.
a forage cap.
a party sent out after forage.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foraged ; p. pr. & vb. n. Foraging
entry.def: To wander or rove in search of food; to collect food, esp. forage, for horses and cattle by feeding on or stripping the country; to ravage; to feed on spoil.
entry.q: His most mighty father on a hill Stood smiling to behold his lion's whelpForage in blood of French nobility.

entry.def: To strip of provisions; to supply with forage; as, to forage steeds.
One who forages.

entry.ety: L. forare to bore + -lite
entry.def: A tubelike marking, occuring in sandstone and other strata.

entries.entry:
‖Fo*ra"men
Foramen of Monro Anat the opening from each lateral into the third ventricle of the brain. Foramen of Winslow Anat the opening connecting the sac of the omentum with the general cavity of the peritoneum.
n.; pl. L. Foramina #, E. Foramines #. L., fr. forare to bore, pierce A small opening, perforation, or orifice; a fenestra.

entry.ety: L. foraminatus
entry.def: Having small opening, or foramina.
One of the Foraminifera.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. foramen -aminis, a foramen + ferre to bear
entry.def: An extensive order of rhizopods which generally have a chambered calcareous shell formed by several united zooids. Many of them have perforated walls, whence the name. Some species are covered with sand. See Rhizophoda.

sn.def: Having small openings, or foramina.
Pertaining to, or composed of, Foraminifera; as, foraminiferous mud.

entry.ety: L. foraminosus
entry.def: Having foramina; full of holes; porous.
In consideration that; seeing that; since; because that; -- followed by as. See under For prep.

entry.ety: Another form of forahe. Cf. Forray
entry.def: A sudden or irregular incursion in border warfare; hence, any irregular incursion for war or spoils; a raid.
entry.q: The huge Earl Doorm, . . . Bound on a foray, rolling eyes of prey.

entry.def: To pillage; to ravage.
entry.q: He might foray our lands.

entry.def: One who makes or joins in a foray.
entry.q: They might not choose the lowland road, For the Merse forayers were abroad.

entry.def: imp. of Forbid.
To bathe.

entry.ety: See Fore, and Bear to produce
entry.def: An ancestor; a forefather; -- usually in the plural.
entry.q: Yourforbearsof old.

entry.vmorph: imp. Forbore Forbare Obs); p. p. Forborne; p. pr. & vb. n. Forbearing
entry.ety: OE. forberen, AS. forberan; pref. for- + beran to bear. See Bear to support

sn.def: To refrain from proceeding; to pause; to delay.
sn.q: Shall I go against Ramoth-gilead to battle, or shall I forbear?

sn.def: To refuse; to decline; to give no heed.
sn.q: Thou shalt speak my words unto them, whether they will hear, or whether they will forbear.

sn.def: To control one's self when provoked.
sn.q: The kindest and the happiest pair Will find occasion to forbear.
Both bear and forbear.

sn.def: To keep away from; to avoid; to abstain from; to give up; as, to forbear the use of a word of doubtful propriety.
sn.q: But let me that plunder forbear.
The King In open battle or the tilting fieldForbore his own advantage.

sn.def: To treat with consideration or indulgence.
sn.q: Forbearing one another in love.

sn.def: To cease from bearing.
sn.q: Whenas my womb her burden would forbear.

entry.def: The act of forbearing or waiting; the exercise of patience.
entry.q: He soon shall findForbearance no acquittance ere day end.

sn.def: The quality of being forbearing; indulgence toward offenders or enemies; long-suffering.
sn.q: Have a continent forbearance, till the speed of his rage goes slower.

entry.def: Forbearing.
One who forbears.
Disposed or accustomed to forbear; patient; long-suffering.

entry.vmorph: imp. Forbade fŏr*băd"; p. p. Forbidden fŏr*bĭd"d'n Forbid Obs); p. pr. & vb. n. Forbidding fŏr*bĭd"dĭng
entry.ety: OE. forbeden, AS. forbeódan; pref. for- + beódan to bid; akin to D. verbieden, G. verbieten, Icel. fyrirbjōða forboða, Sw. förbjuda, Dan. forbyde. See Bid v. t.

sn.def: To command against, or contrary to; to prohibit; to interdict.
sn.q: More than I have said . . . The leisure and enforcement of the timeForbids to dwell upon.

sn.def: To deny, exclude from, or warn off, by express command; to command not to enter.
sn.q: Have I not forbid her my house?

sn.def: To oppose, hinder, or prevent, as if by an effectual command; as, an impassable river forbids the approach of the army.
sn.q: A blaze of glory that forbids the sight.

sn.def: To accurse; to blast.
sn.q: He shall live a man forbid.

sn.def: To defy; to challenge.
sn.syn: To prohibit; interdict; hinder; preclude; withhold; restrain; prevent. See Prohibit.

entry.def: To utter a prohibition; to prevent; to hinder.
entry.q: I did not orforbid.

entry.def: The act of forbidding; prohibition; command or edict against a thing.
entry.q: How hast thou yield to transgress The strict forbiddance.

entry.cs: Forbidden fruit. Any coveted unlawful pleasure, -- so called with reference to the forbidden fruit of the Garden of Eden. Bot A small variety of shaddock (Citrus decumana). The name is given in different places to several varieties of Citrus fruits.
entry.def: Prohibited; interdicted.
entry.q: I know no spells, use no forbidden arts.

entry.def: In a forbidden or unlawful manner.
One who forbids.
Repelling approach; repulsive; raising abhorrence, aversion, or dislike; disagreeable; prohibiting or interdicting; as, a forbidding aspect; a forbidding formality; a forbidding air.
entry.syn: Disagreeable; unpleasant; displeasing; offensive; repulsive; odious; abhorrent.

entry.def: Very black.
entry.q: As any raven's feathers it shone forblack.

entry.def: p. p. of Forbid.
imp. of Forbear.
p. p. of Forbear.
To bruise sorely or exceedingly.
entry.q: All forbrosed, both back and side.

entry.ety: See Foreby
entry.def: Near; hard by; along; past.
entry.q: To tell her if her child went ought forby.
To the intent that ships may pass along forby all the sides of the city without let.

entry.def: To cut completely; to cut off.

entry.ety: See Farce to stuff
entry.def: To stuff; to lard; to farce.
entry.q: Wit larded with malice, and malice forced with wit.

entry.ety: Of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. fors foss, Dan. fos
entry.def: A waterfall; a cascade.
entry.q: To see the falls for force of the river Kent.

entry.cs:
Animal force Physiol muscular force or energy. Catabiotic force Gr. � down (intens.) + � life Biol the influence exerted by living structures on adjoining cells, by which the latter are developed in harmony with the primary structures.
Centrifugal force Centripetal force Coercive force, etc. See under Centrifugal Centripetal, etc.
Composition of forces Correlation of forces, etc. See under Composition Correlation, etc. Force and arms trans. of L. vi et armis
Law an expression in old indictments, signifying violence.
In forceorOf force
of unimpaired efficacy; valid; of full virtue; not suspended or reversed. “A testament is of force after men are dead.” Heb. ix. 17. Metabolic force Physiol the influence which causes and controls the metabolism of the body. No force no matter of urgency or consequence; no account; hence, to do no force, to make no account of; not to heed. Obs Chaucer. Of force of necessity; unavoidably; imperatively. “Good reasons must, of force, give place to better.” Shak. Plastic force Physiol the force which presumably acts in the growth and repair of the tissues. Vital force Physiol that force or power which is inherent in organization; that form of energy which is the cause of the vital phenomena of the body, as distinguished from the physical forces generally known.
entry.usage: Force Strength. Strength looks rather to power as an inward capability or energy. Thus we speak of the strength of timber, bodily strength, mental strength strength of emotion, etc. Force, on the other hand, looks more to the outward; as, the force of gravitation, force of circumstances, force of habit, etc. We do, indeed, speak of strength of will and force of will; but even here the former may lean toward the internal tenacity of purpose, and the latter toward the outward expression of it in action. But, though the two words do in a few cases touch thus closely on each other, there is, on the whole, a marked distinction in our use of force and strength. “Force is the name given, in mechanical science, to whatever produces, or can produce, motion.”
entry.ety: F. force, LL. forcia fortia, fr. L. fortis strong. See Fort n.

sn.def: Capacity of exercising an influence or producing an effect; strength or energy of body or mind; active power; vigor; might; often, an unusual degree of strength or energy; especially, power to persuade, or convince, or impose obligation; pertinency; validity; special signification; as, the force of an appeal, an argument, a contract, or a term.
sn.q: He was, in the full force of the words, a good man.

sn.def: Power exerted against will or consent; compulsory power; violence; coercion; as, by force of arms; to take by force .
sn.q: Which now they hold by force, and not by right.

sn.def: Strength or power for war; hence, a body of land or naval combatants, with their appurtenances, ready for action; -- an armament; troops; warlike array; -- often in the plural; hence, a body of men prepared for action in other ways; as, the laboring force of a plantation; the armed forces .
sn.q: Is Lucius general of the forces?

sd.def: Strength or power exercised without law, or contrary to law, upon persons or things; violence.
Validity; efficacy.

sn.def: Any action between two bodies which changes, or tends to change, their relative condition as to rest or motion; or, more generally, which changes, or tends to change, any physical relation between them, whether mechanical, thermal, chemical, electrical, magnetic, or of any other kind; as, the force of gravity; cohesive force; centrifugal force.
sn.syn: Strength; vigor; might; energy; stress; vehemence; violence; compulsion; coaction; constraint; coercion.
sn.q: Thy tears are of no force to mollify This flinty man.
More huge in strength than wise in works he was.
Adam and first matron Eve Had ended now their orisons, and foundStrength added from above, new hope to spring Out of despair.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forced; p. pr. & vb. n. Forcing
entry.ety: OF. forcier, F. forcer, fr. LL. forciare fortiare. See Force n.

sn.def: To constrain to do or to forbear, by the exertion of a power not resistible; to compel by physical, moral, or intellectual means; to coerce; as, masters force slaves to labor.
To compel, as by strength of evidence; as, to force conviction on the mind.
To do violence to; to overpower, or to compel by violence to one's will; especially, to ravish; to violate; to commit rape upon.
sn.q: To force their monarch and insult the court.
I should have forced thee soon wish other arms.
To force a spotless virgin's chastity.

sn.def: To obtain, overcome, or win by strength; to take by violence or struggle; specifically, to capture by assault; to storm, as a fortress; as, to force the castle; to force a lock.
To impel, drive, wrest, extort, get, etc., by main strength or violence; -- with a following adverb, as along away from into through out, etc.
sn.q: It stuck so fast, so deeply buried lay That scarce the victor forced the steel away.
To force the tyrant from his seat by war.
Ethelbert ordered that none should be forced into religion.

sn.def: To put in force; to cause to be executed; to make binding; to enforce.
sn.q: What can the church force more?

sn.def: To exert to the utmost; to urge; hence, to strain; to urge to excessive, unnatural, or untimely action; to produce by unnatural effort; as, to force a conceit or metaphor; to force a laugh; to force fruits.
sn.q: High on a mounting wave my head I bore,Forcing my strength, and gathering to the shore.

sn.def: To compel (an adversary or partner) to trump a trick by leading a suit of which he has none.
To provide with forces; to reënforce; to strengthen by soldiers; to man; to garrison.
To allow the force of; to value; to care for.
sn.q: For me, I force not argument a straw.
sn.syn: To compel; constrain; oblige; necessitate; coerce; drive; press; impel.

sn.def: To use violence; to make violent effort; to strive; to endeavor.
sn.q: Forcing with gifts to win his wanton heart.

sn.def: To make a difficult matter of anything; to labor; to hesitate; hence, to force of, to make much account of; to regard.
sn.q: Your oath once broke, you force not to forswear.
I force not of such fooleries.

sn.def: To be of force, importance, or weight; to matter.
sn.q: It is not sufficient to have attained the name and dignity of a shepherd, not forcing how.

entry.cs: Forced draught. See under Draught. Forced march Mil a march of one or more days made with all possible speed.
entry.def: Done or produced with force or great labor, or by extraordinary exertion; hurried; strained; produced by unnatural effort or pressure; as, a forced style; a forced laugh.
to feed (someone) against his will, as during a hunger strike.
a method of lubricating internal combustion engines in which a pump forces oil into the engine bearings.
entry.syn: lubricating system, force-feed lubricating system, force feed, pressure-feed lubricating system, pressure feed.

entry.def: Full of or processing force; exerting force; mighty.
entry.q: Against the steed he threw His forceful spear.

entry.def: Having little or no force; feeble.
entry.q: These forceless flowers like sturdy trees support me.

entry.def: physical energy or intensity.

entry.ety: Corrupt. for farce-meat, fr. F. farce stuffing. See Farce n.
entry.def: Meat chopped fine and highly seasoned, either served up alone, or used as a stuffing.
The act of forcing; compulsion.
entry.q: It was imposed upon us by constraint; And will you count such forcement treachery?

entry.cs: Dressing forceps. See under Dressing.
entry.ety: L. forceps -cipis, from the root of formus Hot + capere to take; akin to E. heave. Cf. Furnace

sn.def: A pair of pinchers, or tongs; an instrument for grasping, holding firmly, or exerting traction upon, bodies which it would be inconvenient or impracticable to seize with the fingers, especially one for delicate operations, as those of watchmakers, surgeons, accoucheurs, dentists, etc.
The caudal forceps-shaped appendage of earwigs and some other insects. See Earwig.

entries.entry: Force" pump`. Mach A pump having a solid piston, or plunger, for drawing and forcing a liquid, as water, through the valves; in distinction from a pump having a bucket, or valved piston. A pump adapted for delivering water at a considerable height above the pump, or under a considerable pressure; in distinction from one which lifts the water only to the top of the pump or delivers it through a spout. See Illust. of Plunger pump, under Plunger.

sn.def: One who, or that which, forces or drives.

sd.def: The solid piston of a force pump; the instrument by which water is forced in a pump.
A small hand pump for sinking pits, draining cellars, etc.

cs.cd: the entering upon and taking and withholding of land and tenements by actual force and violence, and with a strong hand, to the hindrance of the person having the right to enter.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. forcible forcible, forceable that may be forced

sn.def: Possessing force; characterized by force, efficiency, or energy; powerful; efficacious; impressive; influential.
sn.q: How forcible are right words!
Sweet smells are most forcible in dry substances, when broken.
But I have reasons strong and forcible.
That punishment which hath been sometimes forcible to bridle sin.
He is at once elegant and sublime, forcible and ornamented.

sn.def: Violent; impetuous.
sn.q: Like mingled streams, more forcible when joined.

sn.def: Using force against opposition or resistance; obtained by compulsion; effected by force; as, forcible entry or abduction.
sn.q: In embraces of King James . . . forcible and unjust.
sn.syn: Violent; powerful; strong; energetic; mighty; potent; weighty; impressive; cogent; influential.

entry.ety: From Feeble, a character in the Second Part of Shakespeare's “King Henry IV.,” to whom Falstaff derisively applies the epithet “forcible.”
entry.def: Seemingly vigorous, but really weak or insipid.
entry.q: He [Prof. Ayton] would purge his book of much offensive matter, if he struck out epithets which are in the bad taste of the forcible-feeble school.

entry.def: The quality of being forcible.
In a forcible manner.

entry.cs:
Forcing bedorForcing pit
a plant bed having an under layer of fermenting manure, the fermentation yielding bottom heat for forcing plants; a hotbed. Forcing engine a fire engine. Forcing fit Mech a tight fit, as of one part into a hole in another part, which makes it necessary to use considerable force in putting the two parts together. Forcing house a greenhouse for the forcing of plants, fruit trees, etc. Forcing machine a powerful press for putting together or separating two parts that are fitted tightly one into another, as for forcing a crank on a shaft, or for drawing off a car wheel from the axle. Forcing pump. See Force pump.

sn.def: The accomplishing of any purpose violently, precipitately, prematurely, or with unusual expedition.
The art of raising plants, flowers, and fruits at an earlier season than the natural one, as in a hitbed or by the use of artificial heat.

entry.def: Forked or branched like a pair of forceps; constructed so as to open and shut like a pair of forceps.
Like a pair of forceps; as, a forcipated mouth.
Torture by pinching with forceps or pinchers.

entry.ety: From 3d Force n.
entry.def: A gelatin dynamite in which the dope is composed largely of sodium nitrate.
To cut completely; to cut off.

entry.ety: AS. ford; akin to G. furt, Icel. fjörðr bay, and to E. fare. √78. See Fare v. i., and cf. Frith arm of the sea

sn.def: A place in a river, or other water, where it may be passed by man or beast on foot, by wading.
sn.q: He swam the Esk river where ford there was none.

sn.def: A stream; a current.
sn.q: With water of the ford Or of the clouds.
Permit my ghost to pass the Styg�an ford.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forded; p. pr. & vb. n. Fording
entry.def: To pass or cross, as a river or other water, by wading; to wade through.
entry.q: His last section, which is no deep one, remains only to be forted.

entry.def: Capable of being forded.
Without a ford.
entry.q: A deep and fordless river.

entry.ety: OE. fordon, AS. ford�n; pref. for- + d�n to do. See For-, and Do v. i.

sn.def: To destroy; to undo; to ruin.
sn.q: This is the night That either makes me or fordoes me quite.

sn.def: To overcome with fatigue; to exhaust.
sn.q: All with weary task fordone.

entry.ety: See Fordo
entry.def: Undone; ruined.
To drive about; to drive here and there.
Utterly drunk; very drunk.
Entirely dry; withered.
entry.q: A treefordry.

entry.def: To dwindle away; to disappear.

entry.ety: AS. fōr, fr. faran to go. See Fare v. i.
entry.def: Journey; way; method of proceeding.
entry.q: Follow him and hisfore.

cs.cd: from stem to stern; lengthwise of the vessel; -- in distinction from athwart.
not rigged with square sails attached to yards, but with sails bent to gaffs or set on stays in the midship line of the vessel. See Schooner Sloop Cutter.

entry.ety: AS. fore, adv. & prep., another form of for. See For, and cf. Former Foremost

sn.def: In the part that precedes or goes first; -- opposed to aft after back behind, etc.
Formerly; previously; afore.
sn.q: The eyes, fore duteous, now converted are.

sn.def: In or towards the bows of a ship.

entry.note: ☞ Fore is much used adjectively or in composition.
entry.cs: Fore bay a reservoir or canal between a mill race and a water wheel; the discharging end of a pond or mill race. Fore body Shipbuilding the part of a ship forward of the largest cross-section, distinguished from middle body and after body. Fore boot a receptacle in the front of a vehicle, for stowing baggage, etc. Fore bow the pommel of a saddle. Knight. Fore cabin a cabin in the fore part of a ship, usually with inferior accommodations. Fore carriage. The forward part of the running gear of a four-wheeled vehicle. A small carriage at the front end of a plow beam. Fore course Naut the lowermost sail on the foremost of a square-rigged vessel; the foresail. See Illust. under Sail. Fore door. Same as Front door. Fore edge the front edge of a book or folded sheet, etc. Fore elder an ancestor. Prov. Eng Fore end. The end which precedes; the earlier, or the nearer, part; the beginning. I have . . . paid More pious debts to heaven, than in all The fore end of my time. Shak. In firearms, the wooden stock under the barrel, forward of the trigger guard, or breech frame. Fore girth a girth for the fore part (of a horse, etc.); a martingale. Fore hammer a sledge hammer, working alternately, or in time, with the hand hammer. Fore leg one of the front legs of a quadruped, or multiped, or of a chair, settee, etc. Fore peak Naut the angle within a ship's bows; the portion of the hold which is farthest forward. Fore piece a front piece, as the flap in the fore part of a sidesaddle, to guard the rider's dress. Fore plane a carpenter's plane, in size and use between a jack plane and a smoothing plane. Knight. Fore reading previous perusal. Obs Hales. Fore rent in Scotland, rent payable before a crop is gathered. Fore sheets Naut the forward portion of a rowboat; the space beyond the front thwart. See Stern sheets. Fore shore. A bank in advance of a sea wall, to break the force of the surf. The seaward projecting, slightly inclined portion of a breakwater. Knight. The part of the shore between high and low water marks. Fore sight that one of the two sights of a gun which is near the muzzle. Fore tackle Naut the tackle on the foremast of a ship. Fore topmast. Naut See Fore-topmast, in the Vocabulary. Fore wind a favorable wind. Obs Sailed on smooth seas, by fore winds borne. Sandys. Fore world the antediluvian world. R Southey.
entry.ety: See Fore adv.
