entry.def: Advanced, as compared with something else; toward the front; being or coming first, in time, place, order, or importance; preceding; anterior; antecedent; earlier; forward; -- opposed to back or behind; as, the fore part of a garment; the fore part of the day; the fore and of a wagon.
entry.q: The free will of the subject is preserved, while it is directed by the fore purpose of the state.

entry.cs: At the fore Naut at the fore royal masthead; -- said of a flag, so raised as a signal for sailing, etc. To the fore. In advance; to the front; to a prominent position; in plain sight; in readiness for use. In existence; alive; not worn out, lost, or spent, as money, etc. Irish “While I am to the fore.” W. Collins. “How many captains in the regiment had two thousand pounds to the fore?” Thackeray.
entry.def: The front; hence, that which is in front; the future.
Before; -- sometimes written 'fore as if a contraction of afore or before.
To admonish beforehand, or before the act or event.
To advise or counsel before the time of action, or before the event.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forealleged; p. pr. & vb. n. Forealleging
entry.def: To allege or cite before.
To set, order, or appoint, beforehand.
Previous appointment; preordinantion.
To arm or prepare for attack or resistance before the time of need.
That part of the arm or fore limb between the elbow and wrist; the antibrachium.
The breast beam of a loom.
An ancestor. See Forbear.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foreboded; p. pr. & vb. n. Foreboding
entry.ety: AS. forebodian; fore + bodian to announce. See Bode v. t.

sn.def: To foretell.
To be prescient of (some ill or misfortune); to have an inward conviction of, as of a calamity which is about to happen; to augur despondingly.
sn.q: His heart forebodes a mystery.
Sullen, desponding, and foreboding nothing but wars and desolation, as the certain consequence of Cæsar's death.
I have a sort of foreboding about him.
sn.syn: To foretell; predict; prognosticate; augur; presage; portend; betoken.

entry.def: To foretell; to presage; to augur.
entry.q: If I forebode aright.

entry.def: Prognostication; presage.
The act of foreboding; the thing foreboded.
One who forebodes.
Presage of coming ill; expectation of misfortune.
In a foreboding manner.
A rope applied to the fore yardarm, to change the position of the foresail.
The anterior of the three principal divisions of the brain, including the prosencephalon and thalamencephalon. Sometimes restricted to the prosencephalon only. See Brain.

entry.ety: Fore + by
entry.def: Near; hard by; along; past. See Forby.

sn.def: To plan beforehand; to scheme; to project.
sn.q: He shall forecast his devices against the strongholds.

sn.def: To foresee; to calculate beforehand, so as to provide for; as, to forecast the weather; to forecast prices.
sn.q: It is wisdom to consider the end of things before we embark, and to forecast consequences.

entry.def: To contrive or plan beforehand.
entry.q: If it happen as I did forecast.

entry.def: Previous contrivance or determination; predetermination.
entry.q: He makes this difference to arise from the forecast and predetermination of the gods themselves.

sn.def: A calculation predicting future events; the foresight of consequences, and provision against them; prevision; premeditation; as, the weather forecast .
sn.q: His calm, deliberate forecast better fitted him for the council than the camp.

entry.def: One who forecast.
The process of calculating and predicting future events, usually based on extrapolation from past experience, and with varying degress of uncertainty.
A short upper deck forward, formerly raised like a castle, to command an enemy's decks.
That part of the upper deck of a vessel forward of the foremast, or of the after part of the fore channels.
In merchant vessels, the forward part of the vessel, under the deck, where the sailors live.
Chosen beforehand.
Cited or quoted before or above.

cs.cd: to cut him off by a judgment of court from the power of redeeming the mortgaged premises, termed his equity of redemption.
not technically correct, but often used to signify) the obtaining a judgment for the payment of an overdue mortgage, and the exposure of the mortgaged property to sale to meet the mortgage debt.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foreclosed; p. pr. & vb. n. Foreclosing
entry.ety: F. forclos, p. p. of forclore to exclude; OF. fors, F. hors, except, outside (fr. L. foris outside) + F. clore to close. See Foreign, and Close v. t.
entry.def: To shut up or out; to preclude; to stop; to prevent; to bar; to exclude.
entry.q: The embargo with Spain foreclosed this trade.

entry.def: The act or process of foreclosing; a proceeding which bars or extinguishes a mortgager's right of redeeming a mortgaged estate.
To preconceive; to imagine beforehand.
To date before the true time; to antedate.
The fore part of a deck, or of a ship.
To recognize or judge in advance; to forebode.
entry.q: Laugh at your misery, as foredeeming you An idle meteor.

entry.ety: Cf. Foredoom
entry.def: To know or discover beforehand; to foretell.
entry.q: Which [maid] could guess and foredeem of things past, present, and to come.

entry.def: To plan beforehand; to intend previously.
To determine or decree beforehand.
To bestow beforehand.
entry.q: King James had by promise foredisposed the place on the Bishop of Meath.

entry.ety: Cf. Foredeem
entry.def: To doom beforehand; to predestinate.
entry.q: Thou art foredoomed to view the Stygian state.

entry.def: Doom or sentence decreed in advance.
entry.q: A dreadforedoomringing in the ears of the guilty adult.

cs.cd: the anniversary of the day (December 21) on which the Pilgrim Fathers landed at Plymouth, Massachusetts (1620). On account of a mistake in reckoning the change from Old Style to New Style, it has generally been celebrated on the 22d.

entry.def: One who precedes another in the line of genealogy in any degree, but usually in a remote degree; an ancestor.
entry.q: Respecting your forefathers, you would have been taught to respect yourselves.

entry.def: To feel beforehand; to have a presentiment of.
entry.q: As when, with unwieldy waves, the great sea forefeels winds.

entry.def: Defense in front.

entry.ety: OE. forfenden; pref. for- + fenden to fend. See Fend v. t.
entry.def: To hinder; to fend off; to avert; to prevent the approach of; to forbid or prohibit. See Forfend.
entry.q: God forefend it should ever be recorded in our history.
It would be a far better work . . . to forefend the cruelty.

entry.def: The finger next to the thumb; the index finger.
To flow before.

sn.def: One of the anterior feet of a quadruped or multiped; -- usually written fore foot.
A piece of timber which terminates the keel at the fore end, connecting it with the lower end of the stem.

entry.def: Foremost part or place.
entry.q: Set ye Uriah in the forefront of the hottest battle.
Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, standing in the forefront for all time, the masters of those who know.

entry.def: A first game; first plan.

entry.ety: Prop., a goer before cf. G. voregänger. See Fore, and Gang
entry.def: A short rope grafted on a harpoon, to which a longer line may be attached.
Same as Forgather.
A premium paid by a lessee when taking his lease.
An antecedent or premonitory gleam; a dawning light.
entry.q: The foregleams of wisdom.

entry.note: ☞ Forgo is the better spelling etymologically, but the word has been confused with Forego, to go before.
entry.vmorph: imp. Forewent 2; p. p. Foregone ?; 115; p. pr. & vb. n. Foregoing
entry.ety: See Forgo

sn.def: To quit; to relinquish; to leave.
sn.q: Stay at the third cup, or forego the place.

sn.def: To relinquish the enjoyment or advantage of; to give up; to resign; to renounce; -- said of a thing already enjoyed, or of one within reach, or anticipated.
sn.q: All my patrimony,, If need be, I am ready to forego.
Thy lovers must their promised heaven forego.
He] never forewent an opportunity of honest profit.

cs.cd: a conclusion which has preceded argument or examination; a predetermined conclusion.

entry.ety: AS. foregān; fore + gān to go; akin to G. vorgehen to go before, precede. See Go v. i.
entry.def: To go before; to precede; -- used especially in the present and past participles.
entry.q: Pleasing remembrance of a thought foregone.
For which the very mother's face forewent The mother's special patience.

sn.def: One who goes before another; a predecessor; hence, an ancestor; a progenitor.
A purveyor of the king; -- so called, formerly, from going before to provide for his household.

entry.ety: Etymologically forgoer
entry.def: One who forbears to enjoy.
past; -- used of time; as, foregone summers. Contrassted to present.
An inevitable outcome; a certain result; a certainty.

On a painting, and sometimes in a bas-relief, mosaic picture, or the like, that part of the scene represented, which is nearest to the spectator, and therefore occupies the lowest part of the work of art itself. Cf. Distance n., 6.
To conjecture.
The anterior part of the alimentary canal, from the mouth to the intestine, or to the entrance of the bile duct.

sn.def: All that part of a horse which is before the rider.
The chief or most important part.
Superiority; advantage; start; precedence.
sn.q: And, but for ceremony, such a wretch . . . Had the forehand and vantage of a king.

entry.def: Done beforehand; anticipative.
entry.q: And so extenuate the forehand sin.

sn.def: Early; timely; seasonable.
sn.q: Forehandedcare.

sn.def: Beforehand with one's needs, or having resources in advance of one's necessities; in easy circumstances; as, a forehanded farmer.
Formed in the forehand or fore parts.
sn.q: A substantial, true-bred beast, bravely forehanded.

sn.def: The front of that part of the head which incloses the brain; that part of the face above the eyes; the brow.
The aspect or countenance; assurance.
sn.q: To look with forehead bold and big enough Upon the power and puissance of the king.

sn.def: The front or fore part of anything.
sn.q: Flames in the forehead of the morning sky.
So rich advantage of a promised glory As smiles upon the forehead of this action.

entry.def: To hear beforehand.
The forward extension of the hearth of a blast furnace under the tymp.
See Forhend.
To hew or cut in front.
The forward part of the hold of a ship.
Ominous foreboding; superstitious prognostication.
A piece of timber placed across the stem, to unite the bows and strengthen the fore part of the ship; a breast hook.

cs.cd: a process by which the property of a foreign or absent debtor is attached for the satisfaction of a debt due from him to the plaintiff; an attachment of the goods, effects, or credits of a debtor in the hands of a third person; -- called in some States trustee, in others factorizing, and in others garnishee process.

a bill drawn in one country, and payable in another, as distinguished from an inland bill, which is one drawn and payable in the same country. In this latter, as well as in several other points of view, the different States of the United States are foreign to each other. See Exchange n., 4.
a substance occurring in any part of the body where it does not belong, and usually introduced from without.
that department of the government of Great Britain which has charge British interests in foreign countries.

entry.ety: OE. forein, F. forain, LL. foraneus, fr. L. foras foris, out of doors, abroad, without; akin to fores doors, and E. door. See Door, and cf. Foreclose Forfeit Forest Forum

sn.def: Outside; extraneous; separated; alien; as, a foreign country; a foreign government.
sn.q: Foreignworlds.

sn.def: Not native or belonging to a certain country; born in or belonging to another country, nation, sovereignty, or locality; as, a foreign language; foreign fruits.
sn.q: Domestic andforeignwriters.
Hail, foreign wonder! Whom certain these rough shades did never breed.

sn.def: Remote; distant; strange; not belonging; not connected; not pertaining or pertient; not appropriate; not harmonious; not agreeable; not congenial; -- with to or from; as, foreign to the purpose; foreign to one's nature.
sn.q: This design is not foreign from some people's thoughts.

sn.def: Held at a distance; excluded; exiled.
sn.q: Kept him a foreign man still; which so grieved him, That he ran mad and died.
sn.syn: Outlandish; alien; exotic; remote; distant; extraneous; extrinsic.

entry.def: born in another area or country than that lived in; -- of persons.
A person belonging to or owning allegiance to a foreign country; one not native in the country or jurisdiction under consideration, or not naturalized there; an alien; a stranger.
entry.q: Joy is such a foreigner, So mere a stranger to my thoughts.
Nor could the majesty of the English crown appear in a greater luster, either to foreigners or subjects.

entry.def: Anything peculiar to a foreign language or people; a foreign idiom or custom.
entry.q: It is a pity to see the technicalities of the so-called liberal professions distigured by foreignisms.

entry.def: The quality of being foreign; remoteness; want of relation or appropriateness.
entry.q: Let not the foreignness of the subject hinder you from endeavoring to set me right.
A foreignness of complexion.

entry.def: Foreign.

entry.ety: Fore + judge
entry.def: To judge beforehand, or before hearing the facts and proof; to prejudge.

entry.ety: For forjudge, fr. F. forjuger; OF. fors outside, except + F. juger to judge
entry.def: To expel from court for some offense or misconduct, as an attorney or officer; to deprive or put out of a thing by the judgment of a court.
A judgment by which one is deprived or put out of a right or thing in question.
Prejudgment.

entry.vmorph: imp. Foreknew; p. p. Foreknown; p. pr. & vb. n. Foreknowing
entry.def: To have previous knowledge of; to know beforehand.
entry.q: Who would the miseries of man foreknow?

entry.def: That may be foreknown.
One who foreknows.
With foreknowledge.
entry.q: He who . . . foreknowingly loses his life.

entry.def: Knowledge of a thing before it happens, or of whatever is to happen; prescience.
entry.q: If I foreknew,Foreknowledge had no influence on their fault.

entry.ety: OE. forelcase, sheath, OF. forel fourel, F. fourreau, LL. forellus, fr. OF. forre fuerre, sheath, case, of German origin; cf. OHG. fuotar, akin to Goth. fōdr; prob. not the same word as E. fodder food. Cf. Fur Fodder food
entry.def: A kind of parchment for book covers. See Forrill.
To bind with a forel.

sn.def: A promontory or cape; a headland; as, the North and South Foreland in Kent, England.
A piece of ground between the wall of a place and the moat.
That portion of the natural shore on the outside of the embankment which receives the stock of waves and deadens their force.
To lay down beforehand.
sn.q: These grounds being forelaid and understood.

sn.def: To waylay. See Forlay.

entry.def: One who leads others by his example; a guide.
See Forlend.
entry.q: As if that life to losse they had forelent.

entry.def: See Forlet.
To lie in front of.
entry.q: Which forelay Athwart her snowy breast.

entry.def: To lift up in front.

cs.cd: a bolt retained by a key, gib, or cotter passing through a slot.
a winch or whirl by which a bunch of three yarns is twisted into a standard.
cs.mcol: To take time by the forelockorTo take occasion by the forelock
cs.cd: to make prompt use of anything; not to let slip an opportunity.

sn.def: The lock of hair that grows from the forepart of the head.
A cotter or split pin, as in a slot in a bolt, to prevent retraction; a linchpin; a pin fastening the cap-square of a gun.
sn.q: Time is painted with a lock before and bald behind, signifying thereby that we must take time by the forelock; for when it is once past, there is no recalling it.
On occasion's forelock watchful wait.

entry.def: To look beforehand or forward.

entries.entry: Fore"man n.; pl.Foremen. The first or chief man; as: The chief man of a jury, who acts as their speaker. The chief of a set of hands employed in a shop, or on works of any kind, who superintends the rest; an overseer.

entry.def: The position of a foreman.

cs.cd: a common sailor; also, a man stationed to attend to the gear of the foremast.

entry.def: The mast nearest the bow.
Intended beforehand; premeditated.
Mentioned before; already cited; aforementioned.
The milk secreted just before, or directly after, the birth of a child or of the young of an animal; colostrum.

entry.ety: OE. formest first, AS. formest fyrmest, superl. of forma first, which is a superl. fr. fore fore; cf. Goth. frumist fruma, first. See Fore adv., and cf. First Former Frame v. t. Prime a.
entry.def: First in time or place; most advanced; chief in rank or dignity; as, the foremost troops of an army.
entry.q: THat struck the foremost man of all this world.

entry.def: In the foremost place or order; among the foremost.
A female ancestor.
A name that precedes the family name or surname; a first name.
To name or mention before.
Named before; aforenamed.

entry.ety: Hung., lit., House of Lords
entry.def: See Legislature.

entry.ety: See Fore, and Anent
entry.def: Over against; opposite to.
entry.q: The land forenenst the Greekish shore.

entry.def: The evening between twilight and bedtime.
The early part of the day, from morning to meridian, or noon.
Notice or information of an event before it happens; forewarning.
Forensic.

cs.cd: medical jurisprudence; medicine in its relations to law.

entry.ety: L. forensis, fr. forum a public place, market place. See Forum
entry.def: Belonging to courts of judicature or to public discussion and debate; used in legal proceedings, or in public discussions; argumentative; rhetorical; as, forensic eloquence or disputes.
An exercise in debate; a forensic contest; an argumentative thesis.
Forensic.
To ordain or appoint beforehand; to preordain; to predestinate; to predetermine.
To foreordain.
Previous ordination or appointment; predetermination; predestination.
The part most advanced, or first in time or in place; the beginning.
Bygone.

sn.def: Holding or held formerly in possession.
Preoccupied; prepossessed; preëngaged.
sn.q: Not extremely forepossessed with prejudice.

entry.def: To prize or rate beforehand.
Promised beforehand; preëngaged.
Cited before; quoted in a foregoing part of the treatise or essay.
imp. of Forerun.
The first rank; the front.
To advance or gain upon; -- said of a vessel that gains upon another when sailing closehauled.
To shoot ahead, especially when going in stays.
To tell beforehand; to signify by tokens; to predestine.
Named or recited before.
entry.q: Theforerecitedpractices.

entry.def: Called to mind previously.
Ready; directly forward; going before.
entry.q: Aforerightwind.

entry.def: Right forward; onward.

sn.def: To turn before; to precede; to be in advance of (something following).
To come before as an earnest of something to follow; to introduce as a harbinger; to announce.
sn.q: These signs forerun the death or fall of kings.

sn.def: A messenger sent before to give notice of the approach of others; a harbinger; a sign foreshowing something; a prognostic; as, the forerunner of a fever.
sn.q: Whither the forerunner in for us entered, even Jesus.
My elder brothers, my forerunners, came.

sn.def: A predecessor; an ancestor.
A piece of rag terminating the log line.

entry.def: Mentioned before; aforesaid.
The sail bent to the foreyard of a square-rigged vessel, being the lowest sail on the foremast.
The gaff sail set on the foremast of a schooner.
The fore staysail of a sloop, being the triangular sail next forward of the mast.

entry.ety: AS. foresecgan; fore + secgan to say. See Say v. t.
entry.def: To foretell.
entry.q: Her danger nigh that sudden change foresaid.

entry.ety: AS. foreseón; fore + seón to see. See See v. t.

sn.def: To see beforehand; to have prescience of; to foreknow.
sn.q: A prudent man foreseeth the evil.

sn.def: To provide.
sn.q: Great shoals of people, which go on to populate, without foreseeing means of life.

entry.def: To have or exercise foresight.
being such as may reasonable be anticipated; as, foreseeable costs were well within the budget.

entries.entry: Fore*seen" conj., or (strictlyp. p. Provided; in case that; on condition that. Obs One manner of meat is most sure to every complexion, foreseen that it be alway most commonly in conformity of qualities, with the person that eateth.

entry.def: One who foresees or foreknows.
To seize beforehand.
To shadow or typi�y beforehand; to prefigure.
See Foreshow.
The fore part of a ship.
the part of the seashore between the high-water and and low-water marks.

sn.def: To represent on a plane surface, as if extended in a direction toward the spectator or nearly so; to shorten by drawing in perspective.
Fig.: To represent pictorially to the imagination.
sn.q: Songs, and deeds, and lives that lieForeshortened in the tract of time.

entry.def: Representation in a foreshortened mode or way.
In distillation of low wines, the first portion of spirit that comes over, being a fluid abounding in fusel oil.

entry.ety: AS. foresceáwian to foresee, provide; fore + sceáwian to see. See Show v. t.
entry.def: To show or exhibit beforehand; to give foreknowledge of; to prognosticate; to foretell.
entry.q: Your looks foreshow You have a gentle heart.
Next, like Aurora, Spenser rose, Whose purple blush the day foreshows.

entry.def: One who predicts.

sn.def: The front side; the front; esp., a stretch of country fronting the sea.
The outside or external covering.
The act or the power of foreseeing; prescience; foreknowledge.
Action in reference to the future; provident care; prudence; wise forethought.
sn.q: This seems an unseasonable foresight.
A random expense, without plan or foresight.

sn.def: Any sight or reading of the leveling staff, except the backsight; any sight or bearing taken by a compass or theodolite in a forward direction.
Muzzle sight. See Fore sight, under Fore a.

entry.def: Sagacious; prudent; provident for the future.
Foresighted.
To signify beforehand; to foreshow; to typify.
The fold of skin which covers the glans of the penis; the prepuce.
The front skirt of a garment, in distinction from the train.
entry.q: Honor's train Is longer than his foreskirt.

entry.def: See Forslack.
The sleeve below the elbow.

entry.ety: See Forslow
entry.def: To make slow; to hinder; to obstruct. Obs See Forslow v. t.
entry.q: No stream, no wood, no mountain could foreslow Their hasty pace.

entry.def: To loiter. Same as Forslow.
See Forspeak.
To foretell; to predict.
entry.q: My mother was half a witch; never anything that she forespake but came to pass.

entry.def: A prediction; also, a preface.
A preface.

entry.ety: Fore + spent
entry.def: Already spent; gone by; past.
See Forspent.
One who rides before; a harbinger.

entry.ety: OF. forest, F. forêt, LL. forestis, also, forestus forestum foresta, prop., open ground reserved for the chase, fr. L. foris foras, out of doors, abroad. See Foreign

sn.def: An extensive wood; a large tract of land covered with trees; in the United States, a wood of native growth, or a tract of woodland which has never been cultivated.

A large extent or precinct of country, generally waste and woody, belonging to the sovereign, set apart for the keeping of game for his use, not inclosed, but distinguished by certain limits, and protected by certain laws, courts, and officers of its own.

entry.cs: Forest fly. Zoöl One of numerous species of blood-sucking flies, of the family Tabanidæ, which attack both men and beasts. See Horse fly. A fly of the genus Hippobosca, esp. H. equina. See Horse tick. Forest glade a grassy space in a forest. Thomson. Forest laws laws for the protection of game, preservation of timber, etc., in forests. Forest tree a tree of the forest, especially a timber tree, as distinguished from a fruit tree.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a forest; sylvan.
To cover with trees or wood.
An instrument formerly used at sea for taking the altitudes of heavenly bodies, now superseded by the sextant; -- called also cross-staff.

entry.ety: Cf. F. forestage
entry.def: A duty or tribute payable to the king's foresters.
A service paid by foresters to the king.
Of or pertaining to forests; as, forestal rights.

cs.cd: to buy or contract for merchandise or provision on its way to market, with the intention of selling it again at a higher price; to dissuade persons from bringing their goods or provisions there; or to persuade them to enhance the price when there. This was an offense at law in England until 1844.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forestalled; p. pr. & vb. n. Forestalling
entry.ety: OE. forstallen to stop, to obstruct; to stop (goods) on the way to the market by buying them beforehand, from forstal obstruction, AS. forsteal foresteall, prop., a placing one's self before another. See Fore, and Stall

sn.def: To take beforehand, or in advance; to anticipate.
sn.q: What need a man forestall his date of grief, And run to meet what he would most avoid?

sn.def: To take possession of, in advance of some one or something else, to the exclusion or detriment of the latter; to get ahead of; to preoccupy; also, to exclude, hinder, or prevent, by prior occupation, or by measures taken in advance.
sn.q: An ugly serpent which forestalled their way.
But evermore those damsels did forestall Their furious encounter.
To be forestalled ere we come to fall.
Habit is a forestalled and obstinate judge.

sn.def: To deprive; -- with of.
sn.q: All the better; may This night forestall him of the coming day!

sn.def: To obstruct or stop up, as a way; to stop the passage of on highway; to intercept on the road, as goods on the way to market.

entry.def: One who forestalls; esp., one who forestalls the market.
A large, strong rope, reaching from the foremast head to the bowsprit, to support the mast. See Illust. under Ship.
covered with forest; as, efforts to protect forested lands of the northwest.

entry.ety: F. forestier, LL. forestarius

sn.def: One who has charge of the growing timber on an estate; an officer appointed to watch a forest and preserve the game.
An inhabitant of a forest.
A forest tree.
A lepidopterous insect belonging to Alypia and allied genera; as, the eight-spotted forester A. octomaculata), which in the larval state is injurious to the grapevine.

entry.def: Front stick of a hearth fire.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. foresterie
entry.def: The art of forming or of cultivating forests; the management of growing timber.
See Forswat.
A taste beforehand; enjoyment in advance; anticipation.

sn.def: To taste before full possession; to have previous enjoyment or experience of; to anticipate.
To taste before another.
sn.q: Foretastedfruit.

entry.def: One who tastes beforehand, or before another.
To teach beforehand.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foretold; p. pr. & vb. n. Foretelling
entry.def: To predict; to tell before occurence; to prophesy; to foreshow.
entry.q: Deeds then undone my faithful tongue foretold.
Prodigies, foretelling the future eminence and luster of his character.

entry.def: To utter predictions.
One who predicts.

sn.def: To think beforehand; to anticipate in the mind; to prognosticate.
sn.q: The soul of every man Prophetically doth forethink thy fall.

sn.def: To contrive (something) beforehend.

entry.def: To contrive beforehand.
Thought of, or planned, beforehand; aforethought; prepense; hence, deliberate.
entry.q: Forethoughtmalice.

entry.def: A thinking or planning beforehand; prescience; premeditation; forecast; provident care.
entry.q: A sphere that will demand from him forethought, courage, and wisdom.

entry.def: Having forethought.
The past; the time before the present.
entry.q: A very dimforetime.

entry.ety: AS. foretācen. See Token
entry.def: Prognostic; previous omen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foretokened; p. pr. & vb. n. Foretokening
entry.ety: AS. foretācnian; fore + tācnian
entry.def: To foreshow; to presignify; to prognosticate.
entry.q: Whilst strange prodigious signs foretoken blood.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Foretell.
One of the teeth in the forepart of the mouth; an incisor.

sn.def: The hair on the forepart of the head; esp., a tuft or lock of hair which hangs over the forehead, as of a horse.
That part of a headdress that is in front; the top of a periwig.
The platform at the head of the foremast.

entry.def: Designating the mast, sail, yard, etc., above the topmast; as, the fore-topgallant sail. See Sail.
The mast erected at the head of the foremast, and at the head of which stands the fore-topgallant mast; the mast next above the foremast. See Ship.
the topsail on a foremast. See Sail.

entry.note: ☞ In England, for and ever are usually written and printed as two separate words; but, in the United States, the general practice is to make but a single word of them.

cs.cd: an emphatic “forever.”

entry.ety: For, prep. + ever

sn.def: Through eternity; through endless ages; eternally.
At all times; always.
sn.syn: Constantly; continually; invariably; unchangeably; incessantly; always; perpetually; unceasingly; ceaselessly; interminably; everlastingly; endlessly; eternally.

entry.def: Formerly vouched or avowed; affirmed in advance.
The van; the front.
entry.q: My foreward shall be drawn out all in length, Consisting equally of horse and foot.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forewarned fōr*w�rnd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Forewarning
entry.def: To warn beforehand; to give previous warning, admonition, information, or notice to; to caution in advance.
entry.q: We were forewarned of your coming.

entry.def: See Forewaste.

entry.ety: Fore + wend
entry.def: To go before.
To wish beforehand.

sn.def: A leader, or would-be leader, in matters of knowledge or taste.
sn.q: Nor that the forewits, that would draw the rest unto their liking, always like the best.

sn.def: Foresight; prudence.
sn.q: Let this forewit guide thy thought.

entry.vmorph: pres. indic. sing., 1st & 3d pers. Forewot 2d person Forewost pl. Forewiten; imp. sing. Forewiste pl. Forewisten; p. pr. & vb. n. Forewiting
entry.ety: AS. forewitan. See Wit to know
entry.def: To foreknow.

entries.entry: Fore"wom`an n.; pl.Forewomen. A woman who is chief; a woman who has charge of the work or workers in a shop or other place; a head woman.

entry.def: A preface.

entry.ety: See Forworn
entry.def: Worn out; wasted; used up.
entry.q: Old foreworn stories almost forgotten.

entry.def: pres. indic., 1st & 3d pers. sing. of Forewite.

entry.note: See Illust. of Ship
entry.def: The lowermost yard on the foremast.
Forfeiture.

entry.ety: OE. forfet crime, penalty, F. forfait crime (LL. forefactum forifactum), prop. p. p. of forfaire to forfeit, transgress, fr. LL. forifacere, prop., to act beyond; L. foris out of doors, abroad, beyond + facere to do. See Foreign, and Fact

sn.def: Injury; wrong; mischief.
sn.q: To seek arms upon people and country that never did us any forfeit.

sn.def: A thing forfeit or forfeited; what is or may be taken from one in requital of a misdeed committed; that which is lost, or the right to which is alienated, by a crime, offense, neglect of duty, or breach of contract; hence, a fine; a mulct; a penalty; as, he who murders pays the forfeit of his life.
sn.q: Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithal Remit thy other forfeits.

sn.def: Something deposited and redeemable by a sportive fine; -- whence the game of forfeits.
sn.q: Country dances and forfeits shortened the rest of the day.

entry.ety: F. forfait, p. p. of forfaire. See Forfeit n.
entry.def: Lost or alienated for an offense or crime; liable to penal seizure.
entry.q: Thy wealth being forfeit to the state.
To tread the forfeit paradise.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forfeited; p. pr. & vb. n. Forfeiting
entry.ety: OE. forfeten. See Forfeit n.
entry.def: To lose, or lose the right to, by some error, fault, offense, or crime; to render one's self by misdeed liable to be deprived of; to alienate the right to possess, by some neglect or crime; as, to forfeit an estate by treason; to forfeit reputation by a breach of promise; -- with to before the one acquiring what is forfeited.
entry.q: They] had forfeited their property by their crimes.
Undone and forfeited to cares forever!

sn.def: To be guilty of a misdeed; to be criminal; to transgress.
To fail to keep an obligation.
sn.q: I will have the heart of him if he forfeit.

entry.def: In the condition of being forfeited; subject to alienation.
entry.q: Once more I will renew His lapsèd powers, though forfeite.

entry.def: Liable to be forfeited; subject to forfeiture.
entry.q: For the future, uses shall be subject to the statutes of mortmain, and forfeitable, like the lands themselves.

entry.def: One who incurs a penalty of forfeiture.

entry.ety: F. forfeiture, LL. forisfactura

sn.def: The act of forfeiting; the loss of some right, privilege, estate, honor, office, or effects, by an offense, crime, breach of condition, or other act.
sn.q: Under pain of foreiture of the said goods.

sn.def: That which is forfeited; a penalty; a fine or mulct.
sn.q: What should I gain By the exaction of the forfeiture?

entry.note: ☞ This is etymologically the preferable spelling.
entry.ety: Pref. for- + fend. See Forewend
entry.def: To prohibit; to forbid; to avert.
entry.q: Which peril heaven forefend!

entry.ety: See For-, and Fear
entry.def: Excessively alarmed; in great fear.
entry.q: Forferedof his death.

entry.ety: See Forfeit
entry.def: To incur a penalty; to transgress.
entry.q: And all this suffered our Lord Jesus Christ that never forfeted.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A pair of shears.

entry.ety: L. forfex forficis, shears
entry.def: Deeply forked, as the tail of certain birds.

entry.ety: L., small shears, scissors, dim. of forfex shears
entry.def: A genus of insects including the earwigs. See Earwig, 1.
A natural family of insects incliuding the typical earwigs.
To convene; to gossip; to meet accidentally.
entry.q: Within that circle he forgathered with many a fool.

entry.def: imp. of Forgive.

entry.cs:
American forge a forge for the direct production of wrought iron, differing from the old Catalan forge mainly in using finely crushed ore and working continuously. Raymond. Catalan forge. Metal See under Catalan. Forge cinder the dross or slag form a forge or bloomary.
Forge rolls Forge train
the train of rolls by which a bloom is converted into puddle bars. Forge wagon Mil a wagon fitted up for transporting a blackmith's forge and tools. Portable forge a light and compact blacksmith's forge, with bellows, etc., that may be moved from place to place.
entry.ety: F. forge, fr. L. fabrica the workshop of an artisan who works in hard materials, fr. faber artisan, smith, as adj., skillful, ingenious; cf. Gr. � soft, tender. Cf. Fabric

sn.def: A place or establishment where iron or other metals are wrought by heating and hammering; especially, a furnace, or a shop with its furnace, etc., where iron is heated and wrought; a smithy.
sn.q: In the quick forge and working house of thought.

sn.def: The works where wrought iron is produced directly from the ore, or where iron is rendered malleable by puddling and shingling; a shingling mill.
The act of beating or working iron or steel; the manufacture of metallic bodies.
sn.q: In the greater bodies the forge was easy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forged; p. pr. & vb. n. Forging
entry.ety: F. forger, OF. forgier, fr. L. fabricare fabricari, to form, frame, fashion, from fabrica. See Forge n., and cf. Fabricate

sn.def: To form by heating and hammering; to beat into any particular shape, as a metal.
sn.q: Mars's armor forged for proof eterne.

sn.def: To form or shape out in any way; to produce; to frame; to invent.
sn.q: Those names that the schools forged, and put into the mouth of scholars, could never get admittance into common use.
Do forge a life-long trouble for ourselves.

sn.def: To coin.
To make falsely; to produce, as that which is untrue or not genuine; to fabricate; to counterfeit, as, a signature, or a signed document.
sn.q: That paltry story is untrue, And forged to cheat such gulls as you.
Forged certificates of his . . . moral character.

entry.ety: See Forge v. t., and for sense 2, cf. Forge compel

sn.def: To commit forgery.
To move heavily and slowly, as a ship after the sails are furled; to work one's way, as one ship in outsailing another; -- used especially in the phrase to forge ahead.
sn.q: And off she [a shipforged without a shock.

entry.def: To impel forward slowly; as, to forge a ship forward.

entry.note: Also used metaphorically of results requiring intense or difficult effort.

sn.def: Not genuine; counterfeit; -- used mostly of signatures and documents. See forge v. t., 4.
shaped by strong pressure in a press, or by heatng and hammering; -- of metal objects.

entries.entry: Forge"man n.; pl.Forgemen. A skilled smith, who has a hammerer to assist him.

entry.ety: Cf. F. forgeur metal worker, L. fabricator artificer. See Forge n. & v. t., and cf. Fabricator
entry.def: One who forges, makes, of forms; a fabricator; a falsifier.

sn.def: Especially: One guilty of forgery; one who makes or issues a counterfeit document.

entries.entry:
For"ger*y
Counterfeit is chiefly used of imitations of coin, or of paper money, or of securities depending upon pictorial devices and engraved designs for identity or assurance of genuineness. Forgery is more properly applied to making a false imitation of an instrument depending on signatures to show genuineness and validity. n.; pl.Forgeries #. Cf. F. forgerie
The act of forging metal into shape. Obs Useless the forgery Of brazen shield and spear.
The act of forging, fabricating, or producing falsely; esp., the crime of fraudulently making or altering a writing or signature purporting to be made by another; the false making or material alteration of or addition to a written instrument for the purpose of deceit and fraud; as, the forgery of a bond.
That which is forged, fabricated, falsely devised, or counterfeited. These are the forgeries of jealously. The writings going under the name of Aristobulus were a forgery of the second century.
Counterfeit; Forgery.

entry.cs: To forget one's self. To become unmindful of one's own personality; to be lost in thought. To be entirely unselfish. To be guilty of what is unworthy of one; to lose one's dignity, temper, or self-control.
entry.vmorph: imp. Forgot Forgat Obs.); p. p. Forgotten Forgot; p. pr. & vb. n. Forgetting
entry.ety: OE. forgeten foryeten, AS. forgietan forgitan; pref. for- + gietan gitanonly in comp.), to get; cf. D. vergeten, G. vergessen, Sw. förgäta, Dan. forgiette. See For-, and Get v. t.

sn.def: To lose the remembrance of; to let go from the memory; to cease to have in mind; not to think of; also, to lose the power of; to cease from doing.
sn.q: Bless the Lord, O my soul, and forget not all his benefits.
Let my right hand forget her cunning.
Hath thy knee forget to bow?

sn.def: To treat with inattention or disregard; to slight; to neglect.
sn.q: Can a woman forget her sucking child? . . . Yes, they may forget, yet will I not forget thee.

sn.def: Apt to forget; easily losing remembrance; as, a forgetful man should use helps to strengthen his memory.
Heedless; careless; neglectful; inattentive.
sn.q: Be not forgetful to entertain strangers.

sn.def: Causing to forget; inducing oblivion; oblivious.
sn.q: Theforgetfulwine.

entry.def: In a forgetful manner.

entry.usage: Forgetfulness is Anglo-Saxon, and oblivion is Latin. The former commonly has reference to persons, and marks a state of mind; the latter commonly has reference to things, and indicates a condition into which they are sunk. We blame a man for his forgetfulness; we speak of some old custom as buried in oblivion. But this discrimination is not strictly adhered to.

sn.def: The quality of being forgetful; prononess to let slip from the mind.
Loss of remembrance or recollection; a ceasing to remember; oblivion.
sn.q: A sweet forgetfulness of human care.

sn.def: Failure to bear in mind; careless omission; inattention; as, forgetfulness of duty.

entry.ety: From Forge
entry.def: Inventive; productive; capable.

entry.note: ☞ Formerly the name was given to the Ajuga Chamæpitus.
entry.ety: Cf. G. vergissmeinnicht
entry.def: A small perennial herb, of the genus Myosotis Myosotis scorpiodes Myosotis palustris Myosotis incespitosa, etc.), bearing a beautiful bright blue or white flowers, and extensively considered the emblem of fidelity.
Liable to be, or that may be, forgotten.
One who forgets; a heedless person.
By forgetting.

sn.def: The act of shaping metal by hammering or pressing.
The act of counterfeiting.
A piece of forged work in metal; -- a general name for a piece of hammered iron or steel.
sn.q: There are very few yards in the world at which such forgings could be turned out.

entry.def: Capable of being forgiven; pardonable; venial.

entry.note: ☞ Sometimes both the person and the offense follow as objects of the verb, sometimes one and sometimes the other being the indirect object. “Forgive us our debts as we forgive our debtors.” Matt. vi. 12. “Be of good cheer; thy sins be forgiven thee.” Matt. ix. 2.
entry.vmorph: imp. Forgave; p. p. Forgiven; p. pr. & vb. n. Forgiving
entry.ety: OE. forgiven foryiven foryeven, AS. forgiefan forgifan; perh. for- + giefan gifan to give; cf. D. vergeven, G. vergeben, Icel. fyrirgefa, Sw. f�rgifva, Goth. fragiban to give, grant. See For-, and Give v. t.

sn.def: To give wholly; to make over without reservation; to resign.
sn.q: To them that list the world's gay shows I leave, And to great ones such folly do forgive.

sn.def: To give up resentment or claim to requital on account of (an offense or wrong); to remit the penalty of; to pardon; -- said in reference to the act forgiven.
sn.q: And their sins should be forgiven them.
He forgive injures so readily that he might be said to invite them.

sn.def: To cease to feel resentment against, on account of wrong committed; to give up claim to requital from or retribution upon (an offender); to absolve; to pardon; -- said of the person offending.
sn.q: Father, forgive them; for they know not what they do.
I as free forgive you, as I would be fforgiven.

entry.usage: Forgiveness Pardon. Forgiveness is Anglo-Saxon, and pardon Norman French, both implying a giving back. The word pardon, being early used in our Bible, has, in religious matters, the same sense as forgiveness; but in the language of common life there is a difference between them, such as we often find between corresponding Anglo-Saxon and Norman words. Forgive points to inward feeling, and suppose alienated affection; when we ask forgiveness, we primarily seek the removal of anger. Pardon looks more to outward things or consequences, and is often applied to trifling matters, as when we beg pardon for interrupting a man, or for jostling him in a crowd. The civil magistrate also grants a pardon, and not forgiveness. The two words are, therefore, very clearly distinguished from each other in most cases which relate to the common concerns of life.
entry.ety: AS. forgifnes

sn.def: The act of forgiving; the state of being forgiven; as, the forgiveness of sin or of injuries.
sn.q: To the Lord our God belong mercies and forgivenesses.
In whom we have . . . the forgiveness of sin.

sn.def: Disposition to pardon; willingness to forgive.
sn.q: If thou, Lord, shouldest mark iniquities, O Lord, who shall stand? But there is forgiveness with thee, that thou mayest be feared.

entry.def: One who forgives.
Disposed to forgive; inclined to overlook offenses; mild; merciful; compassionate; placable; as, a forgiving temper.
a tendency to be kind and forgiving.

entry.note: ☞ This word in spelling has been confused with, and almost superseded by, forego to go before. Etymologically the form forgo is correct.
entry.vmorph: imp. Forwent; p. p. Forgone; p. pr. & vb. n. Forgoing
entry.ety: OE. forgan forgon forgoon, AS. forgān, prop., to go past, hence, to abstain from; pref. for- + gān to go; akin to G. vergehen to pass away, to transgress. See Go v. i.

sn.def: To pass by; to leave. See 1st Forego.
sn.q: For sith [since] I shall forgoon my liberty At your request.
And four [days] since Florimell the court forwent.

sn.def: to abstain from; to do without; to refrain from; to renounce; -- said of a thing already enjoyed, or of one within reach, or anticipated. See 1st forego, 2.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Forget.
p. p. of Forget.

entry.ety: Pref. for- + hale to draw
entry.def: To harass; to torment; to distress.
To seize upon.

entry.ety: L. forinsecus from without
entry.def: Foreign; alien.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forisfamiliated; p. pr. & vb. n. Forisfamiliating
entry.ety: LL. forisfamiliatus, p. p. of forisfamiliater to forisfamiliate; L. foris abroad, without + familia family
entry.def: Literally, to put out of a family; hence, to portion off, so as to exclude further claim of inheritance; to emancipate (as a with his own consent) from paternal authority.
To renounce a legal title to a further share of paternal inheritance.
The act of forisfamiliating.

entry.cs:
Fork beam Shipbuilding a half beam to support a deck, where hatchways occur. Fork chuck Wood Turning a lathe center having two prongs for driving the work. Fork head. The barbed head of an arrow. The forked end of a rod which forms part of a knuckle joint. In fork. Mining A mine is said to be in fork, or an engine to “have the water in fork,” when all the water is drawn out of the mine. Ure.
The forks of a riverorThe forks of a road
the branches into which it divides, or which come together to form it; the place where separation or union takes place.
entry.ety: AS. forc, fr. L. furca. Cf. Fourché Furcate

sn.def: An instrument consisting of a handle with a shank terminating in two or more prongs or tines, which are usually of metal, parallel and slightly curved; -- used for piercing, holding, taking up, or pitching anything.
Anything furcate or like a fork in shape, or furcate at the extremity; as, a tuning fork .
One of the parts into which anything is furcated or divided; a prong; a branch of a stream, a road, etc.; a barbed point, as of an arrow.
sn.q: Let it fall . . . though the fork invade The region of my heart.
A thunderbolt with three forks.

sn.def: The place where a division or a union occurs; the angle or opening between two branches or limbs; as, the fork of a river, a tree, or a road.
The gibbet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forked; p. pr. & vb. n. Forking

sn.def: To shoot into blades, as corn.
sn.q: The corn beginneth to fork.

sn.def: To divide into two or more branches; as, a road, a tree, or a stream forks .

cs.cd: to hand or pay over, as money; to cough up.

entry.def: To raise, or pitch with a fork, as hay; to dig or turn over with a fork, as the soil.
entry.q: Forking the sheaves on the high-laden cart.

entry.def: A European fish (Raniceps raninus), having a large flat head; -- also called tadpole fish, and lesser forked beard.
The European forked hake or hake's-dame (Phycis blennoides); -- also called great forked beard.

cs.cd: a cross, the ends of whose arms are divided into two sharp points; -- called also cross double fitché. A cross forked of three points is a cross, each of whose arms terminates in three sharp points.
advice pointing more than one way; ambiguous advice.

sn.def: Formed into a forklike shape; having a fork; dividing into two or more prongs or branches; furcated; bifurcated; zigzag; as, the forked lighting.
sn.q: A serpent seen, with forked tongue.

sn.def: Having a double meaning; ambiguous; equivocal.

entry.def: See Forcarve v. t.
The quality or state or dividing in a forklike manner.
Having no fork.
One of several Asiatic and East Indian passerine birds, belonging to Enucurus, and allied genera. The tail is deeply forked.
A salmon in its fourth year's growth.

cs.cd: a tropical American flycatcher (Milvulus tyrannus).
a gull of the genus Xema, of two species, esp. X. Sabinii of the Arctic Ocean.
a graceful American kite (Elanoides forficatus); -- called also swallow-tailed kite.

entry.def: Having the outer tail feathers longer than the median ones; swallow-tailed; -- said of many birds.
Opening into two or more parts or shoots; forked; furcated.
entry.q: Forkytongues.

entry.def: p. p. of Forleave.

entry.ety: Pref. for- + lay
entry.def: To lie in wait for; to ambush.
entry.q: An ambushed thief forlays a traveler.

entry.ety: OE. forleven; pref. for- + leven to leave
entry.def: To leave off wholly.
To give up wholly.

entry.ety: OE. forlesen. See Forlorn
entry.def: To lose utterly.

entry.ety: OE. forleten, AS. forlǣtan; pref. for- + lǣtan to allow; akin to G. verlassen to leave. See Let to allow
entry.def: To give up; to leave; to abandon.
entry.q: Toforletsin.

entry.def: See Forelie.
imp. pl. & p. p. of Forlese.
entry.q: The beasts their caves, the birds their nests forlore.

cs.ety: D. verloren hoop, prop., a lost band or troop; verloren, p. p. of verliezen to lose + hoop band; akin to E. heap. See For-, and Heap
cs.cd: a body of men (called in F. enfants perdus, in G. verlornen posten) selected, usually from volunteers, to attempt a breach, scale the wall of a fortress, or perform other extraordinarily perilous service; also, a desperate case or enterprise.

entry.ety: OE., p. p. of forlesen to lose utterly, AS. forleósanp. p. forloren); pref. for- + leósanin comp.) to lose; cf. D. verliezen to lose, G. verlieren, Sw. förlora, Dan. forloren, Goth. fraliusan to lose. See For-, and Lorn a. Lose v. t.

sn.def: Deserted; abandoned; lost.
sn.q: Of fortune and of hope at once forlorn.
Some say that ravens foster forlorn children.

sn.def: Destitute; helpless; in pitiful plight; wretched; miserable; almost hopeless; desperate.
sn.q: For here forlorn and lost I tread.
The condition of the besieged in the mean time was forlorn in the extreme.
She cherished the forlorn hope that he was still living.
sn.syn: Destitute, lost; abandoned; forsaken; solitary; helpless; friendless; hopeless; abject; wretched; miserable; pitiable.

sn.def: A lost, forsaken, or solitary person.
sn.q: Forced to live in Scotland a forlorn.

sn.def: A forlorn hope; a vanguard.
sn.q: Our forlorn of horse marched within a mile of the enemy.

entry.def: In a forlorn manner.
State of being forlorn.
Same as Forlie.

entries.entry:
-form. See Form n.
A suffix used to denote in the form or shape of resembling, etc.; as, valiform; oviform .

cs.cd: the general appearance, condition or action, originally of horses, afterwards of persons; as, the members of a boat crew are said to be in good form when they pull together uniformly. The phrases are further used colloquially in description of conduct or manners in society; as, it is not good form to smoke in the presence of a lady.

entry.pr: fōrm; in senses 8 & 9, often fōrm in England
entry.ety: OE. & F. forme, fr. L. forma; cf. Skr. dhariman. Cf. Firm

sn.def: The shape and structure of anything, as distinguished from the material of which it is composed; particular disposition or arrangement of matter, giving it individuality or distinctive character; configuration; figure; external appearance.
sn.q: The form of his visage was changed.
And woven close close, both matter, form, and style.

sn.def: Constitution; mode of construction, organization, etc.; system; as, a republican form of government.
Established method of expression or practice; fixed way of proceeding; conventional or stated scheme; formula; as, a form of prayer.
sn.q: Those whom form of laws Condemned to die.

sn.def: Show without substance; empty, outside appearance; vain, trivial, or conventional ceremony; conventionality; formality; as, a matter of mere form .
sn.q: Though well we may not pass upon his life Without the form of justice.

sn.def: Orderly arrangement; shapeliness; also, comeliness; elegance; beauty.
sn.q: The earth was without form and void.
He hath no form nor comeliness.

sn.def: A shape; an image; a phantom.
That by which shape is given or determined; mold; pattern; model.
A long seat; a bench; hence, a rank of students in a school; a class; also, a class or rank in society.
sn.q: Ladies of a highform.

sn.def: The seat or bed of a hare.
sn.q: As in a form sitteth a weary hare.

sn.def: The type or other matter from which an impression is to be taken, arranged and secured in a chase.
The boundary line of a material object. In painting, more generally, the human body.
The particular shape or structure of a word or part of speech; as, participial forms; verbal forms.
The combination of planes included under a general crystallographic symbol. It is not necessarily a closed solid.

That assemblage or disposition of qualities which makes a conception, or that internal constitution which makes an existing thing to be what it is; -- called essential or substantial form, and contradistinguished from matter; hence, active or formative nature; law of being or activity; subjectively viewed, an idea; objectively, a law.

Mode of acting or manifestation to the senses, or the intellect; as, water assumes the form of ice or snow. In modern usage, the elements of a conception furnished by the mind's own activity, as contrasted with its object or condition, which is called the matter; subjectively, a mode of apprehension or belief conceived as dependent on the constitution of the mind; objectively, universal and necessary accompaniments or elements of every object known or thought of.
The peculiar characteristics of an organism as a type of others; also, the structure of the parts of an animal or plant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Formed fôrmd; p. pr. & vb. n. Forming
entry.ety: F. former, L. formare, fr. forma. See Form n.

sn.def: To give form or shape to; to frame; to construct; to make; to fashion.
sn.q: God formed man of the dust of the ground.
The thought that labors in my forming brain.

sn.def: To give a particular shape to; to shape, mold, or fashion into a certain state or condition; to arrange; to adjust; also, to model by instruction and discipline; to mold by influence, etc.; to train.
sn.q: 'T is education forms the common mind.
Thus formed for speed, he challenges the wind.

sn.def: To go to make up; to act as constituent of; to be the essential or constitutive elements of; to answer for; to make the shape of; -- said of that out of which anything is formed or constituted, in whole or in part.
sn.q: The diplomatic politicians . . . who formed by far the majority.

sn.def: To provide with a form, as a hare. See Form n., 9.
sn.q: The melancholy hare is formed in brakes and briers.

sn.def: To derive by grammatical rules, as by adding the proper suffixes and affixes.

To treat (plates) so as to bring them to fit condition for introduction into a storage battery, causing one plate to be composed more or less of spongy lead, and the other of lead peroxide. This was formerly done by repeated slow alternations of the charging current, but now the plates or grids are coated or filled, one with a paste of red lead and the other with litharge, introduced into the cell, and formed by a direct charging current.

cs.cd: to form a lengthened line with reference to (any given object) as a basis.

sn.def: To take a form, definite shape, or arrangement; as, the infantry should form in column.
To run to a form, as a hare.

entry.ety: L. formic + alcohol
entry.def: See Methylal.

entry.cs: Formal cause. See under Cause.
entry.usage: Formal Ceremonious. When applied to things, these words usually denote a mere accordance with the rules of form or ceremony; as, to make a formal call; to take a ceremonious leave. When applied to a person or his manners, they are used in a bad sense; a person being called formal who shapes himself too much by some pattern or set form, and ceremonious when he lays too much stress on the conventional laws of social intercourse. Formal manners render a man stiff or ridiculous; a ceremonious carriage puts a stop to the ease and freedom of social intercourse.
entry.ety: L. formalis: cf. F. formel

sn.def: Belonging to the form, shape, frame, external appearance, or organization of a thing.

Belonging to the constitution of a thing, as distinguished from the matter composing it; having the power of making a thing what it is; constituent; essential; pertaining to or depending on the forms, so called, of the human intellect.
sn.q: Of [the sounds represented by] letters, the material part is breath and voice; the formal is constituted by the motion and figure of the organs of speech.

sn.def: Done in due form, or with solemnity; according to regular method; not incidental, sudden or irregular; express; as, he gave his formal consent.
sn.q: His obscure funeral . . . No noble rite nor formal ostentation.

sn.def: Devoted to, or done in accordance with, forms or rules; punctilious; regular; orderly; methodical; of a prescribed form; exact; prim; stiff; ceremonious; as, a man formal in his dress, his gait, his conversation.
sn.q: A cold-looking, formal garden, cut into angles and rhomboids.
She took off the formal cap that confined her hair.

sn.def: Having the form or appearance without the substance or essence; external; as, formal duty; formal worship; formal courtesy, etc.
Dependent in form; conventional.
sn.q: Still in constraint your suffering sex remains, Or bound in formal or in real chains.

sn.def: Sound; normal.
sn.q: To make of him a formal man again.
sn.syn: Precise; punctilious; stiff; starched; affected; ritual; ceremonial; external; outward.

entry.ety: Formic + aldehyde
entry.def: A colorless, volatile liquid, H2CO, resembling acetic or ethyl aldehyde, and chemically intermediate between methyl alcohol and formic acid.

entry.ety: Formic + aldehyde + -in
entry.def: An aqueous solution of formaldehyde, used as a preservative in museums and as a disinfectant.
The practice or the doctrine of strict adherence to, or dependence on, external forms, esp. in matters of religion.
entry.q: Official formalism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. formaliste
entry.def: One overattentive to forms, or too much confined to them; esp., one who rests in external religious forms, or observes strictly the outward forms of worship, without possessing the life and spirit of religion.
entry.q: As far a formalist from wisdom sits, In judging eyes, as libertines from wits.

entries.entry:
For*mal"i*ty n.; pl.Formalities #. Cf. F. formalité
The condition or quality of being formal, strictly ceremonious, precise, etc.
Form without substance. Such [books] as are mere pieces of formality, so that if you look on them, you look though them.
Compliance with formal or conventional rules; ceremony; conventionality. Nor was his attendance on divine offices a matter of formality and custom, but of conscience.
An established order; conventional rule of procedure; usual method; habitual mode. He was installed with all the usual formalities.
pl. The dress prescribed for any body of men, academical, municipal, or sacerdotal. Obs The doctors attending her in their formalities as far as Shotover.
That which is formal; the formal part. It unties the inward knot of marriage, . . . while it aims to keep fast the outward formality.
The quality which makes a thing what it is; essence. The material part of the evil came from our father upon us, but the formality of it, the sting and the curse, is only by ourselves. The formality of the vow lies in the promise made to God.
Scholastic. Philos The manner in which a thing is conceived or constituted by an act of human thinking; the result of such an act; as, animality and rationality are formalities .

entry.def: a set of procedures required to make a transaction official.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Formalized fôrm"�l*īzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Formalizing fôrm"�l*ī`zĭng

sn.def: To give form, or a certain form, to; to model.
To render formal.

entry.def: To affect formality.

sn.def: concerned with or characterized by rigorous adherence to recognized forms, especially in religion or art; using formalism; as, highly formalized plays like "Waiting for Godot".
given formal standing or endorsement; made official or legitimate by the observance of proper procedures.
sn.conseq: official (vs. unofficial) --- (having official authority or sanction: "official permission"; "an official representative")

entry.def: In a formal manner; essentially; characteristically; expressly; regularly; ceremoniously; precisely.
entry.q: That which formally makes this [charity] a Christian grace, is the spring from which it flows.
You and your followers do stand formally divided against the authorized guides of the church and rest of the people.

entry.def: attire to wear on formal occasions in the evening.

entry.ety: F. or G. Cf. Formation

sn.def: The shape and size of a book or other printed publication; hence, its external form.
sn.q: The older manuscripts had been written in a much larger format than that found convenient for university work.
One might, indeed, protest that the format is a little too luxurious.

sn.def: the arrangement of the parts of a printed page, such as text and graphics; as, text flowing around an illustration provides a more pleasing format; multiple columns are a more common format for large pages.

The pattern of organization of information in an electronic storage medium, such as the number and size of records, or the size, spacing, or separation symbols for fields in a record. A computer file, for example, may be in fixed-length format, in which each field or record occupies the same number of bytes, or in variable-length format, in which the lengths of fields or records varies. The number of formats are unlimited, being specifiable at will by programmers or in some cases by the users of programs.
The general organization, form, or plan for anything, such as an organized social, political, or entertainment event.

entry.def: to set into a specific format; -- of printed matter or data recorded on a data soorage medium.

entry.ety: See Formic
entry.def: A salt of formic acid.

entry.ety: L. formatio: cf. F. formation

sn.def: The act of giving form or shape to anything; a forming; a shaping.
The manner in which a thing is formed; structure; construction; conformation; form; as, the peculiar formation of the heart.
A substance formed or deposited.

sd.def: Mineral deposits and rock masses designated with reference to their origin; as, the siliceous formation about geysers; alluvial formations; marine formations.
A group of beds of the same age or period; as, the Eocene formation .

sn.def: The arrangement of a body of troops, as in a square, column, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. F. formatif

sn.def: Giving form; having the power of giving form; plastic; as, the formative arts.
sn.q: The meanest plant can not be raised without seed, by any formative residing in the soil.

sn.def: Serving to form; derivative; not radical; as, a termination merely formative .
Capable of growth and development; germinal; as, living or formative matter.

entry.def: That which serves merely to give form, and is no part of the radical, as the prefix or the termination of a word.
A word formed in accordance with some rule or usage, as from a root.
Same as Paté or Patté.

entry.ety: OE., fr. AS. forma. See Foremost
entry.def: First.
entry.q: Adam ourformefather.

cs.cd: a term employed by Beale to denote the lifeless matter of a cell, that which is physiologically dead, in distinction from the truly germinal or living matter.

sn.def: Arranged, as stars in a constellation; as, formed stars.
Having structure; capable of growth and development; organized; as, the formed or organized ferments. See Ferment n.

entry.ety: OF., fr. Latin. So called because the plaintiff claimed “by the form of the gift,: L. per formam doni
entry.def: A writ of right for a tenant in tail in case of a discontinuance of the estate tail. This writ has been abolished.

entry.ety: Dim. of F. forme the female of a bird of prey
entry.def: The female of a hawk or falcon.

sn.def: One who forms; a maker; a creator.

sd.def: A shape around which an article is to be shaped, molded, woven wrapped, pasted, or otherwise constructed.
A templet, pattern, or gauge by which an article is shaped.
A cutting die.

entry.ety: A compar. due to OE. formest. See Foremost

sn.def: Preceding in order of time; antecedent; previous; prior; earlier; hence, ancient; long past.
sn.q: For inquire, I pray thee, of the former age.
The latter and former rain.

sn.def: Near the beginning; preceeding; as, the former part of a discourse or argument.
Earlier, as between two things mentioned together; first mentioned.
sn.q: A bad author deserves better usage than a bad critic; a man may be the former merely through the misfortune of an ill judgment; but he can not be latter without both that and an ill temper.
sn.syn: Prior; previous; anterior; antecedent; preceding; foregoing.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: One of the half ribs against the walls in a ceiling vaulted with ribs.
In time past, either in time immediately preceding or at any indefinite distance; of old; heretofore.
Creative; imaginative.
entry.q: Theformfulbrain.

cs.cd: carbamic acid.

a colorless, mobile liquid, HCO.OH, of a sharp, acid taste, occurring naturally in ants, nettles, pine needles, etc., and produced artifically in many ways, as by the oxidation of methyl alcohol, by the reduction of carbonic acid or the destructive distillation of oxalic acid. It is the first member of the fatty acids in the paraffin series, and is homologous with acetic acid.

entry.ety: L. formica an ant: cf. F. formique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, ants; as, formic acid; in an extended sense, pertaining to, or derived from, formic acid; as, formic ether.

entry.ety: L., an ant
entry.def: A Linnæan genus of hymenopterous insects, including the common ants. See Ant.

entry.ety: a trademark
entry.def: A thermosetting plastic material composed of melamine resin, having good heat and chemical resistance, and commonly used as the surface layer in laminated sheets employed as coverings for counter tops, walls, or furniture.

entry.ety: NL. Formicarius, the typical genus + -oid
entry.def: Like or pertaining to the family Formicaridæ or ant thrushes.

entry.ety: LL. formicarium, fr. L. formica an ant
entry.def: The nest or dwelling of a swarm of ants; an ant-hill.

entry.ety: L. formica an ant
entry.def: Resembling, or pertaining to, an ant or ants.

entry.ety: See Formication
entry.def: To creep or crawl like ants; swarm with, or as with, ants.
entry.q: An open space which formicated with peasantry.

entry.ety: L. formicatio, fr. formicare to creep like an ant, to feel as if ants were crawling on one's self, fr. formica ant: cf. F. formication
entry.def: A sensation resembling that made by the creeping of ants on the skin.
Pertaining to the ants.

def2.def: One of the family Formicidæ, or ants.

entry.def: The natural family of insects comprising the ants.
Formidableness.

entry.ety: L. formidabilis, fr. formidare to fear, dread: cf. F. formidable
entry.def: Exciting fear or apprehension; impressing dread; adapted to excite fear and deter from approach, encounter, or undertaking; alarming.
entry.q: They seemed to fear the formodable sight.
I swell my preface into a volume, and make it formidable, when you see so many pages behind.
entry.syn: Dreadful; fearful; terrible; frightful; shocking; horrible; terrific; tremendous.

entry.def: The quality of being formidable, or adapted to excite dread.
In a formidable manner.

entry.ety: L. formidolosus, fr. formido fear
entry.def: Very much afraid.
The act or process of giving form or shape to anything; as, in shipbuilding, the exact shaping of partially shaped timbers.
Shapeless; without a determinate form; wanting regularity of shape.
being a matter of form only; lacking substance.

An island off the coast of China, also called Taiwan. It was occupied by Japan from 1895 to 1945, when it was returned to Chinese sovereignty. After the Communist revolution which took over the Chinese mainland in 1949, the Nationalist Chinese under Chang Kai-Shek retreated to the island of Formosa and established that island as the base of their government, being recognized for several years as the de jure possessor of the China seat in the United Nations. The capital is Taipei. As of 1998, both the Taiwan government and the mainland China government recognized Taiwan as properly a part of China, but the island is currently ruled as a de facto independent nation, though it does not possess a seat in the United Nations. The question of when and under what circumstances the island will be reunited with the mainland government is still unresolved.
of, pertaining to, or characteristic of, Formosa or the natives of Formosa; as, The native Formosan population now forms a minority on their own island..

entries.entry:
For"mu*la ☞ Chemical formulæ consist of the abbreviations of the names of the elements, with a small figure at the lower right hand, to denote the number of atoms of each element contained.
Empirical formula Chem an expression which gives the simple proportion of the constituents; as, the empirical formula of acetic acid is C2H4O2 .
Graphic formula Rational formula
Chem an expression of the constitution, and in a limited sense of the structure, of a compound, by the grouping of its atoms or radicals; as, a rational formula of acetic acid is CH3.(C:O).OH ; -- called also structural formula constitutional formula, etc. See also the formula of Benzene nucleus, under Benzene. Molecular formula Chem a formula indicating the supposed molecular constitution of a compound.
n.; pl. E. Formulas #, L. Formulæ #. L., dim. of forma form, model. SeeForm n.
A prescribed or set form; an established rule; a fixed or conventional method in which anything is to be done, arranged, or said.
Eccl A written confession of faith; a formal statement of foctrines.
Math A rule or principle expressed in algebraic language; as, the binominal formula .
Med A prescription or recipe for the preparation of a medicinal compound.
Chem A symbolic expression (by means of letters, figures, etc.) of the constituents or constitution of a compound.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or exhibiting, formularization.
The act of formularizing; a formularized or formulated statement or exhibition.
To reduce to a forula; to formulate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. formulaire. See Formula
entry.def: Stated; prescribed; ritual.

For"mu*la*ry n.; pl.Formularies #. Cf. F. formulaire
A book containing stated and prescribed forms, as of oaths, declarations, prayers, medical formulaæ, etc.; a book of precedents.
Prescribed form or model; formula.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Formulated; p. pr. & vb. n. Formulating

reduced to a systematic form; reduced to a formula.
The act, process, or result of formulating or reducing to a formula.

The act or process of reducing to a formula; the state of being formulized.

Formerly, the radical methyl, CH3.

sn.def: Vaulted like an oven or furnace; arched.
Arching over; overarched.

entry.ety: L. fornicatus p. p. of fornicari to fornicate, fr. fornix -icis, a vault, a brothel in an underground vault
entry.def: To commit fornication; to have unlawful sexual intercourse.

entry.note: ☞ In England, the offense, though cognizable in the ecclesiastical courts, was not at common law subject to secular prosecution. In the United States it is indictable in some States at common law, in others only by statute.
entry.ety: F. fornication, L. fornicatio

sn.def: Unlawful sexual intercourse on the part of an unmarried person; the act of such illicit sexual intercourse between a man and a woman as does not by law amount to adultery.

sd.def: Adultery.
Incest.
Idolatry.

entry.ety: F. fornicateur, OF. fornicator, from L. fornicator

entries.entry:
‖For"nix n.; pl.Fornices #. L., an arch Anat An arch or fold; as, the fornix, or vault, of the cranium; the fornix, or reflection, of the conjuctiva.
Esp., two longitudinal bands of white nervous tissue beneath the lateral ventricles of the brain.

entry.def: Very old.

entry.def: To pass by or along; to pass over.
To waste away completely by suffering or torment.
entry.q: Pale as aforpinedghost.

entry.ety: OE. forrayen. See Foray

entry.vmorph: imp. Forsook; p. p. Forsaken; p. pr. & vb. n. Forsaking

sn.def: To quit or leave entirely; to desert; to abandon; to depart or withdraw from; to leave; as, false friends and flatterers forsake us in adversity.
sn.q: If his children forsake my law, and walk not in my judgments.

sn.def: To renounce; to reject; to refuse.
sn.q: If you forsake the offer of their love.
sn.syn: To abandon; quit; desert; fail; relinquish; give up; renounce; reject. See Abandon.

entry.ety: Pref. for- + shape, v.t

entry.ety: Pref. for- + slack to neglect
entry.def: To neglect by idleness; to delay or to waste by sloth.

entry.ety: See For-, and Slouth
entry.def: To lose by sloth or negligence.

entry.ety: Pref. for- + slow
entry.def: To delay; to hinder; to neglect; to put off.
To loiter.

entry.ety: AS. forsōð; for, prep. + sōð sooth, truth. See For prep., and Sooth
entry.def: In truth; in fact; certainly; very well; -- formerly used as an expression of deference or respect, especially to woman; now used ironically or contemptuously.
entry.q: A fit man, forsooth, to govern a realm!
Our old English word forsooth has been changed for the French madam.

entry.def: To address respectfully with the term forsooth.
entry.q: The captain of the “Charles” had forsoothed her, though he knew her well enough and she him.

entry.def: A person who used forsooth much; a very ceremonious and deferential person.
entry.q: You sip so like a forsooth of the city.

entry.ety: Pref. for- + speak

sn.def: To forbid; to prohibit.
To bewitch.

entry.def: Wasted in strength; tired; exhausted.
entry.q: A gentleman almost forspent with speed.

A forester.

entry.ety: Pref. for- + straught; cf. distraught

entry.cs: To forswear one's self to swear falsely; to perjure one's self. “Thou shalt not forswear thyself.” Matt. v. 33.

imp. of Forswear.
p. p. of Forswear.

entry.def: Loudly; strongly; powerfully.

out of. Obs Shak. To bring forth. See under Bring.

From this time forth I never will speak word.
I repeated the Ave Maria; the inquisitor bad me say forth; I said I was taught no more.

Going forth.

sn.q: Immediately there fell from his eyes as it had been scales; and he received sight forthwith.

That which fortifies; especially, a work or works erected to defend a place against attack; a fortified place; a fortress; a fort; a castle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fortified; p. pr. & vb. n. Fortifying
entry.ety: F. fortifier, L. fortificare; fortis strong + -ficarein comp.) to make. See Fort, and -fy

sn.def: To add strength to; to strengthen; to confirm; to furnish with power to resist attack.
sn.q: Timidity was fortified by pride.
Pride came to the aid of fancy, and both combined to fortify his resolution.

entry.def: To raise defensive works.

entry.def: A little fort; a blockhouse.

entry.ety: L. fortitudo, fr. fortis strong. See Fort

sn.def: Power to resist attack; strength; firmness.

sn.def: That strength or firmness of mind which enables a person to encounter danger with coolness and courage, or to bear pain or adversity without murmuring, depression, or despondency; passive courage; resolute endurance; firmness in confronting or bearing up against danger or enduring trouble.
sn.q: Extolling patience as the truest fortitude.
Fortitude is the guard and support of the other virtues.
sn.syn: Courage; resolution; resoluteness; endurance; bravery. See Courage, and Heroism.

entry.def: Having fortitude; courageous.
A little fort.

entry.ety: Contr. fr. fourteen nights, our ancestors reckoning time by nights and winters; so, also, seven nights sennight, a week
entry.def: The space of fourteen days; two weeks.
Occurring or appearing once in a fortnight; as, a fortnightly meeting of a club; a fortnightly magazine, or other publication.

def2.def: Once in a fortnight; at intervals of a fortnight.
