To tread down; to trample upon.
entry.q: In hell shall they be all fortroden of devils.

entries.entry:
For"tress A fortress is constructed for military purposes only, and is permanently garrisoned; a fortification is built to defend harbors, cities, etc.; a castle is a fortress of early times which was ordinarily a palatial dwelling; a citadel is the stronghold of a fortress or city, etc. n.; pl.Fortresses #. F. forteresse, OF. forteresce fortelesce, LL. foralitia, fr. L. fortis strong. See Fort, and cf. Fortalice
A fortified place; a large and permanent fortification, sometimes including a town; a fort; a castle; a stronghold; a place of defense or security.
Fortress Fortification Castle Citadel.

entry.def: To furnish with a fortress or with fortresses; to guard; to fortify.

entry.ety: L. fortuitus; akin to forte, adv., by chance, prop. abl. of fors fortis, chance. See Fortune

sn.def: Happening by chance; coming or occuring unexpectedly, or without any known cause; chance; as, the fortuitous concourse of atoms.
sn.q: It was from causes seemingly fortuitous . . . that all the mighty effects of the Reformation flowed.
So as to throw a glancing and fortuitous light upon the whole.

sn.def: Happening independently of human will or means of foresight; resulting from unavoidable physical causes.
sn.syn: Accidental; casual; contingent; incidental. See Accidental.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fortuité
entry.def: Accident; chance; casualty.
the goddess of fortune and good luck; counterpart of Greek Tyche.

entry.usage: Fortunate Successful Prosperous. A man is fortunate, when he is favored of fortune, and has unusual blessings fall to his lot; successful when he gains what he aims at; prosperous when he succeeds in those things which men commonly desire. One may be fortunate, in some cases, where he is not successful; he may be successful, but, if he has been mistaken in the value of what he has aimed at, he may for that reason fail to be prosperous.
entry.ety: L. fortunatus, p. p. of fortunare to make fortunate or prosperous, fr. fortuna. See Fortune n.

sn.def: Coming by good luck or favorable chance; bringing some good thing not foreseen as certain; presaging happiness; auspicious; as, a fortunate event; a fortunate concurrence of circumstances; a fortunate investment.
Receiving same unforeseen or unexpected good, or some good which was not dependent on one's own skill or efforts; favored with good forune; lucky.
sn.syn: Auspicious; lucky; prosperous; successful; favored; happy.

entry.def: In a fortunate manner; luckily; successfully; happily.
The condition or quality of being fortunate; good luck; success; happiness.

cs.cd: a book supposed to reveal future events to those who consult it.
one who seeks to acquire wealth by marriage.
one who professes to tell future events in the life of another.
the practice or art of professing to reveal future events in the life of another.

entry.ety: F. fortune, L. fortuna; akin to fors fortis, chance, prob. fr. ferre to bear, bring. See Bear to support, and cf. Fortuitous

sn.def: The arrival of something in a sudden or unexpected manner; chance; accident; luck; hap; also, the personified or deified power regarded as determining human success, apportioning happiness and unhappiness, and distributing arbitrarily or fortuitously the lots of life.
sn.q: 'T is more by fortune, lady, than by merit.
O Fortune Fortune, all men call thee fickle.

sn.def: That which befalls or is to befall one; lot in life, or event in any particular undertaking; fate; destiny; as, to tell one's fortune .
sn.q: You, who men's fortunes in their faces read.

sn.def: That which comes as the result of an undertaking or of a course of action; good or ill success; especially, favorable issue; happy event; success; prosperity as reached partly by chance and partly by effort.
sn.q: Our equal crimes shall equal fortune give.
There is a tide in the affairs of men, Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune.
His father dying, he was driven to seek his fortune.

sn.def: Wealth; large possessions; large estate; riches; as, a gentleman of fortune .

entry.ety: OF. fortuner, L. fortunare. See Fortune n.

sn.def: To make fortunate; to give either good or bad fortune to.
To provide with a fortune.
To presage; to tell the fortune of.

entry.def: To fall out; to happen.
entry.q: It fortuned the same night that a Christian, serving a Turk in the camp, secretely gave the watchmen warning.

entry.def: Luckless; also, destitute of a fortune or portion.
small genus of shrubs called kumquats, native to South China, producing small ovoid orangelike fruits called kumquats.
a person who claims to be able to foretell events in the future of another person.
To regulate the fortune of; to make happy.

entry.ety: OE. forti fourti fowerti, AS. feówertig; feówer four + suff. -tig ten; akin to OS. fiwartig fiartig, D. veertig, G. vierzig, Icel. fjörutīu, Sw. fyratio, Dan. fyrretyve, Goth. fidwōr tigjus. See Four, and Ten, and cf. Fourteen
entry.def: Four times ten; thirty-nine and one more.

entries.entry:
For"ty n.; pl.Forties -tĭz.
The sum of four tens; forty units or objects.
A symbol expressing forty units; as, 40, or xl.

entry.def: One the miners who took part in the California gold rush in 1849; an argonaut.
The Tasmanian forty-spotted diamond bird (Pardalotus quadragintus).

entries.entry:
Fo"rum n.; pl. E. Forums #, L. Fora #. L.; akin to foris foras, out of doors. See Foreign
A market place or public place in Rome, where causes were judicially tried, and orations delivered to the people.
A tribunal; a court; an assembly empowered to hear and decide causes. He [Lord Camden] was . . . more eminent in the senate than in the forum.

entry.def: Tired out with excessive waking or watching.
To wander away; to go astray; to wander far and to weariness.

entry.ety: OE., fr. AS. foreweard; fore before + weard a ward. See Ward n.
entry.def: An agreement; a covenant; a promise.
entry.q: Tell us a tale anon, as forward is.

entry.ety: AS. forweard foreweard; for fore + -weardes; akin to G. vorwärts. The s is properly a genitive ending. See For Fore, and -ward -wards
entry.def: Toward a part or place before or in front; onward; in advance; progressively; -- opposed to backward.

sn.def: Near, or at the fore part; in advance of something else; as, the forward gun in a ship, or the forward ship in a fleet.
Ready; prompt; strongly inclined; in an ill sense, overready; too hasty.
sn.q: Only they would that we should remember the poor; the same which I also was forward to do.
Nor do we find him forward to be sounded.

sn.def: Ardent; eager; earnest; in an ill sense, less reserved or modest than is proper; bold; confident; as, the boy is too forward for his years.
sn.q: I have known men disagreeably forward from their shyness.

sn.def: Advanced beyond the usual degree; advanced for the season; as, the grass is forward, or forward for the season; we have a forward spring.
sn.q: The most forward bud Is eaten by the canker ere it blow.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Forwarded; p. pr. & vb. n. Forwarding

sn.def: To help onward; to advance; to promote; to accelerate; to quicken; to hasten; as, to forward the growth of a plant; to forward one in improvement.
To send forward; to send toward the place of destination; to transmit; as, to forward a letter.
One who forwards or promotes; a promoter.
One who sends forward anything;
one who transmits goods; a forwarding merchant, such as a freight forwarder .
One employed in forwarding.
The act of one who forwards; the act or occupation of transmitting merchandise or other property for others.
The process of putting a book into its cover, and making it ready for the finisher.

entry.def: planning for the future; concerned primarily with the future; -- contrasted with conern for the immediate present or reacting to past events.
Eagerly; hastily; obtrusively.
The quality of being forward; cheerful readiness; promtness; as, the forwardness of Christians in propagating the gospel.

sn.def: An advanced stage of progress or of preparation; advancement; as, his measures were in great forwardness .
Eagerness; ardor; as, it is difficult to restrain the forwardness of youth.
Boldness; confidence; assurance; want of due reserve or modesty.
sn.q: In France it is usual to bring children into company, and cherish in them, from their infancy, a kind of forwardness and assurance.

sn.def: A state of advance beyond the usual degree; prematureness; precocity; as, the forwardnessof spring or of corn; the forwardness of a pupil.
sn.q: He had such a dexterous proclivity, as his teachers were fain to restrain his forwardness.
sn.syn: Promptness; promptitude; eagerness; ardor; zeal; assurance; confidence; boldness; impudence; presumption.

entry.def: Same as Forward.

entry.ety: Pref. for- + waste
entry.def: To desolate or lay waste utterly.
To weary extremely; to dispirit.
To weep much.
See Forewite.

entry.ety: For + why, AS. hw�, instrumental case of hwā who
entry.def: Wherefore; because.
Much worn.
entry.q: A silly man, in simple weeds forworn.

entry.def: pres. indic. 1st & 3d pers. sing. of Forwete.
To wrap up; to conceal.
entry.q: All mote be said and nought excused, nor hid, nor forwrapped.

entry.ety: AS. forgieldan
entry.def: To repay; to requite.
To forget.
p. p. of Foryete.

entry.ety: It., prop. p. p. of forzare to force
entry.def: See Sforzato.

entries.entry:
‖Fos"sa n.; pl.FossÆ #. L., a ditch. See Fosse
Anat A pit, groove, cavity, or depression, of greater or less depth; as, the temporal fossa on the side of the skull; the nasal fossæ containing the nostrils in most birds.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fossane
entry.def: A species of civet (Viverra fossa) resembling the genet.

entry.cs: Fosse road. See Fosseway.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. fossa, fr. fodere fossum, to dig

sn.def: A ditch or moat.
See Fossa.

entry.def: A faucet.

entry.ety: F., dim. of fosse a fosse

sn.def: A little hollow; hence, a dimple.
A small, deep-centered ulcer of the transparent cornea.

entry.def: One of the great military roads constructed by the Romans in England and other parts of Europe; -- so called from the fosse or ditch on each side for keeping it dry.

entry.ety: Dial. E. fossick fossuck, a troublesome person, fussick to potter over one's work, fussock to bustle about; of uncertain origin. Cf. Fuss

sn.def: To search for gold by picking at stone or earth or among roots in isolated spots, picking over abandoned workings, etc.; hence, to steal gold or auriferous matter from another's claim.
To search about; to rummage.
sn.q: A man who has fossicked in nature's byways.

cs.cd: a resinous substance, first found in the blue clay at Highgate, near London, and apparently a vegetable resin, partly changed by remaining in the earth.
cs.mcol: Fossil cork Fossil flax Fossil paperorFossil wood
cs.cd: varieties of amianthus.
a soft carbonate of lime.
fossiliferous red hematite.

entry.ety: L. fossilis, fr. fodere to dig: cf. F. fossile. See Fosse

sn.def: Dug out of the earth; as, fossil coal; fossil salt.

preserved from a previous geological age; as, fossil water from deep wells; -- usually implying that the object so described has had its substance modified by long residence in the ground, but also used (as with fossil water) in cases where chemical composition is not altered.
Like or pertaining to fossils; contained in rocks, whether petrified or not; as, fossil plants, shells.

entry.note: ☞ Formerly all minerals were called fossils, but the word is now restricted to express the remains of animals and plants found buried in the earth.

sn.def: A substance dug from the earth.
The remains of an animal or plant found in stratified rocks. Most fossils belong to extinct species, but many of the later ones belong to species still living.
A person whose views and opinions are extremely antiquated; one whose sympathies are with a former time rather than with the present.

entry.ety: Fossil + -ferous
entry.def: Containing or composed of fossils.

entry.ety: Fossil + L. facere to make
entry.def: The process of becoming fossil.

sn.def: The science or state of fossils.
The state of being extremely antiquated in views and opinions.

entry.def: One who is versed in the science of fossils; a paleontologist.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fossilisation
entry.def: The process of converting, or of being converted, into a fossil.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fossilized; p. pr. & vb. n. Fossilizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. fossiliser

sn.def: To convert into a fossil; to petrify; as, to fossilize bones or wood.
To cause to become antiquated, rigid, or fixed, as by fossilization; to mummify; to deaden.
sn.q: Ten layers of birthdays on a woman's head Are apt to fossilize her girlish mirth.

sn.def: To become fossil.
To become antiquated, rigid, or fixed, beyond the influence of change or progress.

entry.def: Converted into a fossil; antiquated; firmly fixed in views or opinions.
entry.q: A fossilized sample of confused provincialism.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. fossor� digger, fr. fodere to dig
entry.def: A group of hymenopterous insects including the sand wasps. They excavate cells in earth, where they deposit their eggs, with the bodies of other insects for the food of the young when hatched.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Fossores.

entry.ety: L. fossor a digger
entry.def: Fitted for digging, adapted for burrowing or digging; as, a fossorial foot; a fossorial animal.
Adapted for digging; -- said of the legs of certain insects.

entry.ety: L. fossula little ditch, dim. of fossa. See Fosse
entry.def: Having, or surrounded by, long, narrow depressions or furrows.

entry.ety: OE. fostren, fr. AS. fōster fōstor, food, nourishment, fr. fōda food. √75. See Food

sn.def: To feed; to nourish; to support; to bring up.
sn.q: Some say that ravens foster forlorn children.

sn.def: To cherish; to promote the growth of; to encourage; to sustain and promote; as, to foster genius.

entry.def: To be nourished or trained up together.

entry.cs:
Foster babeorFoster child
an infant or child nursed or raised by a woman not its mother, or bred by a man not its father.
Foster brother Foster sister
one who is, or has been, nursed at the same breast, or brought up by the same nurse as another, but is not of the same parentage. Foster dam one who takes the place of a mother; a nurse. Dryden. Foster earth earth by which a plant is nourished, though not its native soil. J. Philips. Foster father a man who takes the place of a father in caring for a child. Bacon. Foster land. Land allotted for the maintenance of any one. Obs One's adopted country. Foster lean
foster + AS. læn a loan See Loan
remuneration fixed for the rearing of a foster child; also, the jointure of a wife. Obs Wharton. Foster mother a woman who takes a mother's place in the nurture and care of a child; a nurse. Foster nurse a nurse; a nourisher. R Shak. Foster parent a foster mother or foster father. Foster son a male foster child.
entry.ety: AS. fōster fōstor, nourishment. See Foster v. t.
entry.def: Relating to nourishment; affording, receiving, or sharing nourishment or nurture; -- applied to father, mother, child, brother, etc., to indicate that the person so called stands in the relation of parent, child, brother, etc., as regards sustenance and nurture, but not by tie of blood.
A forester.
The care of a foster child; the charge of nursing.
One who, or that which, fosters.

entry.ety: AS. fōstorling
entry.def: A foster child.
Food; nourishment.

entry.ety: For fosteress
entry.def: A woman who feeds and cherishes; a nurse.

entry.ety: OE. fother foder, AS. fō�er a cartload; akin to G. fuder a cartload, a unit of measure, OHG. fuodar, D. voeder, and perh. to E. fathom, or cf. Skr. pātrā vessel, dish. Cf. Fodder a fother

sn.def: A wagonload; a load of any sort.
sn.q: Of dung full many a fother.

sn.def: See Fodder, a unit of weight.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fothered; p. pr. & vb. n. Fothering
entry.ety: Cf. Fodder food, and G. füttern futtern, to cover within or without, to line. √75
entry.def: To stop (a leak in a ship at sea) by drawing under its bottom a thrummed sail, so that the pressure of the water may force it into the crack.

entry.ety: L. fovere fotum, to keep warm, to cherish
entry.def: Nourishing.
Seventy pounds of lead.

entries.entry: Fou`cault" cur`rent. After J. B. L. Foucault1819-68), French physicist Elec An eddy current.

entry.def: A small mine, in the form of a well sunk from the surface of the ground, charged with explosive and projectiles. It is made in a position likely to be occupied by the enemy.
imp. & p. p. of Fight.
p. p. of Fight.

entry.ety: See Fowl
entry.def: A bird.

entry.cs:
Foul anchor. Naut See under Anchor. Foul ball Baseball a ball that first strikes the ground outside of the foul ball lines, or rolls outside of certain limits. Foul ball lines Baseball lines from the home base, through the first and third bases, to the boundary of the field. Foul berth Naut a berth in which a ship is in danger of fouling another vesel.
Foul billorFoul bill of health
a certificate, duly authenticated, that a ship has come from a place where a contagious disorder prevails, or that some of the crew are infected. Foul copy a rough draught, with erasures and corrections; -- opposed to fair or clean copy. “Some writers boast of negligence, and others would be ashamed to show their foul copies.” Cowper. Foul proof an uncorrected proof; a proof containing an excessive quantity of errors. Foul strike Baseball a strike by the batsman when any part of his person is outside of the lines of his position. To fall foul to fall out; to quarrel. Obs “If they be any ways offended, they fall foul.” Burton.
To fall foul oforTo run foul of . See under Fall. To make foul water to sail in such shallow water that the ship's keel stirs the mud at the bottom.
entry.ety: OE. foul ful, AS. fūl; akin to D. vuil, G. faul rotten, OHG. fūl, Icel. fūl foul, fetid; Dan. fuul, Sw. ful foul, Goth. fūls fetid, Lith. puti to be putrid, L. putere to stink, be putrid, pus pus, Gr. py`on pus, to cause to rot, Skr. pūy to stink. √82. Cf. Defile to foul, File to foul, Filth Pus Putrid

sn.def: Covered with, or containing, extraneous matter which is injurious, noxious, offensive, or obstructive; filthy; dirty; not clean; polluted; nasty; defiled; as, a foul cloth; foul hands; a foul chimney; foul air; a ship's bottom is foul when overgrown with barnacles; a gun becomes foul from repeated firing; a well is foul with polluted water.
sn.q: My face is foul with weeping.

sn.def: Scurrilous; obscene or profane; abusive; as, foul words; foul language.
Hateful; detestable; shameful; odious; wretched.
sn.q: Thefoulwith Sycorax.
Who first seduced them to that foul revolt?

sn.def: Loathsome; disgusting; as, a foul disease.
Ugly; homely; poor.
sn.q: Let us, like merchants, show our foulest wares.

sn.def: Not favorable; unpropitious; not fair or advantageous; as, a foul wind; a foul road; cloudy or rainy; stormy; not fair; -- said of the weather, sky, etc.
sn.q: So foul a sky clears not without a storm.

sn.def: Not conformed to the established rules and customs of a game, conflict, test, etc.; unfair; dishonest; dishonorable; cheating; as, foul play.
Having freedom of motion interfered with by collision or entanglement; entangled; -- opposed to clear; as, a rope or cable may get foul while paying it out.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fouled; p. pr. & vb. n. Fouling

sn.def: To make filthy; to defile; to daub; to dirty; to soil; as, to foul the face or hands with mire.
To incrust (the bore of a gun) with burnt powder in the process of firing.
To cover (a ship's bottom) with anything that impered its sailing; as, a bottom fouled with barnacles.
To entangle, so as to impede motion; as, to foul a rope or cable in paying it out; to come into collision with; as, one boat fouled the other in a race.
To become clogged with burnt powder in the process of firing, as a gun.
To become entagled, as ropes; to come into collision with something; as, the two boats fouled .
An entanglement; a collision, as in a boat race.
See Foul ball, under Foul a.
In various games or sports, an act done contrary to the rules; a foul stroke, hit, play, or the like.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: A thin, washable material of silk, or silk and cotton, usually with a printed pattern on it. It was originally imported from India, but now also made elsewhere.
an article of clothing made of foulard{1, such as a neckpiece.

entry.ety: OE. fouldre lightning, fr. F. foudre, OF. also fouldre, fr. L. fulgur. See Fulgor
entry.def: To flash, as lightning; to lighten; to gleam; to thunder.
entry.q: Flames offoulderingheat.

entry.def: Foully.
In a foul manner; filthily; nastily; shamefully; unfairly; dishonorably.
entry.q: I foully wronged him; do forgive me, do.

entry.def: Using language scurrilous, opprobrious, obscene, or profane; abusive; as, noisy foul-mouthed women all shouting at once.
entry.q: So foul-mouthed a witness never appeared in any cause.

entry.ety: AS. fūlnes
entry.def: The quality or condition of being foul.
emitting an unpleasasnt odor.
entry.syn: fetid, foul, funky, noisome, smelly, putrid, stinking.

entry.def: Using profane, scurrilous, slanderous, or obscene language; same as foul-mouthed.
an embarrassing mistake.
entry.syn: blunder, blooper, bungle, flub, botch, boner, boo-boo, misdoing.

entry.ety: OE. folmard fulmard; AS. fūl foul + mearð meard, marten: cf. F. marte martre. See Foul a., and Marten the quadruped
entry.def: The European polecat; -- called also European ferret, and fitchew. See Polecat.
imp. & p. p. of Find.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Founded; p. pr. & vb. n. Founding
entry.ety: F. fondre, L. fundere to found, pour
entry.def: To form by melting a metal, and pouring it into a mold; to cast.
entry.q: Whereof tofoundtheir engines.

entry.def: A thin, single-cut file for combmakers.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Founded; p. pr. & vb. n. Founding
entry.ety: F. fonder, L. fundare, fr. fundus bottom. See 1st Bottom, and cf. Founder v. i. Fund

sn.def: To lay the basis of; to set, or place, as on something solid, for support; to ground; to establish upon a basis, literal or figurative; to fix firmly.
sn.q: I had else been perfect, Whole as the marble, founded as the rock.
A man that all his time Hath founded his good fortunes on your love.
It fell not, for it was founded on a rock.

sn.def: To take the ffirst steps or measures in erecting or building up; to furnish the materials for beginning; to begin to raise; to originate; as, to found a college; to found a family.
sn.q: There they shall found Their government, and their great senate choose.
sn.syn: To base; ground; institute; establish; fix. See Predicate.

entry.cs:
Foundation course. See Base course, under Base n.
Foundation muslin an open-worked gummed fabric used for stiffening dresses, bonnets, etc. Foundation school in England, an endowed school. To be on a foundation to be entitled to a support from the proceeds of an endowment, as a scholar or a fellow of a college.
entry.ety: F. fondation, L. fundatio. See Found to establish

sn.def: The act of founding, fixing, establishing, or beginning to erect.
That upon which anything is founded; that on which anything stands, and by which it is supported; the lowest and supporting layer of a superstructure; groundwork; basis.
sn.q: Behold, I lay in Zion, for a foundation, a stone . . . a precious corner stone, a sure foundation.
The foundation of a free common wealth.

sn.def: The lowest and supporting part or member of a wall, including the base course (see Base course, under Base n.) and footing courses; in a frame house, the whole substructure of masonry.
A donation or legacy appropriated to support a charitable institution, and constituting a permanent fund; endowment.
sn.q: He was entered on the foundation of Westminster.

sn.def: That which is founded, or established by endowment; an endowed institution or charity; as, the Ford Foundation .
sn.q: Against the canon laws of our foundation.

entry.def: One who derives support from the funds or foundation of a college or school.
Having no foundation.
based; -- often used as combining terms; as, well-founded suspicions.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. fondeor, F. fondateur, L. fundator
entry.def: One who founds, establishes, and erects; one who lays a foundation; an author; one from whom anything originates; one who endows.

entry.cs: Fonder's dust. Same as Facing, 4. Founder's sand a kind of sand suitable for purposes of molding.
entry.ety: From Found to cast
entry.def: One who founds; one who casts metals in various forms; a caster; as, a founder of cannon, bells, hardware, or types.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foundered; p. pr. & vb. n. Foundering
entry.ety: OF. fondrer to fall in, cf. F. s'effondrer, fr. fond bottom, L. fundus. See Found to establish

sn.def: To become filled with water, and sink, as a ship.
To fall; to stumble and go lame, as a horse.
sn.q: For which his horse fearé gan to turn, And leep aside, and foundrede as he leep.

sn.def: To fail; to miscarry.
sn.q: All his tricksfounder.

entry.def: To cause internal inflammation and soreness in the feet or limbs of (a horse), so as to disable or lame him.
A lameness in the foot of a horse, occasioned by inflammation; closh.
An inflammatory fever of the body, or acute rheumatism; as, chest founder . See Chest ffounder.
Difficult to travel; likely to trip one up; as, a founderous road.
The first shaft sunk.

entries.entry:
Found"er*y n.; pl.Founderies #. F. fonderie, fr. fondre. See Found to cast, and cf. Foundry
Same as Foundry.

entry.def: The art of smelting and casting metals.

cs.cd: a hospital for foundlings.

entry.ety: OE. foundling fundling; finden to find + -ling; cf. fündling findling. See Find v. t., and -ling
entry.def: A deserted or exposed infant; a child found without a parent or owner.
A female founder; a woman who founds or establishes, or who endows with a fund.

entries.entry:
Found"ry
Foundry ladle a vessel for holding molten metal and conveying it from cupola to the molds.
n.; pl.Foundries #. See Foundery
The act, process, or art of casting metals.
The buildings and works for casting metals.

entry.ety: See Font
entry.def: A font.

entry.ety: OF. font funt, fr. L. fons fontis, a fountain; of uncertain origin, perh. akin to fundere to pour, E. found to cast. Cf. Font
entry.def: A fountain.

entry.cs: Air fountain. See under Air. Fountain heead primary source; original; first principle. Young. Fountain inkstand an inkstand having a continual supply of ink, as from elevated reservoir. Fountain lamp a lamp fed with oil from an elevated reservoir. Fountain pen a pen with a reservoir in the handle which furnishes a supply of ink. Fountain pump. A structure for a fountain, having the form of a pump. A portable garden pump which throws a jet, for watering plants, etc. Fountain shell Zoöl the large West Indian conch shell (Strombus gigas). Fountain of youth a mythical fountain whose waters were fabled to have the property of renewing youth.
entry.ety: F. fontaine, LL. fontana, fr. L. fons fontis. See 2d Fount

sn.def: A spring of water issuing from the earth.

An artificially produced jet or stream of water; also, the structure or works in which such a jet or stream rises or flows; a basin built and constantly supplied with pure water for drinking and other useful purposes, or for ornament.
A reservoir or chamber to contain a liquid which can be conducted or drawn off as needed for use; as, the ink fountain in a printing press, etc.
The source from which anything proceeds, or from which anything is supplied continuously; origin; source.
sn.q: Judea, the fountain of the gospel.
Author of all being,Fountain of light, thyself invisible.

sn.def: an abundant source.
the source of water from which a stream arises.

entry.def: Having no fountain; destitute of springs or sources of water.
entry.q: Barren desert, fountainless and dry.

entry.def: Full of fountains.
a genus of resinous succulent trees or shrubs of desert and semi-desert regions of the southwestern U. S. that are leafless most of the year.
a small natural family of spiny shrubs or trees of the southwestern U. S.

entry.ety: OE. four fower feower, AS. feówer; akin to OS. fiwar, D. & G. vier, OHG. fior, Icel. fjōrir, Sw. fyra, Dan. fire, Goth. fidwōr, Russ. chetuire chetvero, W. pedwar, L. quatuor, Gr. te`ttares te`ssares pi`syres, Skr. catur. √302. Cf. Farthing Firkin Forty Cater four, Quater-cousin Quatuor Quire of paper, tetrarch
entry.def: One more than three; twice two.

entry.cs: All fours. See All fours, in the Vocabulary.

sn.def: The sum of four units; four units or objects.
A symbol representing four units, as 4 or iv.
Four things of the same kind, esp. four horses; as, a chariot and four .

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A tricky fellow; a cheat.

entry.ety: F. See Fork
entry.def: Having the ends forked or branched, and the ends of the branches terminating abruptly as if cut off; -- said of an ordinary, especially of a cross.

entry.ety: F., dim. of fourche. See Fork

sn.def: A table fork.

sd.def: A small fold of membrane, connecting the labia in the posterior part of the vulva.
The wishbone or furculum of birds.
The frog of the hoof of the horse and allied animals.

sn.def: An instrument used to raise and support the tongue during the cutting of the frænum.
The forked piece between two adjacent fingers, to which the front and back portions are sewed.
The combination of the card immediately above and the one immediately below a given card.

entry.def: Having four corners or angles.
A four-stroke cycle, as the Otto cycle, for an internal-combustion engine.
A machine used in making paper; -- so named from an early inventor of improvements in this class of machinery.

entry.ety: AS. feówerfeold
entry.def: Four times; quadruple; as, a fourfold division.
entry.q: He shall restore the lamb fourfold.

entry.def: Four times as many or as much.
To make four times as much or as many, as an assessment; to quadruple.
Having four feet; quadruped; as, fourfooted beasts.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: An ammunition wagon.
A French baggage wagon.

sn.def: Having four hands; quadrumanous.
Requiring four “hands” or players; as, a fourhanded game at cards.

entry.def: A game in which a pitcher allows the opposing team four hits; as, he pitched a four-hitter .

sn.def: A long necktie that is tied in a slipknot with one end hanging in front of the other.
a coach pulled by four horses with one driver.

Its flowers are white, yellow, and red, and open toward sunset, or earlier in cloudy weather; hence the name. It is also called marvel of Peru, and afternoon lady.

Making or constituting one of fourteen equal parts into which anything may be divided.
One of fourteen equal parts into which one whole may be divided; the quotient of a unit divided by fourteen.
The octave of the seventh.
One next after the thirteenth in a series.

entry.ety: OE. fourthe ferthe feorthe, AS. feórða, fr. feówer four

sn.def: Next in order after the third; the ordinal of four.
Forming one of four equal parts into which anything may be divided.

cs.cd: specifically, in the United States, the fourth day of July, the anniversary of the declaration of American independence; as, to celebrate the Fourth .

cs.cd: a cock connected with four pipes or ports, and having two or more passages in the plug, by which the adjacent pipes or ports may be made to communicate; formerly used as a valve in the steam engine, and now for various other purposes. In the illustration, a leads to the upper end of a steam engine cylinder, and b to the lower end; c is the steam pipe, and d the exhaust pipe.

entry.def: Allowing passage in either of four directions; as, a four-way cock, or valve.

An intersection of two roads having stop signs at all four entry points. The usual rule for such intersections requires that those entering the intersection yield the right of way to vehicles entering before them.
Having four wheels.
A vehicle having four wheels;
a hackney carriage with four weels.

entry.ety: Cf. F. foutu, p. p. of foutre; OF. foutu scoundrel. See Fouter
entry.def: Despicable.

cs.cd: a fowl that frequents the barnyard; the common domestic cock or hen.

entry.ety: OE. foul fowel foghel fuhel fugel, AS. fugol; akin to OS. fugal D. & G. vogel, OHG. fogal, Icel. & Dan. fugl, Sw. fogel fågel, Goth. fugls; of unknown origin, possibly by loss of l, from the root of E. fly, or akin to E. fox, as being a tailed animal

sn.def: Any bird; esp., any large edible bird.
sn.q: Let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the fowl of the air.
Behold the fowls of the air; for they sow not.
Like a flight of fowl Scattered by winds and high tempestuous gusts.

sn.def: Any domesticated bird used as food, as a hen, turkey, duck; in a more restricted sense, the common domestic cock or hen (Gallus domesticus).

cs.cd: a light gun with smooth bore, adapted for the use of small shot in killing birds or small quadrupeds.

entry.q: Such persons as may lawfully hunt, fish, or fowl.

entry.def: A sportsman who pursues wild fowl, or takes or kills for food.

entry.ety: From Dr. Samuel Fowler
entry.def: A variety of rhodonite, from Franklin Furnace, New Jersey, containing some zinc.

entries.entry: Fow"ler's so*lu"tion. An aqueous solution of arsenite of potassium, of such strength that one hundred parts represent one part of arsenious acid, or white arsenic; -- named from Fowler, an English physician who first brought it into use.

Fox ☞ The black or silver-gray fox is a variety of the American red fox, producing a fur of great value; the cross-gray and woods-gray foxes are other varieties of the same species, of less value. The common foxes of Europe and America are very similar; both are celebrated for their craftiness. They feed on wild birds, poultry, and various small animals.
Fox and geese. A boy's game, in which one boy tries to catch others as they run one goal to another. A game with sixteen checkers, or some substitute for them, one of which is called the fox, and the rest the geese; the fox, whose first position is in the middle of the board, endeavors to break through the line of the geese, and the geese to pen up the fox. Fox bat Zoöl a large fruit bat of the genus Pteropus, of many species, inhabiting Asia, Africa, and the East Indies, esp. P. medius of India. Some of the species are more than four feet across the outspread wings. See Fruit bat. Fox bolt a bolt having a split end to receive a fox wedge. Fox brush Zoöl the tail of a fox. Fox evil a disease in which the hair falls off; alopecy. Fox grape Bot the name of two species of American grapes. The northern fox grape (Vitis Labrusca) is the origin of the varieties called Isabella Concord Hartford, etc., and the southern fox grape (Vitis vulpina) has produced the Scuppernong, and probably the Catawba. Fox hunter. One who pursues foxes with hounds. A horse ridden in a fox chase. Fox shark Zoöl the thrasher shark. See Thrasher shark, under Thrasher. Fox sleep pretended sleep. Fox sparrow Zoöl a large American sparrow (Passerella iliaca); -- so called on account of its reddish color. Fox squirrel Zoöl a large North American squirrel (Sciurus niger, or S. cinereus). In the Southern States the black variety prevails; farther north the fulvous and gray variety, called the cat squirrel, is more common. Fox terrier Zoöl one of a peculiar breed of terriers, used in hunting to drive foxes from their holes, and for other purposes. There are rough- and smooth-haired varieties. Fox trot a pace like that which is adopted for a few steps, by a horse, when passing from a walk into a trot, or a trot into a walk.
Fox wedge Mach. & Carpentry a wedge for expanding the split end of a bolt, cotter, dowel, tenon, or other piece, to fasten the end in a hole or mortise and prevent withdrawal. The wedge abuts on the bottom of the hole and the piece is driven down upon it. Fastening by fox wedges is called foxtail wedging. Fox wolf Zoöl one of several South American wild dogs, belonging to the genus Canis. They have long, bushy tails like a fox.
fŏks n.; pl.Foxes #. AS. fox; akin to D. vos, G. fuchs, OHG. fuhs foha, Goth. faúhō, Icel. fōa fox, fox fraud; of unknown origin, cf. Skr. puccha tail. Cf. Vixen
Zoöl A carnivorous animal of the genus Vulpes, family Canidæ, of many species. The European fox (V. vulgaris or V. vulpes), the American red fox (V. fulvus), the American gray fox (V. Virginianus), and the arctic, white, or blue, fox (V. lagopus) are well-known species. Subtle as the fox for prey.
Zoöl The European dragonet.
Zoöl The fox shark or thrasher shark; -- called also sea fox. See Thrasher shark, under Shark.
A sly, cunning fellow. Colloq We call a crafty and cruel man a fox.
Naut Rope yarn twisted together, and rubbed with tar; -- used for seizings or mats.
A sword; -- so called from the stamp of a fox on the blade, or perhaps of a wolf taken for a fox. Obs Thou diest on point of fox.
pl. Ethnol A tribe of Indians which, with the Sacs, formerly occupied the region about Green Bay, Wisconsin; -- called also Outagamies.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Foxed; p. pr. & vb. n. Foxing
entry.ety: See Fox n., cf. Icel. fox imposture

The european dragonet. See Dragonet.

entry.def: Any plant of the genus Digitalis. The common English foxglove (Digitalis purpurea) is a handsome perennial or biennial plant, whose leaves are used as a powerful medicine, both as a sedative and diuretic. See Digitalis.
entry.q: Pan through the pastures oftentimes hath run To pluck the speckled foxgloves from their stem.

Attractive in a sexually appealing way; --of women.
Stylish and sexually attractive; -- of women's clothing; as, wearing a foxy new outfit.

cs.cd: a fraction in which the number of equal parts into which the integer is supposed to be divided is indicated by figures or letters, called the denominator, written below a line, over which is the numerator, indicating the number of these parts included in the fraction; as 1/2, one half, 2/5, two fifths.
a fraction having a fraction or mixed number in the numerator or denominator, or in both.
a fraction of a fraction; two or more fractions connected by of.
cs.mcol: Continued fraction Decimal fraction Partial fraction, etc.
cs.cd: See under Continued Decimal Partial, etc.
a fraction in which the numerator is greater than the denominator.
a fraction in which the numerator is less than the denominator.

entry.ety: F. fraction, L. fractio a breaking, fr. frangere fractum, to break. See Break

sn.def: The act of breaking, or state of being broken, especially by violence.
sn.q: Neither can the natural body of Christ be subject to any fraction or breaking up.

sn.def: A portion; a fragment.
sn.q: Some niggard fractions of an hour.

sn.def: One or more aliquot parts of a unit or whole number; an expression for a definite portion of a unit or magnitude.

entry.def: To separate by means of, or to subject to, fractional distillation or crystallization; to fractionate; -- frequently used with out; as, to fraction out a certain grade of oil from pretroleum.

cs.cd: a process of gradual and approximate purification and separation, by means of repeated solution and crystallization therefrom.
small coin, or paper notes, in circulation, of less value than the monetary unit.
a process of distillation so conducted that a mixture of liquids, differing considerably from each other in their boiling points, can be separated into its constituents.

Relatively small; inconsiderable; insignificant; as, a fractional part of the population.

Fractional.

the act or process of separating a mixture into portions of different composition, as in distillation or fractional crystallization.

sn.def: Separation of crude oil into components of differing composition by fractional distillation.

entry.ety: Cf. Prov. E. frack forward, eager, E. freak fridge; or Prov. E. fratch to squabble, quarrel
entry.def: Apt to break out into a passion; apt to scold; cross; snappish; ugly; unruly; as, a fractious man; a fractious horse.
entry.syn: Snappish; peevish; waspish; cross; irritable; perverse; pettish.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or consequent on, a fracture.

cs.cd: a fracture in which the bone is broken into several parts.
a fracture of the bone combined with the lesion of some artery, nervous trunk, or joint.
a fracture in which there is an open wound from the surface down to the fracture.
a fracture in which the bone only is ruptured. It does not communicate with the surface by an open wound.

entry.usage: These words denote different kinds of breaking, according to the objects to which they are applied. Fracture is applied to hard substances; as, the fracture of a bone. Rupture is oftener applied to soft substances; as, the rupture of a blood vessel. It is also used figuratively. “To be an enemy and once to have been a friend, does it not embitter the rupture?”
entry.ety: L. fractura, fr. frangere fractum, to break: cf. F. fracture. See Fraction

sn.def: The act of breaking or snapping asunder; rupture; breach.
The breaking of a bone.
The texture of a freshly broken surface; as, a compact fracture; an even, hackly, or conchoidal fracture.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fractured #; 135; p. pr. & vb. n.. Fracturing
entry.ety: Cf. F. fracturer
entry.def: To cause a fracture or fractures in; to break; to burst asunder; to crack; to separate the continuous parts of; as, to fracture a bone; to fracture the skull.

entries.entry: ‖Fræn"u*lum n.; pl.Frænula #. NL., dim. of L. fraenum a bridle Anat A frænum.

Fræ"numorFre"num
n.; pl. E. Frænums #, L. Fræna #. L., a bridle Anat A connecting fold of membrane serving to support or restrain any part; as, the frænum of the tongue.

entry.note: This term became popularized when disaffected American troops serving in Vietnam were reported on occasion to kill unpopular commanders by the use of grenades.

entry.def: To assault, especially to kill or wound, with a fragmentation grenade.
a genus of plants comprising the strawberry plants.

entry.ety: L. fragilis, from frangere to break; cf. F. fragile. See Break v. t., and cf. Frail a.
entry.def: Easily broken; brittle; frail; delicate; easily destroyed.
entry.q: The state of ivy is tough, and not fragile.
entry.syn: Brittle; infirm; weak; frail; frangible; slight.

entry.ety: L. fragilitas: cf. F. fragilité. Cf. Frailty

sn.def: The condition or quality of being fragile; brittleness; frangibility.
Weakness; feebleness.
sn.q: An appearance of delicacy, and even of fragility, is almost essential to it [beauty].

sn.def: Liability to error and sin; frailty.
sn.q: The fragility and youthful folly of Qu. Fabius.

entry.ety: L. fragmentum, fr. frangere to break: cf. F. fragment. See Break v. t.
entry.def: A part broken off; a small, detached portion; an imperfect part; as, a fragment of an ancient writing.
entry.q: Gather up the fragments that remain.

sn.def: Fragmentary.
Consisting of the pulverized or fragmentary material of rock, as conglomerate, shale, etc.

entry.def: A fragmentary rock.
In a fragmentary manner; piecemeal.
The quality or property of being in fragments, or broken pieces; incompleteness; want of continuity.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fragmentaire

sn.def: Composed of fragments, or broken pieces; disconnected; not complete or entire.
Composed of the fragments of other rocks.

entry.def: the act or process of separating something into small pieces or fine particles.

A type of hand grenade designed to burst into multiple fragments upon detonation of the explosive charge; the fragments fly away at high velocity, killing or wounding persons nearby. Contrasted to concussion grenade. The common type of fragmentation grenade used by the American military was sometimes jocosely referred to as a pineapple from its reticulated surface appearance, resembling that of the fruit.
Broken into fragments.
A writer of fragments; as, the fragmentist of Wolfenbüttel.

entry.note: Due to confusion with fragrant
entry.ety: L., a breaking to pieces, fr. frangere to break

sn.def: A loud and sudden sound; the report of anything bursting; a crash.
A strong or sweet scent.

entry.ety: L. fragrantia: cf. OF. fragrance
entry.def: The quality of being fragrant; sweetness of smell; a sweet smell; a pleasing odor; perfume.
entry.q: Eve separate he spies, Veiled in a cloud of fragrance.
The goblet crowned, Breathed aromatic fragrancies around.

entry.ety: L. fragrans. -antis, p. pr. of fragrare to emit a smell of fragrance: cf. OF. fragrant
entry.def: Affecting the olfactory nerves agreeably; sweet of smell; odorous; having or emitting an agreeable perfume.
entry.q: Fragrant the fertile earth After soft showers.
entry.syn: Sweet-smelling; odorous; odoriferous; sweet-scented; redolent; ambrosial; balmy; spicy; aromatic.

entry.def: Same as Fraught.

entry.ety: OE. fraiel fraile, OF. fraiel freel frael, fr. LL. fraellum
entry.def: A basket made of rushes, used chiefly for containing figs and raisins.

A rush for weaving baskets.

sn.def: Tender.
sn.q: Deep indignation and compassion frail.

sn.def: Liable to fall from virtue or be led into sin; not strong against temptation; weak in resolution; also, unchaste; -- often applied to fallen women.
sn.q: Man is frail, and prone to evil.

entry.def: Weakly; infirmly.
Frailty.

entries.entry:
frail"ty frāl"t� n.; pl.frailties frāl"tĭz. OE. frelete freilte, OF. fraileté, fr. L. fragilitas. See Frail a., and cf. Fragility
The condition or quality of being frail, physically, mentally, or morally; frailness; infirmity; weakness of resolution; liableness to be deceived or seduced. God knows our frailty, [and] pities our weakness.
A fault proceeding from weakness; foible; sin of infirmity. Frailness; fragility; imperfection; failing.

entry.ety: OF.; F fraicheur, fr. frais, fem. fraîche, fresh; of German origin. See Frash a.
entry.def: Freshness; coolness.

entry.ety: See Froise
entry.def: A large and thick pancake, with slices of bacon in it.

entry.ety: F. fraise, orig., a ruff, cf. F. frise frieze, E. frieze a coarse stuff

sn.def: A defense consisting of pointed stakes driven into the ramparts in a horizontal or inclined position.
A fluted reamer for enlarging holes in stone; a small milling cutter.

entry.def: To protect, as a line of troops, against an onset of cavalry, by opposing bayonets raised obliquely forward.
Fortified with a fraise.
A freckle.
entry.q: A few fraknes in his face.

entry.def: Capable of being framed.

entry.ety: F. & NL., fr. F. framboise raspberry
entry.def: The yaws. See Yaws.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Framed; p. pr. & vb. n. Framing
entry.ety: OE. framen fremen, to execute, build, AS. fremman to further, perform, effect, fr. fram strong, valiant; akin to E. foremost, and prob. to AS. fram from, Icel. fremja frama, to further, framr forward, G. fromm worthy, excellent, pious. See Foremost From, and cf. Furnish

sn.def: To construct by fitting and uniting the several parts of the skeleton of any structure; specifically, in woodwork, to put together by cutting parts of one member to fit parts of another. See Dovetail Halve v. t. Miter Tenon Tooth Tusk Scarf, and Splice.
To originate; to plan; to devise; to contrive; to compose; in a bad sense, to invent or fabricate, as something false.
sn.q: How many excellent reasonings are framed in the mind of a man of wisdom and study in a length of years.

sn.def: To fit to something else, or for some specific end; to adjust; to regulate; to shape; to conform.
sn.q: And frame my face to all occasions.
We may in some measure frame our minds for the reception of happiness.
The human mind is framed to be influenced.

sn.def: To cause; to bring about; to produce.
sn.q: Fear frames disorder, and disorder wounds.

sn.def: To support.
sn.q: That on a staff his feeble steps did frame.

sn.def: To provide with a frame, as a picture.
to manufacture false evidence against (an innocent person), so as to make the person appear guilty of a crime. The act of framing a person is often referred to as a frame-up.
To shape; to arrange, as the organs of speech.
To proceed; to go.
sn.q: The bauty of this sinful dame Made many princes thither frame.

cs.cd: etc. See under Balloon Cant, etc.
cs.mcol: Frame buildingorFrame house a building of which the form and support is made of framed timbers. U.S Frame level
cs.cd: a mason's level.
a thin saw stretched in a frame to give it rigidity.

sn.def: Anything composed of parts fitted and united together; a fabric; a structure; esp., the constructional system, whether of timber or metal, that gives to a building, vessel, etc., its model and strength; the skeleton of a structure.
sn.q: These are thy glorious works, Parent of good, Almighty! thine this universal frame.

sn.def: The bodily structure; physical constitution; make or build of a person.
sn.q: Some bloody passion shakes your very frame.
No frames could be strong enough to endure it.

entry.sn:
A kind of open case or structure made for admitting, inclosing, or supporting things, as that which incloses or contains a window, door, picture, etc.; that on which anything is held or stretched; as: The skeleton structure which supports the boiler and machinery of a locomotive upon its wheels.
Founding A molding box or flask, which being filled with sand serves as a mold for castings.
The ribs and stretchers of an umbrella or other structure with a fabric covering.
A structure of four bars, adjustable in size, on which cloth, etc., is stretched for quilting, embroidery, etc.
Hort A glazed portable structure for protecting young plants from frost.
Print A stand to support the type cases for use by the compositor.
a pair of glasses without the lenses; that part of a pair of glasses that excludes the lenses.

sn.def: A term applied, especially in England, to certain machines built upon or within framework; as, a stocking frame; lace frame; spinning frame, etc.
Form; shape; proportion; scheme; structure; constitution; system; as, a frameof government.
sn.q: She that hath a heart of that fine frame To pay this debt of love but to a brother.
Put your discourse into some frame.

sn.def: Particular state or disposition, as of the mind; humor; temper; mood; as, to be always in a happy frame . Same as frame of mind
Contrivance; the act of devising or scheming.
sn.q: John the bastard Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.

sn.def: In games: In pool, the triangular form used in setting up the balls; also, the balls as set up, or the round of playing required to pocket them all; as, to play six frames in a game of 50 points. In bowling, as in tenpins, one of the several innings forming a game.

entry.def: provided with a frame; as, there were framed snapshots of family and friends on her desk. Opposite of unframed.
mood; mental attitude; mental disposition; same as frame{6.

sn.def: an arbitrary set of spatial coordinates used to describe the position or motion of objects. The coordinates may be fixed or moving; as, a rotating frame of reference .
a set of assumptions or conditions that are used to discuss or understand something; as, a religious frame of reference .

entry.def: One who frames; as, the framer of a building; the framers of the Constitution.

of, pertaining to, or causing a type of mutation consisting of the insertion or deletion of one or more nucleotides in the nucleic acid structure of a gene, when the number of base pairs inserted or deleted is not a multiple of three. If the addition or deletion occurs in multiples of three, the unaffected nucleotides in the genome remain in the proper order ("frame") to be correctly translated into protein; in such cases of insertions or deletions not causing a frame shift, a functional though altered protein may be produced by the organism. Frameshift mutations cause more profound changes in the composition of the protein resulting from translation of the mutated gene.
A conspiracy or plot for a malicious or evil purpose;
an act that incriminates a person on false evidence.

sn.def: The work of framing, or the completed work; the frame or constructional part of anything; as, the framework of society.
sn.q: A staunch and solid piece of framework.

sn.def: Work done in, or by means of, a frame or loom.

cs.cd: a heavy chisel with a socket shank for making mortises.

sn.def: The act, process, or style of putting together a frame, or of constructing anything; a frame; that which frames.
A framework, or a sy� of frames.

entry.ety: Also written frampul frampled framfold
Cf. W. fframfol passionate, ffrom angry, fretting; or perh. akin to E. frump
entry.def: Peevish; cross; vexatious; quarrelsome.
entry.q: Is Pompey grown so malapert, so frampel?

entry.ety: F., fr. franc a Franc. See Frank a.
entry.def: A silver coin of France, and since 1795 the unit of the French monetary system. It has been adopted by Belgium and Swizerland. In 1913 it was equivalent to about nineteen cents American, or ten pence British, and is divided into 100 centimes.

cs.cd: the privilege or right of voting in an election of public officers.

entry.ety: F., fr. franc, fem. franche, free. See Frank a.

sn.def: Exemption from constraint or oppression; freedom; liberty.

A particular privilege conferred by grant from a sovereign or a government, and vested in individuals; an immunity or exemption from ordinary jurisdiction; a constitutional or statutory right or privilege, esp. the right to vote.
sn.q: Election by universal suffrage, as modified by the Constitution, is the one crowning franchise of the American people.

sn.def: The district or jurisdiction to which a particular privilege extends; the limits of an immunity; hence, an asylum or sanctuary.
sn.q: Churches and mobasteries in Spain are franchises for criminals.

sn.def: Magnanimity; generosity; liberality; frankness; nobility.
sn.q: Franchisein woman.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Franchised; p. pr. & vb. n. Franchising
entry.ety: Cf. OF. franchir to free, F., to cross
entry.def: To make free; to enfranchise; to give liberty to.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. franchissement
entry.def: Release; deliverance; freedom.

entry.ety: See Frank a.
entry.def: Pertaining to the Franks, or their language; Frankish.

cs.cd: pious laymen who devote themselves to useful works, such as manual labor schools, and other educational institutions; -- called also Brothers of the Third Order of St. Francis.
nuns who follow the rule of St. Francis, esp. those of the Second Order of St. Francis, -- called also Poor Clares or Minoresses.
the Third Order of St. Francis.

entry.ety: LL. Franciscus Francis: cf. F. franciscain
entry.def: Belonging to the Order of St. Francis of the Franciscans.

A monk or friar of the Order of St. Francis, a large and zealous order of mendicant monks founded in 1209 by St. Francis of Assisi. They are called also Friars Minor; and in England, Gray Friars, because they wear a gray habit.

entry.ety: F.; cf. It. francolino, Sp. francolin
entry.def: A spurred partidge of the genus Francolinus and allied genera, of Asia and Africa. The common species (F. vulgaris) was formerly common in southern Europe, but is now nearly restricted to Asia.
A variety of apatite from Wheal Franco in Devonshire.
An admirer of France and everything French.
a person who hates or fears France, French culture, or the French people.
Able to communicate in the French language; -- used especially of those whose native language is French.
a sharpshooter (in the French army).

entry.ety: L. frangens, p. pr. of frangere. See Fraction
entry.def: Causing fracture; breaking.

entry.ety: Cf. F. frangibilité
entry.def: The state or quality of being frangible.

entry.ety: Cf. F. frangible
entry.def: Capable of being broken; brittle; fragile; easily broken.

entry.ety: F. frangipane; supposed to be called so from the inventor, the Marquis Frangipani, major general under Louis XIV

sn.def: A perfume of jasmine; frangipani.
A species of pastry, containing cream and almonds.

entry.ety: Another spelling of frangipane
entry.def: A perfume derived from, or imitating the odor of, the flower of the red jasmine, a West Indian tree of the genus Plumeria.

cs.cd: a yellow crystalline substance, resembling alizarin, and obtained by the decomposition of frangulin.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or drived from, frangulin, or a species (Rhamnus Frangula) of the buckthorn.
A yellow crystalline dyestuff, regarded as a glucoside, extracted from a species (Rhamnus Frangula) of the buckthorn; -- called also rhamnoxanthin.

entry.ety: Perh. from F. fainéant an idler
entry.def: A paramour; a loose woman; also, a gay, idle fellow.

entry.ety: OF. franc
entry.def: A pigsty.
To shut up in a frank or sty; to pen up; hence, to cram; to fatten.
The common heron; -- so called from its note.

entry.ety: F. franc free, frank, L. Francus a Frank, fr. OHG. Franko the name of a Germanic people on the Rhine, who afterward founded the French monarchy; cf. AS. franca javelin, Icel. frakka. Cf. Franc French a. Franchise n.

sn.def: Unbounded by restrictions, limitations, etc.; free.
sn.q: It is offrankgift.

sn.def: Free in uttering one's real sentiments; not reserved; using no disguise; candid; ingenuous; as, a frank nature, conversation, manner, etc.
Liberal; generous; profuse.
sn.q: Frank of civilities that cost them nothing.

sn.def: Unrestrained; loose; licentious; -- used in a bad sense.
sn.syn: Ingenuous; candid; artless; plain; open; unreserved; undisguised; sincere. See Candid Ingenuous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. franked frăṉkt; p. pr. & vb. n. franking

sn.def: To send by public conveyance free of expense.
To extempt from charge for postage, as a letter, package, or packet, etc.

entry.ety: See Frank a.
entry.def: The privilege of sending letters or other mail matter, free of postage, or without charge; also, the sign, mark, or signature denoting that a letter or other mail matter is to go free of postage. Called also the franking privilege .
entry.q: I have said so much, that, if I had not a frank, I must burn my letter and begin again.

entry.ety: Cf. F. franc. See Frank a.

sn.def: A member of one of the German tribes that in the fifth century overran and conquered Gaul, and established the kingdom of France.
A native or inhabitant of Western Europe; a European; -- a term used in the Levant.
A French coin. See Franc.

entry.ety: F. franc free + Norm. F. almoigne alma, for almosne, F. aumône. See Frank a., and Almoner
entry.def: A tenure by which a religious corporation holds lands given to them and their successors forever, usually on condition of praying for the soul of the donor and his heirs; -- called also tenure by free alms.

entry.ety: Frank free + chase
entry.def: The liberty or franchise of having a chase; free chase.

entry.ety: Frank free + fee
entry.def: A species of tenure in fee simple, being the opposite of ancient demesne, or copyhold.

entries.entry: Frank"fort black`. A black pigment used in copperplate printing, prepared by burning vine twigs, the lees of wine, etc.

entry.ety: OF. franc free, pure + encens incense
entry.def: A fragrant, aromatic resin, or gum resin, burned as an incense in religious rites or for medicinal fumigation. The best kinds now come from East Indian trees, of the genus Boswellia; a commoner sort, from the Norway spruce (Abies excelsa) and other coniferous trees. The frankincense of the ancient Jews is still unidentified.
A method of forming a joint at the intersection of window-sash bars, by cutting away only enough wood to show a miter.
Like, or pertaining to, the Franks.

entry.ety: Frank free + law
entry.def: The liberty of being sworn in courts, as a juror or witness; one of the ancient privileges of a freeman; free and common law; -- an obsolete expression signifying substantially the same as the American expression civil rights.

entry.ety: OE. frankelein; cf. LL. franchilanus. See Frank a.
entry.def: An English freeholder, or substantial householder.
entry.q: The franklin, a small landholder of those days.

cs.cd: electricity produced by friction; called also static electricity.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Benjamin Franklin.
A kind of mineral of the spinel group.

entries.entry: Frank"lin stove`. A kind of open stove introduced by Benjamin Franklin , the peculiar feature of which was that a current of heated air was directly supplied to the room from an air box; -- now applied to other varieties of open stoves.

entry.def: In a frank manner; freely.
entry.q: Very frankly he confessed his treasons.
entry.syn: Openly; ingenuously; plainly; unreservedly; undisguisedly; sincerely; candidly; artlessly; freely; readily; unhesitatingly; liberally; willingly.

entry.ety: Frank free + marriage
entry.def: A certain tenure in tail special; an estate of inheritance given to a man his wife (the wife being of the blood of the donor), and descendible to the heirs of their two bodies begotten.
The quality of being frank; candor; openess; ingenuousness; fairness; liberality.

entry.ety: Frank free + pledge
entry.def: A pledge or surety for the good behavior of freemen, -- each freeman who was a member of an ancient decennary, tithing, or friborg, in England, being a pledge for the good conduct of the others, for the preservation of the public peace; a free surety.
The tithing itself.
entry.q: The servants of the crown were not, as now, bound in frankpledge for each other.

entry.ety: OE. frentik frenetik, F. frentique, L. phreneticus, from Gr. �. See Frenzy, and cf. Frenetic Phrenetic
entry.def: Mad; raving; furious; violent; wild and disorderly; distracted.
entry.q: Die, frantic wretch, for this accursed deed!
Torrents of frantic abuse.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frapped; p. pr. & vb. n. Frapping
entry.ety: Cf. F. frapper to strike, to seize ropes. Cf. Affrap

sn.def: To draw together; to bind with a view to secure and strengthen, as a vessel by passing cables around it; to tighten; as a tackle by drawing the lines together.
To brace by drawing together, as the cords of a drum.

entry.ety: Cf. frap, and Prov. E. frape to scold
entry.def: A crowd, a rabble.
A blusterer; a rowdy.
entry.q: Unpolished, a frapler, and base.

entry.ety: F., p.p. of frapper to strike, to chill
entry.def: Iced; frozen; artificially cooled; as, wine frappé .

def2.def: A frappé mixture or beverage, as a water ice, variously flavored, frozen soft, and served in glasses; also, a milk shake.

entry.ety: From Frap
entry.def: A lashing binding a thing tightly or binding things together.
A genus of North American herbs: columbo; it includes some species sometimes placed in the genus Swertia.
a social club for male college undergraduates; a shortened form of fraternity.
a house used by a chapter of a fraternity at a college.

cs.cd: an apartament in a convent used as an eating room; a refectory; -- called also a fratery.

entry.ety: L., a brother
entry.def: A monk; also, a frater house.
a genus of sea birds, one of the genera of puffins.

entry.ety: F. fraternel, LL. fraternalis, fr. L. fraternus, fr. frater brother. See Brother
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or involving, brethren; becoming to brothers; brotherly; as, fraternal affection; a fraternal embrace.
entry.q: An abhorred, a cursed, a fraternal war.
Fraternal love and friendship.

entry.def: To fraternize; to hold fellowship.
Fraternization.

entries.entry:
Fra*ter"ni*ty n.; pl.Fraternities #. F. fraternité, L. fraternitas
The state or quality of being fraternal or brotherly; brotherhood.
A body of men associated for their common interest, business, or pleasure; a company; a brotherhood; a society; in the Roman Catholic Church, an association for special religious purposes, for relieving the sick and destitute, etc.
Men of the same class, profession, occupation, character, or tastes. With what terms of respect knaves and sots will speak of their own fraternity!
A social club for male college undergraduates. They often have secret initiation rites, and are named by the use of two or three Greek letters. The corresponding association for women students is called a sorority. frat.

entry.def: The act of fraternizing or uniting as brothers.
entry.q: I hope that no French fraternization . . . could so change the hearts of Englishmen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fraternized #; p. pr. & vb. n.. Fraternizing #
entry.ety: Cf. F. fraterniser
entry.def: To associate or hold fellowship as brothers, or as men of like occupation or character; to have brotherly feelings.
To bring into fellowship or brotherly sympathy.
entry.q: Correspondence for fraternizing the two nations.

entry.def: One who fraternizes.

entry.ety: L. frater brother: cf. It. frateria a brotherhood of monks. See Friar
entry.def: A frater house. See under Frater.

entry.ety: L. frater a brother
entry.def: A sharing among brothers, or brothers' kin.

entry.ety: It. fraticelli, lit., little brothers, dim. fr. frate brother, L. frater
entry.def: The name which St. Francis of Assisi gave to his followers, early in the 13th century.

A sect which seceded from the Franciscan Order, chiefly in Italy and Sicily, in 1294, repudiating the pope as an apostate, maintaining the duty of celibacy and poverty, and discountenancing oaths. Called also Fratricellians and Fraticelli.
Of or pertaining to fratricide; of the nature of fratricide.

entry.ety: L. fratricidium a brother's murder, fr. fratricida a brother's murderer; frater fratris, brother + caedere to kill: cf. F. fratricide

sn.def: The act of one who murders or kills his own brother.
One who murders or kills his own brother.

entries.entry:
‖Frau frou n.; pl. Frauen frou"�n . G. Cf. 1st Frow
In Germany, a woman; a married woman; a wife; -- as a title, equivalent to Mrs. Madam.

cs.cd: an act, statement, or omission which operates as a fraud, although perhaps not intended to be such.
a fraud contrived and executed to benefit the church or accomplish some good end, upon the theory that the end justified the means.

an English statute (1676), the principle of which is incorporated in the legislation of all the States of this country, by which writing with specific solemnities (varying in the several statutes) is required to give efficacy to certain dispositions of property.

entry.ety: F. fraude, L. fraus fraudis; prob. akin to Skr. dhūrv to injure, dhvṛ to cause to fall, and E. dull

sn.def: Deception deliberately practiced with a view to gaining an unlawful or unfair advantage; artifice by which the right or interest of another is injured; injurious stratagem; deceit; trick.
sn.q: If success a lover's toil attends, Few ask, if fraud or force attained his ends.

sn.def: An intentional perversion of truth for the purpose of obtaining some valuable thing or promise from another.
A trap or snare.
sn.q: To draw the proud King Ahab into fraud.
sn.syn: Deception; deceit; guile; craft; wile; sham; strife; circumvention; stratagem; trick; imposition; cheat. See Deception.

entry.def: Full of fraud, deceit, or treachery; trickish; treacherous; fraudulent; -- applied to persons or things.
Free from fraud.

entry.ety: L. fraudulentia
entry.def: The quality of being fraudulent; deliberate deceit; trickishness.

entry.ety: L. fraudulentus, fr. fraus fraudis, fraud: cf. F. fraudulent

sn.def: Using fraud; tricky; deceitful; dishonest.
Characterized by, founded on, or proceeding from, fraud; as, a fraudulent bargain.
sn.q: He, with serpent tongue, . . . His fraudulent temptation thus began.

sn.def: Obtained or performed by artifice; as, fraudulent conquest.
sn.syn: Deceitful; fraudful; guileful; crafty; wily; cunning; subtle; deceiving; cheating; deceptive; insidious; treacherous; dishonest; designing; unfair.

entry.def: In a fraudulent manner.

entry.ety: OE.fraight fraght; akin to Dan. fragt, Sw. frakt, D. vracht, G. fracht, cf. OHG. frēht merit, reward; perh. from a pref. corresponding to E. for + The root of E. own. Cf. Freight
entry.def: A freight; a cargo.
Freighted; laden; filled; stored; charged.
entry.q: A vessel of our country richly fraught.
A discourse fraught with all the commending excellences of speech.
Enterprises fraught with world-wide benefits.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fraughted or Fraught; p. pr. & vb. n. Fraughting
entry.ety: Akin to Dan. fragte, Sw. frakta, D. bevrachten, G. frachten, cf. OHG. frēhtōn to deserve. See Fraught n.
entry.def: To freight; to load; to burden; to fill; to crowd.
entry.q: Upon the tumbling billows fraughted ride The armed ships.

entry.def: Freight; loading; cargo.
Constituting the freight or cargo.
entry.q: Thefraughtingsouls within her.

entry.ety: G., dim. of frau woman. See Frau
entry.def: In Germany, a young lady; an unmarried woman; -- as a title, equivalent to Miss.

entries.entry: Fraun"ho*fer lines` prop. n. pl.. Physics The lines of the spectrum; especially and properly, the dark lines of the solar spectrum, so called because first accurately observed and interpreted by Fraunhofer , a German physicist.

frax"in n. From Fraxinus
Chem A colorless crystalline substance (C16H18O10) found in the bark of the ash (Fraxinus), and along with esculin in the bark of the horse-chestnut. It is structurally a derivative of a coumarin glucoside. It shows a delicate blue-green fluorescence in alkaline solutions; -- called also paviin and fraxoside. MI-11br/
8-(β-D-Glucopyranosyloxy)-7-hydroxy-6-methoxy-2H-1-benzopyran-2-one; also, 7,8-dihydroxy-6-methoxy-coumarin-8-β-D-glucoside; fraxetin-8-glucoside.

entry.note: ☞ Fraxinus excelsior is the European ash; Fraxinus Americana, the white ash; Fraxinus sambucifolia, the black ash or water ash.
entry.ety: L., the ash tree
entry.def: A genus of deciduous forest trees, found in the north temperate zone, and including the true ash trees.

entry.ety: Abbreviated from affray
entry.def: An angry quarrel; an affray; contest; combat; broil.
entry.q: Who began this bloody fray?

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frayed frād; p. pr. & vb. n. Fraying
entry.ety: See 1st Fray, and cf. Affray
entry.def: To frighten; to terrify; to alarm.
entry.q: What frays ye, that were wont to comfort me affrayed?

entry.ety: Cf. OF. fraier. See Defray v. t.
entry.def: To bear the expense of; to defray.
entry.q: The charge of my most curious and costly ingredients frayed, I shall acknowledge myself amply satisfied.

entry.ety: OF. freier fraier froier, to rub. L. fricare; cf. friare to crumble, E. friable; perh. akin to Gr. chri`ein to anoint, chri^sma an anointing, Skr. ghṛsh to rub, scratch. Cf. Friction
entry.def: To rub; to wear off, or wear into shreds, by rubbing; to fret, as cloth; as, a deer is said to fray her head.

sn.def: To rub.
sn.q: We can show the marks he made When 'gainst the oak his antlers frayed.

sn.def: To wear out or into shreads, or to suffer injury by rubbing, as when the threads of the warp or of the woof wear off so that the cross threads are loose; to ravel; as, the cloth frays badly.
sn.q: A suit of frayed magnificience.

entry.def: A fret or chafe, as in cloth; a place injured by rubbing.
The skin which a deer frays from his horns.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frazzled; p. pr. & vb. n. Frazzling
entry.ety: Cf. G. faseln, and E. fray
entry.def: To fray; to wear or pull into tatters or tag ends; to tatter; -- used literally and figuratively.
entry.q: Her hair was of a reddish gray color, and its frazzled and tangled condition suggested that the woman had recently passed through a period of extreme excitement.

sn.def: The act or result of frazzling; the condition or quality of being frazzled; the tag end; a frayed-out end.
sn.q: My fingers are all scratched to frazzles.

sn.def: a state of extreme exhaustion; -- often used in the phrase worn to a frazzle.
sn.q: Gordon had sent word to Lee that he “had fought his corps to a frazzle.”

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Freaked frēkt; p. pr. & vb. n. Freaking
entry.ety: Akin to OE. frakin freken, freckle, Icel. freknur, pl., Sw. fräkne, Dan. fregne, Gr. perkno`s dark-colored, Skr. pṛçni variegated. Cf. Freckle Freck
entry.def: To variegate; to checker; to streak.
entry.q: Freaked with many a mingled hue.

entry.ety: Prob. from OE. frek bold, AS. frec bold, greedly; akin to OHG. freh greedly, G. frech insolent, Icel. frekr greedy, Goth. faíhufriks avaricious

sn.def: A sudden causeless change or turn of the mind; a whim of fancy; a capricious prank; a vagary or caprice.
sn.q: She is restless and peevish, and sometimes in a freak will instantly change her habitation.

sn.def: a rare and unpredictable event; as, the July snowstorm was a freak of nature.
an habitual drug user, especially one who uses psychedelic drugs.
an animal or person with a visible congenital abnormality; -- applied especially to those who appear in a circus sideshow.
sn.syn: Whim; caprice; folly; sport. See Whim.

sn.def: to react with irrationality or extreme emotion; to lose one's composure; -- often used in the phrase freak out.
to become irrational or to experience hallucinations under the influence of drugs; -- often used in the phrase freak out.
to cause (a person) react with great distress or extreme emotion; -- often used in the phrase freak out.

entry.def: Freakish.
Apt to change the mind suddenly; whimsical; capricious.
entry.q: It may be a question whether the wife or the woman was the more freakish of the two.
Freakish when well, and fretful when she's sick.

sn.def: rapidly changing and unpredictable; as, freakish weather.
markedly abnormal.

entry.def: marked strangeness or abnormality.
markedly unusual or abnormal; as, freaky weather.

entry.ety: Cf. Freak v. t. Freckle
entry.def: To checker; to diversify.
entry.q: The painted windows, frecking gloom with glow.

entry.ety: Dim., from the same root as freak v. t.

sn.def: A small yellowish or brownish spot in the skin, particularly on the face, neck, or hands.
Any small spot or discoloration.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Freckled frĕk"k'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Freckling frĕk"klĭng
entry.def: To sprinkle or mark with freckles or small discolored spots; to spot.
To become covered or marked with freckles; to be spotted.
Marked with freckles; spotted.
entry.q: Thefreckledtrout.
The freckled cowslip, burnet, and green clover.

entry.def: The state of being freckled.
Full of or marked with freckles; sprinkled with spots; freckled.

entry.ety: AS. frið peace. See Frith inclosure
entry.def: Peace; -- a word used in composition, especially in proper names; as, Alfred; Frederic.
See Fridstol.

entry.cs:
Free agency the capacity or power of choosing or acting freely, or without necessity or constraint upon the will. Free bench Eng. Law a widow's right in the copyhold lands of her husband, corresponding to dower in freeholds. Free board Naut a vessel's side between water line and gunwale. Free bond Chem an unsaturated or unemployed unit, or bond, of affinity or valence, of an atom or radical. Free-borough men O.Eng. Law. See Friborg. Free chapel Eccles a chapel not subject to the jurisdiction of the ordinary, having been founded by the king or by a subject specially authorized. Eng Bouvier. Free charge Elec a charge of electricity in the free or statical condition; free electricity. Free church. A church whose sittings are for all and without charge. An ecclesiastical body that left the Church of Scotland, in 1843, to be free from control by the government in spiritual matters.
Free cityorFree town
a city or town independent in its government and franchises, as formerly those of the Hanseatic league. Free cost freedom from charges or expenses. South. Free and easy unconventional; unrestrained; regardless of formalities. Colloq “Sal and her free and easy ways.” W. Black. Free goods goods admitted into a country free of duty. Free labor the labor of freemen, as distinguished from that of slaves. Free port. Com A port where goods may be received and shipped free of custom duty. A port where goods of all kinds are received from ships of all nations at equal rates of duty. Free public house in England, a tavern not belonging to a brewer, so that the landlord is free to brew his own beer or purchase where he chooses. Simmonds. Free school. A school to which pupils are admitted without discrimination and on an equal footing. A school supported by general taxation, by endowmants, etc., where pupils pay nothing for tuition; a public school. Free services O.Eng. Law such feudal services as were not unbecoming the character of a soldier or a freemen to perform; as, to serve under his lord in war, to pay a sum of money, etc. Burrill. Free ships ships of neutral nations, which in time of war are free from capture even though carrying enemy's goods. Free socage O.Eng. Law a feudal tenure held by certain services which, though honorable, were not military. Abbott. Free States those of the United States before the Civil War, in which slavery had ceased to exist, or had never existed. Free stuff Carp timber free from knots; clear stuff. Free thought that which is thought independently of the authority of others. Free trade commerce unrestricted by duties or tariff regulations. Free trader one who believes in free trade. To make free with to take liberties with; to help one's self to. Colloq To sail free Naut to sail with the yards not braced in as sharp as when sailing closehauled, or close to the wind.
entry.ety: OE. fre freo, AS. freó frī; akin to D. vrij, OS. & OHG. frī, G. frei, Icel. frī, Sw. & Dan. fri, Goth. freis, and also to Skr. prija beloved, dear, fr. prī to love, Goth. frijōn. Cf. Affray Belfry Friday Friend Frith inclosure

sn.def: Exempt from subjection to the will of others; not under restraint, control, or compulsion; able to follow one's own impulses, desires, or inclinations; determining one's own course of action; not dependent; at liberty.
sn.q: That which has the power, or not the power, to operate, is that alone which is or is not free.

sn.def: Not under an arbitrary or despotic government; subject only to fixed laws regularly and fairly administered, and defended by them from encroachments upon natural or acquired rights; enjoying political liberty.
Liberated, by arriving at a certain age, from the control of parents, guardian, or master.
Not confined or imprisoned; released from arrest; liberated; at liberty to go.
sn.q: Set an unhappy prisoner free.

sn.def: Not subjected to the laws of physical necessity; capable of voluntary activity; endowed with moral liberty; -- said of the will.
sn.q: Not free, what proof could they have given sincere Of true allegiance, constant faith, or love.

sn.def: Clear of offense or crime; guiltless; innocent.
sn.q: My hands are guilty, but my heart is free.

sn.def: Unconstrained by timidity or distrust; unreserved; ingenuous; frank; familiar; communicative.
sn.q: He was free only with a few.

sn.def: Unrestrained; immoderate; lavish; licentious; -- used in a bad sense.
sn.q: The critics have been very free in their censures.
A man may live a free life as to wine or women.

sn.def: Not close or parsimonious; liberal; open-handed; lavish; as, free with his money.
Exempt; clear; released; liberated; not encumbered or troubled with; as, free from pain; free from a burden; -- followed by from, or, rarely, by of.
sn.q: Princes declaring themselves free from the obligations of their treaties.

sn.def: Characteristic of one acting without restraint; charming; easy.
Ready; eager; acting without spurring or whipping; spirited; as, a free horse.
Invested with a particular freedom or franchise; enjoying certain immunities or privileges; admitted to special rights; -- followed by of.
sn.q: He therefore makes all birds, of every sect,Free of his farm.

sn.def: Thrown open, or made accessible, to all; to be enjoyed without limitations; unrestricted; not obstructed, engrossed, or appropriated; open; -- said of a thing to be possessed or enjoyed; as, a free school.
sn.q: Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as free For me as for you?
