sn.def: Not gained by importunity or purchase; gratuitous; spontaneous; as, free admission; a free gift.
Not arbitrary or despotic; assuring liberty; defending individual rights against encroachment by any person or class; instituted by a free people; -- said of a government, institutions, etc.
Certain or honorable; the opposite of base; as, free service; free socage.
Privileged or individual; the opposite of common; as, a free fishery; a free warren.
Not united or combined with anything else; separated; dissevered; unattached; at liberty to escape; as, free carbonic acid gas; free cells.
Freely; willingly.
sn.q: I as free forgive you As I would be forgiven.

sn.def: Without charge; as, children admitted free .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Freed; p. pr. & vb. n. Freeing
entry.ety: OE. freen freoien, AS. freógan. See Free a.

sn.def: To make free; to set at liberty; to rid of that which confines, limits, embarrasses, oppresses, etc.; to release; to disengage; to clear; -- followed by from, and sometimes by off; as, to free a captive or a slave; to be freed of these inconveniences.
sn.q: Our land is from the rage of tigers freed.
Arise, . . . free thy people from their yoke.

sn.def: To remove, as something that confines or bars; to relieve from the constraint of.
sn.q: This master keyFrees every lock, and leads us to his person.

sn.def: To frank.
unconstrained and informal; as, an informal free-and-easy manner. Opposite of stiff starchy formal.
lacking normal concern for propriety.

entry.def: to express one's thoughts, ideas, impressions, etc. in an unplanned and unstructured way, allowing each thought or idea to prompt recollection of the next one. It is a process used in psychotherapy.
The act or process of free-associating. It is a technique used in psychoanalysis and is supposed to allow the analyst access to the unconscious thoughts of the analysand. See free-associate.

sn.def: The basic form of an organic amine which is capable of forming acid salts such as hydrochlorides.
The basic form of a drug, often more powerful than a salt form because it is more readily absorbed into the blood stream.

entry.def: To ingest the basic form of a narcotic drug, usually by injection.

entry.ety: D. vrijbuiter, fr. vrijbuiten to plunder; vrij free + buit booty, akin to E. booty. See Free, and Booty, and cf. Filibuster
entry.def: One who plunders or pillages without the authority of national warfare; a member of a predatory band; a pillager; a buccaneer; a sea robber.
The act, practice, or gains of a freebooter; freebooting.
Robbery; plunder; a pillaging.
Acting the freebooter; practicing freebootery; robbing.
entry.q: Your freebooting acquaintance.

entry.def: Freebootery.
Born free; not born in vassalage; inheriting freedom.
burning in a continuous manner; -- of an electric arc; as, heat transfer to the anode in free-burning arcs.

entries.entry: Free coinage. In the fullest sense, the conversion of bullion (of any specified metal) into legal-tender coins for any person who chooses to bring it to the mint; in a modified sense, such coinage when done at a fixed charge proportionate to the cost of the operation.

entry.def: To make free.

entries.entry: Freed"man n.; pl.Freedmen. A man who has been a slave, and has been set free.

cs.cd: a sum paid on entry to incorporations of trades.
the possession of the rights and privileges of a freeman of the city; formerly often, and now occasionally, conferred on one not a resident, as a mark of honorary distinction for public services.

entry.ety: AS. freódōm; freófree + -dom. See Free, and -dom

sn.def: The state of being free; exemption from the power and control of another; liberty; independence.
sn.q: Made captive, yet deserving freedom more.

sn.def: Privileges; franchises; immunities.
sn.q: Your charter and your caty's freedom.

sn.def: Exemption from necessity, in choise and action; as, the freedom of the will.
Ease; facility; as, he speaks or acts with freedom .
Frankness; openness; unreservedness.
sn.q: I emboldened spake and freedom used.

sn.def: Improper familiarity; violation of the rules of decorum; license.
Generosity; liberality.

entry.def: See Fridstol.
a woman who has been freed from slavery. Correlative of freedman.

sn.def: an economic system having predominantly private ownership of the means of production, and relying chiefly on market forces to allocate goods and resources and to determine prices, and having a minimum of governmental interference in economic decisions; also, the political doctrine advocating such a system as the economic system of a country.
The conduct of business according to the principles of the free enterprise doctrine; the conduct of economic activity without governmental interference.

entries.entry: free-enterprise adj. Of or pertaining to the free enterprise system having private ownership of the means of production and competition between enterprises. prenominalNarrower terms: capitalistic, capitalist socialistic competitive, private-enterprise(prenominal).

sn.def: a noisy and disordered fight conducted without rules.

Any vigorous competition in which anyone can compete, with few or no rules, and in which the winner is unpredictable; as, when they began to distribute the free food, the orderly line of hungry recipients degenerated into a free-for-all .

entry.def: Done by the hand, without support, or the guidance of instruments; -- of drawing or sculpture; as, free-hand drawing. See under Drawing.

sn.def: Open-handed; liberal; given or giving freely or liberally; as, a freehanded host.
sn.syn: big, bighearted, bounteous, bountiful, handsome, giving, liberal, openhanded.

sn.def: same as freehand.

entry.def: Open; frank; unreserved; liberal; generous; as, free-hearted mirth. Opposite of stingy.

entry.cs: To abate into a freehold. See under Abate.
entry.def: An estate in real property, of inheritance (in fee simple or fee tail) or for life; or the tenure by which such estate is held.
The possessor of a freehold.

sn.def: a person who acts independently or without authorization of an organization or of his superiors.

a person who pursues a profession independently, and not as the employee of an organization; -- used especially of writers or photographers who sell their work to organizations of which they are not employees.

entry.def: of or pertaining to a freelance{2; as, a freelance photographer.
to work on a free-lance basis; to work as a freelancer.
a freelance{2 n.
One who gratifies his physical appetites without stint; one given to indulgence in eating and drinking.
Unrestrained indulgence of the appetites as a way of life.

entry.note: eating other organisms is not considered "dependence" in this sense.
entry.def: Living independently of other organisms; not parasitic or commensal.
The doctrine or practice of consorting with the opposite sex, at pleasure, without marriage.
One who believes in or practices free-love.
Frailty.

entry.ety: AS. freólice
entry.def: In a free manner; without restraint or compulsion; abundantly; gratuitously.
entry.q: Of every tree of the garden thou mayst freely eat.
Freely ye have received, freely give.
Freely they stood who stood, and fell who fell.
Freely we serve Because we freely love.
entry.syn: Independently; voluntarily; spontaneously; unconditionally; unobstructedly; willingly; readily; liberally; generously; bounteously; munificently; bountifully; abundantly; largely; copiously; plentifully; plenteously.

entries.entry:
Free"man n.; pl.Freemen #. AS. freóman; freófree + mann man
One who enjoys liberty, or who is not subject to the will of another; one not a slave or vassal.
A member of a corporation, company, or city, possessing certain privileges; a member of a borough, town, or State, who has the right to vote at elections. See Liveryman. Both having been made freemen on the same day.

entry.def: An imperfect female calf, twinborn with a male, which is sterile as a result of exposure to masculinizing hormones.

One of an ancient and secret association or fraternity, said to have been at first composed of masons or builders in stone, but now consisting of persons who are united for social enjoyment and mutual assistance.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the institutions or the practices of freemasons; as, a freemasonic signal.
The institutions or the practices of freemasons.
Yielding free gold or silver; -- said of certain ores which can be reduced by crushing and amalgamation, without roasting or other chemical treatment.
Not perplexed; having a mind free from care.
The state or quality of being free; freedom; liberty; openness; liberality; gratuitousness.
One who frees, or sets free.
permitted to graze or forage rather than being confined to a feedlot; -- of livestock and domestic poultry.
a reed that does not fit closely over the aperture.

entries.entry: Free silver. The free coinage of silver; often, specif., the free coinage of silver at a fixed ratio with gold, as at the ratio of 16 to 1, which ratio for some time represented nearly or exactly the ratio of the market values of gold and silver respectively.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or advocating, the non-extension of slavery; -- esp. applied to a party which was active during the period 1846-1856.
Pertaining to territory where slavery was prohibited.

entry.def: Accustomed to speak without reserve; willing to speak out without subtlety.
entry.syn: bluff, blunt, candid, frank, outspoken, plainspoken, point-blank.

entry.def: A stone composed of sand or grit; -- so called because it is easily cut or wrought.
Having the flesh readily separating from the stone, as in certain kinds of peaches.

sn.def: Swimming in the open sea; -- said of certain marine animals.
able to swim about; not attached to a stationary object; -- of aquatic animals.

entry.def: A small swift bat with leathery ears and a long tail; common in warm regions.
A small swift bat with leathery ears and a long tail; common in warm regions.

One who speculates or forms opinions independently of the authority of others; esp., in the sphere or religion, one who forms opinions independently of the authority of revelation or of the church; an unbeliever; -- a term assumed by deists and skeptics in the eighteenth century.
entry.q: Atheist is an old-fashioned word: I'm a freethinker, child.

entry.def: Undue boldness of speculation; unbelief.
inclined to forms one's own opinions rather than depend upon authority, especially about social and religious issues; exhibiting boldness of speculation; skeptical of authority.
Speaking without reserve.

A clutch fitted in the rear hub of a cycle, which engages the rear sprocket with the rear wheel when the pedals are rotated forwards, but permits the rear wheel to run on free from the rear sprocket when the pedals are stopped or rotated backwards. Freewheelcycles are usually fitted with hub brakes or rim brakes, operated by back pedaling.

sd.def: Of a freewheel cycle, to run on while the pedals are held still.
Of a person, to ride a cycle of this manner; to coast in a vehicle having a freewheel. To ride a freewheel cycle.

sn.def: To operate like a freewheel, so that one part moves freely over another which normally moves with it; -- said of a clutch.
to act without controls, external or internal; to live freely, independently, and without concern; -- of people.

entry.def: someone acting freely or even irresponsibly.
acting heedless of consequences; acting without controls, external or internal; as, freewheeling foolishness.

entries.entry:
Free will. A will free from improper coercion or restraint. To come thus was I not constrained, but did On my free will.
The power asserted of moral beings of willing or choosing without the restraints of physical or absolute necessity.

entry.cs: Freewill Baptists. See under Baptist.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to free will; voluntary; spontaneous; as, a freewill offering.
Capable of being frozen.
A frieze.

entry.note: ☞ Water freezes at 32° above zero by Fahrenheit's thermometer; mercury freezes at 40° below zero.
entry.cs: To freeze up Fig.), to become formal and cold in demeanor. Colloq
entry.vmorph: imp. Froze frōz; p. p. Frozen frō"z'n; p. pr. & vb. n. Freezing
entry.ety: OE. fresen freosen, AS. freósan; akin to D. vriezen, OHG. iosan, G. frieren, Icel. frjsa, Sw. frysa, Dan. fryse, Goth. frius cold, frost, and prob. to L. prurire to itch, E. prurient, cf. L. prna a burning coal, pruina hoarfrost, Skr. prushvā ice, prush to spirt. � 18. Cf. Frost

sn.def: To become congealed by cold; to be changed from a liquid to a solid state by the abstraction of heat; to be hardened into ice or a like solid body.
To become chilled with cold, or as with cold; to suffer loss of animation or life by lack of heat; as, the blood freezes in the veins.

cs.cd: to drive out or exclude by cold or by cold treatment; to force to withdraw; as, to be frozen out of one's room in winter; to freeze out a competitor.
cs.q: A railroad which had a London connection must not be allowed to freeze out one that had no such connection.
It is sometimes a long time before a player who is frozen out can get into a game again.

cs.cd: to drive out or exclude by cold or by cold treatment; to force to withdraw; as, to be frozen out of one's room in winter; to freeze out a competitor.
cs.q: A railroad which had a London connection must not be allowed to freeze out one that had no such connection.
It is sometimes a long time before a player who is frozen out can get into a game again.

sn.def: To congeal; to harden into ice; to convert from a fluid to a solid form by cold, or abstraction of heat.
To cause loss of animation or life in, from lack of heat; to give the sensation of cold to; to chill.
sn.q: A faint, cold fear runs through my veins, That almost freezes up the heat of life.

entry.def: The act of congealing, or the state of being congealed.

entry.note: This technique is gentler than other drying techniques and caused less damage or deterioration to sensitive substances. It is used primarily as a method to preserve foods or substances, and permit storage without deterioration.
entry.def: dried by freezing and applying a vacuum; -- used of tissue or blood or serum or other biological substances.

entry.note: This is a relatively gently drying process used to preserve food or sensitive biological materials. For biochemical materials, the term lyophilize is often used.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Freeze-dried; p. pr. & vb. n. Freeze-drying
entry.def: to remove the moisture from (e.g. food) by first freezing and then subjecting to a high vacuum; -- used as a mild method for drying foods or chemicals while causing little decomposition, in contrast to heat-drying.
One who, or that which, cools or freezes, as a refrigerator, or the tub and can used in the process of freezing ice cream.

entry.cs: Freezing machine. See Ice machine, under Ice. Freezing mixture a mixture (of salt and snow or of chemical salts) for producing intense cold. Freezing point that degree of a thermometer at which a fluid begins to freeze; -- applied particularly to water, whose freezing point is at 32° Fahr., and at 0° Centigrade.
entry.def: Tending to freeze; for freezing; hence, cold or distant in manner.
The type genus of the Fregatidae.
A natural family including the genus Fregata, of frigate birds.

entry.ety: Named after the German chemist Freiesleben
entry.def: A sulphide of antimony, lead, and silver, occuring in monoclinic crystals.

entry.ety: F. fret, OHG. frēht merit, reward. See Fraught n.

sn.def: That with which anything is fraught or laden for transportation; lading; cargo, especially of a ship, or a car on a railroad, etc.; as, a freight of cotton; a full freight.

sd.def: The sum paid by a party hiring a ship or part of a ship for the use of what is thus hired.
The price paid a common carrier for the carriage of goods.

sn.def: Freight transportation, or freight line.

entry.cs: Freight agent a person employed by a transportation company to receive, forward, or deliver goods. Freight car. See under Car. Freight train a railroad train made up of freight cars; -- called in England goods train.
entry.def: Employed in the transportation of freight; having to do with freight; as, a freight car.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Freighted; p. pr. & vb. n. Freighting
entry.ety: Cf. F. freter
entry.def: To load with goods, as a ship, or vehicle of any kind, for transporting them from one place to another; to furnish with freight; as, to freight a ship; to freight a car.

sn.def: The charge for transportation; the expense of carriage.
The transportation of freight.
Freight; cargo; lading. Milton.
One who loads a ship, or one who charters and loads a ship.
One employed in receiving and forwarding freight.
One for whom freight is transported.
A vessel used mainly to carry freight.

entry.def: Destitute of freight.

entries.entry: ‖Frei"herr` n.; pl. Freiherrn # . G., lit., free lord In Germany and Austria, a baron.

entry.def: Frailty.

entry.ety: OE., from AS. fremede fremde; akin to G. fremd
entry.def: Strange; foreign.

entries.entry:
Fre*mes"cent
Fre*mes"cence # n.
a. L. fremere to roar, murmur + -escent
Becoming murmurous, roaring.
Fremescentclangor. Carlyle.

entry.ety: L., a murmuring, roaring
entry.def: Palpable vibration or thrill; as, the rhonchial fremitus .

entry.ety: OE. frenne, contr. fr. forrene foreign. See Foreign a.
entry.def: A stranger.

entry.cs:
French bean Bot the common kidney bean (Phaseolus vulgaris). French berry Bot the berry of a species of buckthorn (Rhamnus catharticus), which affords a saffron, green or purple pigment. French casement Arch See French window, under Window. French chalk Min a variety of granular talc; -- used for drawing lines on cloth, etc. See under Chalk. French cowslip Bot The Primula Auricula. See Bear's-ear. French fake Naut a mode of coiling a rope by running it backward and forward in parallel bends, so that it may run freely. French honeysuckle Bot a plant of the genus Hedysarum H. coronarium); -- called also garland honeysuckle. French horn a metallic wind instrument, consisting of a long tube twisted into circular folds and gradually expanding from the mouthpiece to the end at which the sound issues; -- called in France cor de chasse. French leave an informal, hasty, or secret departure; esp., the leaving a place without paying one's debts. French pie
Frenchhere used in sense of “foreign”) + pie a magpie (in allusion to its black and white color) Zoöl the European great spotted woodpecker (Dryobstes major); -- called also wood pie. French polish. A preparation for the surface of woodwork, consisting of gums dissolved in alcohol, either shellac alone, or shellac with other gums added. The glossy surface produced by the application of the above. French purple a dyestuff obtained from lichens and used for coloring woolen and silken fabrics, without the aid of mordants. Ure. French red rouge. French rice amelcorn. French roof Arch a modified form of mansard roof having a nearly flat deck for the upper slope. French tub a dyer's mixture of protochloride of tin and logwood; -- called also plum tub. Ure. French window. See under Window.
entry.ety: AS. frencisc, LL. franciscus, from L. Francus a Frank: cf. OF. franceis franchois françois, F. français. See Frank a., and cf. Frankish
entry.def: Of or pertaining to France or its inhabitants.

sn.def: The language spoken in France.
Collectively, the people of France.

entry.def: Strips of potatoes, usually cut with a rectangular cross-section, cooked by immersing in hot fat or oil.
to cook by immersing in hot fat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frenchified; p. pr. & vb. n. Frenchifying
entry.ety: French + -fy
entry.def: To make French; to infect or imbue with the manners or tastes of the French; to Gallicize.
A French mode or characteristic; an idiom peculiar to the French language.

entries.entry: French"man n.; pl.Frenchmen. A native or one of the people of France.

entry.def: able to communicate in French.

entry.ety: See Frantic a.
entry.def: Distracted; mad; frantic; phrenetic.
Frenetic; frantic; frenzied.

entries.entry:
Fre"num n.; pl. E. Frenums #, L. Frena #. L., a bridle
Zoöl A cheek stripe of color.
Anat Same as Frænum.

entry.def: Frantic.
Affected with frenzy; frantic; maddened.
entry.q: The people frenzied by centuries of oppression.
Up starting with a frenzied look.

entries.entry:
Fren"zy frĕn"z� n.; pl.Frenzies frĕn"zĭz. OE. frenesie fransey, F. frénésie, L. phrenesis, fr. Gr. fre`nhsis for freni^tis disease of the mind, phrenitis, fr. frhn mind. Cf. Frantic Phrenitis
Any violent agitation of the mind approaching to distraction; violent and temporary derangement of the mental faculties; madness; rage. All else is towering frenzy and distraction. The poet's eye in a fine frenzy rolling. Insanity; lunacy; madness; derangement; alienation; aberration; delirium. See Insanity.

entry.def: Mad; frantic.
entry.q: They thought that some frenzy distemper had got into his head.

entry.def: To affect with frenzy; to drive to madness
entry.q: Frenzyinganguish.

entry.def: having passions unrestrained by reason.

entry.ety: See Frequency

sn.def: A crowd; a throng; a concourse.
Frequency; abundance.

entries.entry:
Fre"quen*cy n.; pl.Frequencies #. L. frequentia numerous attendance, multitude: cf. F. fréquence. See Frequent
The condition of returning frequently; occurrence often repeated; common occurence; as, the frequency of crimes; the frequency of miracles.
The reasons that moved her to remove were, because Rome was a place of riot and luxury, her soul being almost stifled with, the frequencies of ladies' visits.
A crowd; a throng. Obs

entry.ety: L. frequens -entis, crowded, frequent, akin to farcire to stuff: cf. F. fréquent. Cf. Farce n.

sn.def: Often to be met with; happening at short intervals; often repeated or occurring; as, frequent visits.
sn.q: Frequentfeudal towers.

sn.def: Addicted to any course of conduct; inclined to indulge in any practice; habitual; persistent.
sn.q: He has been loud and frequent in declaring himself hearty for the government.

sn.def: Full; crowded; thronged.
sn.q: 'T is Cæsar's will to have a frequent senate.

sn.def: Often or commonly reported.
sn.q: 'T is frequent in the city he hath subdued The Catti and the Daci.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frequented; p. pr. & vb. n. Frequenting
entry.ety: L. frequentare: cf. F. fréquenter. See Frequent a.

sn.def: To visit often; to resort to often or habitually; as, to frequent a tavern.
sn.q: He frequented the court of Augustus.

sn.def: To make full; to fill.
sn.q: With their sighs the airFrequenting, sent from hearts contrite.

entry.def: Accessible.
The practice or habit of frequenting.

entry.ety: L. frequentatio a crowding together, frequency: cf. F. fréquentation
entry.def: The act or habit of frequenting or visiting often; resort.

entry.ety: L. frequentativus: cf. F. fréquentatif
entry.def: Serving to express the frequent repetition of an action; as, a frequentative verb.

def2.def: A frequentative verb.

entry.def: One who frequents; one who often visits, or resorts to customarily.
At frequent or short intervals; many times; often; repeatedly; commonly.
The quality of being frequent.

entry.ety: F. See Friar
entry.def: A friar.

entry.ety: See Fresco Fresh a.
entry.def: A cool walk; shady place.

entries.entry:
Fres"co n.; pl.Frescoes or Frescos #. It., fr. fresco fresh; of German origin. See Fresh a.
A cool, refreshing state of the air; duskiness; coolness; shade. R
Fine Arts
The art of painting on freshly spread plaster, before it dries.
In modern parlance, incorrectly applied to painting on plaster in any manner.
A painting on plaster in either of senses and .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frescoed; p. pr. & vb. n. Frescoing
entry.def: To paint in fresco, as walls.

cs.cd: a breeze between a moderate and a strong breeze; one blowinq about twenty miles an hour.
a gale blowing about forty-five miles an hour.
increased speed.

entry.ety: OE. fresch, AS. fersc; akin to D. versch, G. frisch, OHG. frisc, Sw. frisk, Dan. frisk fersk, Icel. frīskr frisky, brisk, ferskr fresh; cf. It. fresco, OF. fres freis, fem. freske fresche, F. frais, fem. fraîche, which are of German origin. Cf. Fraischeur Fresco Frisk

sn.def: Possessed of original life and vigor; new and strong; unimpaired; sound.
New; original; additional.
sn.q: Fear offreshmistakes.
A fresh pleasure in every fresh posture of the limbs.

sn.def: Lately produced, gathered, or prepared for market; not stale; not dried or preserved; not wilted, faded, or tainted; in good condition; as, fresh vegetables, flowers, eggs, meat, fruit, etc.; recently made or obtained; occurring again; repeated; as, a fresh supply of goods; fresh tea, raisins, etc.; lately come or made public; as, fresh news; recently taken from a well or spring; as, fresh water.
Youthful; florid; as, these fresh nymphs.
In a raw, green, or untried state; uncultivated; uncultured; unpracticed; as, a fresh hand on a ship.
Renewed in vigor, alacrity, or readiness for action; as, fresh for a combat; hence, tending to renew in vigor; rather strong; cool or brisk; as, a fresh wind.
Not salt; as, fresh water, in distinction from that which is from the sea, or brackish; fresh meat, in distinction from that which is pickled or salted.
sn.syn: Sound; unimpaired; recent; unfaded: ruddy; florid; sweet; good: inexperienced; unpracticed: unused; lively; vigorous; strong.

entries.entry:
Fresh n.; pl.Freshes.
A stream or spring of fresh water. He shall drink naught but brine; for I'll not show him Where the quick freshes are.
A flood; a freshet. Prov. Eng
The mingling of fresh water with salt in rivers or bays, as by means of a flood of fresh water flowing toward or into the sea.

entry.def: To refresh; to freshen.
recently cut; -- of flowers; as, a fresh-cut bouquet.

cs.cd: to shift Or restore it.
to pay out a little more cable, so as to bring the chafe on another part.
to increase the speed of a vessel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Freshened; p. pr. & vb. n. Freshening

sn.def: To make fresh; to separate, as water, from saline ingredients; to make less salty; as, to freshen water, fish, or flesh.
To refresh; to revive.
To relieve, as a rope, by change of place where friction wears it; or to renew, as the material used to prevent chafing; as, to freshen a hawse.
To grow fresh; to lose saltness.
To grow brisk or strong; as, the wind freshens .

entry.def: a first-year undergraduate.

entry.ety: OE. fresche flood + -et. See Fresh a.

sn.def: A stream of fresh water.
A flood or overflowing of a stream caused by heavy rains or melted snow; a sudden inundation.
sn.q: Cracked the sky, as ice in rivers When the freshet is at highest.

entry.def: In a fresh manner; vigorously; newly, recently; brightly; briskly; coolly; as, freshly gathered; freshly painted; the wind blows freshly.
entry.q: Looks he as freshly as he did?

entries.entry:
Fresh"man
Freshman class the lowest of the four classes in an American college. U. S
n.; pl.Freshmen. A novice; one in the rudiments of knowledge; especially, a student during his first year in a high school, college, or university. frosh. He drank his glass and cracked his joke, And freshmen wondered as he spoke.

entry.def: The state of being a freshman.
Refreshment.
The state of being fresh.
entry.q: The Scots had the advantage both for number and freshness of men.
And breathe the freshness of the open air.
Her cheeks their freshness lose and wonted grace.

entry.def: Unpracticed.

sn.def: Of, pertaining to, or living in, water which is not salty; as, fresh-water geological deposits; a fresh-water fish; fresh-water mussels.
Accustomed to sail on fresh water only; unskilled as a seaman; as, a fresh-water sailor.
Unskilled; raw.
sn.q: Fresh-watersoldiers.

entry.ety: From Fresnel the inventor, a French physicist
entry.def: A lantern having a lamp surrounded by a hollow cylindrical Fresnel lens.

entries.entry:
Fres`nel" lens". See Fresnel lamp
Optics See under Lens.

entry.ety: Yiddish, fresn fr. G. fressen to eat (used of animals)
entry.def: to eat copiously and without restraint; to snack frequently.
See 1st Frith.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fretted; p. pr. & vb. n. Fretting
entry.ety: OE. freten to eat, consume; AS. fretan, for foretan; pref. for- + etan to eat; akin to D. vreten, OHG. frezzan, G. fressen, Sw. fräta, Goth. fra-itan. See For, and Eat v. t.

sn.def: To devour.
sn.q: The sow frete the child right in the cradle.

sn.def: To rub; to wear away by friction; to chafe; to gall; hence, to eat away; to gnaw; as, to fret cloth; to fret a piece of gold or other metal; a worm frets the plants of a ship.
sn.q: With many a curve my banks I fret.

sn.def: To impair; to wear away; to diminish.
sn.q: By starts His fretted fortunes give him hope and fear.

sn.def: To make rough, agitate, or disturb; to cause to ripple; as, to fret the surface of water.
To tease; to irritate; to vex.
sn.q: Fret not thyself because of evil doers.

sn.def: To be worn away; to chafe; to fray; as, a wristband frets on the edges.
To eat in; to make way by corrosion.
sn.q: Many wheals arose, and fretted one into another with great excoriation.

sn.def: To be agitated; to be in violent commotion; to rankle; as, rancor frets in the malignant breast.
To be vexed; to be chafed or irritated; to be angry; to utter peevish expressions.
sn.q: He frets, he fumes, he stares, he stamps the ground.

sn.def: The agitation of the surface of a fluid by fermentation or other cause; a rippling on the surface of water.
Agitation of mind marked by complaint and impatience; disturbance of temper; irritation; as, he keeps his mind in a continual fret .
sn.q: Yet then did Dennis rave in furious fret.

sn.def: Herpes; tetter.
The worn sides of river banks, where ores, or stones containing them, accumulate by being washed down from the hills, and thus indicate to the miners the locality of the veins.

entry.ety: OE. fretten to adorn, AS. frætwan frætwian; akin to OS. fratahōn, cf. Goth. us-fratwjan to make wise, also AS. frætwe ornaments, OS. fratahī adornment
entry.def: To ornament with raised work; to variegate; to diversify.
entry.q: Whose skirt with gold was fretted all about.
Yon gray lines, That fret the clouds, are messengers of day.

cs.cd: a saw with a long, narrow blade, used in cutting frets, scrolls, etc.; a scroll saw; a keyhole saw; a compass saw.

sn.def: Ornamental work in relief, as carving or embossing. See Fretwork.
An ornament consisting of small fillets or slats intersecting each other or bent at right angles, as in classical designs, or at oblique angles, as often in Oriental art.
sn.q: His lady's cabinet is a adorned on the fret, ceiling, and chimney-piece with . . . carving.

sn.def: The reticulated headdress or net, made of gold or silver wire, in which ladies in the Middle Ages confined their hair.
sn.q: A fret of gold she had next her hair.

entry.ety: F. frette a saltire, also a hoop, ferrule, prob. a dim. of L. ferrum iron. For sense 2, cf. also E. fret to rub

sn.def: A saltire interlaced with a mascle.
A short piece of wire, or other material fixed across the finger board of a guitar or a similar instrument, to indicate where the finger is to be placed.

entry.def: To furnish with frets, as an instrument of music.

entry.usage: Fretful Peevish Cross. These words all indicate an unamiable working and expression of temper. Peevish marks more especially the inward spirit: a peevish man is always ready to find fault. Fretful points rather to the outward act, and marks a complaining impatience: sickly children are apt to be fretful. Crossness is peevishness mingled with vexation or anger.
entry.ety: See 2d Fret
entry.def: Disposed to fret; ill-humored; peevish; angry; in a state of vexation; as, a fretful temper.
entry.syn: Peevish; ill-humored; ill-natured; irritable; waspish; captious; petulant; splenetic; spleeny; passionate; angry.

entry.def: A narrow-bladed fine-toothed saw for cutting curved outlines.

entry.ety: See 2d Fret
entry.def: The worn side of the bank of a river. See 4th Fret n., 4.

entry.ety: See Frit
entry.def: A vitreous compound, used by potters in glazing, consisting of lime, silica, borax, lead, and soda.

entry.ety: From 2d Fret

sn.def: Rubbed or worn away; chafed.
Agitated; vexed; worried.

entry.ety: See 5th Fret

sn.def: Ornamented with fretwork; furnished with frets; variegated; made rough on the surface.
Interlaced one with another; -- said of charges and ordinaries.

entry.ety: The old p. p. of fret to rub
entry.def: Rubbed; marked; as, pock-fretten, marked with the smallpox.
One who, or that which, frets.

entry.ety: See 5th Fret
entry.def: Adorned with fretwork.

entries.entry: ‖Fre"tum n.; pl.Freta #. L A strait, or arm of the sea.

entry.ety: 6th fret + work
entry.def: Work adorned with frets; ornamental openwork or work in relief, esp. when elaborate and minute in its parts. Hence, any minute play of light and shade, dark and light, or the like.
entry.q: Banqueting on the turf in the fretwork of shade and sunshine.

entry.def: Sigmund Freud, the founder of the practise of psychoanalysis. Born 1856, died 1939.
of or pertaining to Sigmund Freud; as, Freudian theories.

The god of earth's fertility and peace and prosperity, presiding over rain, sunshine, and all the fruits of the earth, dispensing wealth among men; son of Njorth (Njord) and brother of Freya; originally of the Vanir; later with the Aesir. He was especially worshipped in the temple at Upsala in Sweden

entry.ety: Icel. Freyja
entry.def: The daughter of Njörd, and goddess of love and beauty; the Scandinavian Venus; -- in Teutonic myths confounded with Frigga, but in Scandinavian, distinct.

entry.ety: Cf. F. friabilité
entry.def: The quality of being friable; friableness.

entry.ety: L. friabilis, fr. friare to rub, break, or crumble into small pieces, cf. fricare to rub, E. fray: cf. F. friable
entry.def: Easily crumbled, pulverized, or reduced to powder.
entry.q: Friableground.
Soft andfriabletexture.

entry.cs: Friar bird Zoöl an Australian bird (Tropidorhynchus corniculatus), having the head destitute of feathers; -- called also coldong leatherhead pimlico; poor soldier, and four-o'clock. The name is also applied to several other species of the same genus.Friar's balsam Med a stimulating application for wounds and ulcers, being an alcoholic solution of benzoin, styrax, tolu balsam, and aloes; compound tincture of benzoin. Brande & C. Friar's cap Bot the monkshood. Friar's cowl Bot an arumlike plant (Arisarum vulgare) with a spathe or involucral leaf resembling a cowl. Friar's lantern the ignis fatuus or Will-o'-the-wisp. Milton. Friar skate Zoöl the European white or sharpnosed skate (Raia alba); -- called also Burton skate border ray scad, and doctor.
entry.ety: OR. frere, F. frère brother, friar, fr. L. frater brother. See Brother

sn.def: A brother or member of any religious order, but especially of one of the four mendicant orders, viz: a) Minors, Gray Friars, or Franciscans. b) Augustines. c) Dominicans or Black Friars. d) White Friars or Carmelites. See these names in the Vocabulary.
A white or pale patch on a printed page.
An American fish; the silversides.

entry.def: Like a friar; inexperienced.
A tuberous perennial (Arisarum vulgare) having a cowl-shaped maroon or violet-black spathe; -- found in the Mediterranean, Canaries, and Azores.

entry.ety: From Friar n.
entry.def: Like a friar; pertaining to friars or to a convent.

entry.ety: OF. frerie frairie, fr. frère. See Friar

sn.def: A monastery; a convent of friars.
The institution or practices of friars.

entry.ety: See Friable
entry.def: The act of breaking up or pulverizing.

entry.ety: Cf. F. frivole, L. frivolus, or E. frippery
entry.def: Frivolous; trifling; silly.
A frivolous, contemptible fellow; a fop.
entry.q: A pert fribble of a peer.

sn.def: To act in a trifling or foolish manner; to act frivolously.
sn.q: The fools that are fribbling round about you.

sn.def: To totter.

entry.def: A trifler; a fribble.
Frivolous; trining; toolishly captious.

entry.ety: AS. friðborh, lit., peace pledge; frið peace + borh borg, pledge, akin to E. borrow. The first part of the word was confused with free, the last part, with borough
entry.def: The pledge and tithing, afterwards called by the Normans frankpledge. See Frankpledge.

entry.ety: See Fricassee

sn.def: Meat sliced and dressed with strong sauce.
An unguent; also, the act of rubbing with the unguent.

entry.ety: F. fricandeau; cf. Sp. fricandó
entry.def: A ragout or fricassee of veal; a fancy dish of veal or of boned turkey, served as an entrée, -- called also fricandel.

entry.ety: F. fricassée, fr. fricasser to fry fricassee; cf. LL. fricare, perh. for frictare fricare frictum, to rub. Cf. Fry Friction
entry.def: A dish made of fowls, veal, or other meat of small animals cut into pieces, and stewed in a gravy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fricasseed; p. pr. &. vb. n. Fricasseeing
entry.def: To dress like a fricassee.

entry.ety: L. fricatio, fr. fricare fricatum, to rub.
entry.def: Friction.

entry.ety: See Frication
entry.def: Produced by the friction or rustling of the breath, intonated or unintonated, through a narrow opening between two of the mouth organs; uttered through a close approach, but not with a complete closure, of the organs of articulation, and hence capable of being continued or prolonged; -- said of certain consonantal sounds, as f v s z, etc.

def2.def: A fricative consonant letter or sound. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 197-206, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. L. frictrix, fr. fricare to rub
entry.def: A lewd woman; a harlot.
A bushel basket.

entry.cs:
Angle of friction Mech the angle which a plane onwhich a body is lying makes with a horizontal plane,when the hody is just ready to slide dewn the plane. This angle varies for different bodies, and for planes of different materials. Anti-friction wheels Mach wheels turning freely on small pivots, and sustaining, at the angle formed by their circumferences, the pivot or journal of a revolving shaft, to relieve it of friction; -- called also friction wheels. Friction balls, or Friction rollers balls or rollers placed so as to receive the pressure or weight of bodies in motion, and relieve friction, as in the hub of a bicycle wheel. Friction brake Mach a form of dynamometer for measuring the power a motor exerts. A clamp around the revolving shaft or fly wheel of the motor resists the motion by its friction, the work thus absorbed being ascertained by observing the force required to keep the clamp from revolving with the shaft; a Prony brake. Friction chocks brakes attached to the common standing garrison carriages of guns, so as to raise the trucks or wheels off the platform when the gun begins to recoil, and prevent its running back. Earrow.
Friction clutch Friction coupling
an engaging and disengaging gear for revolving shafts, pulleys, etc., acting by friction; esp.: A device in which a piece on one shaft or pulley is so forcibly pressed against a piece on another shaft that the two will revolve together; as, in the illustration, the cone a on one shaft, when thrust forcibly into the corresponding hollow cone b on the other shaft, compels the shafts to rotate together, by the hold the friction of the conical surfaces gives. A toothed clutch, one member of which, instead of being made fast on its shaft, is held by friction and can turn, by slipping, under excessive strain or in starting. Friction drop hammer one in which the hammer is raised for striking by the friction of revolving rollers which nip the hammer rod. Friction gear. See Frictional gearing, under Frictional. Friction machine an electrical machine, generating electricity by friction. Friction meter an instrument for measuring friction, as in testing lubricants.
Friction powder Friction composition
a composition of chlorate of potassium, antimony, sulphide, etc, which readily ignites by friction.
Friction primer Friction tube
a tube used for firing cannon by means of the friction of a roughened wire in the friction powder or composition with which the tube is filled. Friction wheel Mach one of the wheels in frictional gearing. See under Frictional.
entry.ety: L. frictio, fr. fricare frictum,to rub: cf. F. friction. See Fray to rub, arid cf. Dentifrice

sn.def: The act of rubbing the surface of one body against that of another; attrition; in hygiene, the act of rubbing the body with the hand, with flannel, or with a brush etc., to excite the skin to healthy action.
The resistance which a body meets with from the surface on which it moves. It may be resistance to sliding motion, or to rolling motion.
A clashing between two persons or parties in opinions or work; a disagreement tending to prevent or retard progress.

cs.cd: wheels which transmit motion by surface friction instead of teeth. The faces are sometimes made more or less V-shaped to increase or decrease friction, as required.

entry.def: Relating to friction; moved by friction; produced by friction; as, frictional electricity.
Having no friction.

entry.ety: AS. frigedæg, fr. Frigu, the gooddes of marriage; friqu love + dæg day; cf. Icel. Frigg name of a goddess, the wife of Odin or Wodan, OHG. Frīatag, Icel. Frjādagr. AS. frigu is prob. from the root of E. friend free. See Free, and Day
entry.def: The sixth day of the week, following Thursday and preceding Saturday.

entry.ety: AS. frician to dance, from free bold. Cf. Freak n.
entry.def: To rub; to fray.

entry.ety: AS. friðstōl. See Fred, and Stool
entry.def: A seat in churches near the altar, to which offenders formerly fled for sanctuary.
imp. & p. p. of Fry.
A small cake fried in deep fat.

entry.cs:
A friend at courtorA friend in court
one disposed to act as a friend in a place of special opportunity or influence. To be friends with to have friendly relations with. “He's . . . friends with Cæsar.” Shak. To make friends with to become reconciled to or on friendly terms with. “Having now made friends with the Athenians.” Jowett (Thucyd.).
entry.ety: OR. frend freond, AS. freónd, prop. p. pr. of freón freógan, to love; akin to D. vriend friend, OS. friund friend, friohan to love, OHG. friunt friend, G. freund, Icel. frændi kinsman, Sw. frände. Goth. frijōnds friend, frijōn to love. √83. See Free, and cf. Fiend

sn.def: One who entertains for another such sentiments of esteem, respect, and affection that he seeks his society and welfare; a wellwisher; an intimate associate; sometimes, an attendant.
sn.q: Want gives to know the flatterer from the friend.
A friend that sticketh closer than a brother.

sn.def: One not inimical or hostile; one not a foe or enemy; also, one of the same nation, party, kin, etc., whose friendly feelings may be assumed. The word is some times used as a term of friendly address.
sn.q: Friend, how camest thou in hither?

sn.def: One who looks propitiously on a cause, an institution, a project, and the like; a favorer; a promoter; as, a friend to commerce, to poetry, to an institution.

One of a religious sect characterized by disuse of outward rites and an ordained ministry, by simplicity of dress and speech, and esp. by opposition to war and a desire to live at peace with all men. They are popularly called Quakers.
sn.q: America was first visited by Friends in 1656.

sn.def: A paramour of either sex.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Friended; p. pr. & vb. n. Friending
entry.def: To act as the friend of; to favor; to countenance; to befriend.
entry.q: Fortune friends the bold.

sn.def: Having friends;
Inclined to love; well-disposed.

entry.def: Friendliness.

entry.ety: AS. freóndleás
entry.def: Destitute of friends; forsaken.
In a friendly manner.
The condition or quality of being friendly.

entry.ety: AS. freéndlīce

sn.def: Having the temper and disposition of a friend; disposed to promote the good of another; kind; favorable.
Appropriate to, or implying, friendship; befitting friends; amicable.
sn.q: In friendly relations with his moderate opponents.

sn.def: Not hostile; as, a friendly power or state.
Promoting the good of any person; favorable; propitious; serviceable; as, a friendly breeze or gale.
sn.q: On the first friendly bank he throws him down.
sn.syn: Amicable; kind; conciliatory; propitious; favorable. See Amicable.

entry.def: In the manner of friends; amicably; like friends.
entry.q: In whom all graces that can perfect beauty Are friendly met.

sn.def: A friendly person; -- usually applied to natives friendly to foreign settlers or invaders.
sn.q: These were speedily routed by the friendlies, who attacked the small force before them in fine style.

sn.def: A member of one's own military forces, or of allied forces.

entry.def: Weapons fire{9}, such as artillery or aerial bombardment, from one's own forces; -- used mostly when troops do damage or cause casualties among their own forces; as, the tank was hit by friendly fire .

entry.ety: AS. freóndscipe. See Friend, and -ship

sn.def: The state of being friends; friendly relation, or attachment, to a person, or between persons; affection arising from mutual esteem and good will; friendliness; amity; good will.
sn.q: There is little friendship in the world.
There can be no friendship without confidence, and no confidence without integrity.
Preferred by friendship, and not chosen by sufficiency.

sn.def: Kindly aid; help; assistance,
sn.q: Some friendship will it [a hovel] lend you gainst the tempest.

sn.def: Aptness to unite; conformity; affinity; harmony; correspondence.
sn.q: Those colors . . . have a friendship with each other.

sn.def: One who fries.
same as fryer.

entry.def: Same as Friesic n.
Of or pertaining to Friesland, a province in the northern part of the Netherlands.

The language of the Frisians, a Teutonic people formerly occupying a large part of the coast of Holland and Northwestern Germany. The modern dialects of Friesic are spoken chiefly in the province of Friesland, and on some of the islands near the coast of Germany and Denmark.
Friesic.

entry.ety: Perh. the same word as frieze a, kind of cloth. Cf. Friz
entry.def: That part of the entablature of an order which is between the architrave and cornice. It is a flat member or face, either uniform or broken by triglyphs, and often enriched with figures and other ornaments of sculpture.
Any sculptured or richly ornamented band in a building or, by extension, in rich pieces of furniture. See Illust. of Column.
entry.q: Cornice or frieze with bossy sculptures graven.

entry.ety: F. frise, perh. originally a woolen cloth or stuff from FrieslandF. Frise); cf. LL. frisii panni and frissatus pannus, a shaggy woolen cloth, F. friser to friz, curl. Cf. Friz
entry.def: A kind of coarse woolen cloth or stuff with a shaggy or tufted (friezed) nap on one side.
entry.q: Robes offrieze.

cs.cd: a machine for friezing cloth; a friezing machine.

entry.def: To make a nap on (cloth); to friz. See Friz v. t., 2.
Gathered, or having the map gathered, into little tufts, knots, or protuberances. Cf. Frieze v. t., and Friz v. t., 2.
One who, or that which, friezes or frizzes.

entry.cs: Frigate bird Zoöl a web-footed rapacious bird, of the genus Fregata; -- called also man-of-war bird, and frigate pelican. Two species are known; that of the Southern United States and West Indies is F. aquila. They are remarkable for their long wings and powerful flight. Their food consists of fish which they obtain by robbing gulls, terns, and other birds, of their prey. They are related to the pelicans. Frigate mackerel Zoöl an oceanic fish (Auxis Rochei) of little or no value as food, often very abundant off the coast of the United States. Frigate pelican. Zoöl Same as Frigate bird.
entry.ety: F. frégate, It. fregata, prob. contracted fr. L. fabricata something constructed or built. See Fabricate

sn.def: Originally, a vessel of the Mediterranean propelled by sails and by oars. The French, about 1650, transferred the name to larger vessels, and by 1750 it had been appropriated for a class of war vessels intermediate between corvettes and ships of the line. Frigates, from about 1750 to 1850, had one full battery deck and, often, a spar deck with a lighter battery. They carried sometimes as many as fifty guns. After the application of steam to navigation steam frigates of largely increased size and power were built, and formed the main part of the navies of the world till about 1870, when the introduction of ironclads superseded them.
Any small vessel on the water.

entry.def: Built like a frigate with a raised quarter-deck and forecastle.

entry.ety: It. fregatone: cf. F.frégaton. See Frigate
entry.def: A Venetian vessel, with a square stern, having only a mainmast, jigger mast, and bowsprit; also a sloop of war ship-rigged.

entry.ety: L. frigere to be cold + facere to make
entry.def: The act of making cold. Obs
Cooling.

entry.ety: L. frigerare, fr. frigus cold
entry.def: To make cool.

entry.ety: Icel. Frigg. See Friday
entry.def: The wife of Odin and mother of the gods; the supreme goddess; the Juno of the Valhalla. Cf. Freya.

entry.ety: OE. frigt freyht, AS. fyrhto fyrhtu; akin to OS. forhta, OHG. forhta forahta, G. furcht, Dan. frygt, Sw. fruktan, Goth. faúrhtei fear, faúrhts timid

sn.def: A state of terror excited by the sudden appearance of danger; sudden and violent fear, usually of short duration; a sudden alarm.
Anything strange, ugly or shocking, producing a feeling of alarm or aversion.

entry.vmorph: imp. Frighted; p. pr. & vb. n.. Frighting
entry.ety: OE. frigten to fear, frighten, AS. fyrhtan to frighten, forhtian to fear; akin to OS. forhtian, OHG. furihten forahtan, G. fürchten, Sw. frukta, Dan. frygte, Goth. faurhtjan. See Fright n., and cf. Frighten
entry.def: To alarm suddenly; to shock by causing sudden fear; to terrify; to scare.
entry.q: Nor exile or danger can fright a brave spirit.

entry.vmorph: imp. Frightened #; p. pr. & vb. n. Frightening #
entry.ety: See Fright v. t.
entry.def: To disturb with fear; to throw into a state of alarm or fright; to affright; to terrify.
entry.q: More frightened than hurt.

entry.usage: Frightful Dreadful Awful. These words all express fear. In frightful, it is a sudden emotion; in dreadful, it is deeper and more prolonged; in awful, the fear is mingled with the emotion of awe, which subdues us before the presence of some invisible power. An accident may be frightful; the approach of death is dreadful to most men; the convulsions of the earthquake are awful.

sn.def: Full of fright; affrighted; frightened.
sn.q: See how the frightful herds run from the wood.

sn.def: Full of that which causes fright; exciting alarm; impressing terror; shocking; as, a frightful chasm, or tempest; a frightful appearance.
sn.syn: Terrible; dreadful; alarming; fearful; terrific; awful; horrid; horrible; shocking.

entry.def: In a frightful manner; to a frightful dagree.
The quality of being frightful.
Free from fright; fearless.
Fear; terror.

cs.cd: that part of the earth which lies between either polar circle and its pole. It extends 23� 28� from the pole. See the Note under Arctic.

entry.ety: L. frigidus, fr. frigere to be cold; prob. akin to Gr. � to shudder, or perh. to � cold. Cf. Frill

sn.def: Cold; wanting heat or warmth; of low temperature; as, a frigid climate.

Wanting warmth, fervor, ardor, fire, vivacity, etc.; unfeeling; forbidding in manner; dull and unanimated; stiff and formal; as, a frigid constitution; a frigid style; a frigid look or manner; frigid obedience or service.
Wanting natural heat or vigor sufficient to excite the generative power; impotent.

entries.entry: ‖Frig"i*da`ri*um n.; pl.Frigidaria #. L., neut. of frigidarium cooling The cooling room of the Roman thermæ, furnished with a cold bath.

entry.ety: L. frigiditas: cf. F. frigidité

sn.def: The condition or quality of being frigid; coldness; want of warmth.
sn.q: Ice is water congealed by the frigidity of the air.

sn.def: Want of ardor, animation, vivacity, etc.; coldness of affection or of manner; dullness; stiffness and formality; as, frigidity of a reception, of a bow, etc.
Want of heat or vigor; as, the frigidity of old age.

entry.def: In a frigid manner; coldly; dully; without affection.
The state of being frigid; want of heat, vigor, or affection; coldness; dullness.

entry.ety: L. frigorificus; frigus frigoris, cold + facere to make: cf. F. frigorifique
entry.def: Causing cold; producing or generating cold.

entries.entry:
Fri"jol Fri"jole n.; pl.Frijoles . Also Fre"jol . Sp. fríjol fréjol
In Mexico, the southwestern United States, and the West Indies, any cultivated bean of the genus Phaseolus, esp. the black seed of a variety of P. vulgaris.
The beanlike seed of any of several related plants, as the cowpea. Frijoles are an important article of diet among Spanish-American peoples, being used as an ingredient of many dishes.

entry.def: A shrub or small tree(Sophora secundiflora) having pinnate leaves poisonous to livestock and dense racemes of intensely fragrant blue flowers and red beans.
entry.syn: mescal bean, coral bean, Sophora secundiflora.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. frilled frĭld; p. pr. & vb. n. frilling
entry.ety: OF. friller, fr. L. frigidulus somewhat cold, dim. of frigidus cold; akin to F. frileux chilly

sn.def: To shake or shiver as with cold; as, the hawk frills .
To wrinkle; -- said of the gelatin film.

entry.def: To provide or decorate with a frill or frills; to turn back. in crimped plaits; as, to frill a cap.

entries.entry:
Frill n. See Frill v. i. . Zoöl A ruffing of a bird's feathers from cold. A ruffle, consisting of a fold of membrane, of hairs, or of feathers, around the neck of an animal. See Frilled lizardbelow). A similar ruffle around the legs or other appendages of animals. A ruffled varex or fold on certain shells.
A border or edging secured at one edge and left free at the other, usually fluted or crimped like a very narrow flounce.
Hence: Something superfluous, such as an ornament, or an additional function on a device or in a system not essential to the basic operation. -- Commonly used in the phrase no frills, used adjectively to indicate a fully functional but economical device or service; as, an economical no-frills airline.

cs.cd: a large Australian lizard (Chlamydosaurus Kingii) about three feet long, which has a large, erectile frill on each side of the neck.

entry.def: Furnished with a frill or frills.
Ornamental objects of no great value.
entry.syn: falderal, folderol, gimcrackery, gimcracks, nonsense, trumpery.

entry.def: Having decorative ruffles or frills.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. freme good, bold, and E. frame
entry.def: Flourishing; thriving; fresh; in good condition; vigorous.
entry.q: Frim pastures.

entry.ety: F., fr. frimas hoarfrost
entry.def: The third month of the French republican calendar. It commenced November 21, and ended December 20., See Vendémiaire.

entry.ety: OF, fringe, F. frange, prob. fr. L. fimbria fiber, thread, fringe, cf. fibra fiber, E. fiber fimbriate

sn.def: An ornamental appendage to the border of a piece of stuff, originally consisting of the ends of the warp, projecting beyond the woven fabric; but more commonly made separate and sewed on, consisting sometimes of projecting ends, twisted or plaited together, and sometimes of loose threads of wool, silk, or linen, or narrow strips of leather, or the like.
Something resembling in any respect a fringe; a line of objects along a border or edge; a border; an edging; a margin; a confine.
sn.q: The confines of grace and the fringes of repentance.

sn.def: One of a number of light or dark bands, produced by the interference of light; a diffraction band; -- called also interference fringe.
The peristome or fringelike appendage of the capsules of most mosses. See Peristome.

entry.cs: Fringing reef. See Coral reefs, under Coral.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fringed frĭnjd; p. pr. & vb. n. Fringing
entry.def: To adorn the edge of with a fringe or as with a fringe.
entry.q: Precipices fringed with grass.

cs.cd: a leaf edged with soft parallel hairs.

entry.def: Furnished with a fringe.
Having no fringe.
Encircling like a fringe; bordering.
An annual herb having pinnatifid basal leaves and slender racemes of small white flowers followed by one-seeded winged silicles.

entries.entry: Fringe tree. A small oleaceous tree (Chionanthus virginica), of the southern United States, having clusters of snow-white flowers with slender petals. It is often cultivated.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. fringilla a chaffinch
entry.def: A genus of birds, with a short, conical, pointed bill. It formerly included all the sparrows and finches, but is now restricted to certain European finches, like the chaffinch and brambling.
Fringilline.

A natural family of birds of the finch group having short conical bills adapted for eating seeds, including finches, goldfinches, bullfinches, chaffinches, siskins, canaries, cardinals, grosbeaks, crossbills, linnets, and buntings. This family at one time included the sparrows of the family Emberizinae, but has more recently been restricted in usage.
Pertaining to the family Fringillidæ; characteristic of finches; sparrowlike.
Adorned with fringes.

entry.ety: F. fripier, fr. friper to rumple, fumble, waste
entry.def: One who deals in frippery or in old clothes.
A fripper.

entry.ety: F. friperie, fr. fruper. See Fripper

sn.def: Coast-off clothes.
Hence: Secondhand finery; cheap and tawdry decoration; affected elegance.
sn.q: Fond of gauze and French frippery.
The gauzy frippery of a French translation.

sn.def: A place where old clothes are sold.
The trade or traffic in old clothes.

entry.def: Trifling; contemptible.

entry.ety: F. frisette curl
entry.def: a fringe of hair or curls worn about the forehead by women.

entry.ety: F., fr. friser to curl, frizzle. See Frizzle
entry.def: A hairdresser.
Of or pertaining to Friesland, a province of the Netherlands; Friesic.
A native or inhabitant of Friesland; also, the language spoken in Friesland. See Friesic n.

entry.ety: OF. frieque, cf. OHG. frise lively, brisk, fresh, Dan. & Sw. frisk, Icel. friskr. See Fresh a.
entry.def: Lively; brisk; frolicsome; frisky.
A frolic; a fit of wanton gayety; a gambol: a little playful skip or leap.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frisked; p. pr. & vb. n. Frisking
entry.def: To leap, skip, dance, or gambol, in fronc and gayety.
entry.q: The frisking satyrs on the summits danced.

entry.def: To search (a person) for concealed weapons or other objects, by patting the clothing to detect objects underneath; as, the police pulled the car over and frisked the occupants.
A leap or caper.
One who frisks; one who leaps of dances in gayety; a wanton; an inconstant or unsettled person.

entry.ety: F. frisguette. Perhaps so named from the velocity or frequency of its motion. See Frisk a.
entry.def: The light frame which holds the sheet of paper to the tympan in printing.
Brisk; lively; frolicsome.
In a frisky manner.
State or quality of being frisky.
The act or process of searching someone for concealed weapons.
Inclined to frisk; frolicsome; gay.
entry.q: He is too frisky for an old man.

entry.ety: Cf. Fraise a kind of defense; also Friz
entry.def: A kind of small ruffle.

entry.ety: OE. fristen firsten, to lend, give respite, postpone, AS. firstan to give respite to; akin to first time, G. frist, Icel. frest delay
entry.def: To sell upon credit, as goods.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The dressing of the hair by crisping or curling.

cs.cd: a lump of calcined glass materials, brought to a pasty condition in a reverberatory furnace, preliminary to the perfect vitrification in the melting pot.

entry.ety: F. fritte, fr. frit fried, p. p. of frire to fry. See Far v. t.

sn.def: The material of which glass is made, after having been calcined or partly fused in a furnace, but before vitrification. It is a composition of silex and alkali, occasionally with other ingredients.
The material for glaze of pottery.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fritted; p. pr. & vb. n. Fritting
entry.def: To prepare by heat (the materials for making glass); to fuse partially.
To fritter; -- with away.
A small dipterous fly of the genus Oscinis, esp. O. vastator, injurious to grain in Europe, and O. Trifole, injurious to clover in America.

entry.ety: OE. firth, Icel. fjörðr; akin to Sw. fjärd, Dan. fiord, E. ford. √78. See Ford n., and cf. Firth Fiord Fret a frith, Port a harbor

sn.def: A narrow arm of the sea; an estuary; the opening of a river into the sea; as, the Frith of Forth. Also called firth.
A kind of weir for catching fish.

entry.ety: OE. frith peace, protection, land inclosed for hunting, park, forest, AS. frið peace; akin to frenoð peace, protection, asylum, G. friede peace, Icel. friðr, and from the root of E. free, friend. See Free a., and cf. Affray Defray

sn.def: A forest; a woody place.
A small field taken out of a common, by inclosing it; an inclosure.

entry.def: Woody.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. fritillus dicebox: cf. F. fritillaire. So named from the checkered markings of the petals
entry.def: A genus of liliaceous plants, of which the crown-imperial (Fritillaria imperialis) is one species, and the Guinea-hen flower (F. Meleagris) another. See Crown-imperial.

sn.def: A plant with checkered petals, of the genus Fritillaria: the Guinea-hen flower. See Fritillaria.
One of several species of butterflies belonging to Argynnis and allied genera; -- so called because the coloring of their wings resembles that of the common Fritillaria. See Aphrodite.

entry.ety: L. fritinnire to twitter
entry.def: A chirping or creaking, as of a cricket.

entry.cs: Corn fritter. See under Corn.
entry.ety: OR. fritour friture, pancake, F. friture frying, a thing fried, from frire to fry. See Far v. t.

sn.def: A small quantity of batter, fried in boiling lard or in a frying pan. Fritters are of various kinds, named from the substance inclosed in the batter; as, apple fritters, clam fritters, oyster fritters .
A fragment; a shred; a small piece.
sn.q: And cut whole giants into fritters.

cs.cd: to diminish; to pare off; to reduce to nothing by taking away a little at a time; also, to waste piecemeal; as, to fritter away time, strength, credit, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frittered; p. pr. & vb. n. Frittering

sn.def: To cut, as meat, into small pieces, for frying.
To break into small pieces or fragments.
sn.q: Break all nerves, and fritter all their sense.

entry.ety: See Frit to expose to heat
entry.def: The formation of frit or slag by heat with but incipient fusion.

entries.entry:
Friv"ol
Friv"ol*er # Friv"ol*ler n. All Colloq
v. i. To act frivolously; to trifle. Kipling.

entry.def: Frivolity.

entries.entry:
Fri*vol"i*ty n.; pl.Frivolities #. Cg. F. frivolité. See Frivolous
The condition or quality of being frivolous; also, acts or habits of trifling; unbecoming levity of disposition.

entry.ety: L. frivolus; prob. akin to friare to rub, crumble, E. friable: cf. F. frivole

sn.def: Of little weight or importance; not worth notice; slight; as, a frivolous argument.
Given to trifling; marked with unbecoming levity; silly; interested especially in trifling matters.
sn.q: His personal tastes were low and frivolous.

entry.cs: Frizzing machine. Fabrics A machine for frizzing the surface of cloth. Wood Working A bench with a revolving cutter head slightly protruding above its surface, for dressing boards.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frizzed; p. pr. & vb. n. Frizzing
entry.ety: Cf. F. friser to curl, crisp, frizzle, to raise the nap (on certain stuffs); prob.akin to OFries. frisle hair of the head. Cf. Frieze kind of cloth

sn.def: To curl or form into small curls, as hair, with a crisping pin; to crisp.
sn.q: With her hair frizzed short up to her ears.

sn.def: To form into little burs, prominences, knobs, or tufts, as the nap of cloth.
To soften and make of even thickness by rubbing, as with pumice stone or a blunt instrument.

entries.entry:
Friz n.; pl.Frizzes. That which is frizzed; anything crisped or curled, as a wig; a frizzle.
frizz
He [Dr. Johnson], who saw in his glass how his wig became his face and head, might easily infer that a similar fullbottomed, well-curled friz of words would be no less becoming to his thoughts.

entry.def: See 1st Frieze.
A movable furrowed piece of steel struck by the flint, to throw sparks into the pan, in an early form of flintlock.

entry.ety: F. frisette curl
entry.def: A curl of hair or silk; a pad of frizzed hair or silk worn by women under the hair to stuff it out.
See Friz v. t. & n.

entry.ety: Partly imitative, but cf. Fry
entry.def: To fry, cook, or sear with a sizzling noise; to sizzle.

cs.cd: to crinkle or crisp excessively.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frizzled; p. pr. & vb. n. Frizzling
entry.ety: Dim. of friz
entry.def: To curl or crisp, as hair; to friz; to crinkle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frizzled; p. pr. & vb. n. Frizzling
entry.ety: Freq. of an imitative word frizz, in dial. use

sn.def: To fry, toast, or broil with a sputtering sound to cook with a sizzling noise. Also fig.
To cook, in certain way, so as to curl or crinkle up.
sn.q: Drain and heat it [shaved smoked beef] in one tablespoonful of hot butter, to curl or frizzle it.

entry.def: A curl; a lock of hair crisped.
One who frizzles.
Curled or crisped; as, frizzly, hair.

entry.ety: OE. fra fro, adv. & prep., Icel. frā, akin to Dan. fra from, E. from. See From
entry.def: From; away; back or backward; -- now used only in opposition to the word to, in the phrase to and fro, that is, to and from. See To and fro under To.
From.

entry.cs: Frock coat a body coat for men, usually double-breasted, the skirts not being in one piece with the body, but sewed on so as to be somewhat full. Smock frock. See in the Vocabulary.
entry.ety: F. froc a monk's cowl, coat, garment, LL. frocus froccus flocus floccus, fr. L. floccus a flock of wool; hence orig., a flocky cloth or garment; cf. L. flaccus flabby, E. flaccid

sn.def: A loose outer garment; especially, a gown forming a part of European modern costume for women and children; also, a coarse shirtlike garment worn by some workmen over their other clothes; a smock frock; as, a marketman's frock .
A coarse gown worn by monks or friars, and supposed to take the place of all, or nearly all, other garments. It has a hood which can be drawn over the head at pleasure, and is girded by a cord.
To clothe in a frock.
To make a monk of. Cf. Unfrock.

entry.def: Clothed in a frock.
Destitute of a frock.

entry.ety: See Frow
entry.def: A dirty woman; a slattern; a frow.
entry.q: Raging franticfroes.

entry.ety: See Frow the tool
entry.def: An iron cleaver or splitting tool; a frow.
Pertaining to, or derived from, Friedrich Froebel, or the kindergarten system of education, which he organized.

def2.def: One who teaches by, or advocates the use of, the kindergarten system.

entry.note: ☞ The edible frog of Europe (Rana esculenta) is extensively used as food; the American bullfrog (R. Catesbiana) is remarkable for its great size and loud voice.
entry.cs: Cross frog Railroads a frog adapted for tracks that cross at right angles. Frog cheese a popular name for a large puffball. Frog eater one who eats frogs; -- a term of contempt applied to a Frenchman by the vulgar class of English. Frog fly. Zoöl See Frog hopper. Frog hopper Zoöl a small, leaping, hemipterous insect living on plants. The larvæ are inclosed in a frothy liquid called cuckoo spit or frog spit. Frog lily Bot the yellow water lily (Nuphar). Frog spit Zoöl the frothy exudation of the frog hopper; -- called also frog spittle. See Cuckoo spit, under Cuckoo.
entry.ety: AS. froggu frocga a frog (in sensel); akin to D. vorsch, OHG. frosk, G. frosch, Icel. froskr fraukr, Sw. & Dan. frö

sn.def: An amphibious animal of the genus Rana and related genera, of many species. Frogs swim rapidly, and take long leaps on land. Many of the species utter loud notes in the springtime.

sn.ety: Perh. akin to E. fork, cf. frush frog of a horse
sn.def: The triangular prominence of the hoof, in the middle of the sole of the foot of the horse, and other animals; the fourchette.
A supporting plate having raised ribs that form continuations of the rails, to guide the wheels where one track branches from another or crosses it.

sn.ety: Cf. fraco of wool or silk, L. floccus, E. frock
sn.def: An oblong cloak button, covered with netted thread, and fastening into a loop instead of a button hole.
The loop of the scabbard of a bayonet or sword.

entry.def: To ornament or fasten (a coat, etc.) with trogs. See Frog n., 4.

sn.def: to march a person against his will by any method.
to carry someone against his will upside down such that each limb is held by one person.

entry.def: A European plant (Hydrocharis Morsus-ranæ), floating on still water and propagating itself by runners. It has roundish heart-shaped leaves and small white flowers.
An American plant (Limnobium Spongia), with similar habits.
Spotted with whitish specks due to a disease, or produced artificially by spraying; -- said of tobacco used for cigar wrappers.
See Angler n., 2.
An oceanic fish of the genus Antennarius or Pterophrynoides; -- called also mousefish and toadfish.
Provided or ornamented with frogs; as, a frogged coat. See Frog n., 4.
Abounding in frogs.
One of several species of Asiatic and East Indian birds of the genus Batrachostomusfamily Podargidæ); -- so called from their very broad, flat bills.
Frogbit.
One of numerous species of marine gastropod shells, belonging to Ranella and allied genera.

entry.ety: OE. froise cf. F. froisser to bruise, E. frush to bruise,
entry.def: A kind of pancake. See 1st Fraise.

entry.ety: D. vroolijk; akin to G. frölich, fr. froh, OHG. frō, Dan. fro, OS. frāh, cf. Icel. frār swift; all perh. akin to Skr. pru to spring up
entry.def: Full of levity; dancing, playing, or frisking about; full of pranks; frolicsome; gay; merry.
entry.q: The frolic wind that breathes the spring.
The gay, the frolic, and the loud.

sn.def: A wild prank; a flight of levity, or of gayety and mirth.
sn.q: He would be at his frolic once again.

sn.def: A scene of gayety and mirth, as in lively play, or in dancing; a merrymaking.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frolicked; p. pr. & vb. n. Frolicking
entry.def: To play wild pranks; to play tricks of levity, mirth, and gayety; to indulge in frolicsome play; to sport.
entry.q: Hither, come hither, and frolic and play.

entry.def: Frolicsome.
Frolicsome.
In a frolicsome manner; with mirth and gayety.
Full of gayety and mirth; given to pranks; sportive.
entry.q: Old England, who takes a frolicsome brain fever once every two or three years, for the benefit of her doctors.

entry.note: ☞ From sometimes denotes away from remote from inconsistent with. “Anything so overdone is from the purpose of playing.” Shak. From, when joined with another preposition or an adverb, gives an opportunity for abbreviating the sentence. “There followed him great multitudes of people . . . fromthe landbeyond Jordan.” Math. iv. 25. In certain constructions, as from forth from out, etc., the ordinary and more obvious arrangment is inverted, the sense being more distinctly forth from out from from being virtually the governing preposition, and the word the adverb. See From off, under Off adv., and From afar, under Afar adv.
entry.ety: AS. fram from; akin to OS. fram out, OHG. & Icel. fram forward, Sw. fram, Dan. frem, Goth. fram from, prob. akin to E. forth. �202. Cf. Fro Foremost
entry.def: Out of the neighborhood of; lessening or losing proximity to; leaving behind; by reason of; out of; by aid of; -- used whenever departure, setting out, commencement of action, being, state, occurrence, etc., or procedure, emanation, absence, separation, etc., are to be expressed. It is construed with, and indicates, the point of space or time at which the action, state, etc., are regarded as setting out or beginning; also, less frequently, the source, the cause, the occasion, out of which anything proceeds; -- the antithesis and correlative of to; as, it, is one hundred miles from Boston to Springfield; he took his sword from his side; light proceeds from the sun; separate the coarse wool from the fine; men have all sprung from Adam, and often go from good to bad, and from bad to worse; the merit of an action depends on the principle from which it proceeds; men judge of facts from personal knowledge, or from testimony.
entry.q: Experience from the time past to the time present.
The song began from Jove.
From high Mæonia's rocky shores I came.
If the wind blow any way from shore.
Sudden partings such as press The life from out young hearts.

entry.ety: AS. framweard about to depart. Cf. Froward
entry.def: A way from; -- the contrary of toward.
entry.q: Towards or fromwards the zenith.

entry.ety: L. frons frondis, a leafy branch, foliage
entry.def: The organ formed by the combination or union into one body of stem and leaf, and often bearing the fructification; as, the frond of a fern or of a lichen or seaweed; also, the peculiar leaf of a palm tree.

entry.ety: L. frondatio, from frons. See Frond
entry.def: The act of stripping, as trees, of leaves or branches; a kind of pruning.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A political party in France, during the minority of Louis XIV., who opposed the government, and made war upon the court party.
Furnished with fronds.
entry.q: Fronded palms.

entry.ety: L. frondens, p. pr. of frondere to put forth leaves. See Frond
entry.def: Covered with leaves; leafy; as, a frondent tree.

entry.ety: L. frondescere, inchoative fr. frondere. See Frondent
entry.def: To unfold leaves, as plants.
The time at which each species of plants unfolds its leaves.
The act of bursting into leaf.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A member of the Fronde.

entry.ety: L. frondifer frons a leafy branch + ferre to bear: cf. F. frondifere
entry.def: Producing fronds.
A very small frond, or distinct portion of a compound frond.

entry.ety: L. frondosus leafy
entry.def: Frond bearing; resembling a frond; having a simple expansion not separable into stem and leaves.
Leafy.
Frondose.

entry.ety: L., front
entry.def: The forehead; the part of the cranium between the orbits and the vertex.

cs.cd: a curtain connerting two half bastions.
the door in the front wall of a building, usually the principal entrance.
the works constructed upon any one side of a polygon.
all that part of the field of operations in front of the successive positions occupied by the army as it moves forward.
to attain prominence or leadership.

entry.ety: F. frant forehead, L. frons frontis; perh. akin to E. brow

sn.def: The forehead or brow, the part of the face above the eyes; sometimes, also, the whole face.
sn.q: Bless'd with his father's front, his mother's tongue.
Grim-visaged war hath smoothed his wrinkled front.
His front yet threatens, and his frowns command.

sn.def: The forehead, countenance, or personal presence, as expressive of character or temper, and especially, of boldness of disposition, sometimes of impudence; seeming; as, a bold front; a hardened front ;
an attitude and demeanor intended to represent one's feelings, even if not actually felt; as, to put on a good front .
sn.q: With smiling fronts encountering.
The inhabitants showed a bold front.

sn.def: The part or surface of anything which seems to look out, or to be directed forward; the fore or forward part; the foremost rank; the van; -- the opposite to back or rear; as, the front of a house; the front of an army.
sn.q: Had he his hurts before? Ay, on the front.

sn.def: A position directly before the face of a person, or before the foremost part of a thing; as, in front of un person, of the troops, or of a house.
The most conspicuous part.
sn.q: The very head and front of my offending.

sn.def: That which covers the foremost part of the head: a front piece of false hair worn by women.
sn.q: Like any plain Miss Smith's, who wears s front.

sn.def: The beginning.
sn.q: Summer'sfront.

sn.def: All the works along one side of the polygon inclosing the site which is fortified.

The middle of the upper part of the tongue, -- the part of the tongue which is more or less raised toward the palate in the pronunciation of certain sounds, as the vowel i in machinee in bed, and consonant y in you. See Guide to Pronunciation, §10.
The call boy whose turn it is to answer the call, which is often the word “front,” used as an exclamation.

entry.def: Of or relating to the front or forward part; having a position in front; foremost; as, a front view.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fronted; p. pr. & vb. n. Fronting

sn.def: To oppose face to face; to oppose directly; to meet in a hostile manner.
sn.q: You four shall front them in the narrow lane.

sn.def: To appear before; to meet.
sn.q: Enid] daily fronted him In some fresh splendor.

sn.def: To face toward; to have the front toward; to confront; as, the house fronts the street.
sn.q: And then suddenly front the changed reality.

sn.def: To stand opposed or opposite to, or over against as, his house fronts the church.
To adorn in front; to supply a front to; as, to front a house with marble; to front a head with laurel.
sn.q: Yonder walls, that pertly front your town.

entry.def: To have or turn the face or front in any direction; as, the house fronts toward the east.
The front part of an edifice or lot; extent of front.

entries.entry:
Fron"tal a. Cf. F. frontal
Belonging to the front part; being in front; esp. Anat Of or pertaining to the forehead or the anterior part of the roof of the brain case; as, the frontal bones.

cs.cd: a forge hammer lifted by a cam, acting upon a “tongue” immediately in front of the hammer head.

entry.ety: F. frontal fronteau, OF. Frontel frontal, L. frontale an ornament for the forehead, frontlet. See Front
entry.sn:
Something worn on the forehead or face; a frontlet; as: An ornamental band for the hair.
Mil The metal face guard of a soldier.

sn.def: A little pediment over a door or window.
A movable, decorative member in metal, carved wood, or, commonly, in rich stuff or in embroidery, covering the front of the altar. Frontals are usually changed according to the different ceremonies.
A medicament or application for the forehead.
The frontal bone, or one of the two frontal bones, of the cranium.

entry.def: Growing broader and broader, as a leaf; truncate.
any of the front seats in the House of Commons of Great Britain that are reserved for ministers or ex-ministers.
a member of the House of Commons of Great Britain who is a minister or an ex-minister.
Formed with a front; drawn up in line.

entry.ety: F. frontière, LL. frontaria. See Front

sn.def: That part of a country which fronts or faces another country or an unsettled region; the marches; the border, confine, or extreme part of a country, bordering on another country; the border of the settled and cultivated part of a country; as, the frontier of civilization.
An outwork.
sn.q: Palisadoes, frontiers, parapets.

sn.def: Lying on the exterior part; bordering; conterminous; as, a frontier town.
Of or relating to a frontier.

entry.def: To constitute or form a frontier; to have a frontier; -- with on.
Placed on the frontiers.

entries.entry: Fron"tiers*man n.; pl.Frontiersmen. A man living on the frontier.

entry.ety: So called from Frontignan, a town in Southern France

sn.def: A sweet muscadine wine made in Frontignan (Languedoc), France.
A grape of many varieties and colors.

entry.def: In a fronting or facing position; opposingly.
See Frontignac.

entries.entry:
Fron"tis*piece n. F. frontispice, LL. frontispicium beginning, front of a church, fr. L. frons front + spicere specere, to look at, view: cf. It. frontispizio. See Front and Spy
