The part which first meets the eye; as: Arch The principal front of a building. Obs. or R An ornamental figure or illustration fronting the first page, or titlepage, of a book; formerly, the titlepage itself.

entry.def: Without face or front; shameless; not diffident; impudent.
entry.q: Frontlessvice.
Frontlessflattery.

entry.def: Shamelessly; impudently.

entry.ety: OF. frontelet brow band, dim. of frontel frontal. See Frontal n.

sn.def: A frontal or brow band; a or band worn on the forehead.
sn.q: They shall be as frontlets between thine eyes.

sn.def: A frown (likened to a frontlet).
sn.q: What makes that frontlet on? Methinks you are too much of late i' the frown.

sn.def: The margin of the head, behind the bill of birds, often bearing rigid bristles.

entries.entry: Fron"to-. L. frons frontis, the forehead Anat A combining form signifying relating to the forehead or the frontal bone; as, fronto-parietal, relating to the frontal and the parietal bones; fronto-nasal, etc.

entry.ety: F., a pediment. See Front
entry.def: Same as Frontal, 2.
a competitor thought to be most likely to win.

entry.ety: Cf. Frap Frape
entry.def: Peevish; froward.

entry.ety: See Frorn
entry.def: Frostily.
entry.q: The parching air Burns frore, and cold performs the effect of fire.

entry.ety: AS. froren, p. p. of freósun to freeze. See Freeze
entry.def: Frozen.
entry.q: Well nigh frorn I feel.

entry.ety: AS. freórig. See Frorn

sn.def: Frozen; stiff with cold.
Covered with a froth like hoarfrost.
sn.q: The foaming steed with frory bit to steer.

entries.entry: frosh n.; pl.frosh. from freshman by shortening a student during his first year in a high school, college, or university; a freshman. informal

cs.cd: cold so intense as to freeze vegetation and cause it to turn black, without the formation of hoarfrost.
a philosophical instrument illustrating the freezing of water in a vacuum; a cryophorus.
an American grape, with very small, acid berries.
a lamp placed below the oil tube of an Argand lamp to keep the oil limpid on cold nights; -- used especially in lighthouses.
a nail with a sharp head driven into a horse's shoe to keep him from slipping.
an appearance resembling smoke, caused by congelation of vapor in the atmosphere in time of severe cold.
cs.q: The brig and the ice round her are covered by a strange black obscurity: it is the frost smoke of arctic winters.
cs.cd: a valve to drain the portion of a pipe, hydrant, pump, etc., where water would be liable to freeze.
a popular personification of frost.

entry.ety: OE. frost forst, AS. forst frost. fr. freósan to freeze; akin to D. varst, G., OHG., Icel., Dan., & Sw. frost. √18. See Freeze v. i.

sn.def: The act of freezing; -- applied chiefly to the congelation of water; congelation of fluids.
The state or temperature of the air which occasions congelation, or the freezing of water; severe cold or freezing weather.
sn.q: The third bay comes a frost, a killing frost.

sn.def: Frozen dew; -- called also hoarfrost or white frost.
sn.q: He scattereth the hoarfrost like ashes.

sn.def: Coldness or insensibility; severity or rigidity of character.
sn.q: It was of those moments of intense feeling when the frost of the Scottish people melts like a snow wreath.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frosted; p. pr. & vb. n. Frosting

sn.def: To injure by frost; to freeze, as plants.
To cover with hoarfrost; to produce a surface resembling frost upon, as upon cake, metals, or glass; as, glass may be frosted by exposure to hydrofluoric acid.
sn.q: While with a hoary light she frosts the ground.

sn.def: To roughen or sharpen, as the nail heads or calks of horseshoes, so as to fit them for frosty weather.

entry.def: The golden plover.
The freezing, or effect of a freezing, of some part of the body, as the ears, fingers, toes, or nose. Severe frostbite can lead to the loss of fingers or toes.
To expose to the effect of frost, or a frosty air; to blight or nip with frost.
entry.q: My wife up and with Mrs. Pen to walk in the fields to frostbite themselves.

entry.def: Nipped, withered, or injured, by frost or freezing.
A plant of the genus Atriplex; orache.
The lamb's-quarters (Chenopodium album).
A white arc or circle in the sky attending frosty weather and formed by reflection of sunlight from ice crystals floating in the air; the parhelic circle whose center is at the zenith.

sn.def: Covered with hoarfrost or anything resembling hoarfrost; ornamented with frosting; also, frost-bitten; as, a frosted cake; frosted donuts.
Provided with a surface finish which is matte or with a very fine grain, reminiscent of the surface texture of frost; as, frosted glass. Opposed to polished or burnished.
sn.q: Frosted work is introduced as a foil or contrast to burnished work.

entry.def: The tomcod; -- so called because it is abundant on the New England coast in autumn at about the commencement of frost. See Tomcod.
The smelt.
A name applied in New Zealand to the scabbard fish (Lepidotus) valued as a food fish.
of or pertaining to Robert Frostdefinition 4).
In a frosty manner.
State or quality of being frosty.

sn.def: A composition of sugar and beaten egg, used to cover or ornament cake, pudding, etc.
A lusterless finish of metal or glass; the process of producing such a finish.

the lightened color on part of an object, as of hair, produced by treatment with bleach or other chemicals; as only part of the object is thus treated, the final color of the object is two-toned; also, the process of producing such a two-toned effect.
Free from frost; as, a frostless winter.
same as frost-free.

entry.def: not accumulating frost; -- used especially of refrigerators with an automatic defrost cycle such that the freezer compartment remains free of ice without need for a manual defrosting.

entries.entry: Frost" sig`nal. Meteor A signal consisting of a white flag with a black center, used by the United States Weather Bureau to indicate that a local frost is expected. It is used only in Florida and along the coasts of the Pacific and the Gulf Mexico.

entry.note: ☞ It has large yellow flowers which are often sterile, and later it has abundant but inconspicuous flowers which bear seed. It is so called because, late in autumn, crystals of ice shoot from the cracked bark at the root; -- called also frostwort.
entry.def: An American species of rockrose (Helianthemum Canadense), sometimes used in medicine as an astringent or aromatic tonic.
The figurework, often fantastic and delicate, which moisture sometimes forms in freezing, as upon a window pane or a flagstone.
Same as Frostweed.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. fyrstig

sn.def: Attended with, or producing, frost; having power to congeal water; cold; freezing; as, a frosty night.
Covered with frost; as, the grass is frosty .
Chill in affection; without warmth of affection or courage.
Appearing as if covered with hoarfrost; white; gray-haired; as, a frosty head.

entry.ety: F. frotter
entry.def: To rub or wear by rubbing; to chafe.
One who frotes; one who rubs or chafes.

entry.cs: Froth insect Zoöl the cuckoo spit or frog hopper; -- called also froth spit froth worm, and froth fly. Froth spit. See Cuckoo spit, under Cuckoo.
entry.ety: OE. frothe, Icel. froða; akin to Dan. fraade, Sw. fradga, AS. āfreoðan to froth

sn.def: The bubbles caused in fluids or liquors by fermentation or agitation; spume; foam; esp., a spume of saliva caused by disease or nervous excitement.
Any empty, senseless show of wit or eloquence; rhetoric without thought.
sn.q: It was a long speech, but all froth.

sn.def: Light, unsubstantial matter.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frothed; p. pr. & vb. n.. Frothing

sn.def: To cause to foam.
To spit, vent, or eject, as froth.
sn.q: He . . . froths treason at his mouth.
Is your spleen frothed out, or have ye more?

sn.def: To cover with froth; as, a horse froths his chain.

entry.def: To throw up or out spume, foam, or bubbles; to foam; as beer froths; a horse froths.
In a frothy manner.
State or quality of being frothy.
Exaggerated declamation; rant.
Free from froth.

sn.def: Full of foam or froth, or consisting of froth or light bubbles; spumous; foamy.
Not firm or solid; soft; unstable.
Of the nature of froth; light; empty; unsubstantial; as, a frothy speaker or harangue.

entry.ety: F., of imitative origin

sn.def: A rustling, esp. the rustling of a woman's dress.
showy or frilly ornamentation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frounced; p. pr. & vb. n. Frouncing
entry.ety: OE. frouncen fronsen, to told, wrinkle, OF. froncier, F. froncer, perh. fr. an assumed LL. frontiare to wrinkle the forehead, L. frons forehead. See Front, and cf. Flounce part of a dress
entry.def: To gather into or adorn with plaits, as a dress; to form wrinkles in or upon; to curl or frizzle, as the hair.
entry.q: Not tricked and frounced, as she was wont.

entry.def: To form wrinkles in the forehead; to manifest displeasure; to frown.
entry.q: The Commons frounced and stormed.

sn.def: A wrinkle, plait, or curl; a flounce; -- also, a frown.
An affection in hawks, in which white spittle gathers about the hawk's bill.

entry.def: Without frounces.

entry.ety: Prov. E. frouzy froward, peevish, offensive to the eye or smell; cf. froust a musty smell, frouse to rumple, frouze to curl, and E. frounce frowy
entry.def: Fetid, musty; rank; disordered and offensive to the smell or sight; slovenly; dingy. See Frowzy.
entry.q: Petticoats infrouzyheaps.

entry.ety: D. vrouw; akin to G. frau woman, wife, goth, fráuja master, lord, AS. freá

sn.def: A woman; especially, a Dutch or German woman.
A dirty woman; a slattern.

entry.ety: Cf. Frower
entry.def: A cleaving tool with handle at right angles to the blade, for splitting cask staves and shingles from the block; a frower.
Brittle.

entry.ety: Fro + -ward. See Fro, and cf. Fromward
entry.def: Not willing to yield or compIy with what is required or is reasonable; perverse; disobedient; peevish; as, a froward child.
entry.q: A froward man soweth strife.
A froward retention of custom is as turbulent a thing as innovation.
entry.syn: Untoward; wayward; unyielding; ungovernable: refractory; obstinate; petulant; cross; peevish. See Perverse.

entry.ety: Cf. frow a frower, and Prov. E, frommard
entry.def: A tool. See 2d Frow.

entry.ety: See Frow a.
entry.def: Working smoothly, or without splitting; -- said of timber.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frowned fround; p. pr. & vb. n. Frowning
entry.ety: OF. froignier, F. frogner in se refrogner se renfrogner, to knit the brow, to frown; perh. of Teutonic origin; cf. It. in frigno wrinkled, frowning, Prov. It. frignare to cringe the face, to make a wry face, dial. Sw. fryna to make a wry face,

sn.def: To contract the brow in displeasure, severity, or sternness; to scowl; to put on a stern, grim, or surly look.
sn.q: The frowning wrinkle of her brow.

sn.def: To manifest displeasure or disapprobation; to look with disfavor or threateningly; to lower; as, polite society frowns upon rudeness.
sn.q: The sky doth frown and lower upon our army.

entry.def: To repress or repel by expressing displeasure or disapproval; to rebuke with a look; as, frown the impudent fellow into silence.

sn.def: A wrinkling of the face in displeasure, rebuke, etc.; a sour, severe, or stern look; a scowl.
sn.q: His front yet threatens, and his frowns command.
Her very frowns are fairer far Than smiles of other maidens are.

sn.def: Any expression of displeasure; as, the frowns of Providence; the frowns of Fortune.

entry.def: In a frowning manner.
Frowning; scowling.
entry.q: Her frowny mother's ragged shoulder.

entry.ety: Cf. Frowzy Frouzy
entry.def: Musty; rancid; as, frowy butter.
entry.q: Frowyfeed.

entry.ety: See Frouzy
entry.def: Slovenly; unkempt; untidy; frouzy.
entry.q: With head allfrowzy.
The frowzy soldiers' wives hanging out clothes.

entry.def: imp. of Freeze.

sn.def: Congealed with cold; affected by freezing; as, a frozen brook.
sn.q: They warmed their frozen feet.

sn.def: Subject to frost, or to long and severe cold; chilly; as, the frozen north; the frozen zones.
Cold-hearted; unsympathetic; unyielding.
sn.q: Be not ever frozen, coy.

entry.def: A state of being frozen.

entry.ety: See Furbish
entry.def: To rub up: to furbish.

entry.ety: L. fructus fruit. See Fruit
entry.def: Bearing fruit; -- said of a tree or plant so represented upon an escutcheon.

entry.ety: L. fructus fruit
entry.def: The maturing or ripening of fruit.
Fruitful; full of fruit.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. fructus fruit
entry.def: The twelfth month of the French republican calendar; -- commencing August 18, and ending September 16. See Vendémiaire.

entry.ety: L. fructifer; fructus fruit + ferre to bear; cf. F. fructifère
entry.def: Bearing or producing fruit.

entry.ety: L. fructificatio: cf. F. fructification

sn.def: The act of forming or producing fruit; the act of fructifying, or rendering productive of fruit; fecundation.
sn.q: The prevalent fructification of plants.

sd.def: The collective organs by which a plant produces its fruit, or seeds, or reproductive spores.
The process of producing fruit, or seeds, or spores.

entry.ety: F. fructifier, L. fructificare; fructus fruit + -ficareonly in comp.), akin to L. facere to make. See Fruit, and Fact
entry.def: To bear fruit.
entry.q: Causeth the earth tofructify.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fructified; p. pr. & vb. n. Fructifying
entry.def: To make fruitful; to render productive; to fertilize; as, to fructify the earth.

entry.ety: L. fructus fruit
entry.def: Fruit sugar; levulose.

entries.entry:
Fruc"tu*a*ry frŭk"t�*�*r� n.; pl.Fructuaries -rĭz. L. fructuarius
One who enjoys the profits, income, or increase of anything. Kings are not proprietors nor fructuaries.

entry.def: Produce; fruit.

entry.ety: L. fructuosus: cf, F. fructueux
entry.def: Fruitful; productive; profitable.
entry.q: Nothing fructuous or profitable.

entry.ety: L. frui p. p. fructus, to enjoy. See Fruit n.
entry.def: Use; fruition; enjoyment.

entries.entry: Frue" van"ner. Etymol. uncertain Mining A moving, inclined, endless apron on which ore is concentrated by a current of water; a kind of buddle.

entry.ety: L. frugalis, fr. frugi, lit., for fruit; hence, fit for food, useful, proper, temperate, the dative of frux frugis, fruit, akin to E. fruit: cf. F. frugal. See Fruit n.

sn.def: Economical in the use or appropriation of resources; not wasteful or lavish; wise in the expenditure or application of force, materials, time, etc.; characterized by frugality; sparing; economical; saving; as, a frugal housekeeper; frugal of time.
sn.q: I oft admire How Nature, wise and frugal, could commit Such disproportions.

sn.def: Obtained by, or appropriate to, economy; as, a frugal fortune.
sn.q: Frugalfare.

entries.entry:
Fru*gal"i*ty n.; pl.Frugalities #. L. frugalitas: cf. F. frugalité
The quality of being frugal; prudent economy; that careful management of anything valuable which expends nothing unnecessarily, and applies what is used to a profitable purpose; thrift; --- opposed to extravagance.
Frugality is founded on the principle that all riches have limits.
A sparing use; sparingness; as, frugality of praise. Economy; parsimony. See Economy.

entry.def: Thriftily; prudently.
Quality of being frugal; frugality.

entry.ety: L. frugifer; frux frugis, fruit + ferre to bear: cf. F. frugifere
entry.def: Producing fruit; fruitful; fructiferous.

entry.ety: NL. See Frugivorous
entry.def: The fruit bate; a group of the Cheiroptera, comprising the bats which live on fruits. See Eruit bat, under Fruit.

entry.ety: L. frux frugis, fruit + vorare to devour.: cf. F. frugivore
entry.def: Feeding on fruit, as birds and other animals.

entry.note: ☞ Fruits are classified as fleshy drupaceous, and dry. Fleshy fruits include berries, gourds, and melons, orangelike fruits and pomes; drupaceous fruits are stony within and fleshy without, as peaches, plums, and cherries; and dry fruits are further divided into achenes follicles legumes capsules nuts, and several other kinds.
☞ Fruit is frequently used adjectively, signifying of for or pertaining to a fruit or fruits; as, fruit bud; fruit frame; fruit jar; fruit knife; fruit loft; fruit show; fruit stall; fruit tree; etc.
entry.cs: Fruit bat Zoöl one of the Frugivora; -- called also fruit-eating bat. Fruit bud Bot a bud that produces fruit; -- in most oplants the same as the power bud. Fruit dot Bot a collection of fruit cases, as in ferns. See Sorus.Fruit fly Zoöl a small dipterous insect of the genus Drosophila, which lives in fruit, in the larval state. There are seveal species, some of which are very damaging to fruit crops. One species, Drosophila melanogaster, has been intensively studied as a model species for genetic reserach. Fruit jar a jar for holding preserved fruit, usually made of glass or earthenware. Fruit pigeon Zoöl one of numerous species of pigeons of the family Carpophagidæ, inhabiting India, Australia, and the Pacific Islands. They feed largely upon fruit. and are noted for their beautiful colors. Fruit sugar Chem a kind of sugar occurring, naturally formed, in many ripe fruits, and in honey; levulose. The name is also, though rarely, applied to invert sugar, or to the natural mixture or dextrose and levulose resembling it, and found in fruits and honey. Fruit tree Hort a tree cultivated for its edible fruit. Fruit worm Zoöl one of numerous species of insect larvæ: which live in the interior of fruit. They are mostly small species of Lepidoptera and Diptera. Small fruits Hort currants, raspberries, strawberries, etc.
entry.ety: OE. fruit frut, F. fruit, from L. fructus enjoyment, product, fruit, from frui, p. p. fructus, to enjoy; akin to E. brook v. t. See Brook v. t., and cf. Fructify Frugal

sn.def: Whatever is produced for the nourishment or enjoyment of man or animals by the processes of vegetable growth, as corn, grass, cotton, flax, etc.; -- commonly used in the plural.
sn.q: Six years thou shalt sow thy land, and shalt gather in thefruits thereof.

sn.def: The pulpy, edible seed vessels of certain plants, especially those grown on branches above ground, as apples, oranges, grapes, melons, berries, etc. See 3.
The ripened ovary of a flowering plant, with its contents and whatever parts are consolidated with it.
The spore cases or conceptacles of flowerless plants, as of ferns, mosses, algae, etc., with the spores contained in them.
The produce of animals; offspring; young; as, the fruit of the womb, of the loins, of the body.
sn.q: King Edward's fruit, true heir to the English crown.

sn.def: That which is produced; the effect or consequence of any action; advantageous or desirable product or result; disadvantageous or evil consequence or effect; as, the fruits of labor, of self-denial, of intemperance.
sn.q: The fruit of rashness.
What I obtained was the fruit of no bargain.
They shall eat the fruit of their doings.
The fruits of this education became visible.

entry.def: To bear fruit.

entry.ety: F. fruitage

sn.def: Fruit, collectively; fruit, in general; fruitery.
sn.q: The trees . . . ambrosial fruitage bear.

sn.def: Product or result of any action; effect, good or ill.

entry.def: A ship for carrying fruit.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fruitier
entry.def: One who deals in fruit; a seller of fruits.
A woman who sells fruit.

entries.entry:
Fruit"er*y n.; pl.Fruiteries #. F. fruiterie place where fruit is kept, in OF. also, fruitage
Fruit, taken collectively; fruitage.
A repository for fruit.

entry.def: A fruiteress.
Full of fruit; producing fruit abundantly; bearing results; prolific; fertile; liberal; bountiful; as, a fruitful tree, or season, or soil; a fruitful wife.
entry.q: Be fruitful and multiply and replenish the earth.
Nature] By disburdening grows More fruitful.
The great fruitfulness of the poet's fancy.
entry.syn: Fertile; prolific; productive; fecund; plentiful; rich; abundant; plenteous. See Fertile.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or producing, fruit.
The bearing of fruit.

entry.ety: OF. fruition, L. fruitio, enjoyment, fr. L. frui, p. p. fruitus, to use or enjoy. See Fruit n.
entry.def: Use or possession of anything, especially such as is accompanied with pleasure or satisfaction; pleasure derived from possession or use.
entry.q: Capacity offruition.
Godlikefruition.
Where I may have fruition of her love.

entry.ety: See Fruition
entry.def: Enjoying; possessing.

sn.def: Lacking, or not bearing, fruit; barren; destitute of offspring; as, a fruitless tree or shrub; a fruitless marriage.
Productive of no advantage or good effect; vain; idle; useless; unprofitable; as, a fruitless attempt; a fruitless controversy.
sn.q: They in mutual accusation spent The fruitless hours.
sn.syn: Useless; barren; unprofitable; abortive; ineffectual; vain; idle; profitless. See Useless.

entry.def: Having the odor, taste, or appearance of fruit; also, fruitful.

entry.ety: L. frumentaceus, fr. frumentum corn or grain, from the root of frux fruit: cf. F. frumentacé. See Frugal
entry.def: Made of, or resembling, wheat or other grain.

entry.ety: L. frumentarius
entry.def: Of or pertaining to wheat or grain.

entry.ety: L. frumentatio
entry.def: A largess of grain bestowed upon the people, to quiet them when uneasy.

entry.ety: OF. fromentée, fr. L. frumentum. See Frumentaceous
entry.def: Food made of hulled wheat boiled in milk, with sugar, plums, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. Prov. E. frumple to wrinkle, ruffle, D. frommelen
entry.def: To insult; to flout; to mock; to snub.

sn.def: A contemptuous speech or piece of conduct; a gibe or flout.
A cross, old-fashioned person; esp., an old woman; a gossip.

entry.def: A mocker.

sn.def: Cross-tempered; scornful.
Old-fashioned, as a woman's dress.
sn.q: Our Bell . . . looked very frumpish.

entry.ety: F. froisser to bruise. Cf. Froise
entry.def: To batter; to break in pieces.
entry.q: I like thine armor well; I'll frush it and unlock the rivets all.

entry.def: Easily broken; brittle; crisp.
Noise; clatter; crash.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. frosch frosk, a frog (the animal), G. frosch frog (the animal), also carney or lampass of horses. See Frog n., 2

sn.def: The frog of a horse's foot.
A discharge of a fetid or ichorous matter from the frog of a horse's foot; -- also caled thrush.

entry.ety: L. frustrabilis: cf. F. frustable
entry.def: Capable of beeing frustrated or defeated.

entry.ety: See Frustrate a.
entry.def: Vain; useless; unprofitable.

entry.ety: L. frustratus, p. p. of frustrare frustrari, to deceive, frustrate, fr. frustra in vain, witout effect, in erorr, prob. for frudtra and akin to fraus, E. fraud
entry.def: Vain; ineffectual; useless; unprofitable; null; voil; nugatory; of no effect.
entry.q: Ourfrustratesearch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Frustrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Frustrating

sn.def: To bring to nothing; to prevent from attaining a purpose; to disappoint; to defeat; to baffle; as, to frustrate a plan, design, or attempt; to frustrate the will or purpose.
sn.q: Shall the adversary thus obtain His end and frustrate thine ?

sn.def: To make null; to nullifly; to render invalid or of no effect; as, to frustrate a conveyance or deed.
sn.syn: To balk; thwart; foil; baffle; defeat.

entry.def: In vain.
an act of hindering someone's plans or efforts.

sn.def: preventing realization or attainment of a desire; causing frustration.
discouraging. Opposite of encouraging.

entry.ety: L. frustratio: cf. OF. frustration
entry.def: The act of frustrating; disappointment; defeat; as, the frustration of one's designs.
Tending to defeat; fallacious.

entry.ety: L. frustratorius: cf. F. frustratoire
entry.def: Making void; rendering null; as, a frustratory appeal.

entry.ety: L. frustulum, dim. fr. frustum a piece: cf. F. frustule
entry.def: The siliceous shell of a diatom. It is composed of two valves, one overlapping the other, like a pill box and its cover.

entry.ety: L. frustulentus. See Frustule
entry.def: Abounding in fragments.

entries.entry:
‖Frus"tum n.; pl. L. Frusta #, E. Frustums #. L. fruslum piece, bit
Geom The part of a solid next the base, formed by cutting off the, top; or the part of any solid, as of a cone, pyramid, etc., between two planes, which may be either parallel or inclined to each other.
Arch One of the drums of the shaft of a column.

entry.ety: Cf. Fruitage

sn.def: A picture of fruit; decoration by representation of fruit.
sn.q: The cornices consist of frutages and festoons.

sn.def: A confection of fruit.

entry.ety: L. frutex fruticis, shrub, bush: cf. F. frutescent, L. fruticescens p. pr.
entry.def: Somewhat shrubby in character; imperfectly shrubby, as the American species of Wisteria.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A plant having a woody, durable stem, but less than a tree; a shrub.

entry.ety: L. fruticans p. pr. of fruticare, to become bushy, fr. frutex, fruticis, shrub
entry.def: Full of shoots.

entry.ety: L. fruticosus, from frutex, fruticis, shrub
entry.def: Pertaining to a shrub or shrubs; branching like a shrub; shrubby; shrublike; as, a fruticose stem.
Fruticose.

entry.ety: Dim. fr. L. fruticosus bushy: cf. F. fruticuleux
entry.def: Like, or pertaining to, a small shrub.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fried frīd; p. pr. & vb. n. Frying
entry.ety: OE. frien, F. frire, fr. L. frigere to roast, parch, fry, cf. Gr. �, Skr. bhrajj. Cf. Fritter
entry.def: To cook in a pan or on a griddle (esp. with the use of fat, butter, or olive oil) by heating over a fire; to cook in boiling lard or fat; as, to fry fish; to fry doughnuts.

sn.def: To undergo the process of frying; to be subject to the action of heat in a frying pan, or on a griddle, or in a kettle of hot fat.
To simmer; to boil.
sn.q: With crackling flames a caldron fries.
The frothy billows fry.

sn.def: To undergo or cause a disturbing action accompanied with a sensation of heat.
sn.q: To keep the oil from frying in the stomach.

sn.def: To be agitated; to be greatly moved.
sn.q: What kindling motions in their breasts do fry.

sn.def: A dish of anything fried.
A state of excitement; as, to be in a fry .

entry.ety: OE. fri fry, seed, descendants, cf. OF. froye spawning, spawn of. fishes, little fishes, fr. L. fricare tosub (see Friction), but cf. also Icel. fræ frjō, seed, Sw. & Dan. frö, Goth. fraiw seed, descendants

sn.def: The young of any fish.
A swarm or crowd, especially of little fishes; young or small things in general.
sn.q: The fry of children young.
To sever . . . the good fish from the other fry.
We have burned two frigates, and a hundred and twenty small fry.

sn.def: Something or someone that fries.

entry.ety: acronym from File Transfer Protocol
entry.def: An acronym for file transfer protocol, a standardized protocol used to allow transmission of files between computers; as, send me the file by ftp . It consists of a set of coded signals which are transmitted between computers, and which inform the receiving computer of the nature of a packet of information to be transmitted, and inform the transmitting computer when a packet has been successfully received.

entry.note: The participle forms have not been standardized, and either lower-case or upper-case may be used, but when lower-case is used, either a hyphen or apostrophe is used before the ed or ing endings.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. ftp'dorFTP'd ĕf`tē*pēd"; p. pr. & vb. n. FTPingorftp'ingorftp-ing ĕf`tē*pē"ĭng
entry.ety: acronym from File Transfer Protocol
entry.def: To send from one computer to another by means of the standard file transfer protocol (ftp); as, he ftp'd me the file yesterday.

entries.entry:
Fuch"si*a n.; pl. E. Fuchsias #, L. Fuchsiæ #. NL. Named after Leonard Fuchs , a German botanist
Bot A genus of flowering plants having elegant drooping flowers, with four sepals, four petals, eight stamens, and a single pistil. They are natives of Mexico and South America. Double-flowered varieties are now common in cultivation.
A plant belonging to the genus Fuschia.

entry.ety: Named by the French inventor, from Fuchs a fox, the German equivalent of his own name, Renard
entry.def: Aniline red; an artificial coal-tar dyestuff, of a metallic green color superficially, resembling cantharides, but when dissolved forming a brilliant dark red. It consists of a hydrochloride or acetate of rosaniline. See Rosaniline.

entry.ety: Fucus + L. vorare to eat

A slang term for sexual intercourse.
entry.syn: fucking, screw, screwing, ass, piece of ass, roll in the hay, shag.

entry.syn: love, make love, sleep with, get laid, have sex, know, do it, be intimate, have intercourse, have it away, have it off, screw, jazz, eff, have, hump, lie with, bed, have a go at it, get it on, bonk.

entry.def: snarled or stalled in complete confusion.
a stupid foolish man.

entry.def: the act of sexual intercourse.
entry.syn: fuck, screw, screwing, ass, piece of ass, roll in the hay, shag.

entry.def: unpleasant; annoying; -- also used as an informal intensifier.

entry.ety: Fucus + -oid
entry.def: Properly, belonging to an order of alga: (Fucoideæ) which are blackish in color, and produce oöspores which are not fertilized until they have escaped from the conceptacle. The common rockweeds and the gulfweed (Sargassum) are fucoid in character.
In a vague sense, resembling seaweeds, or of the nature of seaweeds.
A plant, whether recent or fossil, which resembles a seaweed. See Fucoid a.

sn.def: Fucoid.
Containing impressions of fossil fucoids or seaweeds; as, fucoidal sandstone.

entries.entry:
Fu"cus ☞ Formerly most marine algæ were called fuci. n.; pl.Fuci #. L. rock lichen, orchil, used as a red dye, red or purple color, disguise, deceit
A paint; a dye; also, false show. Obs
Bot A genus of tough, leathery seaweeds, usually of a dull brownish green color; rockweed.

entry.ety: Fucus + L. oleum oil

a term or factor inserted into a calculation to compensate for anticipated errors, or to arbitrarily make the result conform to some desired conclusion.

in the gugue style, but not strictly like a fugue.

sn.def: Fleeing from pursuit, danger, restraint, etc., escaping, from service, duty etc.; as, a fugitive solder; a fugitive slave; a fugitive debtor.
sn.q: The fugitive Parthians follow.
Can a fugitive daughter enjoy herself while her parents are in tear?
A libellous pamphlet of a fugitive physician.

sn.def: Not fixed; not durable; liable to disappear or fall away; volatile; uncertain; evanescent; liable to fade; -- applied to material and immaterial things; as, fugitive colors; a fugitive idea.
sn.q: The me more tender and fugitive parts, the leaves . . . of vegatables.
sn.syn: Fleeting; unstable; wandering; uncertain; volatile; fugacious; fleeing; evanescent.

cs.cd: one who, having committed a crime in one jurisdiction, flees or escapes into another to avoid punishment.

sn.def: One who flees from pursuit, danger, restraint, service, duty, etc.; a deserter; as, a fugitive from justice.
Something hard to be caught or detained.

The quality or condition of being fugitive; evanescence; volatility; fugacity; instability.
To maneuver; to move hither and thither.

entries.entry:
Fu"gle*man n.; pl.Fuglemen #. G. flügelmann file leader; flügel wing (akin to E. fly) + mann man. Cf. Flugrelman
Mil A soldier especially expert and well drilled, who takes his place in front of a military company, as a guide for the others in their exercises; a file leader. He originally stood in front of the right wing.
flugelman
Hence, one who leads the way. Jocose

entry.ety: F., fr. It. fuga, fr. L. fuga a fleeing, flight, akin to fugere to fiee. See Fugitive
entry.def: A polyphonic composition, developed from a given theme or themes, according to strict contrapuntal rules. The theme is first given out by one voice or part, and then, while that pursues its way, it is repeated by another at the interval of a fifth or fourth, and so on, until all the parts have answered one by one, continuing their several melodies and interweaving them in one complex progressive whole, in which the theme is often lost and reappears.
entry.q: All parts of the scheme are eternally chasing each other, like the parts of a fugue.

entry.def: A musician who composes or performs fugues.

entries.entry:
-ful. See Full a.
A suffix signifying full of abounding with; as, boastful, harmful, woeful .

Fu"lahs` Foo"lahs` Fu"la*ni
n. pl.; sing. Fulah Foolah . Ethnol A peculiar African race of uncertain origin, but distinct from the negro tribes, inhabiting an extensive region of Western Soudan. Their color is brown or yellowish bronze. They are Mohammedans. Called also Fellatahs Foulahs, and Fellani. Fulah and Fulani are also used adjectively; as, Fulah or Fulani empire, tribes, language.

entry.def: The language of the Fulani people, a member of the Niger-Congo family of languages.
Same as Fulahs.

entry.ety: L. fulcire to prop

Furnished with fulcrums.

entries.entry:
Ful"crum n.; pl. L. Fulcra #, E. Fulcrums #. L., bedpost, fr. fulcire to prop
A prop or support.
Mech That by which a lever is sustained, or about which it turns in lifting or moving a body.
Bot An accessory organ such as a tendril, stipule, spine, and the like. R
Zoöl
The horny inferior surface of the lingua of certain insects.
One of the small, spiniform scales found on the front edge of the dorsal and caudal fins of many ganoid fishes.
Anat The connective tissue supporting the framework of the retina of the eye.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fulfilled; p. pr. & vb. n. Fulfilling
entry.ety: OE. fulfillen fulfullen, AS. fulfyllan; ful full + fyllan to fill. See Full a., and Fill v. t.

sn.def: To fill up; to make full or complete.
sn.q: Fulfillher week
Suffer thou that the children be fulfilled first, for it is not good to take the bread of children and give to hounds.

sn.def: To accomplish or carry into effect, as an intention, promise, or prophecy, a desire, prayer, or requirement, etc.; to complete by performance; to answer the requisitions of; to bring to pass, as a purpose or design; to effectuate.
sn.q: He will, fulfill the desire of them fear him.
Here Nature seems fulfilled in all her ends.
Servants must their masters' minds fulfill.

entry.def: One who fulfills.

entry.ety: Written also fulfilment

sn.def: The act of fulfilling; accomplishment; completion; as, the fulfillment of prophecy.
Execution; performance; as, the fulfillment of a promise.

entry.ety: See fulgent
entry.def: Brightness; splendor; glitter; effulgence.

entry.ety: L. fulgens -entis p. pr. of fulgere to flash, glitter, shine, akin to Gr. � to burn. See Phlox Flagrant

entry.q: Other Thracians . . . fulgent morions wore.

entry.def: Dazzlingly; glitteringly.

entry.ety: L. fulgidus. See Fulgent
entry.def: Shining; glittering; dazzling.
Splendor; resplendence; effulgence.

entry.ety: L. fulgor, fr. fulgere to shine
entry.def: Dazzling brightness; splendor.

entry.ety: L. fulgurans p. pr. of fulgurare
entry.def: Lightening.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A spectro-electric tube in which the decomposition of a liquid by the passage of an electric spark is observed.

entry.def: To flash as lightning.
Resembling lightning; -- used to describe intense lancinating pains accompanying locomotor ataxy.

entry.ety: L. fulguratio: cf. F. fulguration

sn.def: The act of lightening.
The sudden brightening of a fused globule of gold or silver, when the last film of the oxide of lead or copper leaves its surface; -- also called blick.
sn.q: A phenomenon called, by the old chemists, fulguration.

entry.ety: L. fulguritus, p. p. of fulgurire to strike with lightning, fr. fulgur lightning: cf. F. fulgurite
entry.def: A vitrified sand tube produced by the striking of lightning on sand; a lightning tube; also, the portion of rock surface fused by a lightning discharge.

entry.ety: L. fulgur
entry.def: Lightning.

entry.ety: So named because supposed to have been chiefly made at Fulham, in Middlesex, Eng
entry.def: A false die.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fuliginosité
entry.def: The condition or quality of being fuliginous; sootiness; matter deposited by smoke.

sn.def: Pertaining to soot; sooty; dark; dusky.
Pertaining to smoke; resembling smoke.

entry.def: In a smoky manner.
Same as Foumart.

entry.cs:
At full when full or complete. Shak. Full age Law the age at which one attains full personal rights; majority; -- in England and the United States the age of 21 years. Abbott. Full and by Naut sailing closehauled, having all the sails full, and lying as near the wind as poesible. Full band Mus a band in which all the instruments are employed. Full binding the binding of a book when made wholly of leather, as distinguished from half binding. Full bottom a kind of wig full and large at the bottom.
Full brotherorFull sister
a brother or sister having the same parents as another. Full cry Hunting eager chase; -- said of hounds that have caught the scent, and give tongue together. Full dress the dress prescribed by authority or by etiquette to be worn on occasions of ceremony. Full hand Poker three of a kind and a pair. Full moon. The moon with its whole disk illuminated, as when opposite to the sun. The time when the moon is full. Full organ Mus the organ when all or most stops are out. Full score Mus a score in which all the parts for voices and instruments are given. Full sea high water. Full swing free course; unrestrained liberty; “Leaving corrupt nature to . . . the full swing and freedom of its own extravagant actings.” South (Colloq
In full at length; uncontracted; unabridged; written out in words, and not indicated by figures. In full blast. See under Blast.
entry.ety: OE. & AS. ful; akin to OS. ful, D. vol, OHG. fol, G. voll, Icel. fullr, Sw. full, Dan. fuld, Goth. fulls, L. plenus, Gr. plh`rhs, Skr. pūṛna full, prā to fill, also to Gr. poly`s much, E. poly-, pref., G. viel, AS. fela. √80. Cf. Complete Fill Plenary Plenty

sn.def: Filled up, having within its limits all that it can contain; supplied; not empty or vacant; -- said primarily of hollow vessels, and hence of anything else; as, a cup full of water; a house full of people.
sn.q: Had the throne been full, their meeting would not have been regular.

sn.def: Abundantly furnished or provided; sufficient in quantity, quality, or degree; copious; plenteous; ample; adequate; as, a full meal; a full supply; a full voice; a full compensation; a house full of furniture.
Not wanting in any essential quality; complete; entire; perfect; adequate; as, a full narrative; a person of full age; a full stop; a full face; the full moon.
sn.q: It came to pass, at the end of two full years, that Pharaoh dreamed.
The man commands Like a full soldier.
I can not Request a fuller satisfaction Than you have freely granted.

sn.def: Sated; surfeited.
sn.q: I am full of the burnt offerings of rams.

sn.def: Having the mind filled with ideas; stocked with knowledge; stored with information.
sn.q: Reading maketh a full man.

sn.def: Having the attention, thoughts, etc., absorbed in any matter, and the feelings more or less excited by it, as, to be full of some project.
sn.q: Every one is full of the miracles done by cold baths on decayed and weak constitutions.

sn.def: Filled with emotions.
sn.q: The heart is so full that a drop overfills it.

sn.def: Impregnated; made pregnant.
sn.q: Ilia, the fair, . . . full of Mars.

cs.cd: the time of full moon.

entry.def: Complete measure; utmost extent; the highest state or degree.
entry.q: The swan's-down feather, That stands upon the swell at full of tide.

entry.note: ☞ Full is placed before adjectives and adverbs to heighten or strengthen their signification. “Full sad.” Milton. “Master of a full poor cell.” Shak. “Full many a gem of purest ray serene.” T. Gray. Full is also prefixed to participles to express utmost extent or degree; as, full-bloomed, full-blown, full-crammed full-grown, full-laden, full-stuffed, etc. Such compounds, for the most part, are self-defining.
entry.def: Quite; to the same degree; without abatement or diminution; with the whole force or effect; thoroughly; completely; exactly; entirely.
entry.q: The pawn I proffer shall be full as good.
The diapason closing full in man.
Full in the center of the sacred wood.

entry.def: To become full or wholly illuminated; as, the moon fulls at midnight.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fulled; p. pr. & vb. n. Fulling
entry.ety: OE. fullen, OF. fuler fouler, F. fouler, LL. fullare, fr. L. fullo fuller, cloth fuller, cf. Gr. � shining, white, AS. fullian to whiten as a fuller, to baptize, fullere a fuller. Cf. Defile to foul, Foil to frustrate, Fuller. n.
entry.def: To thicken by moistening, heating, and pressing, as cloth; to mill; to make compact; to scour, cleanse, and thicken in a mill.
To become fulled or thickened; as, this material fulls well.
The money or price paid for fulling or cleansing cloth.
A false die. See Fulham.
an offensive football player who plays farther behind the line of scrimmage than the half-back. They are used primarily for blocking and line plunges.

sn.def: To play the position of fullback on a football team; to be the fullback.

Of pure blood; thoroughbred; as, a full-blooded horse.

entry.def: Like a perfect blossom.

sn.def: Fully expanded, as a blossom; completely developed; as, a full-blown rose.
Fully distended with wind, as a sail.
Of full intensity; as, the recession developed into full-blown depression; a full-blown international crisis.

entry.def: having a pronounced womanly shape, with well-developed breasts.
entry.syn: bosomy, buxom, curvaceous, sonsie, sonsy, voluptuous.

sn.def: Full and large at the bottom, as wigs worn by certain civil officers in Great Britain.
Of great capacity below the water line.

entry.def: With direct and violent opposition; with sudden collision.
full evening dress for men.
entry.syn: dress suit, full dress, tailcoat, tail coat, tails, white tie, white tie and tails.

sn.def: suitable for formal occasions; as, a full-dress uniform.
requiring formal clothes; -- of a social event; as, a full-dress ceremony.
complete in every respect, including formalities; as, a full-dress debate; a full-dress investigation.

entry.def: With full speed.

the soapwort (Saponaria officinalis), formerly used to remove stains from cloth.
the teasel (Dipsacus fullonum) whose burs are used by fullers in dressing cloth. See Teasel.
