entry.def: One whose occupation is to full cloth.

entry.ety: From Full a.
entry.def: A die; a half-round set hammer, used for forming grooves and spreading iron; -- called also a creaser.
To form a groove or channel in, by a fuller or set hammer; as, to fuller a bayonet.

entries.entry: Full"er*y n.; pl.Fulleries. The place or the works where the fulling of cloth is carried on.

entry.def: looking forward.
knitted to fit the shape of the body; as, full-fashioned hosiery.

sn.def: having reached full development with fully grown adult plumage; ready to fly; -- of a bird.
having gained full status; -- of persons in respect to human roles; as, a full-fledged lawyer; by the age of seventeen I was a full-fledged atheist .

entry.def: Full in form or shape; rounded out with flesh.
entry.q: The full-formed maids of Afric.

entry.def: Having reached the limits of growth; mature; fully developed; -- used mostly of living organisms; as, A full-grown lion can easily kill an unarmed man..
entry.q: Full-grownwings.

entry.def: Full of courage or confidence.
Very fiery.

entries.entry: Full house. Poker A hand containing three of a kind and a pair, as three kings and two tens. It ranks above a flush and below four of a kind.

cs.cd: a mill for fulling cloth as by means of pesties or stampers, which alternately fall into and rise from troughs where the cloth is placed with hot water and fuller's earth, or other cleansing materials.

entry.def: The process of cleansing, shrinking, and thickening cloth by moisture, heat, and pressure.

sn.def: accommodating the full height of the human figure; as, a full-length mirror.
representing the full height of the human figure; as, a full-length portrait.
unabridged; as, the full-length play. Opposite of abridged.

entry.def: Completely furnished wiith men, as a ship.
See Foumart.
The state of being full, or of abounding; abundance; completeness.
entry.q: “In thy presence is fullness of joy.”

entry.def: the time when the moon is fully illuminated.

entry.ety: L. fullonicus, from fullo a cloth fuller
entry.def: Pertaining to a fuller of cloth.
Having the orb or disk complete or fully illuminated; like the full moon.

sn.def: occupying an entire page in a book or paper; as, a full-page ad.

entry.def: Having all its sails set,; hence, without restriction or reservation.
using all available resources; -- of actions; as, a full-scale effort to find the perpetrator.
Being of the same size as an original.
Undiluted; -- of liquids. Opposite of diluted.
Gestated for the entire duration of normal pregnancy; as, a healthy full-term baby; -- of new-born infants. Opposite of premature.
spending or requiring all of the time normally given to an activity; as, full-time students; a full-time job. Opposite of part-time.

sn.def: Having large and strong or complete wings.
Ready for flight; eager.

cs.cd: committed to prison for trial, in distinction from being detained for examination.

entry.def: In a full manner or degree; completely; entirely; without lack or defect; adequately; satisfactorily; as, to be fully persuaded of the truth of a proposition.
entry.syn: Completely; entirely; maturely; plentifully; abundantly; plenteously; copiously; largely; amply; sufficiently; clearly; distinctly; perfectly.

entry.ety: Icel. fūlmār. See foul, and Man a gull
entry.def: One of several species of sea birds, of the family Procellariidæ, allied to the albatrosses and petrels. Among the well-known species are the arctic fulmar Fulmarus glacialis) (called also fulmar petrel malduck, and mollemock), and the giant fulmar (Ossifraga gigantea).
A genus of birds including many of the fulmars.

entry.ety: L. fulminans p. pr. of fulminare to lighten: cf. F. fulminant
entry.def: Thundering; fulminating.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fulminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Fulminating
entry.ety: L. fulminatus, p. p. of fulminare to lighten, strike with lightning, fr. fulmen thunderbolt, fr. fulgere to shine. See Fulgent, and cf. Fulmine

sn.def: To thunder; hence, to make a loud, sudden noise; to detonate; to explode with a violent report.
To issue or send forth decrees or censures with the assumption of supreme authority; to thunder forth menaces.
To cause to explode.
To utter or send out with denunciations or censures; -- said especially of menaces or censures uttered by ecclesiastical authority.
sn.q: They fulminated the most hostile of all decrees.

cs.cd: an explosive compound of gold; -- called also fulminating gold, and aurum fulminans.

entry.ety: Cf. P. fulminate. See Fulminate v. i.
entry.def: A salt of fulminic acid. See under Fulminic.
A fulminating powder.

The mercury salt of fulminic acid (Hg(CNO)2), called also mercury fulminate. It is prepared as gray crystals, and is used primarily in detonators for detonating high explosives, such as dynamite or TNT.

cs.cd: nitroglycerin.
any violently explosive powder, but especially one of the fulminates, as mercuric fulminate.

sn.def: Thundering; exploding in a peculiarly sudden or violent manner.
Hurling denunciations, menaces, or censures.

entry.ety: L. fulminatio a darting of lightning: cf. F. fulmination

sn.def: The act of fulminating or exploding; detonation.
The act of thundering forth threats or censures, as with authority.
That which is fulminated or thundered forth; vehement menace or censure.
sn.q: The fulminations from the Vatican were turned into ridicule.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fulminatoire
entry.def: Thundering; striking terror.

entry.ety: F. fulminer. See Fulminate v.
entry.def: To thunder.
To shoot; to dart like lightning; to fulminate; to utter with authority or vehemence.
entry.q: She fulmined out her scorn of laws Salique.

entry.ety: L. fulmen thunder
entry.def: Of, or concerning thunder.

cs.cd: a complex acid, H2C2N2O2, isomeric with cyanic and cyanuric acids, and not known in the free state, but forming a large class of highly explosive salts, the fulminates. Of these, mercuric fulminate, the most common, is used, mixed with niter, to fill percussion caps, charge cartridges, etc. Fulminic acid is made by the action of nitric acid on alcohol.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fulminique
entry.def: Pertaining to fulmination; detonating; specifically Chem, pertaining to, derived from, or denoting, an acid, so called; as, fulminic acid.

cs.cd: a white, crystalline, explosive substance, H3C3N3O3, forming well known salts, and obtained from the fulminates. It is isomeric with cyanuric acid, and hence is also called isocyanuric acid.

entry.ety: Fulminic + cyanuric
entry.def: Pertaining to fulminic and cyanuric acids, and designating an acid so called.
See Fullness.

entry.ety: See Fulsome
entry.def: Fulsome.

entry.ety: Full, a. + -some

sn.def: Full; abundant; plenteous; not shriveled.
sn.q: His lean, pale, hoar, and withered corpse grew fulsome, fair, and fresh.

sn.def: Offending or disgusting by overfullness, excess, or grossness; cloying; gross; nauseous; esp., offensive from excess of praise; as, fulsome flattery.
sn.q: And lest the fulsome artifice should fail Themselves will hide its coarseness with a veil.

sn.def: Lustful; wanton; obscene; also, tending to obscenity.
sn.q: Fulsome ewes.

entry.ety: LL. fulvidus, fr. L. fulvus
entry.def: Fulvous.

entry.ety: L. fulvus
entry.def: Tawny; dull yellow, with a mixture of gray and brown.
To play upon a fiddle.
entry.q: Follow me, and fum as you go.

entry.ety: From Fume
entry.def: Smoky; hence, fond of smoking; addicted to smoking tobacco.

entries.entry:
Fu*made" Fu*ma"do
n.; pl.Fumades # Fumadoes #. Sp. fumodo smoked, p. p. of fumar to smoke, fr. L. fumare. See Fume v. i.
A salted and smoked fish, as the pilchard.

entry.ety: OF. fumage fumaige, fr. L. fumus smoke
entry.def: Hearth money.
entry.q: Fumage, or fuage, vulgarly called smoke farthings.

entry.def: A salt of fumaric acid.

cs.cd: a widely occurring organic acid, extracted from fumitory as a white crystallline substance, C2H2(CO2H)2, and produced artificially in many ways, as by the distillation of malic acid; boletic acid. It is found also in the lichen, Iceland moss, and hence was also called lichenic acid.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, fumitory (Fumaria officinalis).

entry.ety: L. fumus smoke, fume
entry.def: An alkaloid extracted from fumitory, as a white crystalline substance.

entry.ety: It. fumaruola, fr. fumo smoke, L. fumus: cf. F. fumerolle fumarolle
entry.def: A hole or spot in a volcanic or other region, from which fumes issue.

entries.entry: ‖Fu`ma*to"ri*um n.; L. pl.-ria # . NL., fr. L. fumare fumatum, to smoke An air-tight compartment in which vapor may be generated to destroy germs or insects; esp., the apparatus used to destroy San José scale on nursery stock, with hydrocyanic acid vapor.

entry.ety: See Fumatorium
entry.def: Pert. to, or concerned with, smoking.
entry.def2: n.; pl.-ries . A place for subjecting things to smoke or vapor.

entry.def: See Fumitory.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fumbled; p. pr. & vb. n. Fumbling
entry.ety: Akin to D. fommelen to crumple, fumble, Sw. fumla to fusuble, famla to grope, Dan. famle to grope, fumble, Icel. falme, AS. folm palm of the hand. See Feel, and cf. Fanble Palm

sn.def: To feel or grope about; to make awkward attempts to do or find something.
sn.q: Adams now began to fumble in his pockets.

sn.def: To grope about in perplexity; to seek awkwardly; as, to fumble for an excuse.
sn.q: My understanding flutters and my memory fumbles.
Alas! how he fumbles about the domains.

sn.def: To handle much; to play childishly; to turn over and over.
sn.q: I saw him fumble with the sheets, and play with flowers.

entry.def: To handle or manage awkwardly; to crowd or tumble together.
One who fumbles.
In the manner of one who fumbles.

cs.cd: in ill temper, esp. from impatience.

entry.ety: L. fumus; akin to Skr. dhūma smoke, dhū to shake, fan a flame, cf. Gr. qy`ein to sacrifice, storm, rage, qy`mon qy`mos, thyme, and perh. to E. dust: cf. OF. fum smoke, F. fumée. Cf. Dust n. Femerell Thyme

sn.def: Exhalation; volatile matter (esp. noxious vapor or smoke) ascending in a dense body; smoke; vapor; reek; as, the fumes of tobacco.
sn.q: The fumes of new shorn hay.
The fumes of undigested wine.

sn.def: Rage or excitement which deprives the mind of self-control; as, the fumes of passion.
Anything vaporlike, unsubstantial, or airy; idle conceit; vain imagination.
sn.q: A show of fumes and fancies.

sn.def: The incense of praise; inordinate flattery.
sn.q: To smother him with fumes and eulogies.

sn.def: Solid material deposited by condensation of fumes; as, lead fumea grayish powder chiefly lead sulphate.

cs.cd: to give way to excitement and displeasure; to storm; also, to pass off in fumes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fumed; p. pr. & vb. n. Fuming
entry.ety: Cf. F. fumer, L. fumare to smoke. See Fume n.

sn.def: To smoke; to throw off fumes, as in combustion or chemical action; to rise up, as vapor.
sn.q: Where the golden altar fumed.
Silenus lay, Whose constant cups lay fuming to his brain.

sn.def: To be as in a mist; to be dulled and stupefied.
sn.q: Keep his brain fuming.

sn.def: To pass off in fumes or vapors.
sn.q: Their parts are kept from fuming away by their fixity.

sn.def: To be in a rage; to be hot with anger.
sn.q: He frets, he fumes, he stares, he stamps the ground.
While her mother did fret, and her father did fume.

sn.def: To expose to the action of fumes; to treat with vapors, smoke, etc.; as, to bleach straw by fuming it with sulphur; to fill with fumes, vapors, odors, etc., as a room.
sn.q: She fumed the temple with an odorous flame.

sn.def: To praise inordinately; to flatter.
sn.q: They demi-deify and fume him so.

sn.def: To throw off in vapor, or as in the form of vapor.
sn.q: The heat will fume away most of the scent.
How vicious hearts fume frenzy to the brain!

entries.entry: Fumed oak. Cabinetwork Oak given a weathered appearance by exposure in an air-tight compartment to fumes of ammonia from uncorked cans, being first given a coat of filler.

entry.def: Free from fumes.

sn.def: One that fumes.
One who makes or uses perfumes.
sn.q: Embroiderers, feather makers, fumers.

entry.def: See Femerell.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fumier dung, OF. femier, fr. L. fimus dung
entry.def: The dung of deer.

entry.ety: F. fumet odor, fume of wine or meat, fr. L. fumus smoke. See Fume n.
entry.def: The stench or high flavor of game or other meat when kept long.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A high-flavored substance, such as extract of game, for flavoring dishes of food; less properly, a ragout of partridge and rabbit braised in wine.
Fumitory.

entry.ety: L. fumidus, fr. fumus smoke. See Fume
entry.def: Smoky; vaporous.
The state of being fumid; smokiness.

entry.ety: L. fumifer; fumus smoke + ferre to bear
entry.def: Producing smoke.

entry.ety: L. fumus smoke + fugare to put to flight, fugere to flee
entry.def: One who, or that which, drives away smoke or fumes.

entry.ety: Fume + -fy
entry.def: To subject to the action of smoke.

entry.ety: L. fumigans p. pr. of fumigare. See Fumigate
entry.def: Fuming.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fumigated; p. pr. & vb. n. Fumigating
entry.ety: L. fumigate, p. p. of fumigare to fumigate, fr. fumus smoke. See Fume n.

sn.def: To apply smoke to; to expose to smoke or vapor; to purify, or free from infection, by the use of smoke or vapors.
To smoke; to perfume.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fumigation

sn.def: The act of fumigating, or applying smoke or vapor, as for disinfection.
Vapor raised in the process of fumigating.

entry.def: One who, or that which, fumigates; an apparattus for fumigating.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fumigatoire
entry.def: Having the quality of purifying by smoke.
Smokily; with fume.

entry.cs: Cadet's fuming liquid Chem alkarsin. Fuming liquor of Libavius Old Chem stannic chloride; the chloride of tin, SnCl4, forming a colorless, mobile liquid which fumes in the air. Mixed with water it solidifies to the so-called butter of tin. Fuming sulphuric acid. Chem Same as Disulphuric acid, uder Disulphuric.
entry.def: Producing fumes, or vapors.
In a fuming manner; angrily.
entry.q: They answerfumingly.

entry.def: Smoky; hot; choleric.
Choler; fretfulness; passion.
Fumitory.

cs.cd: the Alleghany vine (Adlumia cirrhosa); a biennial climbing plant with elegant feathery leaves and large clusters of pretty white or pinkish flowers looking like grains of rice.

entry.ety: OE. fumetere, F. fumeterre, prop., smoke of the ground, fr. L. fumus smoke + terra earth. See Fume, and Terrace
entry.def: The common uame of several species of the genus Fumaria, annual herbs of the Old World, with finely dissected leaves and small flowers in dense racemes or spikes. F. officinalis is a common species, and was formerly used as an antiscorbutic.
A hinny.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. fumosité
entry.def: The fumes of drink.

entry.ety: L. fumosus, fr. fumus smoke: cf. F. fumeux

sn.def: Producing smoke; smoky.
Producing fumes; full of fumes.
sn.q: Garlic, onions, mustard, and such-like fumous things.

entry.def: Producing fumes; fumous.
entry.q: Drowned infumywine.

cs.cd: to hold up to, or turn into, ridicule.

entry.ety: Perh. of Celtic origin; cf. Ir. & Gael. fonn pleasure
entry.def: Sport; merriment; frolicsome amusement.
entry.q: Oddity, frolic, andfun.

entry.ety: See Funambulo
entry.def: To walk or to dance on a rope.
Ropedancing.

sn.def: Performing like a ropedancer.
Narrow, like the walk of a ropedancer.
sn.q: This funambulatory track.

entry.def: A ropewalker or ropedancer.

entry.ety: Sp. funambulo, or It. funambolo, fr. L. funambulus; funis rope (perh. akin to E. bind) + ambulare to walk. See Amble, and cf. Funambulist
entry.def: A ropewalker or ropedancer.

entry.cs:
Algebraic function a quantity whose connection with the variable is expressed by an equation that involves only the algebraic operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, raising to a given power, and extracting a given root; -- opposed to transcendental function. Arbitrary function. See under Arbitrary. Calculus of functions. See under Calculus. Carnot's function Thermo-dynamics a relation between the amount of heat given off by a source of heat, and the work which can be done by it. It is approximately equal to the mechanical equivalent of the thermal unit divided by the number expressing the temperature in degrees of the air thermometer, reckoned from its zero of expansion. Circular functions. See Inverse trigonometrical functions (below). -- Continuous function, a quantity that has no interruption in the continuity of its real values, as the variable changes between any specified limits. Discontinuous function. See under Discontinuous. Elliptic functions a large and important class of functions, so called because one of the forms expresses the relation of the arc of an ellipse to the straight lines connected therewith. Explicit function a quantity directly expressed in terms of the independently varying quantity; thus, in the equations y = 6x2
y = 10 -x3 , the quantity y is an explicit function of x. Implicit function a quantity whose relation to the variable is expressed indirectly by an equation; thus, y in the equation x2 + y2 = 100 is an implicit function of x.
Inverse trigonometrical functionsorCircular functions
the lengths of arcs relative to the sines, tangents, etc. Thus, AB is the arc whose sine is BD, and (if the length of BD is x) is written sin -1x, and so of the other lines. See Trigonometrical functionbelow). Other transcendental functions are the exponential functions, the elliptic functions, the gamma functions, the theta functions, etc.
One-valued function a quantity that has one, and only one, value for each value of the variable. Transcendental functions a quantity whose connection with the variable cannot be expressed by algebraic operations; thus, y in the equation y = 10x is a transcendental function of x. See Algebraic functionabove). Trigonometrical function
a quantity whose relation to the variable is the same as that of a certain straight line drawn in a circle whose radius is unity, to the length of a corresponding are of the circle. Let AB be an arc in a circle, whose radius OA is unity let AC be a quadrant, and let OC, DB, and AF be drawnpependicular to OA, and EB and CG parallel to OA, and let OB be produced to G and F. E Then BD is the sine of the arc AB; OD or EB is the cosine, AF is the tangent, CG is the cotangent, OF is the secant OG is the cosecant, AD is the versed sine, and CE is the coversed sine of the are AB. If the length of AB be represented by xOA being unity) then the lengths of Functions. these lines (OA being unity) are the trigonometrical functions of x, and are written sin x cos x tan xor tang x), cot x sec x cosec x versin x coversin x. These quantities are also considered as functions of the angle BOA.
entry.ety: L. functio, fr. fungi to perform, execute, akin to Skr. bhuj to enjoy, have the use of: cf. F. fonction. Cf. Defunct

sn.def: The act of executing or performing any duty, office, or calling; performance.
sn.q: In thefunctionof his public calling.

sn.def: The appropriate action of any special organ or part of an animal or vegetable organism; as, the function of the heart or the limbs; the function of leaves, sap, roots, etc.; life is the sum of the functions of the various organs and parts of the body.
The natural or assigned action of any power or faculty, as of the soul, or of the intellect; the exertion of an energy of some determinate kind.
sn.q: As the mind opens, and its functions spread.

sn.def: The course of action which peculiarly pertains to any public officer in church or state; the activity appropriate to any business or profession.
sn.q: Tradesmen . . . going about their functions.
The malady which made him incapable of performing his regal functions.

sn.def: A quantity so connected with another quantity, that if any alteration be made in the latter there will be a consequent alteration in the former. Each quantity is said to be a function of the other. Thus, the circumference of a circle is a function of the diameter. If x be a symbol to which different numerical values can be assigned, such expressions as x2, 3x, Log. x, and Sin. x, are all functions of x.
A religious ceremony, esp. one particularly impressive and elaborate.
sn.q: Every solemn ‘function' performed with the requirements of the liturgy.

sn.def: A public or social ceremony or gathering; a festivity or entertainment, esp. one somewhat formal.
sn.q: This function, which is our chief social event.

entry.def: To execute or perform a function; to transact one's regular or appointed business.

cs.cd: a disease of which the symptoms cannot be referred to any appreciable lesion or change of structure; the derangement of an organ arising from a cause, often unknown, external to itself opposed to organic disease, in which the organ itself is affected.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or connected with, a function or duty; official.

Pertaining to the function of an organ or part, or to the functions in general; involving or affecting function rather than physiology; as, functional deafness; a functional disease. See functional disease, below.
Designed for or capable of a particular function or use; as, a style of writing in which every word is functional; functional architecture.

Fit or ready for use or service; useable; in working order; as, the toaster was still functional even after being dropped; the lawnmower is a bit rusty but still functional . Antonym of out of order and nonfunctional.
sn.syn: usable, useable, in working order(predicate), operable, operational, running(prenominal), operative.

sn.def: Designed to emphasize practical utility rather than artistic or aesthetic purposes; as, functional education selects knowledge that is concrete and usable rather than abstract and theoretical; functional architecture; an amateurish device, crude but functional .
a psychology based on the assumption that all mental process are useful to an organism in adapting to the environment.
any doctrine that stresses utility or purpose.

entry.def: an adherent of functionalism.
To assign to some function or office.
In a functional manner; as regards normal or appropriate activity.
entry.q: The organ is said to be functionally disordered.

entries.entry:
Func"tion*a*ry n.; pl.Functionaries #. Cf. F. fonctionnaire
One charged with the performance of a function or office; as, a public functionary; secular functionaries.

entry.def: Destitute of function, or of an appropriate organ. Darwin.

cs.cd: the aggregate of sums of money set apart and invested, usually at fixed intervals, for the extinguishment of the debt of a government, or of a corporation, by the accumulation of interest.

entry.ety: OF. font fond, nom. fonz, bottom, ground, F. fond bottom, foundation, fonds fund, fr. L. fundus bottom, ground, foundation, piece of land. See Found to establish

sn.def: An aggregation or deposit of resources from which supplies are or may be drawn for carrying on any work, or for maintaining existence.

A stock or capital; a sum of money appropriated as the foundation of some commercial or other operation undertaken with a view to profit; that reserve by means of which expenses and credit are supported; as, the fund of a bank, commercial house, manufacturing corporation, etc.
The stock of a national debt; public securities; evidences (stocks or bonds) of money lent to government, for which interest is paid at prescribed intervals; -- called also public funds.

An invested sum, whose income is devoted to a specific object; as, the fund of an ecclesiastical society; a fund for the maintenance of lectures or poor students; also, money systematically collected to meet the expenses of some permanent object.
A store laid up, from which one may draw at pleasure; a supply; a full provision of resources; as, a fund of wisdom or good sense.
sn.q: An inexhaustible fund of stories.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Funded; p. pr. & vb. n. Funding

sn.def: To provide and appropriate a fund or permanent revenue for the payment of the interest of; to make permanent provision of resources (as by a pledge of revenue from customs) for discharging the interest of or principal of; as, to fund government notes.
To place in a fund, as money.
To put into the form of bonds or stocks bearing regular interest; as, to fund the floating debt.

entry.def: Capable of being funded, or converted into a fund; convertible into bonds.

entry.ety: OE. fundament fundement fondement, OF. fundement fondement, F. fondement, fr. L. fundamentum foundation, fr. fundare to lay the bottom, to found, fr. fundus bottom. See Fund

sn.def: Foundation.
The part of the body on which one sits; the buttocks; specifically Anat, the anus.

cs.cd: the root note of a chord; a bass formed of the roots or fundamental tones of the chords.
a chord, the lowest tone of which is its root.
red, green, and violet-blue. See Primary colors, under Color.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fondamental
entry.def: Pertaining to the foundation or basis; serving for the foundation.
Essential, as an element, principle, or law; important; original; elementary; as, a fundamental truth; a fundamental axiom.
entry.q: The fundamental reasons of this war.
Some fundamental antithesis in nature.

entry.def: A leading or primary principle, rule, law, or article, which serves as the groundwork of a system; essential part, as, the fundamentals of the Christian faith.

sn.def: A system of beliefs based on the interpretation of every word in the Bible, both old and new testaments, as literal truth. It is primarily held by a branch of American Protestants.
The beliefs or practises based on a rigid adherence to some traditional doctrine; extreme conservatism; as, Moslem fundamentalism; the political fundamentalism of the Christian right.
of or pertaining to fundamentalists or fundamentalism.
characteristic of a fundamentalist; -- especially, resembling the behavior of a fundamentalist; as, a fundamentalist dislike of new ideas.

entry.def: a supporter of fundamentalism.
Primarily; originally; essentially; radically; at the foundation; in origin or constituents.
entry.q: Fundamentallydefective.

sn.def: Existing in the form of bonds bearing regular interest; as, funded debt.
Invested in public funds; as, funded money.

entry.def: One who has money invested in the public funds.

cs.cd: a system or scheme of finance or revenue by which provision is made for paying the interest or principal of a public debt.

sn.def: Providing a fund for the payment of the interest or principal of a debt.
Investing in the public funds.

entry.def: Destitute of funds.

entry.ety: L., bottom
entry.def: The bottom or base of any hollow organ; as, the fundus of the bladder; the fundus of the eye; the fundus of the uterus.

entry.ety: L. funebris belonging to a funeral, fr. funus funeral
entry.def: Pertaining to a funeral or funerals; funeral; funereal.
Funebrial.

entry.ety: LL. funeralia, prop. neut. pl. of funeralis of a funeral, fr. L. funus funeris, funeral: cf. F. funérailles

sn.def: The solemn rites used in the disposition of a dead human body, whether such disposition be by interment, burning, or otherwise; esp., the ceremony or solemnization of interment; obsequies; burial; -- formerly used in the plural.
sn.q: King James his funerals were performed very solemnly in the collegiate church at Westminster.

sn.def: The procession attending the burial of the dead; the show and accompaniments of an interment.
sn.q: The longfunerals.

sn.def: A funeral sermon; -- usually in the plural.
sn.q: Mr. Giles Lawrence preached his funerals.

cs.cd: a structure of combustible material, upon which a dead body is placed to be reduced to ashes, as part of a funeral rite; a pyre.

entry.ety: LL. funeralis. See Funeral n.
entry.def: Pertaining to a funeral; used at the interment of the dead; as, funeral rites, honors, or ceremonies.

An establishment, usually commercial, where the bodies of dead persons are prepared for viewing before burial or cremation; called also funeral parlor mortuary funeral chapel and informally, undertaker's. The body may or may not be preserved by embalming before viewing or burial, and in some cases the body is not exposed for viewing, though present in a casket. Often, some form of memorial service is held for the deceased at the funeral home, where friends and relatives may come to pay their respects to the dead, and express condolence to the family. The work of preparation of the body and many other arrangements related to the funeral and burial are carried out by an undertaker or mortician who manages the funeral home.
Same as funeral home.
of or pertaining to a funeral or to burial of human remains; as, funerary urn.

entry.ety: L. funeratus, p. p. of funerare to funerate, fr. funus. See Funeral
entry.def: To bury with funeral rites.

entry.ety: L. funeratio
entry.def: The act of burying with funeral rites.

entry.ety: L. funereus, fr. fentus a funeral
entry.def: Suiting a funeral; pertaining to burial; solemn; as, at a funereal pace.
Dark; dismal; mournful.
entry.q: What seem to us but sad funereal tapers May be heaven's distant lamps.

entry.ety: L. funestus, fr. funus a funeral, destruction: cf. F. funeste
entry.def: Lamentable; doleful.
entry.q: Funestand direful deaths.
A forerunner of something very funest.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to fungi.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fongate
entry.def: A salt of fungic acid.

entry.ety: L. fungus mushroom, dolt
entry.def: A blockhead; a dolt; a fool.

entries.entry: Fun"gi ☞ The Fungi appear to have originated by degeneration from various algæ, losing their chlorophyll on assuming a parasitic or saprophytic life. In an earlier classification they were divided into the subclasses Phycomycetes, the lower or algal fungi; the Mesomycetes, or intermediate fungi; and the Mycomycetes, or the higher fungi; by others into the Phycomycetes; the Ascomycetes, or sac-spore fungi; and the Basidiomycetes, or basidial-spore fungi. fŭn"jī n. pl.; sing.fungus. Biol A group of thallophytic plant-like organisms of low organization, destitute of chlorophyll, in which reproduction is mainly accomplished by means of asexual spores, which are produced in a great variety of ways, though sexual reproduction is known to occur in certain Phycomycetes, or so-called algal fungi. They include the molds, mildews, rusts, smuts, mushrooms, toadstools, puff balls, and the allies of each. In the two-kingdom classification system they were classed with the plants, but in the modern five-kingdom classification, they are not classed as plants, but are classed in their own separate kingdom fungi, which includes the phyla Zygomycotaincluding simple fungi such as bread molds), Ascomycotaincluding the yeasts), Basidiomycotaincluding the mushrooms, smuts, and rusts), and Deuteromycotathe fungi imperfecti). Some of the forms, such as the yeasts, appear as single-celled microorganisms, but all of the fungi are are eukaryotic, thus distinguishing them from the prokaryotic microorganisms of the kingdon Monera.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. fungus mushroom: cf. F. fongie
entry.def: A genus of simple, stony corals; -- so called because they are usually flat and circular, with radiating plates, like the gills of a mushroom. Some of them are eighteen inches in diameter.
Of or pertaining to the Fungidæ, a family of stony corals.

def2.def: One of the Fungidæ.

entry.ety: LL. (res fungibiles, probably fr. L. fungi to discharge. “A barbarous term, supposed to have originated in the use of the words functionem recipere in the Digeste.” Bouvier. “Called fungibiles quia una alterius vice fungitur.” John Taylor1755). Cf. Function

sn.def: Things which may be furnished or restored in kind, as distinguished from specific things; -- called also fungible things.
Movable goods which may be valued by weight or measure, in contradistinction from those which must be judged of individually.

entry.ety: L. fungus mushroom: cf. F. fungique fongique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or obtained from, mushrooms; as, fungic acid.

entry.ety: Fungi + -cide, fr. L. caedere to kill
entry.def: Anything that kills fungi.

cs.cd: numerous small, rounded eminences on the upper surface of the tongue.

entry.ety: Eungus + -form: cf. F. fongiforme
entry.def: Shaped like a fungus or mushroom.

entry.ety: L. imperfecti imperfect
entry.def: A heterogenous phylum of fungi which lack a sexual phase, or of which the sexual phase is not known. Some undoubtedly represent the conidium stages of various Ascomycetes. It is not considered a natural phylum, and is also called the Deuteromycota. The group is divided into the orders Sphæropsidales Melanconiales, and Moniliales. It includes the genera Penicillium and Aspergillus, which reproduce asexually by means of conidia.
Shaped like a small fungus.

entry.ety: L. fungus mushroom: cf. F, fongine fungine
entry.def: A name formerly given to cellulose found in certain fungi and mushrooms.

entry.ety: L. fungus mushroom: cf. F. pongite
entry.def: A fossil coral resembling Fungia.

entry.ety: L. fungus + vorare to eat greedily: cf. F. fongivore
entry.def: Eating fungi; -- said of certain insects and snails.

entry.ety: Fungus + -oil: cf. F. fongoïde
entry.def: Like a fungus; fungous; spongy.
A mycologist.

entry.ety: Fungus + -logy
entry.def: Mycology.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fungosité fongosité
entry.def: The quality of that which is fungous; fungous excrescence.

entry.ety: L. fungosus: cf. F. fungueux

sn.def: Of the nature of fungi; spongy.
Growing suddenly, but not substantial or durable.

entries.entry:
Fun"gus ☞ The fungi are all destitute of chorophyll, and, therefore, to be supplied with elaborated nourishment, must live as saprophytes or parasites. They range in size from single microscopic cells to systems of entangled threads many feet in extent, which develop reproductive bodies as large as a man's head. The vegetative system consists of septate or rarely unseptate filaments called hyphæ; the aggregation of hyphæ into structures of more or less definite form is known as the mycelium. See Fungi, in the Supplement. n.; pl. L. Fungi #, E. Funguses #. L., a mushroom; perh. akin to a doubtful Gr. � sponge, for �; if so, cf. E. sponge
Bot Any one of the Fungi, a large and very complex group of thallophytes of low organization, -- the molds, mildews, rusts, smuts, mushrooms, toadstools, puff balls, and the allies of each. See fungi.
Med A spongy, morbid growth or granulation in animal bodies, as the proud flesh of wounds.

entry.def: resembling a fungus or fungi.
Funicular.

entry.ety: L. funiculus, dim. of funis cord, rope: cf. F. funicule funicle (in sense 2). Cf. Funambulo

sn.def: A small cord, ligature, or fiber.
The little stalk that attaches a seed to the placenta.

entry.cs: Funicular action Mech the force or action exerted by a rope in drawing together the supports to which its ends are Fastened, when acted upon by forces applied in a direction transverse to the rope, as in the archer's bow. Funicular curve. Same as Catenary. Funicular machine Mech an apparatus for illustrating certain principles in statics, consisting of a cord or chain attached at one end to a fixed point, and having the other passed over a pulley and sustaining a weight, while one or more other weights are suspended from the cord at points between the fixed support and the pulley. Funicular polygon Mech the polygonal figure assumed by a cord fastened at its extremities, and sustaining weights at different points.
entry.ety: Cf. F. funiculaire

sn.def: Consisting of a small cord or fiber.
Dependent on the tension of a cord.
Pertaining to a funiculus; made up of, or resembling, a funiculus, or funiculi; as, a funicular ligament.

entry.def: Forming a narrow ridge.

entries.entry:
‖Fu*nic"u*lus n.; pl.Funiculi #. L., a little cord. See Funicle
Anat A cord, baud, or bundle of fibers; esp., one of the small bundles of fibers, of which large nerves are made up; applied also to different bands of white matter in the brain and spinal cord.
Zoöl
A short cord which connects the embryo of some myriapods with the amnion.
In Bryozoa, an organ extending back from the stomach. See Bryozoa, and Phylactolema.

entry.ety: L. funis rope + -form
entry.def: Resembling a cord in toughness and flexibility, as the roots of some endogenous trees.

entry.ety: L., a rope.
entry.def: A cord; specifically, the umbilical cord or navel string.

entry.ety: OE. funke a little fire; akin to Prov. E. funk touchwood, G. funke spark, and perh. to Goth. fōn fire

sn.def: An offensive smell; a stench.
One who funks; a shirk; a coward.
a state of fear.
a mildly depressed state of mind; -- often used in the phrase blue funk.

entry.def: an earthy, seemingly unsophisticated style of jazz music having elements of black American blues and gospel.

sn.def: To envelop with an offensive smell or smoke.
To funk at; to flinch at; to shrink from (a thing or person); as, to funk a task.
To frighten; to cause to flinch.

cs.cd: to back out in a cowardly fashion.

sn.def: To emit an offensive smell; to stink.
To be frightened, and shrink back; to flinch; as, to funk at the edge of a precipice.
sn.q: To funk right out o' political strife.

entry.def: A shrinking back through fear.
entry.q: The horrid panic, orfunkas the men of Eton call it).

entry.def: A genus of robust East Asian clump-forming perennial herbs having racemose flowers: plantain lilies; sometimes placed in the family Hostaceae.
one of many families or subfamilies into which some classification systems subdivide the Liliaceae, but not widely accepted; it includes the genus Hosta.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, great fear, or funking; having great fear.
having an earthy, unsophisticated style or feeling;
earthy and seemingly unsophisticated, having elements of black American blues and gospel. See 2nd funk n.

cs.cd: an apparatus for collecting finely crushed ore from water.
one of the ropes or rods steadying a steamer's funnel.

entry.ety: OE. funel fonel, prob. through OF. fr, L. fundibulum infundibulum, funnel, fr. infundere to pour in; in in + fundere to pour; cf. Armor. founil funnel, W. ffynel air hole, chimney. See Fuse v. t.

sn.def: A vessel of the shape of an inverted hollow cone, terminating below in a pipe, and used for conveying liquids or pourable solids into a vessel with a narrow opening; a tunnel.
A passage or avenue for a fluid or flowing substance; specifically, a smoke flue or pipe; the iron chimney of a steamship or the like.

entry.def: Having the form of a funnel, or tunnel; that is, expanding gradually from the bottom upward, as the corolla of some flowers; infundibuliform.
The section of a newspaper containing comic strips; called also funny papers and comics. Rarely encountered in the singular.
a comic incident or series of incidents.

entry.cs: Funny bone. See crazy bone, under Crazy.
entry.ety: From Fun
entry.def: Droll; comical; amusing; laughable; inciting laughter.

entries.entry: Fun"ny n.; pl.Funnies. A clinkerbuit, narrow boat for sculling. Eng

entry.ety: OE. furre, OF. forre fuerre, sheath, case, of German origin; cf. OHG. fuotar lining, case, G. futter; akin to Icel. fōðr lining, Goth. fōdr, scabbard; cf. Skr. pātra vessel, dish. The German and Icel. words also have the sense, fodder, but this was probably a different word originally. Cf. Fodder food, Fother v. t. Forel n.

sn.def: The short, fine, soft hair of certain animals, growing thick on the skin, and distinguished from the hair, which is longer and coarser.
The skins of certain wild animals with the fur; peltry; as, a cargo of furs.
Strips of dressed skins with fur, used on garments for warmth or for ornament.
Articles of clothing made of fur; as, a set of furs for a lady (a collar, tippet, or cape, muff, etc.
sn.q: Wrapped up in my furs.

entry.sn:
Any coating considered as resembling fur; as: A coat of morbid matter collected on the tongue in persons affected with fever.
The soft, downy covering on the skin of a peach.
The deposit formed on the interior of boilers and other vessels by hard water.

sn.def: One of several patterns or diapers used as tinctures. There are nine in all, or, according to some writers, only six.

cs.cd: one of several species of seals of the genera Callorhinus and Arclocephalus, inhabiting the North Pacific and the Antarctic oceans. They have a coat of fine and soft fur which is highly prized. The northern fur seal (Callorhinus ursinus) breeds in vast numbers on the Prybilov Islands, off the coast of Alaska; -- called also sea bear.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to furs; bearing or made of fur; as, a fur cap; the fur trade.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Furred; p. pr. & vb. n. Furring

sn.def: To line, face, or cover with fur; as, furred robes.
sn.q: Youfuryour gloves with reason.

sn.def: To cover with morbid matter, as the tongue.

To nail small strips of board or larger scantling upon, in order to make a level surface for lathing or boarding, or to provide for a space or interval back of the plastered or boarded surface, as inside an outer wall, by way of protection against damp.

entry.ety: L. furax -racis thievish, from fur thief
entry.def: Given to theft; thievish.

entry.ety: L. furacitas
entry.def: Addictedness to theft; thievishness.

entry.ety: Prov. F. farbala, equiv. to F. falbala, It. falbalà

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Furbelowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Furbelowing
entry.def: To put a furbelow on; to ornament.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Furbished; p. pr. & vb. n. Furbishing
entry.ety: OE. forbischen, OF. forbir furbir fourbir, F. fourbir, fr. OHG. furban to clean. See -ish
entry.def: To rub or scour to brightness; to clean; to burnish; as, to furbish a sword or spear.

entry.def: One who furbishes; esp., a sword cutler, who finishes sword blades and similar weapons.

entry.ety: L. furca fork. See Fork
entry.def: Forked; branching like a fork; as, furcate twigs.
A branching like a fork.

entry.ety: L. furcifer yoke bearer, scoundrel; furca fork, yoke, fork-shaped instrument of punishment + ferre to bear
entry.def: Rascally; scandalous.
entry.q: Furciferousknaves.

entry.ety: L., a forked prop, dim. of furca a fork

entry.ety: See Fardel, and cf. Furl
entry.def: To draw up into a bundle; to roll up.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Scurf; dandruff.

entry.ety: L. furfuraceus

entry.ety: L. furfur bran
entry.def: A colorless, oily substance, C4H4O, obtained by distilling certain organic substances, as pine wood, salts of pyromucic acid, etc.; -- called also tetraphenol.

entry.ety: L. furfur bran, scurf

A white, crystalline base, obtained indirectly from furfurol.

entry.ety: L. furfur bran + oleum oil
entry.def: A colorless oily liquid, C4H3O.CHO, of a pleasant odor, obtained by the distillation of bran, sugar, etc., and regarded as an aldehyde derivative of furfuran; -- called also furfural.
Made of bran; furfuraceous.

entry.ety: L. furialis: cf. OF. furial

entry.ety: L. furibundus, fr. furere to rage

entry.ety: Furfurol + benzile

Pertaining to, or derived from, furile; as, furilic acid.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: With great force or vigor; vehemently.

entry.ety: L. furiosus, fr. furia rage, fury: cf. F. furieux. See Fury

sn.def: Transported with passion or fury; raging; violent; as, a furious animal.
Rushing with impetuosity; moving with violence; as, a furious stream; a furious wind or storm.
sn.syn: Impetuous; vehement; boisterous; fierce; turbulent; tumultuous; angry; mad; frantic; frenzied.

entry.def: The quality of being furious.
entry.syn: ferocity, fierceness, fury, vehemence, violence, wildness, strength.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Furled fûrld; p. pr. & vb. n. Furling
entry.ety: Contr. fr. furdle, fr. fardel bundle: cf. F. ferler to furl, OF. fardeler to pack. See Furdle Fardel, and cf. Farl
entry.def: To draw up or gather into close compass; to wrap or roll, as a sail, close to the yard, stay, or mast, or, as a flag, close to or around its staff, securing it there by a gasket or line.

entry.ety: p. p. of furl
entry.def: rolled up and secured; as, furled sails bound securely to the spar; a furled flag.

entry.ety: OE. furlong furlang, AS. furlang furlung, prop., the length of a furrow; furh furrow + lang long. See Furrow, and Long a.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. D. verlof, fr. a prefix akin to E. for + the root of E. lief, and akin to Dan. forlov, Sw. förlof, G. verlaub permission. See Life a.
entry.def: Leave of absence; especially, leave given to an officer or soldier to be absent from service for a certain time; also, the document granting leave of absence.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Furloughed; p. pr. & vb. n. Furloughing
entry.def: To furnish with a furlough; to grant leave of absence to, as to an officer or soldier.
Same as Frumenty.

entry.note: ☞ Furnaces are classified as wind or air. furnaces when the fire is urged only by the natural draught; as blast furnaces, when the fire is urged by the injection artificially of a forcible current of air; and as reverberatory furnaces, when the flame, in passing to the chimney, is thrown down by a low arched roof upon the materials operated upon.
entry.cs:
Bustamente furnace a shaft furnace for roasting quicksilver ores. Furnace bridge Same as Bridge wall. See Bridge n., 5. Furnace cadmiamorFurnace cadmia
the oxide of zinc which accumulates in the chimneys of furnaces smelting zinciferous ores. Raymond. Furnace hoist Iron Manuf a lift for raising ore, coal, etc., to the mouth of a blast furnace.
entry.ety: OE. fornais forneis, OF. fornaise, F. fournaise, from L. fornax; akin to furnus oven, and prob. to E. forceps

sn.def: An inclosed place in which heat is produced by the combustion of fuel, as for reducing ores or melting metals, for warming a house, for baking pottery, etc.; as, an iron furnace; a hot-air furnace; a glass furnace; a boiler furnace, etc.
A place or time of punishment, affiction, or great trial; severe experience or discipline.
To throw out, or exhale, as from a furnace; also, to put into a furnace.
sn.q: He furnaces The thick sighs from him.

The type genus of the Furnariidae, comprising the South American ovenbirds.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fourniment. See Furnish
entry.def: Furniture.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Furnished; p. pr. & vb. n. Furnishing
entry.ety: OF. furnir fornir, to furnish finish, F. fournir; akin to Pr. formir furmir fromir, to accomplish, satisfy, fr. OHG. frumjan to further, execute, do, akin to E. frame. See Frame v. t., and -ish

sn.def: To supply with anything necessary, useful, or appropriate; to provide; to equip; to fit out, or fit up; to adorn; as, to furnish a family with provisions; to furnish one with arms for defense; to furnish a Cable; to furnish the mind with ideas; to furnish one with knowledge or principles; to furnish an expedition or enterprise, a room or a house.
sn.q: That the man of God may be perfect, thoroughly furnished unto all good works.

sn.def: To offer for use; to provide (something); to give (something); to afford; as, to furnish food to the hungry: to furnish arms for defense.
sn.q: Ye are they . . . that furnish the drink offering unto that number.
His writings and his life furnish abundant proofs that he was not a man of strong sense.

entry.def: That which is furnished as a specimen; a sample; a supply.

entries.entry: furnished adj. provided with necessary furnishings; -- used especially of rented apartments having furniture included in the rental price; as, a furnished apartment. Opposite of unfurnished.Narrower terms: stocked, stocked with ; appointed; well-appointed, well-found ; fitted out, outfitted equipped.

entry.def: One who supplies or fits out.

sn.def: the furniture and appliances and other movable accessories (including curtains and rugs) that make a home (or other building) livable.
accessory wearing apparel.

entry.def: The act of furnishing, or of supplying furniture; also, furniture.

entry.ety: F. fourniture. See Furnish v. t.

sn.def: That with which anything is furnished or supplied; supplies; outfit; equipment.
sn.q: The form and all the furniture of the earth.
The thoughts which make the furniture of their minds.

sn.def: Articles used for convenience or decoration in a house or apartment, as tables, chairs, bedsteads, sofas, carpets, curtains, pictures, vases, etc.
The necessary appendages to anything, as to a machine, a carriage, a ship, etc.

sd.def: The masts and rigging of a ship.
The mountings of a gun.
Builders' hardware such as locks, door and window trimmings.
Pieces of wood or metal of a lesser height than the type, placed around the pages or other matter in a form, and, with the quoins, serving to secure the form in its place in the chase.

sn.def: A mixed or compound stop in an organ; -- sometimes called mixture.

entry.ety: See Furfurol
entry.def: A colorless, crystalline substance, C10H8O4, from furfurol.
an interest followed with exaggerated zeal; a fad.

sn.def: a sudden outburst (as of protest).

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Excitement; commotion; enthusiasm.
covered with a dense coat of fine silky hairs.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fourreur
entry.def: A dealer in furs; one who makes or sells fur goods.

sn.def: Furs, in general.
The business of a furrier; trade in furs.

sd.def: The leveling of a surface, or the preparing of an air space, by means of strips of board or of larger pieces. See Fur v. t., 3.
The strips thus laid on.

sn.def: Double planking of a ship's side.
A deposit from water, as on the inside of a boiler; also, the operation of cleaning away this deposit.

cs.cd: a weed which grows on plowed land.
to live correctly; not to deviate from the right line of duty.

entry.ety: OE. forow forgh furgh, AS. furh; akin to D. voor, OHG. furuh, G. furche, Dan. fure, Sw. f�ra, Icel. for drain, L. porca ridge between two furrows

sn.def: A trench in the earth made by, or as by, a plow.
Any trench, channel, or groove, as in wood or metal; a wrinkle on the face; as, the furrows of age.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Furrowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Furrowing
entry.ety: From Furrow n.; cf. AS. fyrian

sn.def: To cut a furrow in; to make furrows in; to plow; as, to furrow the ground or sea.
To mark with channels or with wrinkles.
sn.q: Thou canst help time to furrow me with age.
Fair cheeks were furrowed with hot tears.

entry.def: Furrowed.

entry.ety: From Fur

sn.def: Covered with fur; dressed in fur.
sn.q: Furrynations.

sn.def: Consisting of fur; as, furry spoils.
Resembling fur.

cs.cd: not so near; apart by a greater distance.

entry.ety: A comparative of forth; OE. further forther, AS. fur�or far�ur; akin to G. fürder. See Forth adv.
entry.def: To a greater distance; in addition; moreover. See Farther.
entry.q: Carries us, I know not how much further, into familiar company.
They sdvanced us far as Eleusis and Thria; but no further.

entry.note: ☞ The forms further and farther are in general not differentiated by writers, but further is preferred by many when application to quantity or degree is implied.

sn.def: More remote; at a greater distance; more in advance; farther; as, the further end of the field. See Farther.
Beyond; additional; as, a further reason for this opinion; nothing further to suggest.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Furthered; p. pr. & vb. n. Furthering
entry.ety: OE. furthren forthren, AS. fyrðran fyrðrian. See Further adv.
entry.def: To help forward; to promote; to advance; to forward; to help or assist.
entry.q: This binds thee, then, to further my design.
I should nothing further the weal public.

entry.def: The act of furthering or helping forward; promotion; advancement; progress.
entry.q: I know that I shall abide and continue with you all for yourfurthersnce and joy of faith.
Built of furtherance and pursuing, Not of spent deeds, but of doing.

entry.def: One who furthers. or helps to advance; a promoter.
or conj. Moreover; besides; in addition to what has been said.
Most remote; furthest.
Tending to further, advance, or promote; helpful; advantageous.
entry.q: You will not find it furthersome.

entry.def: superl. Most remote; most in advance; farthest. See Further a.
At the greatest distance; farthest.

entry.ety: L. furtivus, fr. furtum theft, fr. fur thief, akin to ferre to bear: cf. F. furtif. See Fertile
entry.def: Stolen; obtained or characterized by stealth; sly; secret; stealthy; as, a furtive look.
entry.q: A hasty and furtive ceremony.

entry.def: Stealthily by theft.

entry.ety: L. furunculus a petty thief, a boil, dim. of fur thief: cf. F. furoncle
entry.def: A superficial, inflammatory tumor, suppurating with a central core; a boil.
Of or pertaining to a furuncle; marked by the presence of furuncles.

entry.ety: L. fur
entry.def: A thief.
entry.q: Have an eye to your plate, for there be furies.

entries.entry:
Fu"ry n.; pl.Furies #. L. furia, fr. furere to rage: cf. F. furie. Cf. Furor
Violent or extreme excitement; overmastering agitation or enthusiasm. Her wit began to be with a divine fury inspired.
Violent anger; extreme wrath; rage; -- sometimes applied to inanimate things, as the wind or storms; impetuosity; violence.
Furyof the wind. I do oppose my patience to his fury.
pl. Greek Myth The avenging deities, Tisiphone, Alecto, and Megæra; the Erinyes or Eumenides. The Furies, they said, are attendants on justice, and if the sun in heaven should transgress his path would punish him.
One of the Parcæ, or Fates, esp. Atropos. R Comes the blind Fury with the abhorred shears, And slits the thin-spun life.
A stormy, turbulent violent woman; a hag; a vixen; a virago; a termagant. Anger; indignation; resentment; wrath; ire; rage; vehemence; violence; fierceness; turbulence; madness; frenzy. See Anger.

entry.ety: OE. firs, As. fyrs
entry.def: A thorny evergreen shrub (Ulex Europæus), with beautiful yellow flowers, very common upon the plains and hills of Great Britain; -- called also gorse, and whin. The dwarf furze is Ulex nanus.
The whinchat; -- called also furzechuck.
An English warbler (Melizophilus provincialis); -- called also furze wren, and Dartford warbler.
Furzy; gorsy.
Abounding in, or overgrown with, furze; characterized by furze.

entry.ety: F., the spindle tree; also, charcoal made from it
entry.def: Fine charcoal of willow wood, used as a drawing implement.
A drawing made with it. See Charcoal n. 2, and Charcoal drawing, under Charcoal.

entry.ety: F. fusarolle, fr. It. fusaruolo, fr. fuso spindle, shaft of a column. See Fusee a conical wheel
entry.def: A molding generally placed under the echinus or quarter round of capitals in the Doric, Ionic, and Corinthian orders of architecture.

entry.ety: L. fuscare fuscatum, to make dark, fr. fuscus dark
entry.def: A darkening; obscurity; obfuscation.

entry.ety: L. fuscus dark-colored, tawny
entry.def: A brown, nitrogenous pigment contained in the retinal epithelium; a variety of melanin.
A dark-colored substance obtained from empyreumatic animal oil.

entry.ety: L. fuscus
entry.def: Brown or grayish black; darkish.
entry.q: Sad and fuscous colors, as black or brown, or deep purple and the like.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Fused fūzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Fusing
entry.ety: L. fusus, p. p. of fundere to pour, melt, cast. See Foundo to cast, and cf. Futile

sn.def: To liquefy by heat; to render fluid; to dissolve; to melt.
To unite or blend, as if melted together.
sn.q: Whose fancy fuses old and new.

cs.cd: the degree of temperature at which a substance melts; the point of fusion; the melting point.

sn.def: To be reduced from a solid to a fluid state by heat; to be melted; to melt.
To be blended, as if melted together.

cs.cd: the hole in a shell prepared for the reception of the fuse.

entry.ety: For fusee fusil. See 2d Fusil

sn.def: A tube or casing filled with combustible matter, by means of which a charge of powder is ignited, as in blasting; -- called also fuzee. See Fuze.

a mechanism in a bomb, torpedo, rocket, or artillery shell, usually having an easily detonated explosive charge and activated by the shock of impact, which detonates the main explosive charge. Some fuses may have timing mechanisms, delaying the explosion for a short time, or up to several days after impact. Fuses activated by other mechanisms more sophisticated than impact, such as proximity or heat, are used in modern weapons such as antiaircraft or antimissile missiles.

entry.def: A wire, bar, or strip of fusible metal inserted for safety in an electric circuit. When the current increases beyond a certain safe strength, the metal melts, interrupting the circuit and thereby preventing possibility of damage. It serves the same function as a circuit breaker.
joined together into a whole.

entry.ety: See 2d Fusil, and cf. Fuse n.

sn.def: A flintlock gun. See 2d Fusil.
A fuse. See Fuse n.

sd.def: A friction match for smokers' use having a bulbous head which when ignited is not easily blown out even in a gale of wind.
A kind of match made of paper impregnated with niter and having the usual igniting tip.

sn.def: A signal device, usually cylindrical, consisting of a tube filled with a composition which burns with a bright colored light for a definite time. It is used principally for the protection of trains or road vehicles, indicating an obstruction or accident ahead. Also called a flare or railroad flare.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: The track of a buck.

entry.ety: F. fusée a spindleful, fusee, LL. fusata, fr. fusare to use a spindle, L. fusus spindle
entry.def: The cone or conical wheel of a watch or clock, designed to equalize the power of the mainspring by having the chain from the barrel which contains the spring wind in a spiral groove on the surface of the cone in such a manner that the diameter of the cone at the point where the chain acts may correspond with the degree of tension of the spring.
A similar wheel used in other machinery.

entries.entry: Fu"sel n. Fu"sel oil . G. fusel bad liquor Chem A hot, acrid, oily liquid, accompanying many alcoholic liquors (as potato whisky, corn whisky, etc.), as an undesirable ingredient, and consisting of several of the higher alcohols and compound ethers, but mostly of amyl alcohol; hence, amyl alcohol or a mixture of amyl alcohols.

entry.ety: F. fusel spindle-shaped + -age; fr. L. fusus spindle
entry.def: The central, approximately cylindrical portion of an airplane which carries the passengers, crew, and cargo. It usually forms the main structural portion of an airplane, and to it are typically attached the wings, tail, and sometimes the engines. In single-propeller airplanes, the propeller is typically fixed at the front of the fuselage, although variants have been produced with the propeller at the rear. Some airplanes have no fuselage, properly so called.

entries.entry:
Fuse plugorFuze plug . Ordnance A plug fitted to the fuse hole of a shell to hold the fuse.
A fusible plug that screws into a receptacle, used as a fuse in electric wiring.

entry.ety: Cf. F. fusibilité
entry.def: The quality of being fusible.

cs.cd: any alloy of different metals capable of being easily fused, especially an alloy of five parts of bismuth, three of lead, and two of tin, which melts at a temperature below that of boiling water.
a piece of easily fusible alloy, placed in one of the sheets and intended to melt and blow off the steam in case of low water.

entry.ety: F. fusible. See Fuse v. t.
entry.def: CapabIe of being melted or liquefied.

entry.ety: L. fusus spindle + -form: cf. F. fusiforme
entry.def: Shaped like a spindle; shaped like a cylinder that tapers at each end; as, a fusiform root; a fusiform cell.

entry.ety: L. fusilis molten, fluid, fr. fundere fusum, to pour, cast. See Fuse v. t.

sn.def: Capable of being melted or rendered fluid by heat; fusible.

entry.note: ☞The name is derived from the sounds of the first five letters of the runic alphabet, f, u, th, o, r, and c. The vowel sound of the fourth letter corresponded more closely to a in the earlier versions used in Scandinavian countries, and the earlier alphabet is therefore referred to as the futharc or futhark. The fifth rune had a sound like that of k, and in the Danish futhark the fifth character is that transliterated as k. Thus the runic alphabet is also called the futhork or futhark. The third rune had a sound and form resembling that of the Anglo-Saxon thorn, which represented the th sound at the beginning of the word thorn. The origins of the runic alphabet are obscure, but the earliest forms may have been invented around the second century A.D. in eastern Europe. The forms of some of the letters show a relation to the Latin or Greek alphabets, and the futhorc was presumably in part an adaptation of those alphabets to the sound of the Germanic tongues. An inscription of the futhark itself, an ordered list of the runes, was found on an object dated as early as the fifth century A.D. The Scandinavian futharc had 16 runes, but the futhorc used in Anglo-Saxon England had 31. The futhark was mostly used for writing on wood, for which reason the runes were comprised of only vertical and diagonal strokes. The degree of widespread use of the futharc is not known but it was probably used mostly for short messages or inscriptions on objects. Fewer than 10,000 runic inscriptions, both on wood and stone, have been found. The number and forms of some of the runes varied over time and locality.

sn.ety: From the sounds of the first five letters
sn.def: the name for the runic alphabet. See rune.

entry.note: ☞ The spelling futharc represents most accurately the original values of these six Runic letters.
entry.def: The Runic alphabet; -- so called from the first six letters fuþth), oor a), rc=k). See futharc.
entry.q: The letters are called Runes and the alphabet bears the name Futhorc from the first six letters.

entry.ety: L. futilis that easily pours out, that easily lets loose, vain, worthless, from the root of fundere to pour out: cf. F. futile. See Fuse v. t.
